DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL ACTION AT GOVERNMENT PRINTING OFFICE

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Due to industrial action taken at the Government Printing Office, the normal House of Representatives Notice Paper for today was not printed overnight. The business section only of the Notice Paper has been produced in the House of Representatives Department and circulated in the chamber and to honourable members.

INTERJECT.PARA: The industrial action has also prevented the publication of yesterday's House of Representatives Hansard and Hansard for Senate Estimates Committees A, B and C for Tuesday.

PETITION.TITLE: Aid
PETITION.PARA: The Acting Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Aid
To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, wish to record our support for the One World Declaration:
to focus Australian aid, and policies at the World Bank, IMF and Asian Development Bank, on fighting poverty and protecting the environment;
to restore Australian aid to 0.5% of GNP, cut military spending by 1% and work for a fairer international economic system;
to promote human rights through aid and a code of conduct for companies.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives call upon the Government to implement the above.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin (from 713 citizens), Mr Bilney (from 266 citizens), Dr Blewett (from 21 citizens), Mr Dobie (from 12 citizens) and Mr Wright (from 560 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Natural Therapy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament:

We, the citizens of Australia, wish to bring to your attention our objections to the Therapeutic Goods Regulations under the Therapeutic Goods Act, 1989. Under the guise of protecting the public against inferior produce, those Regulations will have the effect of putting out of business many natural therapists and small-scale manufacturers of natural remedies. The clauses in the Regulations which purport to exempt homeopaths and herbalists are so badly drafted as to be inoperable, and the prohibition on allegedly misleading representations will make it impossible to refer to efficacies of natural remedies which have been public knowledge for centuries. The Regulations, therefore, represent a fundamental attack on the Australian people's freedom of choice in medicine and are an abomination.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will reject the Therapeutic Goods Regulations and request the House to constitute a public inquiry into the questions of registration of the natural healing professions and the supervision and regulation of natural therapeutic goods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles (from 17 citizens), Mr Nehl (from 24 citizens), Mr Webster (from 19 citizens) and Dr Bob Woods (from 669 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Earth Repair Action Decade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:
our total global environment is rapidly deteriorating;
important natural resources vital to human life and livelihood such as ozone, trees, soil and water are being depleted at an increasing and alarming rate;
there is an urgent need to educate all people in conservation skills and the responsible use and maintenance of natural resources;
the United Nations Association of Australia (UNAA) has proclaimed an Australian Earth Repair Action (ERA) Decade from 1988;
Earth Repair Action will unite people, communities, religions and nations in the productive purpose of greening and repairing our Earth for a safer and more peaceful future.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:

Propose that an International Earth Repair Action (ERA) Decade begin on World Environment Day, June 5, 1990 with FIERY, the First International Earth Repair Year, and that this be proclaimed by the United Nations General Assembly. This ten-year plan will ignite the spirit of local and global co-operation to hygienically compost all presently wasted bio-degradable materials into humus to revitalise soils; grow billions of trees to replace forests lost and replenish the atmosphere; establish sustainable, economic and agricultural growth internationally and end world hunger.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Carlton (from 15 citizens) and Mr Nehl (from 54 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House of Representatives that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the House will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Courtice (from 40 citizens) and Ms McHugh (from 334 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Romania
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker, and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of Egon NAVRATIL
The organised persecution of minority Hungarians in Rumania must be stopped permanently.

This trouble started 70 years ago (4 June 1920) when the Hungarian land of Transylvania was awarded to Rumania by the Allied and Associated Powers under the Treaty of Trianon. In exchange for the title of the newly acquired land, Rumania was obliged to guarantee minority rights. It has consistently failed to honour this commitment.
Therefore your petitioners humbly pray, that your Honourable House should promote:
Australia take the initiative to re-negotiate or nullify the Treaty that has been constantly violated by successive Rumanian regimes.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the matter of United Nations Covenants and the way in which they may impact on our existing common law system, method of Government and independent judiciary. Your petitioners request the House to legislate or provide for:
1. A 12 month Moratorium on the ratification of the Convention on the Rights of the Child to enable the people of Australia to discuss and examine in detail the 54 Articles of the Convention.
2. A Referendum to follow the 12 month moratorium, seeking public approval before ratification of the Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Howard (from 15 citizens) and Mr Prosser (from 3,464 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. that ratification of United Nations Conventions, such as the above, by the Federal Government, without Parliamentary debate or consultation with the people through a referendum, is a gross abuse of the Australian Constitution and is contrary to democratic principles;
2. that the Convention's philosophy of parent/child relationships is based on a false premise and embodies the totalitarian principles of State ownership of children;

3. that the Christian principle of parental authority is essential for the proper functioning of society, but phrases in the Convention implying parents' rights are virtually meaningless, with escape clauses permitting the widest of interpretation;
4. that Articles 12 to 16 giving children the right to seek, think, say and be whatever, where ever and with whom they wish violates the common sense of any normal parent;
5. that some Articles contradict other Articles and imprecise wording adds to the confusion by providing loopholes for the protection of paedophiles and certain types of child traffickers;

6. that some of the proposed rights are inappropriate for immature child minds and have no logical connection with the protection of children from abuse or deprivation, such protection being already provided by existing Australian laws.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to legislate or provide for:
(a) a twelve month Moratorium on the ratification of the Convention to enable the people of Australia to discuss and examine in detail the 54 Articles;
(b) a referendum to follow the Moratorium, seeking public approval before ratification of the Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Security Benefits: Chinese Students
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in the Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of the State of Victoria, draws to the attention of the house that:

There is widespread concern at the payment of Social Security Benefits, Medicare Payments, Education Allowances and Family Allowances to the 19000 Chinese Students recently granted temporary residence for four (4) years by the Hawke Labor Government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives urge the Government not to pay these benefits because there is no proper justification for them and they are an unfair impost on all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Multifunction Polis
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker, and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the House of Representatives urge the Government to suspend all further considerations regarding the proposed Multi Function Polis forthwith pending:
1. Full public disclosure of the nature and details of the proposal.
2. The Australian people have the opportunity to fully and exhaustively debate the concept.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Animal Patents
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the Australian House of Representatives.

The undersigned citizens of Australia, and custodians of the Earth, oppose the patenting of animals, and the processes for altering them. Animal patents would reduce biodiversity, compromise animal welfare, concentrate ownership of breeding stock, and allow companies to appropriate the fruit of centuries of selective breeding. We note with concern that many applications for animal patents have been lodged with the Australian Patents Office and, without your intervention, may soon be approved. Please take all possible steps immediately to ensure:
1. The Patents Office rejects all existing applications for animal patents and declines to accept any more;
2. The Parliament amends the Patents Bill 1989 to prohibit the patenting of animals.
We pray that all members of Parliament act on this petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Earth Repair Action Decade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled;
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:

our total global environment is rapidly deteriorating and important natural resources vital to human life and livelihood such as ozone, trees, soil and the purity of air and water are being depleted at an increasing and alarming rate;
there is an urgent need to educate all people in conservation skills and the responsible use and maintenance of natural resources;
the United Nations Association of Australia (the people's arm of the UN), has proclaimed an Australian ERA (Earth Repair Action) Decade from 1988;
Earth Repair Action will unite people, communities, religions and nations in the productive and peaceful purpose of greening and repairing our Earth for a healthier and safer future.
Your petitions therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:

Propose that a world-wide ERA (Earth Repair Action) Decade begin on World Environment Day, June 5, 1990 with FIERY, the First International Earth Repair Year, and that this will be proclaimed by the United Nations General Assembly.
This ten-year plan will ignite the spirit of local and global unification and co-operation to stop the current destruction and start repairing our Earth by:
growing billions of trees to replace forests lost and to replenish the atmosphere;
hygienic composting of all presently wasted organic materials into humus to revitalise soils;
establishing globally, permanent, self-sustaining, organic agriculture to end world hunger;
reallocating annually 10% of all military budgets, personnel and resources, within each nation, to fund and support the ERA Decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Public Housing in South Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the state of South Australia supporting the Public Tenants Association draws to the attention of the House the impending reduction of monies available for public housing in South Australia and your petitioners pray that the House do act to prevent the corresponding reduction in the availability of public housing and increase in the rents charged for it.

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker, and Members of The House of Representatives assembled in Parliament the petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of The House the proposed legislation ``The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child''.

We do not support this legislation because we believe it will contribute even further to the breakdown of the Family Unit resulting further in the moral decline of Society, because parents are not allowed to:
* Punish a child in any way for actions or words which might be contrary to the beliefs, opinions or standards of the parents (Article 2).
* Have the final say as to what is in the best interests of the child-the Government will (Article 9).
* Restrict what a child sees, hears, reads or is taught at School (Article 13).
* Influence a child's views on morality or religion, or influence or restrict in any way a child's choice of associates (Articles 14 and 15).
* Determine medical treatment or refuse them some forms of treatment (Article 24).
* Have a child educated at home (Article 28).
Your Petitioners therefore request the House not to support this legislation in any way whatsoever and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Glass Milk Bottles
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out to the House that milk cartons are non-recyclable.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to legislate for the reintroduction of glass milk bottles.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
Your petitioners request the House to raise the priority listing of roads in the Government's expenditure programmes to ensure that sufficient funding is allocated to:
(a) redress the backlog of road works required to raise the Nation's road network to a standard consistent with that of a progressive, developed country;
(b) ensure that Australia's road network is able to be maintained to a standard acceptable to a country so dependent on road transport; and,
(c) permit the progressive improvement and upgrading of the road system so as to keep pace with the demands made upon it.

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence on Television: Sale and Classification of Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Wannon electorate respectfully showeth that:
There is too much crime and violence on TV and depicted in videos and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
1. Urge TV stations to reduce the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes.
2. Introduce tighter controls on the sale and classification of videos so as to limit the access of children to inappropriate material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Office: Mareeba, Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the following situation:

The lack of a Medicare Office in the township of Mareeba, on the Atherton Tableland of North Queensland, is causing extreme hardship to pensioners and other low income earners, who are obliged by circumstances of extremely limited and unsuitable public transport facilities to lodge Medicare claim forms by post with either the Atherton or Cairns Medicare Offices. From experience, these Offices are taking up to four weeks to process the claim forms and return payments.

Such waiting periods are unacceptable to claimants who have large claims outstanding when they are in a financial position where they can least afford to wait for payment. Currently there is no Doctor/Practice in Mareeba which totally bulk bills patients.

Such an Office would also better service the surrounding gulf and outback areas, a great benefit to those rural citizens. Mareeba is the main administrative centre of the northern Tablelands area and with an ever increasing aged population residing in this part of North Queensland, it is considered essential that a Medicare Office be established here.

We petitioners, therefore, respectfully request that the House take action to ensure a Medicare office is situated in Mareeba as soon as possible to alleviate these problems. Failing this, a visiting service similar to that which operates with the Department of Social Security would be greatly welcomed.

PETITION.TITLE: Artificial Food Colourings
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

This petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the House's attention to the harmful health effects of the artificial colours E123 (carmoisine-red colouring) and E 102 (tartrazine-yellow food colouring).
Your petitioners respectfully request the House to urge the Government to:
1. Assess the large amount of scientific evidence now available which links these additives to hyperactivity in children, allergies, eczema and hives.
2. Request the National Health and Medical Research Council to conduct a full investigation into the possible links with increased rates of cancer associated with large intakes of these colourings.
3. Investigate which other countries have legislated bans on the use of these additives in food consumed in their countries.
4. Until a complete report is received from the NHMRC the Government should institute a temporary ban on these dangerous food additives on foods consumed in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Breast Milk Substitutes
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the House's attention to violations of the WHO International Code on Marketing of Breast Milk substitutes that are currently occurring in Western Australia.
Your petitioners are concerned that these violations could have a significant impact on the health of Australian babies and we therefore respectfully request the House to urge the Government to:
1. Implement all the provisions of the WHO International Code of Marketing of Breast Milk Substitutes.

2. Legislate for appropriate penalties for both individuals and companies who knowingly sell and promote breast milk substitutes contrary to the internationally accepted guidelines developed by the World Health Organisation and to which the Australian Government has given its endorsement.

3. Ensure that Australian infants are given the best possible nutritional start to life by encouraging through Government agencies and public hospitals the establishment and maintenance of successful lactation.

PETITION.TITLE: Disposable Nappies
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled.

This petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the House's attention to the presence of the cancer-causing waste product, Dioxin, in babies' disposable nappies which can be in direct skin contact for 2 years.
Your petitioners respectfully request the House to urge the Government to:
(1) Initiate independent research into the precise levels of Dioxin in disposable nappies.
(2) Legislate to force nappy manufacturers to remove Dioxin from these products.
(3) Place pressure on nappy manufacturers to produce these products from unbleached paper therefore eliminating a significant cause of the presence of Dioxin.
(4) Place pressure on nappy manufacturers to produce biodegradable disposable nappies which will be less harmful to the environment.

PETITION.TITLE: Capital Gains Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House the proposal of the Opposition Parties to remove the tax on capital gains which has operated in Australia since September 1985, and points out to the House that such a proposal would:
1. mean a windfall gain of billions of dollars to Australia's richest people
2. disadvantage the 99.2 per cent of Australians who pay no capital gains tax
3. be in complete disregard of the desires of the people of Australia that capital gains be subject to tax
4. restore the tax avoidance industry to the prominence it enjoyed under the former Liberal/National Party government.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House maintain its support for the Government's capital gains tax.

PETITION.TITLE: Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of this House that we are concerned at the threats caused by logging to the integrity and continued existence of what remains of the forests of south eastern Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his government
(1) to phase out woodchipping for export;
(2) NOT to renew a long-term export licence to Harris Daishowa;

(3) to ensure that sensitive environmental areas, and specifically the proposed national park and wilderness areas of Coolangubra, Cathcart, Egan Peaks and the Tantawangalo catchment, are protected and excluded from the proposed woodchip export licence; and

(4) to promote ecologically sound and sustainable forestry practices including: re-afforestation and plantation of native hardwoods on already cleared land to reduce pressure on native forests; and minimisation of wasteful uses of forest products.

PETITION.TITLE: Abortion Funding Abolition Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1988/89 the Federal Government paid $6.9 million from taxpayers' funds for 64,788 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by supporting the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1989 and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Government Funding of Abortion
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1987/88 the Federal Government paid $6.4 million from taxpayers funds for 61,879 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies and abolish Government funding of abortion.

PETITION.TITLE: Five-Dollar Note
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker, and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of teachers, students and community of East Hills Girls' Technology High School respectfully sheweth our protest at the proposed replacement of Caroline Chisholm with the Queen on our Five dollar currency for the following reasons:
(1) Carolyn Chisholm is the only Australian woman recognised for her contribution to our Society and early beginnings in this manner. There is no other Australian woman on any of our currency.

(2) We feel her presence on the Five dollar note is testimony to her life-work for women, the unemployed and the family, for which she obtained little recognition of monetary compensation in her lifetime.
(3) The Queen is currently on all Australian coins.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House dismiss this proposal and maintain Carolyn Chisholm on our Five dollar note.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pacific Highway
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the increasing carnage on the Pacific Highway.

Your petitioners therefore ask the Federal Parliament to accept that the Pacific Highway must be made into a four-lane, dual carriageway divided highway from Hexham to the Queensland border and that the Federal Government provide vastly increased funding to bring this conversion to reality.

PETITION.TITLE: Khmer Refugees
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia and residents in the State of New South Wales, draws to the attention of the House the situation of the inequity caused by the Prime Minister's decision to not accept Khmer Boat People, while accepting Chinese students as residents in this country, despite the suffering faced by Khmer during the past 20 years.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:
Overturn the decision to return the Khmer Boat People and to consider, in the light of humanitarian values, the uncertain situation which will be faced by them if they are returned, and
Put in place an orderly departure programme for Khmer family reunion.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Animals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

There is an urgent need that the Australian Government immediately upgrade the Regulations concerning exportation of animals overseas for slaughter and that there is unnecessary suffering caused to the animals under the present system.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will amend the legislation to ensure that animals being exported be done so humanely and that until this is achieved a total ban be placed on the export of animals for slaughter.
Further it is requested that the export of horses be stopped.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mail Box, Raymond's Hill, Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives assembled in the Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of Raymond's Hill, Ipswich in the State of Queensland, Electors of the Division of Oxley points out to the House:
That the Raymond's Hill region of Ipswich in the State of Queensland is grossly underserviced with mail boxes for the posting of mail by residents of the aforesaid region;

And further, that the aforesaid residents have requested through Mr Robert Bazeley, that Australia Post position a mail box in the vicinity of the shop at 11 Holmes Street, Raymond's Hill and that this request has, to date, been ignored.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to cause all necessary steps to be taken to ensure that a mail box is positioned at 11 Holmes Street, Raymond's Hill aforesaid in accordance with the request made to better service the residents of the Raymond's Hill region.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Les Scott (from four citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament, this petition of certain citizens of Australia invites to the attention of the House that:
(a) there is widespread concern and strong objection to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child; and
(b) guidance and responsibility of our children belongs to us, the parents, NOT the government.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled require the Government to refrain from ratifying this convention.
And your petitioners, as is duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: RAAF No. 7 Stores Depot, Toowoomba
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, this petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia invites to the attention of the House that:

(a) Government interference in Defence Department decision making processes will lead to the concentration of Defence warehousing facilities, from somewhat decentralised locations into others that are questionable on political, cost efficiency and strategic grounds;

(b) the RAAF No. 7 Stores Depot, at Toowoomba, Queensland, is less than 90km from Amberley Airforce Base and 30km from the Army Aviation Centre at Oakey. It is a perfectly functioning multi-Service storage facility which could be enhanced at minimal cost and should not be closed down and have its functions relocated to Amberley; and

(c) relocation will cost many millions of dollars for the construction of replacement facilities at both Amberley and Oakey; employee resettlement and redundancy arrangements; and unquantifiable social and community costs to the people and commerce of the city of Toowoomba.

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives require the Government to reverse its questionable directions to the Department of Defence until a full debate on the political, cost efficiency and strategic implications confirms its decision on the closure of RAAF No. 7 Stores Depot to be correct.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Aid
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament, this petition of certain citizens of Australia invites to the attention of the House that:
(a) Since 1984 the Federal Government has reduced Australian aid to impoverished foreign countries by some 7% in real terms;
(b) the Federal Government is budgeting to reduce Australian aid even further, in the future; and
(c) the internationally recognised and UN accepted benchmark for foreign aid is 0.7% of gross national product (GNP).

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled require the Government to increase Australian aid to deserving countries, progressively, until reaching the benchmark of 0.7% of GNP annually.
And your petitioners, as is duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Investment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, this petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia invites to the attention of the House that:
(a) there is within the community an increasing concern for the well being of our heritage, culture, traditions and the sovereign independence of our country and its assets; and
(b) foreign investment in Australia has been increasing at an alarming rate, particularly by predatory countries like Japan.

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives require the Government to limit foreign investment in Australian homes, land, business enterprises, resorts, farms and basic resources to 45% of each purchase. 65% investment in such enterprises may only be permitted on a lease hold basis for periods not exceeding 20 years, the remaining equity must remain in the hands of Australian nationals.

PETITION.TITLE: Lithuania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That whereas on 11th March 1990, the democratically elected and legal Government of Lithuania re-declared its independence from the Soviet Union into which it had been forcibly incorporated in 1940.

And whereas the Soviet Union is refusing to recognise this rightful independence and is applying threats and intimidation to pressurise the people and government of Lithuania into rescinding their declaration,

And whereas the Australian Government, whilst not recognising annexation of Lithuania by the Soviet Union, has not taken up this opportunity to demonstrate support for the justified aspirations of the Lithuanian people for freedom.

So therefore do the undersigned sincerely and urgently petition the Senate to pursue immediate steps for the issuing of formal recognition of Lithuania's Declaration of Independence and to publicly endorse the right of the Lithuanian people to self-determination.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Natural Therapy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

We, the citizens of Australia, wish to bring to your attention our objections to the Therapeutic Goods Regulations under the Therapeutic Goods Act, 1989. Under the guise of protecting the public against inferior therapeutic goods and devices, the Regulations will have the effect of putting out of business many Alternative Practitioners and small-scale manufacturers of natural remedies. The Clauses in the Regulations which purport to exempt Homeopaths and Herbalists are poorly drafted and the prohibition on representations will make it impossible for Australians to use natural medicines. The Regulations, therefore, represent a fundamental attack on the Australian people's freedom of choice in medicine and are an abomination.
Your petitioners, therefore, pray that the House will reject the Therapeutic Goods Regulations and request the House to constitute a Public Enquiry into the registration of Alternative Practitioners.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will forever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Natural Therapy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House that we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, here register our firm protest against the current form of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989, which seeks to restrict as S2 and S4 poisons those traditional natural medicines which have been used safely for centuries. The effect of these regulations will be to:

1. Restrict approximately forty or more major healing herbs and their homoeopathic derivatives as scheduled poisons, (eg: Comfrey) to be dispensed only by general practitioners, veterinary surgeons, dentists and pharmacists.

2. Prohibit manufacturers of traditional natural medicines from communicating any information regarding the use of their preparations to those specialised in their use-even in private or during an educational seminar limited to practitioners. This right to knowledge will now be exclusive to doctors, dentists, veterinary surgeons and pharmacists.
3. Increase the cost of all natural therapeutic substances by imposing exorbitant registration, licensing and inspection fees.
4. Require wholesalers and manufacturers of herbal materials to meet the same standards regarding equipment and premises as large scale pharmaceutical manufacturers.
If these regulations are allowed to be proclaimed, it will severely hamper natural therapy practice and deny the right of citizens of this country to choose the therapy they wish.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House:
1. Set aside the passing of this legislation until thorough public investigation of the ramifications of the Act upon the natural therapies professions is carried out.

2. Carry out an impartial assessment of the effect of this legislation upon the rights of the individual to select the mode of wholistic health care of ones choice, which is presently affordable and accessible to all.
3. Immediately begin procedures leading to the registration of practitioners of natural therapies now under threat of prohibition by this Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs I present the report of the Committee entitled Our Future, Our Selves, together with the minutes of the proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House take note of the report.

The report I have just tabled, Our Future, Our Selves, is the final report of the inquiry into support services for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. In the last Parliament the Committee tabled an interim report on the inquiry indicating that the inquiry would be divided into four areas. That was followed up by the report A Chance For The Future which contained the Committee's conclusions and recommendations on the education and training aspects of the inquiry. This report deals with self-determination and self-management and impediments to their further development. It also deals with funding, coordination, accountability and resources to allow greater self-determination and self-management.

Other members who participated in the previous Parliament will speak in more detail on this report, but I want to say a few things briefly in relation to the all-important question of this report's recommendations in relation to the difference between consultation and negotiation. The report recommends that we should start thinking about the way in which we deal with Aboriginal communities in a very different framework.

The report deals with the existing process of consultation in chapter 4 and notes at 4.24 the way in which Aboriginal communities regard the existing consultation processes. The report notes that Aboriginal perceptions are very different from those of government. Almost invariably they reflected dissatisfaction. When the subject was raised by the Committee during informal discussions, Aboriginal communities were repeatedly dismissive and sometimes even derisive about attempts at consultation by all levels of government as their previous experience had led them to believe that it would achieve very little. There was a strong perception that whatever consultation occurred was inadequate.

For some communities, after years of having decisions taken for them by outsiders, to be suddenly allowed to be involved in matters affecting the community was a novel experience and was viewed with some surprise and scepticism. Aboriginal people may have been involved in the decisions but they still felt the decisions were being taken far away. There was also criticism of the way in which government departments were essentially using the rhetoric of consultation as a screen to justify what was in effect ratification of decisions which had already been taken.

Of course, there are some communication difficulties with respect to processes of consultation and the Committee addressed that matter, noting, for example, the need to develop a much more widespread use of plain English in communication, documentation and correspondence with Aboriginal communities. But more substantially the report recommends that our thinking about the concept of discussion with Aboriginal communities should be framed in terms of negotiation rather than consultation. In that process there is a need to change the emphasis in the process from one of listening to and advising communities to one where communities have a more direct say in deciding final outcomes. Instead of being merely involved, Aboriginal people must be integral to deciding policy and programs which directly affect their lives. That is essentially the difference between consultation and negotiation as explained in this report.

The work for this report was largely undertaken by the Committee in the previous Parliament under the chairmanship of Allen Blanchard and, later, under the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon). To enable the Committee to take advantage of the experience of the previous members we appointed a subcommittee of the honourable member for the Northern Territory, as Chairman, the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) and the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler), all members of the previous Committee, to complete the report. The honourable member for Macquarie and the honourable member for Leichhardt agreed to be additional members of the Committee for this purpose.

While the Committee as a whole takes responsibility for the content of the report, we should acknowledge the substantial authorship of the subcommittee. On behalf of the Committee I would like to thank the honourable member for the Northern Territory in particular for the considerable effort he put into the preparation of the report and for chairing the subcommittee in this Parliament. I also thank the other members of the subcommittee, the full Committee and the secretariat for their efforts to complete this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon The Hon W.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I wish to thank my colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) for his kind words in his introduction to the tabling of this report of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs. At the outset I would like to thank a number of people who have made a great contribution to this Committee but who are, for one reason or another, no longer on it. The first is Allen Blanchard, who was Chairman prior to my period as Chairman of that Committee. Allen is no longer a member of the House but his efforts in the area of Aboriginal affairs and his efforts on this Committee in particular have not gone unnoticed. I believe that he is one person who, having left the Parliament, can say that he did indeed make a contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to acknowledge my friends and colleagues the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) and the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler), both of whom served on the Committee in the previous Parliament and both of whom were members of the subcommittee which finalised this report. They were kind enough to stay on as members of the Committee to see that this report was completed.

I would also like to acknowledge the work of David Elder, who is no longer the Secretary of the Committee but who was Secretary for a number of years. His advice and assistance with regard to the operation of the Committee and in the preparation of documents were without peer in terms of my experience in this Parliament. Peter Stephens and Auriel Bloomfield were also instrumental in the writing of the initial drafts of this report. Peter and Auriel are no longer with the Committee. On behalf of the Committee I would like to acknowledge their work and assistance.

Last, but by no means least, I would like to acknowledge members of the current Committee for their forbearance in being able to go through this very lengthy document on the basis that they got a nod and wink from the honourable member for Leichhardt, the honourable member for Macquarie and me about its appropriateness. I must say that they did that rather well. We were able to negotiate any issues that may have been contentious without any great difficulty.

I would also like to acknowledge Allan Kelly and the current secretariat for having to take on a report which, although drafted in the first instance, was not completed. They had the difficult task of amending drafts of a report that they had not been involved in and they have done it extremely well.

The two reports of this Committee make it starkly obvious that there has been insufficient effort in marrying the Government's policies of Aboriginal self-determination and self-management with appropriate planning and management mechanisms to ensure that Aboriginal and Islander people have the means to control their lives. It is apparent that the consultation process has been largely ineffective. It has not been a process of which dialogue has been a feature; rather, it has been one in which, after discussions of varying lengths, views from outside have been imposed.

It is obvious that the consultation process should be based on negotiation when government and other agencies deal with Aboriginal and Islander people. Negotiation is necessary if meaning is to be given to self-determination. The distinction between the terms `self-determination' and `self-management' is important. On the one hand, self-management focuses on efficient administration of communities and organisations. Self-determination, on the other hand, goes well beyond this and implies control over policy and decision- making, especially the determination of structures, processes and priorities. The differences between the two concepts often provide a dilemma for government agencies. Indeed, if an Aboriginal organisation encounters problems pressure is placed on government officials to intervene in this self-management process and rectify matters. By doing this, however, Aboriginal people may end up sacrificing self-determination as control of their affairs is transferred out of their hands.

The Committee examined a number of impediments to self-determination and self-management. The concept of community, for example, as it applies to Aboriginal structures is not always clear and often fails to recognise the differing factions, groups and interests in communities. There is often a conflict between Aboriginal cultural obligations and the political or administrative requirements of community management. Non-Aboriginal structures are often seen as being unrepresentative and lacking in authority by Aboriginal people. At the same time Aboriginal organisations lack authority in the non-Aboriginal power structures. The resources and skills provided to Aboriginal communities to enable them effectively to manage themselves have thus far been inadequate.

A central recommendation of this Committee resulted in the Government's acknowledgment that to give effect to policies of self-determination and self-management it is necessary to reappraise the effectiveness of existing structures and methods of dealing with Aboriginal and Islander people and that such a reappraisal should, firstly, acknowledge that the process of consultation has generally not given rise to genuine dialogue and has been largely ineffective; and, secondly, accept the need for policies and outcomes to be determined by a process of negotiation which better accords with traditional decision making processes. The Committee further recommended that the process of negotiation with Aboriginal people should replace the current process of consultation, and that, when negotiating structures, governments should avoid placing undue pressure on Aboriginal people in such a way as to achieve an outcome that would conform to established government policy or meet a government imposed timetable.

The Committee has made a number of more detailed recommendations on general principles to be observed when establishing structures for Aboriginal people and for discussions and negotiations with Aboriginal people. I do not have time this morning to go through the whole gamut of the recommendations in this document, but I will, if I may, just alert the House to the major headings which the recommendations address. They address concerns relating to women in Aboriginal communities and coordination of the administration of Aboriginal affairs in terms of policies from State and Territory governments. A very interesting and important recommendation of this Committee, and one about which we had some discussion with the current shadow Minister, was on the coordination and role of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) in dealing with the coordination of Aboriginal programs. Recommendation 17 of this report recommends that:

As the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission develops its structures and administrative capacities, Commonwealth, State, Territory and local governments view the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission as the co-ordinating agency for working with Aboriginal people.

I think that is a very important recommendation. It goes to a number of things which this Government has been addressing over the last short period, particularly in relation to looking at aspects of public administration in terms of micro-economic reform. There is absolutely no point, in my view, in the stupid duplication of services that currently exists in the administration of Aboriginal affairs in this country. Some commentators outside this place have taken the view that ATSIC ought to be white-anted and that indeed it should not be seen as the main carrier of Aboriginal affairs administration in this country. They have adopted the view that it is an undemocratic organisation which does not represent Aboriginal interests. In fact, the Northern Territory Chief Minister has asserted that it is against the interests of the wider community. That, of course, is arrant nonsense. There was enough debate in this Parliament and there were enough amendments to this legislation to ensure that it accords with the majority view.

However, I am happy to say that this Committee has always operated in a bipartisan manner. It is a great credit to this Committee that on an issue which has caused great division in this House over the past couple of years its reports have invariably been brought down with bipartisan support. It is a credit not only to the members of the Government but also to the Opposition. In this particular instance I must say that on these issues the shadow Minister has shown himself prepared to examine the issues with a great deal of objectivity. That is the course that we ought to follow when we are addressing Aboriginal issues generally.

It also accords with a recent address to the United Nations in Geneva by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner). He was addressing the issue of reconciliation. In that context he said that a precondition of any reconciliation must be the adoption of a national goal for all levels of government working with Aboriginal people to address cooperatively issues of land, housing, health, infrastructure, education, employment and economic development of Aboriginal Australia in the period leading up to the centenary of federation in 2001.

I think that it has to happen a lot sooner than that. This report addresses some of the key issues in getting that coordination and cooperation together. It addresses a whole range of other issues which I do not have time to address this morning. One of them is the issue of community development.

One of the problems we have had in the area of Aboriginal affairs in this country, certainly since the mid-1970s, is that in terms of giving back to people control over their affairs, we have been all too short in insisting that when we do that, they do what we say. That is no longer good enough. ATSIC sets up the framework whereby Aboriginal people can have a proper say in the administration of Aboriginal affairs. More importantly, in the area of community development we ought to be considering appropriate community development planning.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, in speaking to the tabling of this report I would first like to thank the staff of the secretariat of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs for the very hard work they have done, particularly in recent weeks. Other than the members of the Committee, very few people see just how hard those people work. I should say also that I came to this Committee only at the commencement of this Parliament, after the very hard work that was done by the Committee of the previous Parliament. So, coming late to this Committee, I will speak for only a few moments. I acknowledge that this report is largely the work of others.

SPEECH.PARA: In many ways, this report is an indictment of the way successive State and Federal governments have developed a patchwork quilt to try to deal with problems in Aboriginal affairs. I have been very concerned to read the reports of the work that the Committee did around the country during the life of the last Parliament and to read some of the conclusions that were reached.

The previous two speakers, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) and the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon), talked about consultation and negotiation. The two areas of this report that concern me the most are those of coordination and funding. Ultimately, if government cannot get its act together on coordination and funding, it can have very little credibility.

Chapter 6 of the report deals with coordination. The Committee makes some observations that are worthy of mention in this Parliament. Aboriginal communities may have to deal with up to 18 different State and Commonwealth government bodies when trying to coordinate the different programs in their communities. This would be a gargantuan task for any group. For a group of people who are only now having full access to education and for many of whom English may be a second or foreign language, this becomes a burden that really is something that has not been properly considered.

What is even more disturbing is that when the Committee looked at the reasons for the ineffective coordination, it appeared that this was a result of there being a plethora of agencies involved in service delivery which resulted in overlap, duplication and wastage. There was poor communication within and between agencies. There was rivalry and hostility. Because of the differing structures in differing agencies, the bureaucratic mechanism could not communicate between one level and another. There was a lack of overall coordination between States and Territories.

The point was made to the Committee, and it is restated in the report, that this proliferation of agencies, policies and programs in Aboriginal communities leads to duplication, high administrative costs, lack of efficiency in program delivery and an increasing territorial rivalry. In the five months that I have travelled around the country since I became shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs, I have seen the very real need that exists in Aboriginal communities. I am intensely annoyed that when this need exists, so much of our resources goes on duplication, rivalry and wastage.

Chapter 7 deals with funding. Again, it is an indictment of the way that successive State and Territory governments have put patchwork programs together without any overall coordination. It was put to the Committee by the South Australian Government that this lack of coordination led to fragmented policy development and planning and unnecessary financial arrangements. These are all the consequences of the way we do things.

These problems were most notable in the community of Toomelah in New South Wales. I visited that community two weeks ago. Some time ago the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission reported on the conditions at Toomelah. The appalling conditions in that community were largely attributable to conflict over appropriate policy and respective funding responsibilities between the Commonwealth and the State. Quite frankly, different levels of government had let the people down.

Finally, it was put to the Committee by the Auditor-General that because of the duplication of funding sources, existing projects were assessed not on an ongoing basis or against their initial justification, and any new projects could not get up on their merits. Quite simply, the current situation of duplication and wastage is failing Aboriginal people.

Coming to this report late, I may differ in emphasis from some of the recommendations that have been placed, but the report has gone through as it has because I felt it would have been unreasonably pedantic to try to dot every i and cross every t. The way that people had worked in the previous Parliament and the sense that we wanted to get a report that largely reflected the views across the parties are reasons why I have not been pedantic about this report. I may differ in my assessment of ATSIC from the honourable member for the Northern Territory. In my view, certainly ATSIC is now on notice but, if it can get its act and accountability in order, we will have to look at it in the light of that.

This report is an important contribution to the debate on Aboriginal affairs and I hope that the Government will take it a little more seriously than it has taken the previous reports of this Committee. This is the seventh report in nearly seven years-since November 1984. The Committee has yet to receive a single reply from the Government. People put a lot of work into these committees, and if they want to feel that working for common ground means anything it is important that they get a response from the Government as to what the value of their work is. I commend the report to the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) would like to have been here today as he worked so hard on this report. Unfortunately he is overseas and, therefore, as another new member of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, it falls to me to have an opportunity to speak. I am not an expert in the area and I was not involved in taking the evidence or writing the report but, as the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) has said, I did get fairly heavily involved in some of the reviewing and redrafting and so I have some knowledge, obviously, of what is there.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that many members of this House will have heard on a number of occasions before the sorts of issues that are raised in this report. It is perhaps not to our credit as a country that such fundamental problems have not been adequately resolved before. I would like to pay tribute to those who worked so hard on this Committee and also to the staff who worked so ably with them. The Chairman, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), who spoke initially, the honourable member for the Northern Territory and the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) have dealt with the main provisions. I would like to cover just a few of the truths that particularly struck me when I was reviewing the report and its recommendations.

Firstly, of course, we place great emphasis on a bipartisan approach, and I think that is right, but we also need to be aware that Aboriginals themselves do not always see a bipartisan approach as necessarily positive. In fact, a number of them regard it with suspicion and see it as collusion by the non-Aboriginal community, and that is often a view that is expressed. Aboriginal problems, of course, vary from area to area by geography, by custom and by history and, therefore, we cannot say there are any blanket solutions to many of the problems that have been identified. What is quite clear is that imposed solutions will not work. We need ideas percolating upwards from the Aboriginal communities, but I believe the overwhelming need is for continuity and certainty in funding and in programs.

Frequently we and our constituents in dealing with the bureaucracy around the country become confused and cannot handle it. For Aboriginals it is much worse because the very structures that we have imposed are totally alien to their culture. Therefore, training and involvement of Aboriginals is important, but of critical importance, I suggest, is the training of the non-Aboriginal people who are going to work with the Aboriginals.
Finally, I would like to say a special word about Aboriginal women. I quote an extract from the report which I think is most important:

A recent Queensland Health Department report shows that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women are 17 times more likely to die from diabetes than white women in Australia. They are 13 times more likely to die from pneumonia, 9 times more likely to die of cervical cancer and 7 times more likely to die from bronchitis, emphysema and asthma. Many women are still being removed from communities weeks before childbirth. They and their families often do not have suitable accommodation near the hospital. Giving birth in a non-Aboriginal environment with males present disrupts traditional practices and often leaves the woman with little or no personal support.

Women and children are frequently the victims of domestic violence stimulated by alcohol. A recent report shows that one in four deaths of women in Alice Springs town camps resulted from alcohol related violence.

I believe that that encapsulates the plight of many Aboriginal women in remote communities. If anything, the report understates its evidence about women and its recommendations are a minimal position. I commend the report to the House and I urge the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) to pursue its recommendations with alacrity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I pay tribute to the effort of all the members of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, including Opposition members, who worked in a bipartisan way to produce what I believe is a comprehensive and well directed report entitled Our Future, Our Selves. I also endorse the remarks of the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) in asking the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) to be positive in his approach and response to the report, because I believe that some of the short term difficulties that exist in Aboriginal and Islander communities are addressed in this report.

SPEECH.PARA: One important area dealt with by the Committee relates to the range of structures available for the incorporation of Aboriginal organisations. The Commonwealth policy of direct funding of organisations has seen-maybe for better, maybe for worse-a wide range of Aboriginal organisations incorporated. In Queensland and the Northern Territory there are forms of local government for Aboriginal community councils. These councils have access to local government Commonwealth Grants Commission funding. Elsewhere in Australia, community councils and other organisations are incorporated under association Acts. However, Commonwealth legislation is available for both Aboriginal community councils and other Aboriginal organisations. A particular difficulty for community councils set up under association Acts is the lack of adequate powers over such matters as land and the oft quoted problem of alcohol.

I turn to some of the difficulties in my State of Queensland. In Queensland the model for community management of former missions and government reserves takes two forms: firstly, communities constituted under the Local Government (Aboriginal Lands) Act 1975, that is, only Aurukun and Mornington Island; and, secondly, communities which have been constituted under the Community Services (Aborigines) Act 1984 and the Community Services (Torres Strait) Act 1984. That includes some 18 Torres Strait islands and 14 mainland Aboriginal communities in receipt of local government Grants Commission funding.

In addition, a number of other Aboriginal organisations involved with self-management have used other State or Commonwealth mechanisms to incorporate as associations. For example, there are some 125 bodies incorporated under the Commonwealth's Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act.

During the 1970s the Queensland Government implemented the Local Government (Aboriginal Lands) Act and established Aurukun and Mornington Island as local government authorities, conferring upon them all the functions, powers, duties and obligations of any other local government authority in Queensland. This step was taken to thwart Commonwealth intervention in the two communities following the withdrawal of the Uniting Church.

After that, the previous Queensland Government enacted further legislation in relation to the control and management of land set aside for Aboriginal people through the community services legislation. The community councils established under this legislation are broadly similar in function to those created under the Local Government Act, although the legislation also provides for land to be transferred in perpetuity to the elected Aboriginal and Islander councils by way of a deed of grant in trust.

Although the detail of the two types of legislation varies, the theory and practical impact of both statutes at a community level is similar. One of the Committee's advisers noted at a seminar held in Brisbane that the community services legislation was an attempt to construct another form of local government that was equivalent in status to mainstream local government. I quote the adviser:
Both Acts seem to me to be in theory versions of a conventional local government model--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for committee reports has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That:
(1) noting the scarcity of information on the distribution of wealth in Australia;
(2) recognising that concern regarding inequality is shared by all major political parties in Australia;

(3) noting that the most recently published survey on the distribution and composition of personal wealth in Australia, Dilnot Australian Economic Review-lst quarter 1990, has concluded that over half the total personal wealth in Australia is held by the wealthiest 10 per cent of the population and the effective tax rate on income from savings falls as wealth rises; and
(4) sharing the sentiments expressed by the Prime Minister in his maiden speech to the House-
this House calls on the Government to:
(a) collect and publish national statistical information regarding the distribution of wealth in Australia; and
(b) commission a study to give detailed consideration to, and to report upon, measures available to reduce the inequality of wealth distribution in Australia.

There is an old saying which goes that the best way to judge even the most affluent society is by how well it treats its poor. I rise today to bring to the attention of the House how little we know about the distribution of wealth in this country. By not knowing about wealth we run the very real risk of misapplying aid that goes to our less fortunate citizens. The most recent analysis of wealth was by A. W. Dilnot writing as Downing Fellow at the University of Melbourne and published in the Australian Economic Review, first quarter, 1990. Dilnot made the point that very little is known of wealth distribution in Australia, especially at the most wealthy end. Dilnot's sentiments echoed those of John Pigott writing in the same journal, third quarter, 1988, in an article called `The Distribution of Wealth-What is it, What Does it Mean and is it Important?'. Pigott states:
No comprehensive survey data on personal wealth holdings have been collected since the late 1960s.

Pigott poses the question: Is the distribution of wealth important? I contend that it is of vital significance to all of us who are concerned about inequality in Australia. A recent Economic Planning Advisory Council discussion paper showed up an existing inequality when it estimated that household wealth net of debt increased dramatically between 1983 and 1990, from the equivalent of 3.2 times gross private income to nearly 4.5 times. That is a laudable increase except for the fact that the increase largely rested on a rapid rise in house values, especially in Sydney.

Who benefited from this dramatic increase? It is obvious from Dilnot's analysis who did not benefit. Some 30 per cent of the Australian population have no wealth at all; so any increase in wealth just serves to widen the gap between the haves and have nots. The rich just get richer.

Dilnot's analysis shows that the wealthiest 10 per cent of the population hold 55.2 per cent of Australia's private wealth. This concentration begs the question: What effect does so much wealth have in so few hands? Recent examples of how several of Australia's more wealthy businessmen have conducted their business affairs would lead to the conclusion that the concentration of wealth in a few hands can lead to major damage being done, not only to our economy but also to our international prestige.

Wealth gives its holders opportunities and economic power that the less well off in our community do not have. An example of this advantage is the opportunity to minimise taxation liabilities by concentrating wealth in non-taxed or minimally taxed assets. The people at the lower end of the wealth scale have no such flexibility. Any wealth they hold is held predominantly in bank deposits, the interest on which is fully taxed at their marginal rate of tax. Dilnot's paper shows that people with small amounts of wealth suffer higher effective rates of taxation, for example 47c in the dollar. These effective rates fall rapidly as wealth increases, with the top one per cent facing an effective rate of 9c in the dollar. That serves only to increase and help maintain the inequality of wealth distribution.

Wealth also contributes to and confers a degree of political power on its holders. I do not need to go into any more detail on the influence that wealthy groups and individuals have had on the political direction that Australia has taken in the past. Those groups and individuals have been experts in exercising their power to protect their interests and to maintain the status quo. Wealth also gives its holders choices about lifestyles and activities that are not available to all Australians. It is apparent from the analysis of effective taxation rates that taxation of wealth is biased against the least wealthy in the population. The taxation system has had the effect of making some types of wealthholding more attractive than others.

The fact that capital gains associated with private residences are not taxed aids those in the community who are able to afford a basic house. This leads to a benefit to the house owner when he or she retires, and helps to fund his or her aged care. We, of course, all see the value of this arrangement, but the inequity is that at the wealthier end of the scale there is an incentive for people to invest in nonproductive residences in order to achieve the maximum tax-free capital gain. The recent housing boom in Sydney with several well-publicised sales of harbourfront residences, for what can only be called obscene sums, is a case in point. The tax treatment of capital gains, both in rental property with negative gearing components, and in share transactions with a tax incentive to invest in Australian companies, also allows the more wealthy end of the spectrum to gain, because the real capital gains are only taxed after income is adjusted downwards for inflation.

To achieve a more equitable tax base we must understand fully the distribution of wealth and the way in which it is held. One of the most important contributing factors to the concentration of wealth in the top 10 per cent of the population is inheritance. There are no figures available in Australia, but figures from the United States of America show that in 1962, 34 per cent of people with assets in excess of $500,000 had inherited a substantial proportion of that wealth. The effect of inheritance is not only to maintain the status quo but it also allows for further growth of wealth in the upper percentiles of the population with consequent reinforcement of the inequalities. A United Kingdom report from 1979 reinforces this finding by indicating that 60 per cent of the top 0.1 per cent of the population were preceded by wealthy fathers. There is, of course, a simple answer to the question of inheritance; and that is the reintroduction of estate and gift duties. These would ensure that some redress of present inequalities is made. The reintroduction would be aimed at redressing the most apparent inequality in relation to the top 10 per cent of the population. Such new imposts would, of course, need to be specifically targeted so as not to affect the ordinary householder who, naturally, will want to pass his or her estate on to children and family.

It is easy to justify the introduction of such taxes on the grounds of philosophy and fairness. The passing of wealth from generation to generation confers relatively tax-free benefits on the recipients. But it is harder to justify such a return to estate and gift duties if we do not have a clear view of where wealth is located within society and without a complete understanding of the effect of such imposts across the population. Certainly, none of us would wish to see the imposition of a tax regime on inheritance which would affect ordinary Australians in a way that would prevent them from making proper disposition of their property to their family and children. None of us wants to see Australia as a country where there is a huge disparity between rich and poor. This disparity is evident, however, in some areas of our bigger cities where the haves and have-nots are living cheek by jowl. We do not want a situation like New York where differences in both wealth and values are so apparent and so at odds. These differences can lead only to resentment, driving groups to look outside the normal framework of government for solutions. So I echo the sentiments of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who, in his maiden speech in this House, stated:
We have moved inexorably towards that destabilised and dangerous position described by Disraeli as `Two Nations', the nation of the privileged and the nation of the poor.

I have brought to the attention of the House today the lack of data in Australia on the distribution of wealth. I have pointed out some inequalities that divide our country into the privileged and powerful at one end and the poor and the powerless at the other. The obscenity of having 10 per cent of the population holding over half of this nation's private wealth is a matter of concern to us all.

I have also outlined some of the problems relevant to our taxation system and the way in which these problems reinforce the existing status quo. It is our responsibility to all Australians as guardians of our country's future to take the myth of Australian egalitarianship and mateship and to put some reality into it. We can only redress the existing inequalities if we know the facts. We can only know the facts if the Government makes a collection of data concerning wealth a matter of priority and commissions a study to recommend measures to reduce the inequality of wealth distribution in our country. In this way all Australians can know the facts and be certain of the Government's commitment to its own vision of Australia as a nation where all citizens can truly have a fair go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the House calls on the Government to collect statistical information on the distribution of wealth and to commission a study to report on measures to reduce the inequality of wealth in Australia. The preamble to the motion suggests bipartisan political concern regarding the current levels of wealth inequality. There is broad concern at the number of poor in our society, particularly when contrasted with the obscenity of high-flying entrepreneurs scrambling over one another to accumulate more debt-ridden assets. However, the question should be asked whether equality of itself is achievable or even desirable.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no argument that in our country all are born equal and that all should have equal opportunity. However, to suggest that all should be kept equal is to ignore the important role that incentive plays in building our society. One cannot legislate for equality of achievement. A government can offer the opportunity but those who put in the greatest effort are surely entitled to the rewards of their endeavours.

Many who advocate a redistribution of wealth are motivated by the Robin Hood philosophy: taking from the rich and giving to the poor. This Government has invented a whole range of new taxes which have been very effective in taking a bigger share of the national cake, discouraging even the most hard-working Australians from succeeding. Indeed, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is proud of his record in broadening and developing new tax bases. Although the Treasurer boasts of broadening the tax base, one does not make one man rich by making another man poor. Governments have a much better record of making the rich poor than they do of making the poor rich.

It is more important for us as a nation that we create more wealth rather than waste what little we have arguing about who should possess it.
