If we are going to commission studies and research let us devote the maximum resources to studying ways of building up our nation and increasing its economy. Our national success is built upon the individual success of its people. Our country prospers when its people prosper. We should be proud of those in our nation who succeed and encourage them, not belittle them and attempt to take away their achievements just because others are not so successful.

The preamble also speaks of the maiden speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) almost 10 years ago in which he referred at some length to the need for a caring society to devote more of its resources to helping the poor and disadvantaged. What a change there has been in the attitude of the honourable member for Wills since he has become Prime Minister. These days he prefers the company of the rich and the infamous, and the praise of the Brotherhood of St Laurence in his maiden speech contrasts vividly with the insults he recently handed out to that organisation.

His promise that no child would live in poverty by 1990 was laudable, but when he declared last year that the promise had been fulfilled, he clearly indicated that he had lost touch with the real world and forgotten the message of his maiden speech. The longest reigning Labor Prime Minister in Australia has sadly impoverished the nation but he has done little to relieve individual personal poverty.

The facts are that there has been a significant redistribution of wealth in Australia over recent years. The Labor Government's economic policies have created a new poor, new poverty traps, and a new generation of disadvantaged Australians. Some of these new poor still have assets but little or no disposable income.

Australia's economic wealth has been built upon small business and the primary sector. However, it is from just these groups-under constant assault of the economic policies of the Labor Government-that many of our nation's new poor are emerging. Farmers' terms of trade have declined significantly and further reductions of over 50 per cent are predicted for 1990-91. Small business has been squeezed by high levels of taxation and increasing wage demands and other costs beyond its control. This Government has presided over the greatest exodus of farmers in the history of our nation, and the level of small business bankruptcies and closures rises with monotonous regularity.

The Government's assets tests frequently deny small businessmen and farmers access to family allowance payments, Austudy, and the like, trapping them and their families in a poverty cycle. Almost half the farm children in the South Burnett in my electorate are living in families which have had negative incomes for the majority of the past seven years. These people are a part of the new poor created by the policies of Labor in Government.
In an excellent series last month in the Courier-Mail, rural editor, Gordon Collie, reported on the poverty that `is rearing its head in the Queensland bush'. He said:

Hardly anyone in the city has noticed yet. They still have bountiful food on the table and all that macro-economic business about billion dollar export earnings is too hard for most to understand. Just about everyone in the rural sector is hurting. Government and private farm financial advisers are reporting a sharp rise in the number of farm families hopelessly in debt. Land valuations have been on the slide, eroding equity, pushing more and more families beyond hope of recovery.
Banks are reluctant to order fire sales for fear of a chain reaction. They see little point in owning a stack of deeds to unsaleable land.

In an accompanying editorial entitled `The Bush Needs a Helping Hand', the Courier-Mail highlighted `personal and corporate taxation, Government duties on fuel and a plethora of other charges which flow from burdensome bureaucracy' as causes of `the hardship factor'. The editorial called for `a little vision to comprehend the facts of life'. Quite a remarkable editorial, coming as it did from the Courier-Mail, which these days is little more than a newsletter for the Queensland Australian Labor Party.

These days the majority of rural Australians are not farmers. The vacant farm homes and abandoned properties are being occupied by a new generation of rural resident. Many thousands of people are forsaking the increasingly degraded lifestyle of our capital cities and choosing to live amidst the peace and the quiet of the bush.

Some come with an expectation of actually crafting a subsistence lifestyle from their few acres, fooled by the city-created image of wealthy landed gentry. Some are already invalided out of the work force or are having difficulty finding employment. Unfortunately, for most of these people there are no jobs when they move to their new community. They often find that, in addition to a long duration of unemployment, they have left their friends behind and find it difficult to adjust to a rural lifestyle.

The rural residential estates are becoming major poverty traps and social problem areas. In a recent series in the South Burnett Times, Mr Rick Palmer discussed the problems of the rural residential dweller. He said they were attracted `80 per cent by the pure economics of cheap housing and 20 per cent by the desire for a rural lifestyle'. He pointed out that many of the rural residential subdivisions had been approved in years gone by and did not have basic amenities such as electricity and sealed roads.

Mr Palmer's series on the social changes in the South Burnett spoke about the appalling living conditions being experienced by some of these new settlers, whom he described as `living in abject poverty'.

Mr Palmer reported neighbourhood discontent about the `hovel-type dwellings' being built by some. Where houses were not visible from the road they were sometimes built without council approval. He reported one complaint of six families living on the one block at the one time without any toilet, power, or fresh water facilities. A survey by a Kingaroy surgeon, Dr Phil Benjamin, concluded that over half of that shire's population growth over the past three years was made up of welfare recipients.

In Nanango an adult self-help group has been established. Mrs Glad Duxsbury from the group expressed concern about the lack of incentive to work. She said that there was little difference between the dole and their wages and the loss of the pensioner health card could effectively mean those in low paying jobs were better off financially by not working.

The Government's directive to suspend unemployment benefits to people moving to areas where there were reduced job opportunities frequently applies to this immigrant population group, leaving these new settlers with little or no money for survival.

The surge of development has resulted in the creation of 2,500 rural residential subdivision blocks in the Nanango Shire alone and a further 1,200 rural blocks in the neighbouring Wondai Shire. Many of these subdivisions were undertaken by big name developers and sold in southern capitals and overseas to buyers who had never even seen them.

In the coastal city of Hervey Bay, Australia's fourth fastest growing local authority area and another locality populated by people relocating from the southern cities, unemployment stands at 21 per cent. In the Nanango Shire, despite the presence of the Tarong power station, unemployment is at 16.6 per cent, almost treble the national average.

We need to recognise, as a society, this significant change in the population. There are still plenty of good reasons to live in a rural environment and there can be no doubt that the population drift is going to continue. Rural areas are great places in which to raise a family and to develop a healthy and happy lifestyle. Indeed, the move to the country should be encouraged for economic as well as social reasons. Governments need to ensure the provision of services appropriate to meet the needs of this new population group. They should also launch a positive program to encourage industry into regional areas to ensure that there are employment opportunities, not just poverty, awaiting those joining the movement to the country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion of the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr). I thought the contribution of the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) actually confirmed the thrust of the motion that we need some basis of knowledge about wealth distribution, not just guesswork, hunch, suspicion or superstition.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is essential that members of parliament and, even more importantly, our advisers in the bureaucracy who make the increasingly important decisions and provide critical input into the policy process, have some understanding about how the economic system works in practice and what the distribution of wealth is. Surprisingly little is known about the precise distribution of wealth in Australia.

Let me declare an interest for a moment and quote myself as an authority in this area. In the first edition of Sleepers, Wake!, published in 1982, I relied heavily on material that came out of the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty which was set up by the Whitlam Government. Even when Henderson carried out his poverty inquiry in the mid-1970s he in his turn was relying on surveys that had been carried out by the universities of Macquarie and Queensland between 1966 and 1968. So when the appropriate Henderson report was published in 1978, the material included was already 10 to 12 years out of date. I used that material in the earlier editions, but when I came to prepare the sixteenth impression of Sleepers, Wake! for 1990, it seemed ridiculous to use figures that were 22 to 24 years out of date. I spent some time trying to get the best information on the distribution of poverty.

There had been a series of small-scale surveys and certain interesting pieces of data came out of those surveys. First, the people who prepared them were not exactly willing to sign an affidavit on them! They were simply indicative; a fair approximation. The short answer is that we simply do not know the size of the problem.

Back in 1982, based on the work of Podder in the Henderson inquiry, I published a neat little pyramid `Distribution of Wealth and Income in Australia 1966-68', which compared the figures for disposable income after tax and net worth assets. That indicated that the lower 50 per cent of the population in Australia, the 50 per cent of people at the bottom of the pyramid, had 15.45 per cent of the net worth assets; the top 5 per cent had just on 25 per cent; the next 5 per cent had 12 per cent; and in the middle, 40 per cent of the population had 48 per cent of the net worth.
When I tried to get updated material to represent the situation of the 1980s, it was very much vaguer. I quote from Sleepers, Wake!:
Recent analyses by the Australian Bureau of Statistics and Dr Peter Saunders of the University of New South Wales suggest that inequality of income has increased slightly since 1978-79.
This needs to be underlined:
(Data on wealth has not been collected since the Henderson inquiry).

Then there is a table which I have not cleared with the Opposition. It might be useful if the table could be incorporated; otherwise I would simply read out figures. I seek leave of the House for that table on page 124 to be incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The passage continues:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1981-82 Australia's income distribution was less egalitarian than Britain, Canada, New Zealand and Sweden (the most equal of all), more so than the United States or Germany. Without a wealth inquiry, estimates of poverty rely on sampling. The National Institute of Economic and Industry Research (NIEIR) estimated that income units (especially the single unemployed) below the poverty line in Australia increased from 11.5 per cent in 1981-82 to 12.4 per cent in 1985-86.

There is a tremendous amount of information that we need. More recently, Andrew Dilnot of the University of Melbourne was able to conclude that in the mid-1980s the wealthiest one per cent of Australians held 20 per cent of total wealth, the top 5 per cent four, and the top 10 per cent 55 per cent. At the other extreme, at least 30 per cent had no wealth. They owed more than they possessed in assets, usually their homes, and the bottom 50 per cent possessed only 1.5 per cent of private wealth. Dilnot pointed out that it was inheritance, wealth creating wealth, and the tax system-rather than physical exertion or intellect-which determined a person's wealth. As pointed out eloquently by the honourable member for Denison, who introduced the motion, Dilnot concluded:
Closer examination of the composition of wealth uncovers a pattern of asset holding which is consistent with the highly distorting taxation of personal savings.
Concern with the distribution of wealth has a number of dimensions.

Firstly, extreme wealth concentration can be associated with the development of a super wealthy power group whose collective actions may be inimical to the efficient operation of the market system. When ownership of strategic resources lies in a few hands, there is a danger that governments can be forced into action which confers further benefits on the wealthy to the cost of the community at large.

Secondly, great wealth is sometimes seen as conferring prestige and flexibility on its owners, in ways which are distinct from the benefits of the implied income flow. Thirdly, wealth is sometimes seen as relevant to policy proposals of other kinds and wealth statistics are seen as important in assessing the impact of such policy reforms.

I want to put these concerns, particularly the last, into perspective by concentrating on the current privatisation debate, not otherwise before the House; it may be the only time that we discuss it in this chamber. Andrew Dilnot's analysis of personal wealth in Australia subdivided that wealth held by percentile groups into housing or property, equities or shares, and interest on earnings and in superannuation.

The first form of wealth accretion held by an individual is interest bearing deposits which appear to plateau at about $4,000 for the bottom 20 per cent. Any subsequent accumulation comes in the form of housing. It is not until the top 5 per cent of the distribution is reached that a fairly dramatic shift into equities or shares begins. For the top percentile, 61 per cent of wealth is held in the form of equities. Shares are the least spread of all wealth forms studied.

It is important to remind people that this dissection of wealth is not the total wealth of Australia but is an examination of private wealth. To this must be added the wealth of the public sector which, it goes without saying, is owned collectively so far by all Australians. We each have an equal stake in such enterprises as Australian Airlines Ltd, Qantas Airways Ltd, Telecom Australia, Aussat Pty Ltd and the Commonwealth Bank.

Our share in public assets counteracts to a certain degree the inequality in the distribution of private wealth. Privatisation is a shift in ownership away from the perfectly egalitarian distribution of public assets to what has, in other cases, proved to be the greatly distorted and unequal distribution of private assets. If privatisation goes ahead without concern for who gains the shares in our government business enterprises (GBEs) over a short time, it can be predicted with a fair degree of confidence that they will end up in the hands of comparatively few people.

This underlines the social concerns that I mentioned earlier associated with concentrated ownership of certain types of wealth. These problems can be overcome. If the Government proceeds with privatisation it is imperative that shares in GBEs are spread as widely as possible and that the spread is permanent. I know, for example, that the Treasurer (Mr Keating), is undertaking some research following the last Caucus meeting on this subject about the potential role of the various trade union superannuation funds in having a share of the action. Employees, by the investment they put into the superannuation funds, can have a share of the action which by its very nature will be dispersed.

The Dilnot data indicates that the increasingly uniform spread of superannuation among workers provides an avenue for distribution of shares. The percentage of heads of income units in each wealth category who are members of super schemes ranges from 19 per cent in the lowest three deciles to a maximum of 48 per cent in any other decile or percentile group, including the top percentiles. If shares were confined to superannuation funds, the spread of wealth would be greatly maximised among participants.

Furthermore, the funds were more interested in maximising the return to their members as required under their trust deeds than in forcing governments to confer benefits upon a few shareholders, thus overcoming one of the major concerns mentioned earlier. The implementation of employee participation schemes, with workers in GBEs owning shares while they remain employed in a privatised or semi-privatised GBE, will further correct the distortion of wealth distribution in the form of equities as the bulk of employees will be in the lower deciles of wealth ownership.

Privatisation is a vexed question for those who consider economics as a tool to achieve desirable social ends. For many, privatisation takes public wealth away from the poorest in our society and redistributes that wealth to the richest. I have urged the Government that, should privatisation go ahead as expected, shares should be limited to employees of GBEs and to superannuation funds to maximise the distribution effects of this wealth transfer.

The consequence of privatisation is only one example of how necessary it is to collect and publish national information on wealth distribution in Australia so that measures and policies can be developed to reduce the inequality of wealth distribution and increase the equality of life's chances for all Australians, especially our youth.

We are still blundering around in the dark if we do not understand precisely what we are talking about. For an informed debate about the future of the economy of this country we need that statistical base. I regard the failure to collate that information as a major failure. Many honourable members will remember the former member for Hawker, Mr Ralph Jacobi, who was consistent in his advocacy that we have a proper wealth inquiry.

We need the data. Unfortunately that data is not readily available. The result is that we have to rely on surveys which have all the methodological deficiencies that are sometimes associated with surveys no matter how skilfully they are carried out. I hope that the House will give bipartisan support to this suggestion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Broadbent Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me no pleasure whatsoever to follow the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones). What was a laudable and simple motion a few minutes ago has now become one of the most complicated exercises I have ever faced. It was interesting to hear the honourable member for Lalor speak. A great deal of information pours out of this honourable member when he addresses this House.

SPEECH.PARA: What was not mentioned, of course, was the political will that needs to be placed behind this motion to have it carried through. It could be seen as perhaps a veiled attack on the government of the day. We have to look at the reality. We have to come into this House and talk about the realities. The realities are that in 1983, when the honourable member for Lalor was certainly in this House, this Government, under our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), invited Professor Peter Karmel, Vice-Chancellor of the Australian National University, to prepare a proposal for a similar inquiry. In 12 months Karmel's plan for a five-year study had been dropped. The cost of that study would have been $8m. It was shelved. By 1985 that was all gone.

By 1986, under the direction of the ministerial subcommittee comprising the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the now Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) and Senator Peter Walsh, an inter-departmental committee was set up but by mid-1987 the ministerial committee had failed to meet. The reality of what is happening in Australia today is embarrassing for those who sit on the other side of the House, having regard to the history of their Party and their leadership in regard to this type of inquiry.

I also learned from the honourable member for Lalor today that a GBE is a government business enterprise. I assumed that a GBE was a great big ego! It is not; it is a government business enterprise and I like the way that it has been used.

The honourable member for Lalor mentioned that information that we need is out of date. I am afraid that this debate is seven years out of date. This should have been promised seven years ago. A former member of this House, Mr Jacobi, was mentioned. We should have been having this debate seven years ago. The information this nation needs should be presented to the next government so that we can get out of the difficulties that we face today. I refer the members of this House to the Australian Labor Party platform of 1984 where it was said:

Deficiencies in the availability of information essential for responsible decision making will be corrected and the Australian Bureau of Statistics will be strengthened to ensure that all relevant statistical information for planning is collected and published promptly.

This has been set down in the Australian Labor Party's policy statements. It has not been followed through by this Government. The word for today perhaps is `transient'. That word was used extensively yesterday, and perhaps this whole debate and argument have been transient now for seven years. The debate has continued to move but it has not arrived anywhere. It is interesting that an honourable member is now prepared to bring the debate to this House and put it before the Australian people.

There should be some condemnation of what has really happened over that seven years and we should address ourselves to this very carefully. I agree that there are people who have grown very wealthy in the last seven years and there are people who have become very poor, especially in my electorate of Corinella. We spoke of reports from many bodies which are interested in the health and welfare of people in the lower income bracket, and a few have been referred to today. My area is facing that exact situation. What have we failed to do? In the last seven years we have torn middle Australia to pieces. That is why there is now a greater difference between the rich and poor: the middle man has been cut out. A good example of that is that there is nowhere else to go to to buy concrete or pipes in Australia today. This Government has created monopolies. The little guy has gone. The contractors have gone.

Even today's papers talk about what is happening in Victoria, especially with regard to retail sales. Boy, are they transient at the moment. They are moving downwards. Our long-term outlook is pretty tragic for this nation at this time because we have lost those middle people. Therefore, they are not out there supporting around them that social base and that social fabric that were there before.

Another example is the young entrepreneurs who at the moment have their trucks parked around this building. Honourable members should ask them about the distribution of wealth in Australia and how we should go about it. Perhaps they might give us a more commonsense approach to what we are doing, might make the argument more simple. I understand that the Government wants information with which to make quality decisions. That is terribly important. But are there not simple ways of going about that, especially in regard to how we are taxing our community in such a big way?

DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSED JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON CERTAIN ASPECTS OF THE OPERATION AND INTERPRETATION OF THE FAMILY LAW ACT 1975

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a Joint Select Committee, to be known as the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act 1975, be appointed to inquire into and report upon the following matters: the practice and application of the following aspects of the Family Law Act 1975:
(a) whether Parts II and III of the Act have been found to provide adequately for effective counselling and independent mediation;

(b) whether Part VII of the Act has been found to provide for fair and equitable resolution of custody and access matters and, in particular, whether the interests of children are being effectively safeguarded;
(c) whether Part VIII of the Act has been found to be effective in arriving at fair and equitable maintenance property settlements;

(d) whether the enforcement provisions of Part XIII of the Act have proven in practice to be effective and how the operation of this Part has been affected by the introduction of the Child Support Agency scheme; and
(e) whether, in the above mentioned Parts of the Act, excessive discretion has been conferred upon the Family Court and, if so, how that discretion may be better defined.
(2) That the committee confine its inquiry and report to the terms of the Family Law Act 1975 and associated relevant policy matters.
(3) That provisions relating to the powers, procedure and composition of the committee be contained in a subsequent resolution.
(4) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting that it concur and take action accordingly.

The genesis of this matter is a private member's motion moved in another place, that is, the Senate, by our colleague on this side of the House, Senator David Brownhill. The shadow Cabinet and the coalition party room believe that Senator Brownhill's motion would be strengthened were there to be a joint parliamentary inquiry of both the Senate and the House of Representatives rather than simply a Senate committee inquiry. That is not denigrating the role of Senate committees by any means but it is just felt that the ambit of this very important area would be better reflected, bearing in mind the number of representations that members of parliament get on family law matters, if the House were to be involved as well as the Senate. It therefore falls to me as shadow Attorney-General to move this motion today.

I should also add by way of preface that such a decision by the coalition in no way detracts from the general principle that we on this side of the House adopt towards family law and matrimonial causes matters where we generally, other than on procedural and technical amendments, on fundamental matters relating to family law and matrimonial causes, allow a conscience vote to our party members. On this the party room spoke and said that if there is a proposal for an inquiry, why not propose in the House at the same time as the Senate that such an inquiry be a joint one. It is believed that the family law system in Australia today is in need of a systematic and comprehensive review.

Honourable members and senators are, as I have just indicated, frequently confronted with grievances, or alleged grievances, from persons who have had some sort of experience with the family law system. In 1975 when the Family Law Act was passed by this Parliament that legislation was believed to be a watershed in the reform of the law relating to the dissolution of marriages. In my own case I believe that it did make some considerable advances. Having been a practitioner in this arena, in that frightful area of having to establish fault, et cetera, I know a whole host of matters were unquestionably improved by the Family Law Act. The reality is that there have been many alleged injustices proffered since that Act came forward. As I will touch on very briefly in a moment, the number of divorces has become a matter of community concern.

I was in the old place when that legislation was debated. The former Labor Prime Minister, the Hon. Gough Whit- lam, spoke then, among other things, of the aim of the Family Court. He did so in the following terms:

Here will be a Court, the expressly stated purpose of which is to provide help, encouragement and counselling to parties with marital problems and to have regard to their human problems, not just their legal rights.

Now some 15 years later the Family Law Act and the family law system generally are believed by many to be in need of a comprehensive review. The issues were succinctly put by the authors of a leading text, H.A. Finlay and R.J. Bailey-Harris, entitled Family Law in Australia, in the following terms:

. . . what we are now seeing is the abandonment of these lofty aspirations and hopes before they have been given a proper chance . . . we suggest the legal and political establishment neither fully understood or desired an integrated Government organ intended to function on a cooperative, inter-disciplinary basis.

Again, as with so many areas, I do not necessarily endorse every element of that quotation, but it is symptomatic of many of the concerns that are expressed in this very delicate and extremely personal and human arena. If there are problems it is believed that it is now time for the legislature to examine the form of legislation that is down. That is why the Opposition is supporting Senator Brownhill's belief that it is time that we as law-makers took up the challenge, examined the family law system and ascertained not just whether those lofty aspirations that I have referred to have been achieved but whether in an area of very great sensitivity to so many people we can improve the system for them.

Figures released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for 1989 indicate that nearly one in every three marriages results in divorce. A recent report by the Australian Institute of Family Studies indicates that the financial costs associated with marital breakdown total some $2 billion per annum. The cost of litigation is a subject for another day-just how many average Australians are unable to even contemplate litigation to rectify some manifest injustice that may be dumped upon them and, in addition, the cost to taxpayers of the legal system itself.

In the narrow confines of family law both the cost to taxpayers of the maintenance of the family law system and the cost to individuals in seeking redress, assistance or counselling or the dissolution of a marriage are very great indeed. It does, of course, have to be recognised that regardless of whatever family law system we may have the social phenomena of divorce may continue unless we have an adequate multi-disciplinary approach to the problem. The desirability of such an approach is, in the view of those on this side of the House-I do not intend to inject any politics into this sort of matter and debase it-is nevertheless reflected in the coalition's law and justice policy which encourages the use of counselling services before a marriage breakdown and the use of mediation services during the process of breakdown.

The proposal for such an inquiry, as first proffered by Senator Brownhill-and this motion endorses and broadens it-would ensure that the family law system would be examined in a broad manner and not simply from a narrow legal perspective. An illustration, though, of the difficulties we face in this area can be found in the recently introduced Family Law Amendment Bill 1990. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) will be familiar with the submissions that are coming in regarding this Bill which show that, notwithstanding the good intentions behind it, legislating in this area is fraught with difficulties.

There have been a number of ad hoc inquiries in the area, including, firstly, a recent report by a Family Court steering committee on the use of mediation procedures in the court; secondly, a report by the Australian Institute of Family Studies on the effectiveness of marriage counselling services; and, thirdly, reports by the Australian Law Reform Commission on matrimonial property and by the Family Law Council on access. What we are saying is that these inquiries and the reports that have resulted from them can be taken as perhaps a starting point for a more thorough, broader examination of the efficacy of the Family Law Act.

On 31 May this year, in the West Australian newspaper, the Attorney-General is reported to have indicated that it is the Government's view that such a parliamentary review would be unnecessary in the light of the various reviews, some of which I have mentioned today. We do not agree and we sincerely hope that, when this matter is adjourned today, the Government will see the wisdom of the move and will support us. It should know that there is a need for such a comprehensive review so that views may be put forward on how the family law system can be made more accessible, more cost effective and more relevant to the community, so that from such an inquiry an improved system may be proposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion moved today by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), as he quite correctly pointed out, had its genesis in the Senate by way of a proposal put forward by Senator Brownhill. Two issues are raised by it: firstly, whether an inquiry into the Family Law Act is required, having regard to the various matters specified in the motion; and, secondly, if so, what is the most appropriate mechanism that this particular inquiry should proceed with.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to address both of those issues. I think it is important to be able to place this matter in context. Nineteen-ninety is the fifteenth anniversary of the passage of the Family Law Act. It was a hugely significant piece of social reform in this country. It is a tribute to the then Attorney-General, the late Lionel Murphy, that he pioneered this legislation and gained approval for it by both Houses of Parliament. At that time it was quite an achievement, given that the period 1972-75 was not the easiest period in which a government had to operate.

The introduction of the Family Law Act followed a number of Senate inquiries. One was by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, as it was then called, in 1971. A Law Council of Australia report came up with the first draft of the Act in 1972, and there was another Senate committee inquiry in 1974. That particular inquiry, which relied extensively on a paper prepared by Watson QC, was the basis of our current Family Law Act.

In the intervening period since the Act was passed in 1975 it has hardly been static. The Act has evolved and there have been numerous reviews into various aspects of its operation. This Parliament has passed very substantial amendments to it. Certainly, even in my brief time here, we have seen the introduction of very major measures, such as the Child Support Agency, which completely rewrites and redirects the question of child maintenance. We have also seen the emergence of many pressing issues.

It is interesting to note, as the honourable member for Kooyong mentioned, that we as members of parliament now receive most of our complaints not so much in the area of divorce itself, that is, principal relief under the Act, but in the area of what was described under the Matrimonial Causes Act and is still so described under our current law as ancillary relief-matters concerned with children and property.

In the debate which occurred when the Act was first passed-the honourable member mentioned the contribution of the then Prime Minister; and I have also looked at the contribution of other members, including the Attorney-General at that time-there was a great deal of focus on this question of principal relief. That is the area on which the debate focused in 1975. That is where a great amount of the discussion on the social implications of this legislation was focused. The question of ancillary relief was still very much, as the term implies, off to the side.

The Act, I think it would be fair to say, despite the criticisms we may well have of it, certainly markedly improved the question of principal relief. Certainly, as the shadow Attorney pointed out, the grounds which one had to establish under the old Matrimonial Causes Act really did nothing in terms of the dignity of parties and the ability of people to live through what is without doubt the most traumatic part of a person's life-the breakdown of the major relationship, the marriage, in which they were involved. Certainly, the Act has been successful in that regard.

Perhaps the focus at that time on principal relief has led to problems. If one reads the speeches at that time one sees that it was assumed that the processes of counselling and conciliation which would be set up in this court would be nothing like what was available in other courts. The whole process of the court was designed so that it would not be a case of two parties slugging it out in the normal conflict situation in which our courts operate; rather, it would provide a process to bring people together and talk them through the issues. It was thought that those processes would prove to be the way to overcome disputes concerning custody of and access to children and the division of property.

Unfortunately, that was probably pie in the sky stuff at the time. Even though there were the best intentions in the world, it has not proved to be successful. Certainly, as someone who practiced quite extensively in family law prior to my election to this place, I know that the real emotion and hurt often surfaced in conflicts over children and the division of property.

My opinion is that the basic provisions as they are set down in the law are probably adequate, but the court itself has laboured under great difficulty. For instance, it was often said at the time that the Act was passed that one of the benefits would be to remove ancillary relief from the hands of magistrates courts, which did not have provision for counselling and where one would be rubbing shoulders with the drink driver and the petty criminal. That was a particularly degrading experience to go through. It was said that the transfer of ancillary relief cases from the magistrates court to the Family Court would be a major achievement. Ironically, at no stage have the magistrates courts in this country played a very major role in the jurisdiction of this particular Act.

Indeed, it is ironic that in Senator Murphy's speech at the time he made mention of the fact that legal aid would be available to all in need to make sure that they had access to the Family Court. Legal aid guidelines almost inevitably force people to go to the magistrates court because of the cost implications-the exact reverse of what was intended at that time.

There are problems which have not been dealt with. Magistrates still have to deal with a lot of maintenance applications. There are fewer maintenance applications now than in the past, but a certain amount of that work will continue for some time. Certainly magistrates will be required to deal with interim custody applications and uncontested custody applications. Recently the jurisdiction of magistrates in terms of property has been increased, I think from $5,000 to $20,000. So, they are dealing with even larger numbers of smaller property settlements. Again, this is to do with time and cost. Over the years the Family Court has had its problems with resources.

The way in which the court has responded to the major question of property settlement has been through the development of the Order 24 conference, or its forerunner, the Regulation 96 conference. This process has been successful in resolving property disputes. I think the figures are that some--

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The time allocated for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Flags Amendment Bill 1990 is to amend the Flags Act 1953 in simple terms to ensure that no attempt to change the Australian flag can be made without reference to the people of Australia. In other words, there should be a referendum of all Australians before any attempt is made to change our flag. Many people throughout Australia are very proud of our flag. People have been prepared to give their lives for it. It is recognised throughout the nation that Australians can look with pride at their flag as a symbol of national unity.

I present this Bill on behalf of the Opposition yet again in an attempt to ensure that the minority who from time to time have tried to change this great flag of ours do not have that opportunity without first getting majority support of the Australian people. I might add that I think they would find it extraordinarily difficult to get that support. The Bill reflects the strong and unequivocal support the Liberal and National parties have for our flag. This support, of course, reflects view of the majority.

I challenge the Government to accept this Bill, to accept that any suggestion to change the flag should be subject to a referendum. I challenge the Government to show that it is, in fact, genuine when it claims to support the Australian flag. Obviously, in supporting our flag not only am I conscious of the very strong support that the majority of Australians have shown for this flag since 1901 but also I am very conscious of the fact that the ill-fated Ausflag 88 campaign, which was started in 1985, was a dismal failure.

At the time when the Australian flag was created, which was, of course, just after Australia became a Commonwealth, it was inaugurated under the slogan `One People: One Destiny: One Flag'. I suggest to all honourable members that that slogan is as true today as it was back in 1901.

It is worth recalling that whilst the present Government claims to have a certain amount of support for the Australian flag, that has not always been the case. In fact, for some years the Australian Labor Party had as part of its platform a resolution to change our national flag, although, interestingly, in 1988 the Party platform deleted this particular point.

The purpose of the Bill is to remove any shadow of doubt about the Government's sincerity. I believe that if the Government refuses to support this legislation, the people of Australia, and indeed all honourable members, will continue to have reason to doubt the Government's sincerity in its supposed new-found support for the flag. I remind honourable members on the other side of the House that the Opposition has attempted to introduce this legislation previously. In fact, since 1985 this legislation has been rejected by the Government on three occasions.

The Opposition doubts the Government's support for the present Australian flag. In 1981 in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans was recorded in Hansard as making some very disparaging remarks about the Australian flag. I think those comments are worth repeating today so that they are not forgotten. Senator Evans said:

We can do better than the present undistinguished and undistinctive bit of cloth which we have inherited from our colonial past and which manifestly does not set anybody's pulse racing in the community at large except, perhaps the occasional Returned Services League blimp or a proportion of the Tory backbench opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an unpatriotic thing to say.
—It is more than unpatriotic. I think it is downright insulting. Honourable members should not be allowed to forget the words of someone who is now a senior Cabinet Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the years there have been some suggestions as to why we might change our flag. I think most of those suggestions are sheer nonsense. It has been suggested that some people may find it difficult to distinguish the Australian flag from others. That suggestion is sheer and utter nonsense. It has been suggested that others may have difficulty recognising our flag. I think that point can be responded to quite simply. If I were to ask people `What does the national flag of Spain or Thailand or Chile or of a number of other countries all around the world look like?', I am sure I would find that Australians would have just as much difficulty in distinguishing other national flags as foreigners would have in recognising our flag.

It is worth recalling some very worthwhile quotations about the importance of why we should look upon our Australian flag as not only a symbol of national unity but also as something that reminds us of some of the great strengths of our democratic country. Our flag symbolises our Australian heritage. It represents the democratic processes we have inherited from the founding fathers of this great nation.

While some may say that it is important that we recognise that our role should be focused more and more on Asia-and I certainly agree with that view-I still believe we should remind ourselves and future generations that Asia did not give Australia the concept of limited constitutional government. Asia did not give us the priceless heritage of English common law, or of trial by jury, or, most importantly, the Christian concepts of behaviour. Those who talk about removing the Union Jack from the Australian flag should be reminded that the Union Jack is a symbol of Australia's British heritage.
I remind honourable members of what the famous Roman statesman, Cicero, had to say:
Not to know what happened before you were born is always to be a child.
I think that sentiment reflects very much the importance of the Australian flag in reminding us what happened before we were born.
As the great English statesman Edmund Burke warned:
People will not look forward to posterity, who never look back to their ancestors.

There are many in the community nowadays who seem to think that we should be trying to obliterate our past. I say to all honourable members: I am very proud of our past traditions. I am very proud of the fact that we have so many traditions that we have inherited from the United Kingdom. In particular, I cite limited constitutional government, English common law, trial by jury and, of course, the Christian concepts of behaviour. For all those reasons, I think that we have a--

TALK.START.PARA: —Proud of that, are you?
-The honourable member for the Northern Territory should restrain himself. I invite the honourable member for Wannon to ignore the interjections.
—The $6m man is trying to speak up.
—I ask the honourable member for Wannon to continue his speech and let us keep going in the silence we have had so far.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for that. I conclude by saying that I am very proud of our flag and I believe that the vast majority of Australians are very proud of our flag. In fact, opinions polls have shown again and again and again that the great majority of Australians want to keep the fine flag we have now. I would therefore urge all honourable members to support this amendment to the Flags Act 1953, to support the maintenance of our great Australian flag, and to ensure that no changes can ever be contemplated without referring the matter to the majority of the people of Australia.
—Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the very outset let me say in this House that I have never listened to 10 minutes of such hypocrisy in all my life. The honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) in introducing the Flags Amendment Bill stated that the object, to use his words, `is to ensure that there is no change to our existing Australian national flag without a referendum'. At the outset, let me reject the underlying presumption of this Bill, that is, that the Government intends to change our flag by stealth.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would be very well aware, this is not the first occasion upon which the Opposition has taken up the valuable time of this House with these conspiracy theories. Last year the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife) introduced the Flag Amendment Bill of 1989. A very similar Bill was brought before the House as well as the Senate in 1988. When the Bill was introduced in 1988 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) indicated that he had no intention of trying to change the Australian flag. Yet still the Opposition persisted. The honourable member for Hume in his speech in 1989, when he introduced his Bill, appeared to hold the gravest fears that at any moment the Governor-General, using powers available under the Flags Act of 1953, would appoint another flag to replace the Australian national flag.

Our Governor-General, Bill Hayden, made it perfectly clear in an interview just before his swearing-in in February 1989 that he was in favour of retaining the Australian flag. Of course, the honourable member for Wannon did not want to bring that quotation into the House during his speech, but I will give it. The Governor-General said:
The present flag represents the struggle, achievement and aspirations of the people.
Further, let me make this point clear: the Australian Labor Party does not have a policy of wanting to change the flag.

I find the underlying presumption of the Bill before the House an affront to me personally. I have always supported the current flag and I, as a member of this House, have made every effort to ensure that the flag and the information about it are available to schools, the community and service organisations within my electorate. Whenever it is possible, I arrange to present the flag personally. When I visit schools I talk to the students about the history and the significance of our flag. I explain to them that the flag is used as a symbol of national authority. In fact-and the honourable member for Wannon should check his facts-the first time a flag was used in this way on Australian soil was when Cook, and I quote from his journal, `hoisted English colours and in the name of His Majesty King George III, took possession of the whole eastern coast from the above latitude down to this place by the name of New South Wales'.

The English colours to which Cook referred was the Union flag and not the Union Jack as we know it today. The Union flag consisted only of the St George Cross and the St Andrew's Cross. The cross of St Patrick was not added until 5 November 1800, when the King in Council approved the report of a committee of the Privy Council that the Union flag should be altered.

The new Union Jack flew in Australia for the whole of the nineteenth century. It was carried by the explorers who unlocked the continent, the mariners who circumnavigated our great south land, and the founding fathers who established the new colonies. From the 1850s a growing Australian nationalism brought forth many unofficial flags, but all of them incorporating the constellation of the Southern Cross, which was universally accepted as the emblem of the great south land. I refer to the flags of the Australian Anti-Transportation League, the goldminers' rebellion at Eureka, the racial riots at Lambing Flat goldfields, and the Federation League.

With the federation of the six colonies to form a single Commonwealth on 1 January 1901, there was an urgent demand for a new flag for our new nation. Shortly before the opening of the first Parliament it was decided to hold a world-wide competition to obtain designs for two Australian flags: one for official and naval purposes and the other for the merchant navy service. Over 30,000 designs were submitted from all over the world. The judges finally decided to divide the prize money of pounds equally between five entrants because their designs were identical. They were Ivor Evans, a 14-year-old school boy of Melbourne; Anne Darrington from Perth; L.J. Hawkins from Leichhardt in New South Wales; E. Nuttall from Victoria; and N. Stevens from Auckland.

In February 1903-this is another fact that the honourable member for Wannon refused to bring forward-it was announced in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette that King Edward VII had approved a design for the flag of Australia. Of course, the flag was not exactly as we now know it. The star under the Union Jack then had only six points, representing the then six States of the Commonwealth. In 1908 the Government decided there should be a seven-point star under the Union Jack. The extra point represented the Territories. The four main stars of the Southern Cross were also made seven-pointed.

The flag has been a symbol of nationhood in war and in peace. It has become intrinsically linked to our successes. It was flown over the site of the new national capital in 1908; on the first ships of the Australian Navy in 1910; and over Australia's base on the Antarctic continent. Since 1908 it has been raised for medal winners at every Olympic Games, and in 1956 it flew with pride of place as the flag of the host nation at the Melbourne Olympics. The flag was carried into New Guinea at the outbreak of World War I, by the Anzacs who landed at Gallipoli, and by the diggers who fought on the battlefields of France.

Our forces again fought under it in World War II. When Singapore was retaken in 1945, the first flag to fly was an Australian ensign. That particular flag had become a source of hope, an inspiration for the prisoners of Changi, the prisoner-of-war camp. It was made secretly by an Australian prisoner, Captain Robert Strawbridge, who at the risk of immediate execution hid that flag in the lining of a calico bag for years. It became very precious to him and the other prisoners during their time in that camp. I am very pleased to see that that flag was finally returned to Australian soil in April of this year.

It should not be forgotten that for many years the flag was regarded as an official flag and its use on land was restricted to government establishments. It was that great Australian Labor Prime Minister, Ben Chifley, who in February 1947 actively encouraged the lifting of restrictions on the flying of the flag and the greater use of the flag on public buildings by schools and private citizens. Also important to note is that it was not until 1951 that King George VI approved a recommendation by the Government that the Commonwealth blue ensign be adopted as our Australian flag. The Flags Act 1953 finally established the Australian national flag and prescribed the Australian red ensign for merchant ships within Australia.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I sincerely hope that this puts to rest Opposition allegations that the Government intends to change the flag by stealth and its imputation that only the Opposition is the protector of the flag. Let us hope that its cheap political point scoring is over and that this Parliament's time can be spent on more pressing and critical issues in the future.
