SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) recognises the importance of forest industries to Australia's social and economic future;
(2) requests the Government to facilitate industries that will add value to our wood resource; and
(3) strongly opposes minority groups who undermine balanced development projects.

It is very relevant that the Parliament is considering a motion along these lines today, having regard to the considerations being given by the Cabinet to the forest industries and the fact that so many families are around Parliament House with their trucks showing a concern about not only their futures as regards job opportunities and their livelihood but also the future prosperity of this country. We are dependent upon truck owners, loggers and the people involved in the forest industries to ensure that we do have products which we can export to the world markets.

Yesterday we had a debate between the Opposition and the Government on a matter of public importance which centred around the economy and the environment in this country coming together in a balanced way which will lead to a sustainable development policy. That is where we should be at as a country in this debate. But, unfortunately, we still have a large number of people out there, to whom I would refer as the radical green element, who continue to have myths put around with regard to the forest industries.

First of all, we need to understand the extent and importance of the forest industries to Australia. I inform the House of a few figures in connection with that. In 1988-89, our exports in forest industries were worth $500m, but our imports of forest or wood products were worth $2.1 billion-in other words, 10 per cent of our trading debt each year. But the interesting thing is that, of our exports, 74 per cent of that $500m is in woodchips.

We have been saying repeatedly in this Parliament that we have to have added value in our manufacturing industries so that this country can trade its way out of the debt crisis with which it is faced. Yet we have a situation now, as we see with the loggers outside Parliament House, where a decision has not been made by the Federal Government. It is interesting to note that, as a country, we have got ourselves into a position where I understand that on Friday the Federal Cabinet will actually consider which 40 hectare coupes can be logged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sawdust for brains; it's ridiculous!

—It is a ridiculous situation, as the honourable member for Berowra says, that the Federal Cabinet should have got to that point of discussion. There are other more major issues with which it should be concerning itself, such as the debate about whether land use matters should remain with State governments and so on. There has been procrastination, delay and many inquiries. There have been inquiries to end inquiries. Speaking from my experience, in Tasmania there have been 11 inquiries in 13 years into forest industries, all with the intention of putting an end to inquiries and confrontation between radical greens and the productive side of the community. The following remarks relate to where the forest industries stand at the moment. More than $100m worth of woodchips are burnt each year because the State Government will not make a decision on whether it should proceed with the establishment of a pulp and paper mill. There is no way Australia can become a clever country if it continues down this track.
—What does that do to the greenhouse effect?

—I will respond to the interjection by the honourable member for Wakefield in a moment. As a nation Australia must recognise the importance of environmental qualities. Nobody will deny that. However, at the same time we must marry the economic imperatives of manufacturing in this country. The forest industry is one of the industries in which that can be done successfully, and it should be possible to do it quickly. There has been enough debate on this issue. If Australia exports its wood products as woodchips, as is being done at present, it is losing a tremendous amount. Bleached pulp can be sold for export for $495 a tonne compared with $78 a tonne for exported woodchips. For fine paper exports as much as $995 a tonne can be obtained. At present Australia exports woodchips to Japan and buys back fine paper from that country. Is it any wonder that this country's trade balance is as bad as it is, if that is the way we run our affairs? It is all very well for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to say we need to become a clever country, but what Australia really needs is clever leadership. We need decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: What else does the forest industry do? It provides 106,000 jobs throughout Australia and supports many families. As the honourable member for Wakefield asked by way of interjection, what will the industry do for the greenhouse effect? It is important to note that the forest industry is planting l50 million trees a year and cutting down only 20 million a year. That practice has had an advantage, in that companies and private enterprise in Australia have responded to the call and have been planting trees. That will be great for the future of Australia. The forest industry should be given every encouragement to continue its tree planting program. That will reduce the greenhouse effect. An enormous amount of carbon dioxide is converted to oxygen by young vigorous forests. Once trees get beyond 60 or 100 years of age they become static and use the same amount of oxygen as the quantity of carbon dioxide they take from the atmosphere. It is a static equation. Therefore it is important to have young vigorous forests, so this House should give every support possible to the forest industries.

The next item I draw to the attention of the House in this debate relates to some of the myths of the radical greens about forest industries. One myth is that the forest industry people, the loggers and pulp mill operators and others, plan for unrestricted development. That was said by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly). Those in the forest industry do not plan for unrestricted development. A large amount of this nation's forests is now protected, as it should be. That myth is therefore untrue. It is, as I said, a total myth. As I said, Australia is planting seven times more trees than are being harvested.

The second myth that has been used in the debate, especially regarding the south-east forests, is that they are old growth, pristine, ancient forests which have special spiritual qualities. That has never been the case with forests. Forests change continually; they are never a static phenomenon. There is always serial change. As fires go through different parts of forests in Australia and in other countries, then other trees grow and the forests develop.

The third myth is that logging will reduce genetic reserves and diversity and will cause a loss of species. If we manage our forests carefully that can be avoided. I want to put on the record that there is probably more genetic diversity in a handful of soil-because of the number of viruses, bacteria and individual species contained in it-than in all of the four-legged species in Australia. So it is nonsense to say that we are going to reduce the amount of genetic diversity by having managed and careful logging in this country. It is not true.

The fourth myth concerns the claim that organochlorides and many of the chemicals which come from our pulp mills are man-made only. Two recent surveys have come out of Sweden which indicate that organochlorides occur naturally in large quantities and flow down the rivers of Sweden, in particular. It has been identified that, even in Sweden, there are 300,000 tonnes of naturally occurring organochlorides-those chemicals which the radical greens have said are very detrimental. Some of them may be, but let us look at this issue scientifically and let us adopt a balanced point of view on these types of issues.

At this stage, it is very important that urgent decisions are made concerning the forest industries so that we can adopt a sustainable development approach which marries the interests of our community, including those of the loggers and their families, with our environmental concerns. That is absolutely vital. We can no longer object to progress and development in this industry which is sensitive, scientifically able and accurate, if we are going to overcome many of our difficulties. I urge the House to support this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles). The motion, in seeking balance, rests on the acceptance of some truths which preservationist, fundamentalist propagandists have been conveniently ignoring. The first truth is that disturbance is important in maintaining diversity of habitat in the forest; preservation is often unnatural in the forest. The second truth is that the negative growth which would result from the application of principles espoused by preservationist, fundamentalist propagandists would be a big financial blow to most people, not only in country areas, but also in the cities. The third is that foresters graduating today are, more than ever, environmentalists and ecologists who want a sustainable industry. The fourth is that National Estate areas are not national parks and can be farmed, logged, built on and fished. No government, including the environmentalist-backed Tasmanian Government, has tried to go back on that, and, in relation to the south-east forests issue, it is important to recognise that there need be no more substantial inquiries before a decision is made. A decision can be made now on an integrated logging program.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, on the point of disturbance, one of the important points made in the report on the study of biological conservation of the south-east forests by the joint scientific committee, set up by this Government in partnership with the New South Wales Government and actually established on the initiative of Senator Peter Cook, was that disturbance is an important factor in maintaining diversity of habitat in the forest. Natural processes in the forest are a result of disturbance which allows the normal processes of regeneration, growth and death to pass through the various successional stages. So disturbance is natural and there has always been some degree of disturbance. There are people who conveniently forget that.

Next, it is important to recognise that current forestry operations in the south-east forests recognise that the structure of the forests will change, but under carefully controlled harvesting procedures conducted over a period of 100 years from the year 1990 to the year 2090-that is, 100 years of planning, happening now by forestry in the south-east forests of New South Wales. Under that arrangement all age classes will be represented, including trees well in excess of the age when a commercial crop is harvested. They will be retained to provide hollow bearing trees for natural habitat.

It is quite clear from the joint scientific study that the committee, which was set up not just of foresters but of people trained in environmental and ecological disciplines, recognised the very important fact that management can and will proceed on a 100-year basis so that the forests will progress gradually to a stage where all age classes of trees will be present up to trees 150 years of age. The old notion of clear-felling, the way it used to be done, has been discarded. It is extremely important that these factors are recognised when we look at the forests issue, especially in the south-east forests of New South Wales.

Looking at this issue from a national viewpoint, the forest products industry has real prospects for $7 billion of investment in export development and import replacement. That is why this Government has established a number of studies, some of them on the recommendation of environmental groups; they have cooperated. They include studies on the recovery of pulpwood following hardwood logging operations in the south-east of New South Wales; the feasibility of establishing a flitch mill in south-eastern New South Wales; the development of a plantation strategy for the south-east forests of New South Wales-I must say that the environmental groups called for this study but did not put in a submission; and value adding manufacture in the sawmilling industry.

The sawmillers are waiting to buy new equipment so that they can make better use of their timber in the south-east forests of New South Wales and in other areas of Australia. They will do that once they know that they have an industry and that they have security in their industry. They are ready to do it and want to do it. They will make much better use of the timber.

There is a potential $7 billion of investment in export development and import replacement. Within 10 years or so this investment alone could turn around the current $1.8 billion trade deficit and turn it into a trade surplus. But none of this investment will take place if the current political instability continues. If it gets worse, city people will be hurt as well as country people. Every person who wants to limit the harvesting of our resources must consider that every tonne of ore unmined or trees unharvested has an effect on the income of every pensioner, every wage earner, every social security beneficiary, every business person, every farmer and every retiree. It affects the ability of people to pay mortgages, so it has to be taken into consideration.

Certainly, some resources have to be protected. Some areas should not be harvested. But the people outside this Parliament have been waiting for 5 1/2 years for decisions. They are people with families to support and who want to have security of income. They have equipment to pay off and to maintain. The communities around them depend on these people having that security. There is insecurity in the local communities as well. So it is extremely important that we resolve very quickly the issues before the Federal and State governments this week.

The pulp and paper industry's current capacity in Australia will decline if it cannot move to world scale mills to supply pulp at competitive prices. I include bleached pulp which, for a wide variety of reasons which I will not go into now, some of which are very good reasons, is still in heavy demand. This will increase the current trade imbalance in forest products, running at 10 per cent of foreign debt last financial year. This industry can turn around our trade deficit if it operates in an environmentally sensitive but economically and socially responsible way.

It is important that we adopt a package that is based on the report of the joint scientific study set up on the initiative of Senator Peter Cook with the cooperation of the New South Wales Government. Now is the time to do it. The study recommendation for a variable minimum area reservation delivers a principled position which we can adopt. It is important that we adopt it because it involves protection of the environment whilst minimising job losses. It is quite clear that logging can proceed in National Estate areas not recommended for reservation by the joint scientific study.

The Government should now honour its previous commitment on wood supply; that is, that timber resource will be guaranteed over the period to July 1993 at a level sufficient to retain the industry at the current level of activity and employment. That is a commitment that we made and that we should now adhere to. The New South Wales Government needs to set up a 15-year licensing system. Senator Richardson recommended to Senator Cook many months ago that we could now proceed to 15-year licences subject to a range of conditions for woodchip export. But we ought at the same time to move towards processing the product in Australia much more than we do now rather than exporting the raw material, as is the case with a wide range of other materials.

In February the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) guaranteed to the New South Wales Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions that there will be sufficient wood resource until such time as a long term industry strategy is developed to protect the environment, secure the resource base for industry access and promote the highest possible value adding of our valuable hardwood resource. It is extremely important that the Prime Minister now adhere to that commitment. This must now be the agenda: today, the four New South Wales and Federal Government Ministers who are having discussions here come to agreement; tomorrow, in-principle endorsement of the joint scientific study; and, by the end of the year, a clear plan from the two Ministers and two governments responsible. Whether it be for the export of woodchips which is the Federal issue or the harvesting of timber which is the New South Wales issue, it is time for them to make a decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I totally support the proposition moved by the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles). I was delighted to hear also what the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) had to say, but I have to say to him that he can wave in the air all of those reports and those studies, but they do not mean a thing unless there is some action and decisions. I must say to the honourable member that, unless his Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) makes the right decision today, all of the pious platitudes that he has been mouthing today will not go down well with the men surrounding this Parliament with the timber jinkers-people who are really concerned about the future of the timber industry. They have every right to be concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not just the people here from the southern areas of New South Wales who are making the point. On the evening of Thursday 23 August in Grafton 3,000 people held a rally because they were fearful of losing their jobs. They are concerned about the future. They are concerned about the future not only of their jobs, but of their families, of Australia and of our forests, because their livelihood depends on the forests.

Quite frankly, it is my opinion that the timber industry is not getting a fair go-not under any circumstances-because we find that, while there are sane, sensible and reasonable environmental people, there are a great many that one can describe only as the fanatical ratbag fringe. They are the ones that get all the media coverage; they are the ones that chain themselves to trucks and do untold damage to the future of our logging industry. What we must have are policies for forestry which are rational, reasonable and balanced. After all, our forests are a renewable resource. They are harvested; they are farmed; this is the way it should be. Nobody would deny that in the last century, in the development of Australia, and even earlier this century, mistakes were made. But we have all learnt, and I do not believe there is any sensible, intelligent Australian left who is not a conservationist; everybody must be for the future of our earth, of course. We have to realise that in New South Wales, for instance, one and a half trees are being planted for every tree that is cut, and we want many more.

We should also realise that the forested areas of Australia are growing every year. This is the reality; yet we hear such incredible statements. I heard a man speaking on radio in northern New South Wales only last week, after the State Government made its sensible, rational decision to support the previous Labor Government's policy on logging the Washpool-a decision which was absolutely right. I must say to the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell), who is to be the next speaker, that he had better stand up and say where he stands on the logging of the Washpool. Now is the time for him to stand up and be counted and to let the people that he represents know where he stands on the saving of jobs, the saving of families and the development of export industries for Australia, because this is vitally important. I shall conclude so that he does have a little time to do that. Even though the honourable member for Eden-Monaro took some of his time from him, I will be generous and give up some of my time so that the honourable member for Richmond can tell his electors where he stands. He should put up or shut up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) for putting this motion before the House and I also sincerely trust that not just the honourable member for Braddon but all of his colleagues in his minority group opposite share his recognition of the forest industries. The forest industries are one of the many industries, organisations and resources that are important to our social and economic future. It is indeed gracious, if not timely, that such a motion has been moved.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Braddon also mentioned in his discussion that the use of the value added products is something which we have to consider greatly because of the economic need of Australia. The use of value added products to enhance our economic well-being is fine. The call to process wood products prior to export so that the clever country can gain is important. What is also important and clever is to ensure that the processing by the clever country is just that-and not, in itself, an environmental disaster.

The Government put in place guidelines for pulp mills yet the industry ran away from these because it felt that our standards would compromise the operations in other parts of the planet. We cannot back down from our standards. Better production and products from, and extension of, plantations have been and are being implemented. It is unfortunate that there has been a long and critical period of exploitation prior to harvesting on a sustainable basis. The honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) has explained the long term nature of planning that is required. In fact, this long term planning that is required is probably unique in this industry.

Overall, the extent of forest industry production and the potential exploitation does come down to finding a balance in the degree between preserved estate and the level of exploitation that can be sustained on adjacent and managed regions. Bearing in mind, firstly, that the level of forest cover of this continent 200 years ago was not high; secondly, the recognised need for biological protection of all forms of life from man's impact; and, thirdly, our very late commitment to developing forest resources on a sustainable basis, then both government and community need to extend every assistance to the forest industries to smooth this difficult transition from what I would term a period of production through head down, butt up persistence to one of sustainable development. This assistance must recognise that, like any other industry that is undergoing micro-economic reform that often accompanies new technologies, the forestry industries must also realise and be exposed to these reforms. In the long term it will lessen the impact of our new technologies and assist the integration and acceptance of new approaches. This renewable resource will continue to be productive and to contribute to the future well-being of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allocated for this debate has expired. It being 12.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 104A. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a former Chairman of the Opposition's sports committee and having been involved with many sporting activities all my life, during this grievance debate this afternoon I would like to take issue with the lack of coverage for an international event which took place in Lubeck, West Germany, this year. I refer to the world lifesaving championships. The previous world championships were held on the Gold Coast in Queensland. As was the case then, the Australian team is again the world champion. I am also delighted to inform the House that the Cronulla Surf Life Saving Club, having been the world champion surf lifesaving club at the Gold Coast championships, has held the title in 1990 at Lubeck in West Germany.
—Thirroul won the beach relay.

—Yes; the honourable member will hear that. The results show the Cronulla Life Saving Club winning with 240 points; Surfers Paradise was second with 142; Los Angeles came third with 116 and Thirroul-the team of the honourable member for Macarthur, who is interjecting-came fourth with 102 points. It was a great result for all three Australian clubs. West German teams filled fifth and sixth places.

SPEECH.PARA: The complaint I make is the lack of media attention to both Australia's victory once more and to the continuing world championship title which the prestigious and senior surf club, namely Cronulla, has retained. I remind the House that this happened to netball for many, many years and it is only recently that Australia's continuing and outstanding pre-eminence in international netball has been acknowledged by the sporting writers and commentators-and even then only to a limited extent considering the number of Australian women who play the sport.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to their football team?

—I suggest to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security, who is sitting at the table, that he should have taken this issue up in Queensland, but he did not. I am going to take the time of the House to detail some information which should have appeared in the written media sporting pages, and at the very least rated a mention in the electronic media sports shows. I am appalled that none of the channels covered these events. However, I come back to the Cronulla Surf Life Saving Club. I just mention and record in the national Parliament that Richard Ford picked up five gold medals; Warren Buchan, Daniel McLennan and Deacon Spicer, the former Tasmanian surfer, each picked up three gold medals; Dale Rigney, Trent Duffey, Mal Butterfield and Derek Meredith all picked up two gold medals; Jeremy Macpherson and Greg Hoare picked up one each, while Paul Broadhurst won one silver medal and Kim Tunnell won two silver medals.
—Excellent.

—This was a splendid achievement-I am glad to have the honourable member interjecting again-for the club of which I have been a vice-president for the past 25 years. Every club member from Cronulla who competed won a medal. I am very pleased that the honourable member for Macarthur has mentioned to me that Thirroul won the beach relay. Congratulations to them.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to congratulate not only the competitors from Cronulla but also their manager, life member Allan Hanson, and their assistant manager, Baden Green, for their work, and particularly the coach, Ted Larsen, who did an absolutely splendid job in coaching the team through the winter off season. Unfortunately, he was unable to go to the championships. Cronulla life member, Ian Goode, who was the coach of the successful Australian team, also stood in for Ted Larsen in Germany and deserves special mention.

Some members of the House may think I am parochial in putting this forward. I am concerned that our sporting media seems to be totally oblivious, firstly, to this important surfing event and, secondly, to the success of our surf lifesaving club members, not only from Cronulla but also from Surfers Paradise, Thirroul and other clubs who went to Germany at no cost to the sporting authorities and as a result of very concentrated efforts to raise the large amount of money which was needed to send these competitors to this international event.
As the very popular patron of the Cronulla club, Mr Bill Marshall, said in a letter to me:

The sky blue, black and white were clear winners, which says a lot for their dedication, ability and coaching, not to mention the moral backing of team management and the club officialdom, which also includes the army of supporters. The results show that the medals were shared around every member of the Cronulla team which must say a lot for their team work
Bill finished his message by saying:
It was heap good medicine.
It sure was. I am sure all surf lifesaving clubs which were unable to go to Germany will be delighted to have seen the success of Cronulla and the other clubs which made the effort to go.

I remind the House that, despite this sporting achievement, for all surf club members throughout Australia at district, branch and national surfing levels, the surf lifesaving organisation remains a service organisation, with sporting achievement as its secondary activity. Before any surf club member can compete in any interclub sporting event, each competitor must meet his normal surf club obligations of maintaining patrols on the beaches and saving an unbelievably large number of people from drowning around all Australian beaches. Surf club membership demands and gets dedication and an awareness of the tasks required to make our beaches safe and therefore enjoyable to the Australian public, who are often oblivious to the continuing voluntary work of surf club members.

Though our national and State championships do get media coverage, it is surprising and disappointing that there has been no mention whatever, so far as I have been able to observe, on any of the television channels, in Sydney at least, of this important international event, namely, the world surf lifesaving championships. We will all hope for some change next time.

The second point I wish to raise is indeed parochial. It relates to the small and somewhat isolated suburb of Kurnell. I am delighted to mention in the Federal Parliament that, in the primary school competition in New South Wales, Kurnell public school became the 10B State Rugby League champions. For a school that has only 55 boys attending it this is a wonderful result, and I say well done to John Riley, the Principal, to Andrew Wassell, the coach, and to Smith Hartley from Caltex who generously gave the enthusiastic school team all their gear. I say thank you and well done. I am sorry my parliamentary duties do not allow me to be at the special presentation at the school at this very time today, but I will be visiting soon to congratulate them for I hope some of these boys will go up in the league and play for the Cronulla Sharks. I see some honourable members smiling and being amused that I am mentioning this in the national Parliament. Well, Kurnell is the birthplace of the nation and it is a part of my electorate that does not have too many advantages. I think it is just wonderful that the school has achieved the 10B State championships in rugby league for public schools.

There is a third sporting matter I wish to raise in the short time I have left to speak. While I was overseas in the winter recess on my study tour it was my happy experience to attend the 1990 Summer Special Olympic Games. These were held in my birthplace, namely, Glasgow, and it was an inspiration to see quite a number of the events and to meet quite a number of the world figures attending these games.

The 1990 summer games consisted of some 2,200 athletes from 31 countries with 2,000 volunteers. It was chaired by Mr Bill Hughes and 32,000 people were at the opening ceremony of the Special Olympics. It is true to say that the whole of Glasgow took the Special Olympics to heart. The organisation was superb and it was a great experience meeting and talking at length with Mrs Eunice Kennedy Shriver, founder and honorary chairman of Special Olympics International. Her main objectives in establishing these special games was to seek the prevention of mental handicap by identifying its cause, and to improve the means by which society deals with its citizens with mental handicaps.
The history of the special games has been spectacular. We are lucky in Australia to have a fine committee and it is my intention to speak on this subject on further occasions in the House.
It was inspiring in Glasgow to see the diversity of people who get behind and support, as officers or directors, the work of Special Olympics International.

As I have mentioned, it was my special experience to meet with Mrs Shriver and members of her family and also to meet with Queen Noor of Jordan, who had managed by enthusiasm to have that country included in the European Games; Dr Hilary, whom we have met here in this House, the charming wife of the Irish President; the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Glasgow; my close friend Sir Eldon Griffiths, MP, Chairman of the Special Olympics, United Kingdom, and former Minister for Sport; and Tom Songster, the international director.

Having had this lifelong association with the mentally handicapped, being at the European games was a special inspiration. I hope to speak more on this subject in this House; I have done so on previous occasions. I wish Will Hoehndorf and his team achievement and success, and I hope that in the future we will see that encouragement is given for the continuance and further development of special games within and throughout Australia. I shall be speaking on this subject again and again in Australia.
I mention in conclusion that the sad thing is that it is just too expensive to have people who volunteer their services to help to get these teams, in large numbers, to international events.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most publicised Australian economic problem is the current account deficit and the resulting high overseas debt. We are importing more than we are exporting. Australia is also suffering from high interest rates. The Government has kept interest rates high in order to restrain economic activity, and so reduce imports. However, that is only a short term solution. The only permanent solution is stronger growth of exports. This has been happening during the last four financial years; the volume of exports has grown by a quarter.

SPEECH.PARA: We must concentrate more attention, though, on the policies which will enhance the dynamism of the economy. That will allow continued growth of employment and improvements in the security of living standards, which are also widely sought economic goals. The dynamism of the economy depends on innumerable aspects of both public and private sector activity. One important area over which the Government has control is public investment; another is research and development. I will make a few comments about both.

One of the few economic relationships about which economists agree is that between investment and economic growth, yet public investment as a proportion of national income is now at the lowest level it has been since the war. Public investment includes public enterprises, especially in the electricity, gas, water, transport and communications industries, and general government, especially roads, education and health.

Public investment as a proportion of national income peaked in the early fifties at about 10 per cent, and has since declined to little more than half of that. In 1989-90, public gross fixed capital expenditure was 5.6 per cent of gross domestic product. The largest declines have been in investment by public enterprises. State and local governments undertake most public sector investment and they have also made large reductions in their investment. The Commonwealth exerts considerable financial influence over State and local government spending through direct funding and also through setting limits on their borrowing through the Loan Council.

Given that Australia's population growth is at its highest level since the early 1970s, the low growth in public investment suggests that either the public infrastructure is being used more efficiently or is being allowed to deteriorate. Both are happening in fact. The public and private sectors are complementary. A decline in public capital stock makes private capital less productive. Conversely, growing public investment leads to growth in private investment by increasing rates of return on private capital.

Dr David Aschauer has shown that in the United States there is a striking tendency for profits to be higher when the level of public capital formation is high over the course of several years, even after excluding business cycle effects. So there are real risks to Australian productivity from the decline in public investment.
A recent paper published by the Australian National University Centre for Economic Policy Research and written by Alesina, Gruen and Jones concluded:
In common with the experiences of Belgium, Sweden and the UK, a disproportionate part of the recent Australian fiscal adjustment-
they mean by that the cuts in public spending-

has been at the expense of public investment spending. Cutting public investment spending has serious adverse effects on labour productivity and long-term economic growth. Further, the Australian public sector is now a large net saver (especially when adjustment is made for inflation) and the level of public debt in Australia is low. Therefore, cutting public investment spending is an inappropriate response to an increase in foreign borrowing which is largely funding a private investment boom.

There is growing public concern about at least some aspects of this decline. Both parties recognised during the recent election campaign the strength of public demand for increased road funding. The neglect of investment in rail is increasingly widely criticised. The inadequacies of the Sydney and Launceston sewerage systems and of the Perth water supply are generally recognised in those cities. Major new investment is required at Sydney Airport. Most Australian cities need ring roads.

TALK.START.PARA: — Yes.

— I thank the honourable member for his comment. The largest investing enterprise in Australia, Telecom Australia, must continue to rapidly improve its technology, including through the installation of optical fibre and the introduction of the integrated services digital network. And so the examples could be continued.

SPEECH.PARA: A related area of concern is maintenance. Declining public investment is linked with declining spending on maintenance. The worst fears of major Australian infrastructure networks falling apart at the same time are probably unfounded. Many of our infrastructure services and networks compare well with the best in the world, but the avoidance of the problem of the gradual inevitable deterioration of infrastructure needs careful planning, for without adequate maintenance they will deteriorate rapidly.

Maintenance and replacement needs will substantially increase during the rest of this century due to the age pattern of Australian infrastructure. Unless funding requirements due to ageing can be offset by savings elsewhere, aggregate public investment must rise. It says something for the managers of public assets that they have been able to maintain public infrastructure with a generally declining share of national resources, but this situation is about to change with increased requirements for rehabilitation and maintenance in the 1990s.

Private investment grew strongly between 1982-1983 and 1988-1989. In 1988-1989 business investment was 13.5 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). High interest rates caused a reduction in business investment last year, however. The most dramatic growth in the earlier years was in investment for equipment, computers forming a significant part of that. That private investment is vital for the growth of productivity and output, but it will be much less effective unless complemented by essential public investment. Public investment must have a higher priority in budget preparation in the 1990s.

A second theme on which I would like to make a few comments is the role of technological change and of research and development in increasing the dynamism of the economy. New technology offers opportunities for increasing the cost effectiveness of all investment, yet technological innovation in Australia is lagging behind much of that in the rest of the Western world because of our relatively low level of spending on research and development.

The first report by the Science Council, set up by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), showed that Australian expenditure on research and development as a proportion of GDP was lower than in any of the other 11 countries listed. We are spending 1.2 per cent compared with Japan, which spends the most on research and development-2.9 per cent of GDP. The Science Council also concluded that the proportion of our research and expenditure on engineering and the natural sciences is particularly low. The Council commented:

The status of science and technology courses is declining just at the time when the economic, social and environmental futures of Australia are more dependent on science and technology than ever before.

Many industry and public leaders accept that total research and development in Australia is at less than adequate levels. Industry research and development is a fundamental constraint on Australian economic growth. Most Western countries accept that improved technology is essential to improving productivity. A committee that I chaired on the public infrastructure concluded:

...that the Government should give high priority to promoting research and development by the CSIRO, universities and other public authorities related to improving the efficiency and effectiveness of the provision and management of the public infrastructure.

I could make a lot more comments on that but, in order to complete my comments in the time available, I conclude by saying that the permanent elimination of Australia's current account deficit requires a large and permanent increase in our exports of goods and services. To achieve this, both our national infrastructure and our support for research and development must be improved. The latter task has begun; the former must start now. Therefore, I strongly support the comments made last week by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) in his opening address to the Third National Infrastructure Conference. Without increased investment in the public infrastructure, both the relative efficiency and equity of the Australian economy will deteriorate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on an issue which is not debated in this Parliament, that is, the signing of international treaties, in particular the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. I raise this issue mainly in regard to the process, but also in regard to some of the content because it is only on these occasions that we can get any opportunity to really air this type of issue within the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: These treaties can be organised and signed by executive government and the Parliament does not have the opportunity to debate them. I recognise that there are some treaties in which executive government should be involved and which it is inappropriate for the Parliament to debate. Those treaties relate, in particular, to matters of national security. I believe that it is a reasonable position that the Parliament not necessarily debate those issues. However, because of the way in which the Constitution has been interpreted by the High Court in the last decade in particular, I believe that there should be an opportunity for debate in the Parliament of those treaties which have domestic ramifications in this country-clear domestic application. In other words, the process which we have at the present time here in Australia in regard to the signing of international treaties, I believe, is inappropriate; and we ought, as a parliament, to look at that process.

At the moment, as many of us realise, there is a cynicism out there in the electorate about the way in which the democratic processes operate in this country. I believe one of the reasons that that does develop in the community is that there are some issues which people believe are vital but which are not debated or publicly aired by having a parliamentary debate. The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child is one of those. From talking to other members of the Parliament, I believe that there are many people-although very few in my own electorate have approached me over this matter-who are interested in this issue. So I am using this brief period also to highlight some of those issues which I have a concern about in regard to this particular treaty. The most important thing in this area at this stage, I believe, is for us as a parliament to look at the process by which these treaties are dealt with; and I am saying that we should debate them, particularly when they have domestic ramifications.

I turn now to the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, and there are many excellent proposals in that convention which I fully support. Nevertheless, it does have to be said that, as these conventions are developed and signed and ratified and brought into operation in different countries, they increase the power of the state over the individual. This convention, in particular, does that. In regard to social matters within our nation, I think we have to ask whether extra regulation in these areas is going to develop a more compassionate and more effective society. There is no doubt that there are people, particularly children, in our society who do not get a fair deal and who are not treated fairly and genuinely by their parents or their relatives; and there are young people who, through various circumstances, end up in a destitute position. I do not deny that, but I do question whether the way we ought to be addressing these issues is by having legislation flow from an international treaty.

If we as a country believe that there is a great need to address these issues, we should do it within the parliaments of our country without this overriding type of covenant. I believe that the changed interpretation of the Federal Constitution gives the opportunity to the Federal Parliament to override what was the intended Constitution of Australia. Again, that adds to confusion rather then contributing to the betterment of people in Australia. In the debate that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has suggested we should have over the next 10 years in the lead-up to the year 2001, maybe we should look at the powers which State parliaments have to legislate and at the powers of the Commonwealth. I believe that a tremendous amount of confusion can develop when legislative powers which should remain with the States get taken up by the Federal Parliament; and this is one of them. I do not believe that there is any need for Australia to ratify this treaty for us to address the issues which confront children in this country. If we are deeply and genuinely concerned about the welfare of our young people and if we believe that those needs are out there at the present time, we should be encouraging the State parliamentary arena in this country to make those changes.

People say that parents' rights in this particular legislation are protected. When one talks to different lawyers, one gets different opinions on this. They often quote article 5 in this regard. But often when the people who are quoting this article say that parents' rights are protected, they do not read out the provisos which are in that article. There are two provisos. For the information of the House and for the people who might be listening to this debate, I will just read this article:

State parties shall respect the responsibilities, rights and duties of parents or, where applicable, the members of the extended family or community as provided by local custom. Legal guardians or other persons legally responsible for the child to provide-
and then come the provisos. The first is:
in a manner consistent with the evolving capacities of the child.
The second is:
appropriate direction and guidance in the exercise by the child of the recognised rights in the present convention.

Who determines what is `in a manner consistent with the evolving capacities'? Ultimately under this covenant as it would develop in legislation in this country no doubt there would be public servants who would determine whether the manner is consistent with the evolving capacities. There is nothing in this proposed covenant that says that the rights, responsibilities and duties of parents are really protected and encouraged. I believe that we have to look at this type of legislation which flows from these sorts of covenants, and that it should be fully debated before we get to the point of ratification of these types of treaties.

I go back to one point which I just raised very briefly, that is: will these types of covenants bring about a greater common good for this country? Having looked at this and the type of social legislation which often comes about because governments believe they can determine better than parents overall and generally, I can say that governments fail more than parents. I believe that, as a country, we need to look not only at the legislative obligations which flow from these treaties at the national level, but also at the legislation which is already in place within the States.

If we are going to take responsibilities from parents with the assumption that governments are always going to pick them up, we will continue to have more children who will need government support, because parents believe their authority has been undermined by government authorities. We would do far better in this country if we talked about the authority of parents and the responsibility of parents to nurture and to care for their children in a loving atmosphere. We will then get a far more healthy society.
