DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr Gary Carter: Control of Companies

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the House this afternoon a grave miscarriage of justice which has been perpetrated on the people of New South Wales by the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs in that State, the Hon. Gerald Peacocke. What concerns me greatly is the inactivity on behalf of that Minister to act on information which he has had in his possession for over 12 months on the unsavoury history of a number of companies being operated by a Mr Gary Carter and his associates. Unfortunately, for reasons best known to Mr Peacocke, he appears to be either paralysed from doing anything or unwilling for some other reason that perhaps he does not want known.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a very unsavoury history associated with Mr Carter and the companies which, as I have indicated, he does control. It is very difficult to go back through the very complex raft of information which has come into my possession on the companies that he controls to try to follow the paper trail and to get a handle on exactly how exchanges of shares were made through the purchase of preference shares, the selling of those within a two-week period, and the personal gain that has come to Mr Carter to the detriment of the ordinary shareholders-in fact, to get quite to the base of some of the concerns that obviously I am going to raise here this afternoon.

Let me give some examples of the sorts of problems I wish to bring to the attention of the House. The first concerns a transaction by ATS Resources Ltd, that is, the Entity Group Ltd, which has been brought to the attention of the general public-the latest occasion being yesterday in the national media in comments made by Mr Hartnell, the new Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission, which is to take effect on 1 January next year.

On 30 June 1988 Mr Carter, on behalf of ATS Resources directors, wrote to shareholders seeking the approval of a deal involving the purchase of shares in a group called APA Holdings. That letter was clearly misleading. It said to the people: `Give me the opportunity to buy these shares because it has been cleared by company consultants and there is no benefit to anybody other than you, the shareholders'. That was clearly in breach of legal advice obtained by Mr Carter from Allen, Allen and Hemsley, noted solicitors in Sydney. The whole $20m deal involving preference shares was redeemed within a fortnight of the transaction at the shareholders' meeting which gave approval for that particular matter.

At that time, and due to the activity of Mr Carter through this particular company and its various offshoots, the former National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) was carrying out a number of investigations. Arising out of those particular investigations were two letters directed to the Business and Consumer Affairs Agency of the New South Wales State Government. I would like to read into Hansard the contents of those letters. In the first, dated 23 May 1989 and directed to Mr B. French, Director of Compliance, Business and Consumer Affairs Agency, Sydney, Mr Schoer, Executive Director of the NCSC, said:
Dear Mr French,
ATS RESOURCES LTD: CARTER, BLAXLAND AND VICKERY

You are requested to institute proceedings in the name of the National Companies and Securities Commission against Messrs Carter, Blaxland and Vickery in respect of offences committed by them in the course of their directorships of ATS Resources (``ATSR'') from August 1987 until October 1988. The attached memorandum (Annexure A) sets out, in a general way, the matters alleged against those directors.

The action officer handling this matter at the Commission is Mr David McLennan. He has been directed to make himself available for the purpose of assisting and briefing the officer nominated by you as being responsible for dealing with our request.
A high priority has been assigned to this task.
Yours sincerely,
R.J. Shoer
Executive Director.
No action was taken, so on 19 June 1989 a letter, again from the NCSC, again from the Executive Director, Mr Shoer, again to Mr B. French, said:

I refer to my letter of 23 May 1989 requesting that you institute criminal proceedings against certain directors of ATS Resources. At the most recent meeting of the full Commission, the members unanimously reaffirmed the earlier decision to take proceedings in NSW and asked that I write to you to have the matter expedited.

I note that we have also raised with Mr P. Stepek of your office the prospect of civil proceedings alleging a breach of section 11 of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) (NSW) Code and seeking a remedial order. While this may be a way of dealing with one aspect of the general situation more quickly than in the context of a prosecution, it is not regarded by the Commission as a substitute for criminal proceedings.
I would be grateful if you would give a high priority to this request.
Yours sincerely,
R.J. Shoer
Executive Director.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I say to you and to this House that on 23 May 1989 and 19 June 1989 the Minister directly responsible for this portfolio in New South Wales would have been advised about that advice coming from the NCSC. And what action has been taken since then until now? Absolutely nothing. Despite the fact that the NCSC has said that these transgressions warrant high priority criminal prosecution, Mr Peacocke, is apparently satisfied that a full market disclosure, which is this document in my hand, made by Mr Carter and Entity and other directors, together with measures designed to compensate some minority shareholders in the Entity Group, were sufficient. That is contradicted by the McCusker report into the Rothwells fiasco, which was released a couple of weeks ago. That report clearly states that what Mr Carter and his companies did was for personal gain and to the detriment of the shareholders. So we have damning evidence not only from the NCSC but also from the McCusker report into Rothwells, released very recently, because the money was obtained for Carter from Rothwells. Yet what has the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs in New South Wales chosen to do about this? Absolutely nothing.

This is a scandal of monumental proportions because what it does is to throw into consideration what role the New South Wales Government will see for the new Australian Securities Commission when it commences next year. Will it cooperate with Mr Hartnell? As I have already indicated, Mr Hartnell, as reported in the newspapers yesterday, went on to identify a number of high-fliers that would be on his target list. High on that list is the Unity group that Mr Carter owns and that Mr Carter has been involved with.

It is also interesting to see that in recent times Mr Carter has tried to divest his interests in many of these associated companies. He stood down as a chairman of some of them, he has amalgamated others, he has advised the stock exchange of the non-existence of others, and so on- all, however, not necessarily meaning any benefit to minority shareholders or shareholders of his original companies who suffered losses because of the investment decisions that he was making on their behalf, and making those decisions by providing them with false information knowingly and willingly so that the benefit that would flow to the company would flow principally to him and not to the shareholders.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I am today calling on Mr Peacocke to do what the NCSC requested him to do last year, that is, to institute, as a matter of high priority, criminal proceedings against Mr Carter and his associates in the New South Wales court system. If he does not, it throws into whole question once again the cosy relationship that exists between certain members of the New South Wales Government and business operatives in that State. It throws into confusion and uncertainty what role the New South Wales Government will play with the Australian Securities Commission when it is established. We all know, of course, that one of the problems in getting that body established originally was the intransigence on the part of the New South Wales Government in giving up some of its controls, rights and responsibilities in the legal system to get it in place.

In my view, this is an absolute scandal. It is one that has been known about for over 12 months by the New South Wales Government. As I have indicated, we cannot get it any more plainly stated than by the NCSC or by damning reports that have arisen simply because of this sort of activity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the House a report which was sponsored by the Country Education Project, the Office of Rural Affairs, and the Victorian Country Youth Affairs Network, and it relates to the Austudy rural inequities. It was completed in March 1990, but was not released until after the 1990 Federal Budget. It is regrettable that the Government chose to take that action because there is a wealth of valuable information in it regarding the inequities for rural students under Austudy.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to compliment the members of the research group who prepared this report-Dr Doug Lloyd, the Dean of Education of the Bendigo College of Advanced Education, and Jennifer Sheed, Lecturer at the Faculty of Education, Bendigo College of Advanced Education-for the excellent report which they have produced.
There are a number of issues which I want to address, and I want to quote extensively from this report. On page 6 it addresses the impact of Austudy on rural students:
There is little information available related to the impact Austudy is having on specific groups of students, in particular the impact of Austudy on students from rural areas.
Hence, the need for this study. Under `Rural Population Growth' it says:

Since the 1970s the proportion of persons in rural Victoria has been increasing in relation to Melbourne . . . The fact that the rural population is not declining adds urgency to the task of finding appropriate models for provision of services in rural areas . . .

One of the things, of course, in this Austudy scheme is the complexity of the arrangements which are put in place and go right back to the Student Assistance Act 1973, which gave birth to the tertiary education assistance scheme (TEAS). Many of those regulations are of great intricacy and much ambiguity. In 1990 Austudy has been further amended so that it now has its own unique set of complex regulations. Of course, that is making it extremely difficult for people to follow the system.

The sources of Austudy information for Victorian rural students and parents have been difficult to obtain; people are not informed where they can obtain this information. There are two Austudy offices in Victoria-one in Exhibition Street, Melbourne, the other in Dandenong-and a 008 number is provided for people in rural areas. But many people do not realise that the Commonwealth Employment Service offices do have a role of dissemination of information in this area.
Telephone inquiries are quite another thing, and I have a quote here from a parent in northern Victoria in 1989:

I tried the 008 number, that took 1 hour and 20 minutes to get through, they picked up their receiver but spoke not one word. I held on for 30 minutes during this time not one word from Austudy, someone from their end just hung up.
I then decided that I would ring for a Telecom operator to connect a reverse charge call-I explained what had occurred. I suggested perhaps there was some fault with my phone.

It took half an hour for the telephonist to get through, the receiver was picked up and no word spoken, after fifteen minutes a voice said ``Please hold the line'' (no chance for the telephonist to say a word). She held for a further twenty minutes without a word from the other end. The Telecom Operator confessed she had not believed me. She tried the number again and after fifteen minutes got through properly.

This is just one example of what is happening on that number. The student assistance and secondary schooling aspects of this also can have a dramatic impact on rural families, who can incur two types of cost when their children complete secondary schooling-income forgone and the actual cost involved in having a child attend school.

The assets test, of course, causes great pain and difficulty for people in rural areas. I want to refer to page 47 of this excellent report, which concerns the introduction of the assets test in 1989. This test is perceived by farmers, in particular, to be inequitable. One parent expressed her frustration. This parent came from the Wimmera and made this quote in 1989. She expressed her frustration with the following comment:
I am concerned about the assumption that is made that landholders are wealthy-you can't eat dirt and buildings.

The frustrations keep on coming out. Farmers have assets, but they are tied up in land and stock. Austudy does not take into account that farms need a lot of assets just to function normally. Of course, the problems are related not only to the rural area: this report highlights and points out the inequities which are faced by students who live in remote locations.

The transition from dependence to independence is very important for students, and in fact it is always a very difficult time. Anyone in this House who has put students through tertiary education of any form will know just how difficult it is. Some young people have a well established attachment to the labour force through working part time for several years while they are doing a course. They have even managed to save money and live either relatively independently or completely independently of parents; yet they are unable to claim independent status for Austudy on the basis of their work history. In fact, trying to help oneself in this situation is not taken into consideration. A student named Jeff, who is a second-year university student, said the following:

I think it was deceptive from the beginning. My main argument about Austudy is that it deceives a person, especially if you have to move away from home . . . to believe that you can study and also live.

I now want to return to a brief summary of the main findings and recommendations of this report, because there has been an enormous amount of work put into this document. It is unfortunate that the Government did not choose to have the report made available prior to the 1990 Budget so that the considerations of this report could be taken into hand at that time.

The summary in the report includes five main issues: access to reliable and accurate information about Austudy; the adequacy of the living away from home allowance; the impact of Austudy on secondary school retention rates; the assets test; the transition from dependence to independence for young people; and assumptions made by Austudy about that transition.

I could go through all of the recommendations but, regrettably, time is against me. I do commend this report and I think that it is well summed up on the cover. It indicates that it is about Austudy rural inequities, a joint project of the Country Education Project, the Office of Rural Affairs and the Victorian Country Youth Affairs Network, funded by the Federal Government. There is an illustration of four young people looking extremely worried about Austudy, and the caption reads:
Nobody told us . . . nobody knew . . .

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Tickle Pot Program-Provisional Parliament House: Proposed Use

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Catley Dr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, as honourable members will be enviously aware, I represent the finest city in the Southern Hemisphere. My electorate contains the central business district and most of its great cultural and commercial monuments. These range from botanic gardens to the stock exchange and from art galleries to the zoo. For the most part, government should leave these great institutions to get on with their job, but from time to time they deserve our chastisement or encouragement; and today I would like to draw the attention of the House to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and to the Constitutional Museum.

SPEECH.PARA: The ABC's State headquarters sit in the middle of my electorate, barely a mile from where I live. I frequented it earlier as an academic commentator and I now go there as a local member; and I know that it contains some very good people. However, there is some monkey business afoot at the ABC, or rather there is no more monkey business afoot at the ABC. The ABC has gone bananas and axed Tickle Pot and sacked both its producer and its production assistant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Incredible.

—For those culturally deprived members-and I see that the honourable member is not one-who missed out on the joys of Tickle Pot, allow me to explain. Tickle Pot was a 10-minute radio program broadcast daily by Radio National to an Australia-wide audience of 3- to 7-year-olds. It starred Australia's best selling and most popular children's singer and songwriter, Peter Combe, and his mouse mate, Monkey. It was a mixture of music, comedy, fantasy and madness built around subtle educational themes promoting positive social values. It was a winning formula and it was the only program on Australian radio for that age group.
—Shortsighted.

—Absolutely true. Over the past 2 1/2 years, as the honourable member points out, over 400 programs have been recorded and the Tickle Pot success in reaching its target audience has been unprecedented. The Tickle Pot crew have received over 25,000 drawings and letters from children, parents and teachers, proving it was a very highly successful family and classroom listening experience. The recently started Tickle Pot fan club already has 5,000 members. Now, these Ticklepotters ring up the production office in tears wanting to know where Peter and Monkey have gone.

SPEECH.PARA: The program was even generating income for the ABC, in terms of sales of cassettes and books and the enormous success of the live Tickle Pot concerts. Indeed, ABC enterprises are demonstrating their faith in the popularity of Tickle Pot by releasing a Tickle Pot book and a record of Monkey songs even after the axing of the program.

The success of Tickle Pot was not only in Australian terms; it was also hailed by its professional peers around the world. Tickle Pot won the 1988 Peter Gold award for the best children's radio program in the world; in 1989 it capped this by winning the gold medal at the International Radio Festival in New York for the best educational children's radio program in the world; and in 1990 it won the bronze medal at the same festival in the children's-young adults section. The British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) in the United Kingdom broadcast a series of episodes of Tickle Pot in 1989 and was so delighted with it that it has since made many unsuccessful attempts to imitate the inimitable Tickle Pot format. It has now given up and is soon going to repeat the original Australian series.

The producer of Tickle Pot, Heather Steen, who is a friend of mine and a South Australian and Adelaide resident, was awarded a Churchill Fellowship for her work in children's radio and was invited to assist the BBC in setting up a new station-Radio 5-which will consist primarily of programs for the children: a whole radio station. It was while Heather Steen was so engaged that the ABC axed Tickle Pot and made her redundant. So we have this splendid irony, Mr Deputy Speaker. But while the BBC was setting up a new children's radio station in England, with assistance from the ABC, the ABC axed all its children's radio programs in Australia. Scandalous! There are no programs for children broadcast on the ABC radio at this time.

There are approximately 1.4 million children in Australia between the ages of three and seven. This means that, at a rate of 8c a day, which we are all told is the current cost of the ABC, these children contribute nearly $41m a year to the ABC. `That ain't peanuts', says Monkey, who claims that he was only paid peanuts by the ABC, anyway. What does the ABC do with $41m worth of children's money? It cuts their radio programs to zero. And what does the ABC's radio charter have to say about that? I will quote it:
The Corporation shall take account of . . . the provision of broadcasting programs and television programs of an educational nature.

It is true that that does not specifically mention children, but Mr David Hill, who is usually a very sensible person, although he is with the North Sydney rugby league crowd, writes in a document called The ABC of Literacy:
The ABC, with its national television and radio networks, and a comprehensive range of educational services for people of all ages, is uniquely placed to help.

A clear contradiction. We all know that when there is a shortfall of funds programs have to be axed and cuts have to be made. But is it fair, right or honourable to start by attacking an audience group which cannot defend itself, which cannot fill out rating books and which is grotesquely underserviced anyway by the general national media?

Do we really want a uniquely Australian culture for our children or are we prepared to throw them away to the teenage mutant ninja turtles? As more than 2,000 children and their parents chanted at a recent Tickle Pot protest concert, `What do we want? Tickle Pot. When do we want it? Now'. On the other hand, Mr Speaker, the Constitutional Museum on North Terrace offers--

TALK.START.PARA: —If I could interrupt the honourable member for just one second: I appreciate the promotion you are giving me, but I am Mr Deputy Speaker.
—I am terribly sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker. Please accept my humble apologies.
—Oh, I do.

—On the other hand, the Constitutional Museum on North Terrace, again in my seat, offers some positive lessons of which I was reminded only this morning when passing Canberra's old Parliament House. Why is nothing happening to the old Parliament House, in which I used to work for a number of Ministers in the old days? A great national asset is there lying idle with its future in doubt, and I have received no information on what has happened to the plans by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to do something about it. So I would like to make some suggestions in this grievance debate.

SPEECH.PARA: An excellent example of what to do with such a facility already exists in Adelaide, where the old State Parliament House has been turned into a very successful model that Canberra could adopt. The building's basic use is as a museum of political history, although there are many other rooms which also serve other purposes. The old members' refreshment room has become a restaurant open to the public. This means that the public and politicians from the neighbouring State Parliament House can partake of excellent bistro-style cuisine. The old Parliamentary library has become a specialist library and research centre, but it is also available for public use. It has touch screen computer technology which visitors can use to punch up information about their local members, their local Ministers or other political matters. The old House of Assembly chamber has a sound and light show to explain its history. Other rooms and the garden are popular venues for meetings and receptions of various kinds and in fact I spent my fortieth birthday evening there at an exhibition commemorating the opposition to the war in Vietnam, so foolishly waged by the political parties now in Opposition. Recent shows have also included one on the role of women in the political history of South Australia.

These imaginative uses, if adopted in Canberra, would provide excellent guided public access to an important historic site and also bring in some income to offset running costs. The old Parliament House in Adelaide in fact holds a valuable collection of documents pertaining to the opening of the first Federal Parliament in 1901, and it considers that it is holding them only until such time as the much needed museum of Federal politics comes into being. The centenary of the Federation of 1901 might be the perfect official opening date and, at our present rate of progress, it might be a suitable one.

Australians are delighted that we have got back an original copy of the national Constitution and that it is going to be located here. But it is important to put it somewhere where it is accessible and is in context, that is, surrounded by an interpretive display which reveals it for what it was and is-a compromise between the different political interests of the 1890s, a living document still adapting itself as times change, and a legal framework which has an impact on the daily lives of Australians. As we now go into a process of reforming that Constitution in the 1990s, such a display could be augmented by appropriate contemporary documents.

Susan Tonkin, a constituent of mine, Mr Deputy Speaker, and Director of South Australia's Constitutional Museum, assures me of her readiness to advise on the creation of such a national equivalent, and I only hope that her offer will be taken up. And I should close by pointing out that once again this confirms that Adelaide is more than just a nice place to have lunch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I enjoyed the contribution of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley), and I certainly agree with him on the axing of the children's programs on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. However, due to the policies of this Government, Australia unfortunately is moving into a recession, joblessness at present is skyrocketing and country areas particularly are being hard hit. We have got record interest rates; a record level of the Australian dollar in recent times; record costs through inflation; and, compared with the rest of the world, and on top of this, commodity prices are down, particularly in the wool industry and the wheat industry.

SPEECH.PARA: With this basis I would like to speak this afternoon about the importance of restoring the live sheep trade to the Middle East, acknowledging of course that Iraq and Kuwait have to be removed from the equation for the time being. At the height of this trade a couple of years ago we were exporting some seven million sheep to this part of the world. When we think of it, that is about one-third the number presently being mooted as the number that we might have to move into in our slaughter program, if we go ahead with it, to get rid of our oversupply of wool.

I believe the Government could be doing much more in restoring this live sheep trade, or at the very least attempting to do something. The fiasco in this area has dragged on for far too long and is long overdue for some concentrated attention from the Government. It appears that the Government does not know what to do. The Government is moribund on this issue and, in fact, the Government cannot even begin to understand what to do on the issue. I will admit that it is a very complex area, but certain actions of the Government, far from helping the situation, seem to be aggravating the situation.

Let me say that there is no one magical answer that will restore the live sheep trade overnight. However, a number of steps, I believe, could be taken by the Government, which could also help by modifying its behaviour in other areas. One of these, I believe, centres around the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I believe he should become fully briefed on this situation. I have mentioned the Prime Minister because the situation encompasses several portfolios, Primary Industries and Energy, Foreign Affairs, and Trade Negotiations, just to mention three. The Prime Minister himself does not seem particularly interested, unfortunately, in the live sheep trade. He seems more intent on trying to get the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) up over our Treasurer (Mr Keating) as his successor.

We particularly need, I believe, closer consultation between the Government and the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC). I believe the Government should offer every assistance possible to it so that it can re-establish as soon as possible a warm and genuine link between itself and the Middle East, which has been somewhat lacking in present times. I believe more top class information should be coming through from the Foreign Affairs and Trade Negotiations portfolios to the AMLC and that top priority must be given to repairing the damage that has occurred.

In particular I want to mention one incident: the withdrawal of the licence of the Al Mukarrish Co. by the AMLC. I believe this particular incident needs thorough analysis and I would urge the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) to take up my suggestion. I know that this company sailed into Saudi Arabia with a load of live sheep at the very time when we had a ban on live sheep going to that country because it had been turning our boats away. There is no doubt that this company committed a clear breach of policy. Nevertheless, I believe it now should be looked at again. Saudi Arabia, when all is said and done, is our biggest customer for live sheep-it takes 50 per cent or more of what we send out of this country-and the Al Mukarrish Co. was the biggest operator into Saudi Arabia, with 25 per cent of that trade. But the AMLC has taken the attitude that that is it, the company is finished. Even if it reapplied for a licence, I do not think that the AMLC would be all too enamoured to grant it one. The AMLC has taken the attitude that other companies will take up the shortfall, but I put it to the Corporation that this has not happened. To some extent, in fact, New Zealand has taken up the shortfall.

I realise that the trade has resumed and a ship has left Australia and is sailing over there now, but whether that will be accepted or whether ships will continue to be accepted is very much up in the air. I realise that health and proper age protocols have been put in place, and I acknowledge the importance of those and the work that has been done in that area, but that is not the full story on why our sheep are not getting out of this country to the Middle East.

The Al Mukarrish Co. operator came from a high-born Saudi Arabian family and the connections he had in that country, I think, were vital; we should recognise that. That company never had a ship stopped, to my knowledge; it always paid promptly and in its own way it indirectly helped other shipments get in there. I think that the time has come to admit that perhaps we have cut off our nose to spite our face and that it is not just a matter of that company reapplying for a licence. We must realise the cultural differences between us: if something like a licence is taken away, it is regarded as a grave slight. If we had suspended the company for a time and had had a revision at the end of a proper period, that might have been acceptable; but to take the licence away willy-nilly, I think, is in the long run going to do us in Australia, particularly the growers, of course, more harm than good, and it has substantial flow on effects which we are witnessing today.

There are sensitivities here in understanding how the Middle East mind works which are not even being considered, and I believe bridges must be rebuilt. It is too big an issue for personalities and ego and pride to come into.

In another area, I believe the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade should look at revamping its Middle East section. I believe the performance of Senator Evans and the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Dr Blewett) has been abysmal. They have neglected the Middle East almost totally. They show indifference to that part of the world. Some people are saying that we have less than the most effective teams of diplomats and advisers over there. I believe that both Ministers should give priority to this area. Personality clashes between our key players and important people over there such as the Saudi Arabian Primary Industry Minister, Dr Abdul Al Shaikh, I believe, are intolerable. I do not mean in any way to denigrate the efforts of staff over there, but I believe our Government must monitor more fully what is happening there and make sure that the people who go there are genuinely interested in the area, give attention to the customs of that area and are able to develop positive relations with trade contacts over there.

Our approach perhaps should be more akin to that of Great Britain. Even though that country makes the odd mistake, it specialises in and cultivates the Middle East in a thoroughly professional manner. I believe attention must be given to the observance of even the most basic customs and cultural procedures, because these are being constantly violated. Incidents like the appointment of a woman to a high diplomatic position do not necessarily go down well in the Middle East, nor does having our Prime Minister, who is regarded over there as an infidel, writing directly to the King in an ill-advised and naive attempt to resolve the live sheep issue. Such actions usually end up doing more harm than good.

I believe we should be monitoring press articles more closely over there than we are and, if incorrect and adverse comment comes on Australia or on the quality of our sheep or other primary products that we are trying to send in there, then we should have immediate balancing replies prepared and submitted to those newspapers. With the relationships we build up with them, we should have a good chance of having them being submitted, because this sort of damaging thing has happened in the past.

I believe the Prime Minister, when he makes his pro-Israeli statements, should perhaps curb them to some extent, because they are invariably reported right throughout the Middle East and he is painted over there as strongly pro-Zionist. I am not suggesting that he should change his opinion, for which I have some sympathy, or that he should remain mute. However, he should not be ignorant of the consequences of these statements and should temper them accordingly and perhaps occasionally say something positive about Saudi Arabia, which is a very fine country.

The issue is very complex, I admit. It has many facets to it. There are vast cultural differences to be acknowledged and there are other factors, such as the expatriates over there being fewer in numbers than they were and less meat being eaten. But I despair that we can really restore good government to government relations while this present Government is in power, and that is desperately needed. At the very least, the private industries and individuals should be allowed to get on with the job. The Government should give them every support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the decision last year to decommission the 12th Squadron at Amberley Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) base and mothball the Chinook helicopters, many misinformed and incorrect statements have been made by those opposite to gain media attention. Nothing was more blatant than recent comments by the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), who was obviously using the opportunity for blatant political grandstanding. Unfortunately, this was done on the fiftieth anniversary of the first RAAF plane actually landing at Amberley.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer honourable members specifically to comments made by the honourable member for Ryan during the parliamentary recess in regard to the RAAF's Chinook helicopters, which are presently stored at Amberley. In a media release on 3 July the honourable member for Ryan claimed that the Australian taxpayers are paying some $6,000 a month to keep the 11 Chinook helicopters mothballed at Amberley. The media release went on to claim that in the last year alone the Chinooks cost taxpayers some $70,000 while they sat idle during Queensland's horrific floods. It is very emotional stuff, but the facts just were not there. Setting in place the necessary equipment to keep the Chinooks operational has larger up-front costs which prove more cost effective over time. Dividing the annual operating costs for the first year by the number of months and adding on an inflated amount for the maintenance of spare parts hardly presents a true indication of the true costs of running the equipment. The honourable member for Ryan's sensational comments certainly caught the attention of the local media and, instead of big headlines about the celebrations coming forth on that day, 4 July, it said something like: `The idle Chinooks hit taxpayers'.

In fact the claims were quite incorrect. The claim was made that a cost of $6,000 a month indicates that there was a daily operating cost of some $200. In actual fact, the daily operating cost is less than $10-quite a substantial difference. The honourable member for Ryan seems to have discarded the No. 1 economic rule for marginal cost analysis in one move.

In contrast to the emotional retorts of the honourable member, the Government has undertaken a review looking at a range of options, the final outcome of which was announced by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) early last month.

The honourable member for Ryan has not been on his own in this sort of criticism. Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator MacGibbon also joined in this opportunity, from time to time, to criticise the decisions of the Australian Defence Force.

It must be remembered that the primary role of the Air Force, and all defence forces, is to look after the defence of the nation. We often hear of criticisms that suggest that we should be using our military operations for civilian duties. Whilst it is always very good to use those things, the primary role of our Defence Force, of course, is defence. I think we should be very careful in thinking that there is any other reason for using it.

This Government has a very proud record in looking after our defence people and I think that our defence people at Amberley were particularly disappointed that the opportunity was taken on such an important celebration as the fiftieth anniversary at Amberley for members of the Opposition to do some political grandstanding. I would ask honourable members opposite in future to really think twice about making these statements that tend, in a lot of cases, to offend the hardworking people in our defence forces, for whom I certainly have a very high regard, as I know do other members on this side of the Parliament. The Government has helped our defence forces in many ways, including housing and such things as FIND, which is an area of information for defence people when they move into new areas. I think there have been very innovative ideas that this Government has brought forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106, as amended for this session, the debate is interrupted. I put the question:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, students from the Mountain District Christian School in Belgrave Heights in my electorate have expressed their disapproval of the removal of Caroline Chisholm from the $5 note. Caroline Chisholm is one of Australia's most famous women and has graced the face of our blackberry coloured $5 note since its introduction in 1967. She was one of the first pioneers of this great country, who helped and assisted other young women emigrate to what was then the colony of New South Wales. The fact that Caroline Chisholm was put on our first $5 note was recognition of her contribution to Australia and the more general acknowledgment of the pioneering spirit of our early women settlers.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my view that she should remain on our currency as a reminder of the women pioneers who stood alongside their husbands, kept their families together through thick and thin, and helped make this country what it is today. Perhaps it is an indictment of the officials who make these decisions that, because the notes will now be made of a more durable material, an Australian woman pioneer should be declared obsolete. Without the pioneering spirit of women such as Elizabeth McArthur, Louisa Lawson and Caroline Chisholm, Australian history would be the poorer.

I understand that it was not fashionable for women to accept the kudos for the work that they did in those very early days, but surely we do not need to perpetuate that farce today. I urge the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to ask the Reserve Bank to reconsider this retrograde step and restore Caroline Chisholm to the face of our new plastic $5 note.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have got only 90 seconds to speak, so I will step on the gas. I am absolutely astounded at the price of petrol-80c a litre it will be shortly. Some of the pensioners in my electorate of Franklin have some of the older cars that use a lot of petrol. It is costing them $3.20 a day to come to work. It has just gone to the impossible.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me talk also about liquefied petroleum gas (LPG). It will save engine wear, it is cheaper and it could be used as an alternative if governments had a bit of foresight and decided to give tax reductions to people that converted to LPG. Let me talk about the price of LPG in Australia. It is outrageous also. In Tasmania, it is twice the price in Victoria.

Let me talk about the Prices Surveillance Authority. I think that is a toothless tiger, and when we become the Government of Australia we will get rid of that and we may bring a bit of sanity into the petrol pricing structure of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hulls Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise today to pay tribute to Robert Jeppeson, a hero who has left an indelible mark on the history of the western Queensland town of Longreach and on the lives of 13 people. Tragedy struck in Longreach in the early hours of Wednesday, 5 September, when fire completely destroyed the 75-year-old Commercial Hotel and five other businesses. Fourteen people were in the hotel at the time and 13 of them owe their lives to the one man who did not make it. Robert Jeppeson, a 38-year-old man from Enoggera in Brisbane, displayed a commitment to the welfare of other people that serves as an example to us all. Tragically, in helping others, he lost his life. A major in the Army Reserve, Mr Jeppeson was in Longreach to investigate future military exercise sites in western Queensland and was staying at the Commercial Hotel on the night of the fire. It was he who first became aware that the building was ablaze and, instead of just moving himself to safety, raised the alarm and helped the other guests to escape.

SPEECH.PARA: After getting the others to safety, Robert ran back into the building to ensure that no one was left, but the building collapsed. His wife, Fay, has every right to claim he died a hero and his two children, Kelly and Cameron, can be very proud of their dad. However, this knowledge alone will not alleviate their grief and struggle over the next few months and years.

It is important that people like Robert Jeppeson who give their lives in the service of others receive due public recognition and that their loved ones are not just left to fend for themselves. I fully support the actions of the Longreach Shire Council in launching an appeal for Fay, Kelly and Cameron and congratulate it on such a quick and thoughtful response. I know that the people of western Queensland will not forget Robert Jeppeson or his family.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I have received the following letter from a constituent:

SPEECH.PARA: I am on a supporting parent benefit, I have two sons at tech, and I live in a Ministry of Housing house. After 7 months of serious job hunting and a six week course in March/April, last week I started part-time work three hours each Friday and Saturday night as a kitchen hand. I was really pleased when I picked up my pay. I had earned $64.14. I first went to Social Security and advised them. After 15 weeks I will lose $2 a week off my pension. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, in previous comments I made the plea to colleagues from Victoria on both sides of the House and also to our colleagues from Western Australia, Queensland and New South Wales that the move by the Port Adelaide Football Club to go into the Australian Football League (AFL) needs to be taken very seriously.
