SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to raise a matter of privilege.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—On Monday of this week, I received a letter from a firm of solicitors, Dunhill Madden Butler, signed by a Mr A. Elder. In his letter, Mr Elder indicates that he is acting on behalf of Mr Bill Farrow, the major partner in the Farrow Corporation and a director in the Pyramid Building Society.

SPEECH.PARA: The letter contains paragraphs which I believe would inhibit me in the passage of my duties as a member of this Parliament and as a representative of the Corio electorate. The House will be aware that the Pyramid Building Society was a major institution in the Geelong area and that some 76,000 persons in the Geelong area held deposits in the Society. Clearly, it is a matter of serious consequence to all persons, and particularly parliamentary representatives of that area.

My duty as a member of parliament is to represent the views of those people, and I believe any action which would inhibit me from doing so would deny the people I represent and this Parliament their proper role in what is a matter of significant and major public comment and public administration.

I go to the specific paragraph, which asks me to pre-empt my right to any future comment on these matters, even though anyone who has taken an interest in them would know that I have a series of questions on the Notice Paper, I should have thought not unfriendly to the views being expressed by Mr Farrow. The paragraph refers to a document which I distributed to branch members of my Party in my electorate and to the Secretary of the Geelong Trades Hall Council-that being, for the information of honourable members, something under 200 copies by private letter. It was not released by me to the press and it was not published or commented on by me in any media release or in any other fashion. The letter that I received, which is posed in a very courteous fashion-and I acknowledge that-states:
I ask you not to distribute the document further, to tell the people to whom you have distributed it that it should be put to one side, and that you refrain from making such statements in future.

I refer to the last part of that sentence, that I 'refrain from making statements in future'. Anyone who reads the Notice Paper will know that I have questions which, once answered, whether they are in favour of or detrimental to the Government, it would be impossible, as a member of parliament, for me not to comment on.

Reports on the activities of Pyramid will be coming out over a period of time and, as the representative of the Corio electorate, it will be my responsibility to make comment on the matter, particularly on behalf of those people who have lost their funds, who are shareholders and who have been deprived.

I have no animosity towards Mr Farrow and I do not think that at any time during the 20-odd years that I have known him or been a member of this Parliament we have had any altercation other than a letter once about what I thought was an improper action in reducing some interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable member for Corio has put before the House the matter that he wished to raise.

—I wish to put certain documents before the House for the consideration of the Privileges Committee. It is possible from my knowledge of privilege that the particular matter is not covered because privilege was, in fact, derived in the eighteenth century and some of the present legal practices were not paramount in those days. I seek leave to table a letter from Dunhill Madden Butler which contains the paragraphs which I find offensive; an attachment to that letter which purports to answer matters which I raised in the circular which I sent out and which, had I not been told I could not distribute, I would have sent to my electorate because it is entitled to know those views too; the letter that was actually sent to the branch members, and the attachment; the report published of the administrator of the Pyramid Building Society which sets out his views of the operation of the Society; a series of press releases which were published prior to the making of my statement, which have a total distribution of something in excess of two million, and against none of whom writs have been issued or action taken, clearly indicating that the action threatened against me is to prevent me, as a member of parliament, from taking part in public debate, not a matter of damage, because these articles are far more damaging and potentially damaging to Mr Farrow; finally, a list of members of parliament which was issued by the Friends of Pyramid Building Society which clearly puts my name at the top of that list-the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) is second-on a matter which normally would have been of State importance, but which, I think, reflects the importance which is placed on my contribution and my participation in a matter which is of significant importance to my electorate and the people I represent.

SPEECH.PARA: I claim, Mr Speaker, that the threat contained in the letter, if I were to comply with it, would inhibit me and prevent me in future from carrying out my duties as a member of this Parliament and thus would prevent this Parliament from having my services on a basis which I would think is right and proper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted for the documents to be tabled? There being no objection, leave is granted. I will take account of the matter raised by the honourable member for Corio and will report my views back to the House at a later date.

—My question without notice is directed to the Prime Minister. In view of his often repeated remarks that `you can't govern the country if you can't govern yourselves', does he share and support the view of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, as reported in yesterday's Australian, that the European issue `drags on and on because the party (ALP) can't take a decision'? Will the Prime Minister undertake to seek approval from the ALP conference on 24 September for a rational debate about the Government's current uranium policy, the three-mine policy, and hopefully bring about a rational resolution?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand that those opposite are somewhat stung by the language that I used in the last election because it struck a very responsive chord with the Australian electorate, as indeed it should have. Nothing has happened since the election in regard to the fundamental issues of importance to this country which should change its decision or its mind in any way as between the Government and the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of uranium, it is the case that the Party has had well-known publicised differences of view and at successive stages of its history has adopted different positions. It embraced new mines with a reasoning which, I confess, does not fit with all the best known forms of logic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ah!

—It just shows how far behind the game honourable members opposite are, because I have said that on so many occasions that it surprises me that one should say `Ah!' now, but that is about the extent of his capacity in this area. It is something I have said on many occasions. In regard to that situation, what the Party did was to establish a committee which is examining this issue and in due time it will come up with a recommendation which will be considered. I can assure the honourable member that it will not be considered at the conference on the twenty-fourth. I think we will have enough on the agenda to fill up that day.

—Can the Minister for Employment, Education and Training inform the House what the Government is doing to foster cooperation between trade unions, industry and governments to boost Australia's training effort?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and acknowledge his deep and abiding interest in the crucial issue of improving skills within this country. The House has often heard the Prime Minister and even me refer to the great success that the Government has had in increasing participation rates, particularly in our schools and also within our universities, and it has been wider even than that. But Australia has lagged, and to some extent continues to lag, behind some parts of the world in the area of our concentration on vocational education. Something like 30,000 of our young people leave school and enter the work force without any additional vocational preparation.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, this is quite out of line with what happens in many other parts of the world. In West Germany, for example, 63 per cent of people in the age group 25 to 34 have a post-year 12 qualification other than one which they have gained at a university-in other words, 63 per cent have a qualification which we in Australia would broadly describe as a vocational qualification-whereas in Australia the comparable figure is only 37 per cent. This area has been of considerable concern to us in the Government and, indeed, to some of our colleagues in the States.

I do not want to give the impression that nothing has happened. If we look at technical and further education (TAFE) enrolments, we find that over the last few years the number of student places in the preparatory and vocational courses has increased by 21 per cent or an additional 166,000 student places. We also find that there has been more than a doubling of the number of intakes for apprenticeships and traineeships since the time we came to office. That is, another 37,000 young Australians have engaged in apprenticeships or traineeships since the time we came to office.

But a number of issues still have to be contended with and we need to work on a number of problems. Even in this Budget, where we have continued our restraint in relation to expenditure, we find that we have continued to maintain, and in some areas increase substantially, Commonwealth expenditure in areas such as TAFE funding, where we will now be spending something like twice as much as the States are spending on capital, and in other areas where we are encouraging industry training efforts.

But I think the area of vocational training, as the question implies, is not just a matter for governments, whether State or Federal. It is a matter for our joining together with industry-both employers and unions-to ensure that we can have a coordinated approach to this issue.

If we thought about the question of skill formation we would imagine that most employers would take it as being axiomatic that if they wanted to improve the performance of their businesses they would invest significantly in the formation and improving of the skills of their work force generally. Unfortunately, in Australia there has not been a strong tradition of industry investing in training. We have found that as soon as there is even the suggestion of a downturn in economic activity one of the first casualties is the area of apprenticeship intakes and other areas of training expenditure.

It is for that reason that the Government decided to introduce the training guarantee to ensure that all employers spend at least something on their training efforts rather than having a continuation of a situation where some 60 per cent of employers spend absolutely nothing on training.

We think that as a result of that measure and the other measures that we are taking we will be able to change the views and the culture of industry. We want to do that in a cooperative way and hence we are having, and will continue to have, very detailed discussions with industry and with the unions. This problem is one of the consequences of having an industry in Australia which was so protected from the forces of international competition that issues of quality which go to the questions of training and skill development were ignored by Australian industry. Again we find that it is the Government which is setting the pace in this area.

The Opposition has nothing sensible to say about what should be done about skills formation and improving the skills of the Australian work force. It knows a lot about discouraging that kind of activity; it knows nothing and has said nothing about how we might improve this in the future. All it does is resort to its simplistic slogan that all that needs to be done is deregulate the labour market when, in fact, there is enough evidence to suggest that if one did deregulate the labour market in the way that the Opposition intends it would have an entirely contradictory effect in terms of improving the development of skills in this country.

What we have done through the development of the wage fixation system in Australia is make an essentially centralised system work to our advantage so that in the future people increasingly will be paid in accordance with the skills they have and the skills they use rather than the job classification which they happen to occupy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sit down.
—Wind him up.

—Again the Opposition resorts to its usual form of gibberish. Once again it is sidelined on this debate as it is on all the significant and important debates that confront the country now and into the future.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to his statement yesterday on telecommunications when he said that what the Minister for Transport and Communications has proposed is not a permanent duopoly but a transient duopoly. I ask the Treasurer to inform the House for how long will the transient duopoly remain and what sort of additional competition will then take its place.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a question that should be put to the Minister.
—You said it.
—I did say it. The honourable member is now asking about policy in the future, which should be put to the Minister. I am, nevertheless, happy to answer it.
—You can't control yourself.

—At least I am competent enough to answer it, which is more than most members of the Opposition are about the subjects they have been given charge of. The rationale for the Minister's proposition is that in facing an entrenched monopoly, which is what Telecom Australia is, a competitor should be able to devise a corporate strategy to develop a competitive operation against the monopoly. Therefore, he reasons that this will take some time. It is upon examination of the progress of the duopolist that decisions will then need to be made as to how much time should be either permitted or extended to the duopolist, if any. It is the Government's intention over the longer haul to see that there is a competitive framework. That may well extend beyond a simple duopoly.

ANSWER.PARA: I make this simple point in observation: the duopolies which the coalition constructed, particularly with the airlines, were duopolies which had a certain tenure. They were then reviewed and it decided to extend them for a number of years. I think they were for five or seven years duration. Such a review will be part and parcel of the process of telecommunications reform envisaged by the Government.

The point I made yesterday was that we are being asked about a competitive framework built around, in the first instance, a duopoly by a party which specialised in monopolies or very extended duopolies. I note that one empty-headed member opposite is rattling his head again. How can he refute that fact? Those opposite were specialists at monopolies. A lot of the competitive inhibitions in this economy and much of the monopolisation of the economy are their legacies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Community Services and Health confirm whether the number of accommodation support places available to people with disabilities under the national attendant care scheme and the 325 places scheme will be fully utilised in this financial year? Has the Government conducted any evaluation of the success of these schemes which provide alternatives to inappropriate nursing home care? Also, can the Minister give assurances regarding the future of these initiatives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Phillip for her question. I was recently in the electorate of Phillip, in the city of Waverley, where a very enthusiastic meeting endorsed the extension of a job link program in that city. What struck me about that occasion was the recognition on the part of people working in the area of disability of the enormous strides that had been made by this Government, particularly with regard to the Disability Services Act. If there were an area in which the Government conceptually had broken new ground-and it ought to be very strongly supported by every member of this House-it was in the area of the Disability Services Act and the new, more active approach that the Government has been pursuing in this area-against, I might say, quite strong resistance from conservative groups.

ANSWER.PARA: I say to the honourable member for Phillip and to other members that the Government intends to go on in the direction that has been set. In the Budget this year we have seen a very strong confirmation of that continued direction and the resources that are necessary to make a very great success of what is an intractable problem.

More specifically, in terms of what the honourable member said, I confirm that the Government this year has carried out its commitments to this point. On top of the additional places that we have been putting on-stream, we have carried out a major evaluation of the attendant care scheme, which, together with the 325 scheme, has been of great assistance to people with severe disabilities.

On the one hand, the attendant care scheme, as honourable members will be aware, means that people from institutions are able to move into the community and lead independent lives with attendant care. On the other hand, the 325 scheme means that people who are in the community but who could live more fulfilling and sustaining lives get additional assistance.

Both of those schemes have been the subject of a major evaluation. I say to all honourable members that that evaluation has been extraordinarily promising. People have been able to live within the community with greater independence, with greater quality of life, and with a great deal more satisfaction for themselves at less cost to the taxpayer. By innovation and creativity we have shown that people who have lived very limited lives are able to live much fuller lives in the community at less cost overall. That is fully in line with the disability services legislation and it is a very clear case where individual people are able to experience enormous joy in living whereas before there was a great sense of restriction.

In the Budget, as honourable members will know, the Government has made decisions that indicate we are moving to expand both of these schemes. We will put into place 200 additional care places with respect to attendant care and 350 additional support places for the 325 scheme. There will be 550 additional places in total.

Mr Speaker, the Government has made a significant commitment to this program. This expansion involves additional expenditure of $32m-a not insubstantial amount of money. The program will provide these people with a much greater quality of life. Compared with the alternatives, it will be an extremely cost effective program and the improvements will result from the evaluation undertaken.
One can understand why the city of Waverley, for example, in the honourable member's electorate, would so enthusiastically support attendant care and innovative disability programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister's attention been drawn to remarks attributed to Senator Walsh concerning Melbourne's bid for the 1996 Olympic Games? Is there factual basis for Senator Walsh's statement? Does his statement alter in any way the Government's support for Melbourne's bid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. Certainly, the remarks of Senator Walsh have been brought to my attention. Let me say that Senator Walsh is speaking for himself, not for the Government, and I entirely repudiate his sentiments. The Commonwealth is happy to support the Victorian bid for the Olympic Games. I will indeed be proud to be a member of the bid team visiting Tokyo next week for the meeting of the International Olympic Committee.

ANSWER.PARA: I welcome the fact that this, again, is an issue on which there is no difference across the Parliament. I welcome the unequivocal support that has been given consistently by the Opposition to the Government's position on this matter. I welcome very much the fact that the Leader of the Opposition will also be in Tokyo playing his part in trying to win the votes for Melbourne. I feel certain that on its merits, Melbourne's bid stands an excellent chance of success.

Let me turn now to some of the matters that Senator Walsh has mentioned. In January of this year my Government agreed to the request of the Premier of Victoria to provide $125m, to be indexed in 1990 prices, towards the construction of a world standard sporting complex at Albert Park should Melbourne be successful. As I understand the position, in that decision the Government has the complete support of the Opposition. I do not think there has been any opposition to that. Indeed, there has been support.

That will be a major new facility. That decision was taken following the investigation of an interdepartmental committee made up of representatives of the Department of Finance and Australian Construction Services which reported on the Victorian estimates. Subsequently, the committee reported that the cost estimates were reasonable, given the scope of the project. Should the Melbourne bid be successful, I am confident that the trade unions will respond positively.

Let me give the House the facts. Early in September an agreement was signed between the Victorian State Government, the Trades Hall Council, the building industry unions and employer groups. That was done to ensure that the planned facilities are built on time and within budget. The agreement signed by all those parties pledged the parties to abide by the disputes settlement procedures laid down under the Victorian building industry agreement. Those are facts.

For one who purports to pride himself on his intellectual astringency, Senator Walsh never lets a few facts get in the way of his well developed prejudices. On its merits, the Melbourne bid deserves to succeed. If it does succeed, it will be of very significant economic benefit for the whole of Australia. If the bid does succeed next Tuesday night, I believe that that will be reason for the overwhelming majority of Australians to have a legitimate cause for celebration. Let it be, for Senator Walsh, another excuse to drown his bitter sorrows.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel: What is the status of legal proceedings against the seaman who was charged with being absent without leave from HMAS Adelaide?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no person in this House who takes as close or as supportive an interest in the affairs of our defence forces as the honourable member for Herbert. In answer to his question, may I inform the House that, following a preliminary hearing, the commanding officer of HMAS Penguin referred the matter of Leading Seaman Jones's actions to the Naval Support Commander, Rear Admiral Tony Horton.

ANSWER.PARA: As the convening authority under the Defence Force Discipline Act of 1942, Rear Admiral Horton has made a decision that Leading Seaman Jones will be court-martialled on the charge of being absent without leave from HMAS Adelaide. Leading Seaman Jones will of course be entitled to legal representation, which will be provided free of charge by a legally qualified officer of the Defence Force in accordance with normal practice. The general court martial will be held at HMAS Penguin commencing on 24 September. The matter is sub judice, therefore, and there will be no further comment from the Government or from the Navy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to the huge losses incurred by the State Bank of Victoria and Tricontinental Corporation Ltd and to the Treasurer's statement on 28 August that the Commonwealth was `not the supervisor' of the State Bank of Victoria. I ask the Treasurer: Is it not the case that, as claimed by the then Victorian Treasurer, Rob Jolly, for some years prior to 23 February 1990 an informal arrangement existed under which, in virtually all respects, the State Bank had a relationship with the Reserve Bank of Australia identical to that between the Reserve Bank and private banks authorised under the Banking Act; that the arrangement was formalised on or about 23 February 1990 and continues to this date; that the relevant prudential guidelines applied to both the State Bank of Victoria and its subsidiaries, including Tricontinental? In light of events, what good purpose did the Reserve Bank-State Bank of Victoria arrangement serve, and what reliance should other States now place on the supervisory arrangements between their State banks and the Reserve Bank?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard a lot of noise from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition on this subject. Early this week he put out a press statement saying:

ANSWER.PARA: When Parliament resumes this week, the coalition will press its attack on the Treasurer over his failure to fully disclose what he knew about the financial difficulties leading to the collapse of the Farrow Group of building societies and also the problems of Tricontinental Group which resulted in the sell-off of the State Bank of Victoria to the Commonwealth Bank.

He then lists a whole series of questions. So important were they that on the last day of the sittings, after questions which often have not been of a high national importance, he rolls in with this question, presumably to satisfy the fact that he has at least raised the issue, having fulminated about it earlier in the week. So at least in the eyes of the media he did not squib it entirely.

Let me say this to the issue at hand: there seems to be a view implied in the question that supervision by the Reserve Bank of Australia will mean that no bank will make a decision which it might subsequently regret commercially; that Reserve Bank supervision means that all banks will perform uniformly; that the Reserve Bank places itself in a position where it is making judgments about corporate business and other categories of lending on institutions.

This of course is not so. The Reserve Bank basically obliges banks to meet certain liquidity ratios and, of course, it discusses particularly large transactions to the extent that they might affect the book of a bank with a bank management. But, by and large, it is a supervisory role to see that the general structure of a bank's book is sound and that depositors are protected. It is not there to see that no bank picks up commercially bad business, because it is not in a position to do that.

The State Bank of Victoria was not formally supervised by the Reserve Bank; it was informally supervised. This essentially involved meeting the Reserve Bank's liquidity ratios and, as the Deputy Leader and shadow Treasurer says correctly, it was only in February 1990 that the then Treasurer of Victoria, Mr Jolley, said he was seeking a more formal arrangement with the Reserve Bank of Australia.

I stress that the reporting by the bank under these arrangements was, of course, entirely voluntary. If the State Bank of Victoria or any section of its operations did not wish to give a true picture of that section's activities, a true picture was not in fact obtained. In fact, the full extent of the Tricontinental losses was unknown to the State Bank of Victoria's own board until about mid-year. So it is naive to claim that a full reporting process, even if in place, would have exposed the full losses of Tricontinental earlier than when I was informed of them on 19 June.

Financial institutions generally obtain a true idea of their bad loan portfolio at their half-yearly accounting periods. I am advised that this is the case with Tricontinental, which is why the initial action was taken in February, and the further bad loans only became apparent later.

As has been made clear in numerous statements by Victorian and Federal sources, it was wide public knowledge prior to June that Tricontinental had suffered significant losses, but the full extent of these only progressively became apparent as the Victorian authorities delved deeper into the affairs of Tricontinental. So it is true to say that I was staggered by the revelations of 19 June that the losses of Tricontinental were approximately double those which had been previously and publicly understood to be the case. So the decision by the Victorian Government to have the Reserve Bank formally supervise the State Bank was made in response to earlier knowledge of the Tricontinental debts, which amounted to only about half of what became apparent by 19 June.

The fact of the matter is that it may become apparent over time that, indeed, there are more losses from Tricontinental. I say this without any knowledge, but again one has to look at the security that the bank held and the values of the assets which were encumbered by it. In a market where asset values have been falling, it is very difficult to tell what the ultimate losses will be or what recovery there may be of those losses over time. So one is not in a position to know, and Reserve Bank supervision cannot possibly be able to countenance those things, particularly when the State Bank board itself did not know the extent of the losses of its own subsidiary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Science and Technology aware of media reports regarding funding for scientific research and the Prime Minister's commitment to make Australia the clever country? In the light of Budget outcomes, can the Minister assure the House of the Government's continued support for Australian science?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, I know of the deep interest of the honourable member for Dobell in this matter and, accordingly, thank him for his question. I can assure the honourable member that the Government does have a strong commitment to science and research in this country, and that commitment is based around a strategy that is built on two fundamental principles: firstly, the need to build our strength, our excellence, in long-term, basic scientific research; and secondly, to better commercialise it, better apply it, so that for this country we get the benefits in terms of competitiveness and solutions to our environmental problems.

ANSWER.PARA: The Budget commits to that strategy in two important ways: firstly, so far as funding is concerned; and, secondly, in regard to the announcement in the initial stage of the cooperative research centre program. In terms of funding, it is important for the other side of this House to understand what the Government's commitment is in fostering the excellence. The last Budget developed a program by which, in real outlays, expenditure on research and science in this country has gone up 2.3 per cent. Since the Hawke Government has come to power, real expenditure has gone up 23 per cent in this area against total outlays of 10 per cent. It is a very strong commitment to prioritising the need to improve our research and science base in this country against the background of very tight fiscal discipline.

The Budget is not the only means by which research and development in this country can be funded. The private sector has a responsibility to put more effort into that area. I am pleased to be able to say, again as part of the strategic framework that this Government has developed through initiatives such as the l50 per cent deductability on taxation for qualified research under programs such as the grants for industry research and development scheme and various industry development programs, that private sector expenditure on research and development has more than doubled. Over the past year there has been a l6 per cent increase. In addition, the Budget spelled out the program for cooperative research centres, a program that will focus our efforts better on getting cooperation between the different sectors of research in this country and getting better linkages with industry. It is the commercialisation and the application of our research and development effort that will be a significant contributor to overcoming our balance of payments difficulties.

It is important to allude to Opposition members in this context. I notice that the shadow spokesperson, the honourable member for Gippsland, is not present in the chamber and that is unfortunate. He has made two statements of recent times indicating where the Opposition's thinking is on science and research in this country. First, in a letter published in the Australian Financial Review in August he indicated that so far as the Opposition was concerned there would be no government support for commercialisation-the very thing that this Government is trying to encourage, the Opposition would knock off. Quite apart from what I might have to say about that, it is revealing to see what the Federation of Australian Scientific and Technological Societies, FASTS, has had to say on two occasions. On the first occasion it said:
If the Opposition does not see a role for government in bringing this about-
then perhaps it does not deserve a role in government,
If the coalition thinks that the problems of commercialisation of research are purely those of macro-economic policies, then do we really need a shadow Minister for Science and Technology?

Well we may ask. The second revelation in terms of the Opposition's thinking in this field is a statement that was made by the Opposition spokesman at a forum that he and I attended in relation to post-Budget matters. In that, he suggested that what this country needs to develop its research and science effort is a full-scale review of the structure in which science and technology research takes place. I do not know where the shadow Minister has been over the past few years. I know that he had this shadow portfolio during the previous Government but the simple fact of the matter is that that effort has already been made. That review has been undertaken. The implication in his statement went also to the dismembering of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, a suggestion that was rejected by the Australian Science and Technology Council report, a suggestion that has been condemned by the CSIRO itself, and a suggestion that has been condemned by the National Farmers Federation.

I say simply that the Government's record is a proud one in terms of fostering science and research in this country. It is the correct direction in which this country should go, but what we have to get better at is the commercialisation and the application. We have the strategy for it and those on the other side of the House do not. What I would be interested to hear from them are constructive comments rather than this nitpicking.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question without notice to the Treasurer. I refer to the collapse of Pyramid Building Society and the other building societies in the Farrow group and ask the Treasurer: On what authority did the Reserve Bank of Australia provide advice to the then Cain Government in relation to these non-bank financial institutions? Did the Treasurer, either explicitly or implicitly, sanction the Reserve Bank's involvement? What was the nature of the advice given by the Reserve Bank and did it include advice, in effect, to let the Farrow group go?

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member is paraphrasing exactly a question that I have had on notice for three weeks. It is the second time that he has done this. I would hope that he would find something original to ask.
—What is the number of that question?
—It is question no. 143.
—I think it would be possible for question No. 143, which has 28 paragraphs, to cover nearly everything that could possibly be asked. The question is in order.
—The number of clauses does not indicate that I should not have received an answer.
—The question is in order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a monstrous slur on the Reserve Bank of Australia by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and his Victorian colleague Mr Kennett to suggest, as he put it, that the Reserve Bank advised anybody to let a financial institution go.
—What advice did you give?
—The honourable member has asked his question. He has taken three days to do it, so he may as well listen to the answer.
—But will you indicate--
—Order! The honourable member for Flinders will cease interjecting.

—The honourable member put all of these questions on paper so I will take him through them and then, if he has anything to say, he should say it by way of a substantive motion instead of making these unsubstantiated smears and slurs against honourable people who are running decent institutions. I will run through the questions posed in this macho press statement by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.
—What about the questions I have just asked?
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—I will answer them as the honourable member has put them. Given the fact that he said that when the Parliament resumed he would put all of these questions to me, I have prepared replies to them. The first question stated:

ANSWER.PARA: Given the Treasurer's admission that he was informed of developments regarding Pyramid `as events unfolded', what did he know about the financial difficulties of Pyramid prior to 13 February 1990?

The honourable member did not ask me that question just now, but I am sure that he will, so I might as well do the lot seriatim. The shadow Treasurer seeks to imply that I knew of the financial difficulties of Pyramid prior to 13 February. That is nonsense. The only advice received by my office prior to 13 February was a minute dated 12 February which referred to an article on Pyramid that had appeared in the Sunday Herald on 11 February which stated that there had been small net withdrawals from the Society. That advice in no way even remotely amounted to knowledge of Pyramid's difficulties. In the event the minute was not even drawn to my attention as it was not considered such a serious issue at the time.
What information about Pyramid was communicated to the Prime Minister and other Ministers prior to 13 February 1990?
Nothing was communicated to the Prime Minister and other Ministers because, other than what had been in the media, there was nothing to communicate. The third question stated:
What input did Mr Keating and/or his personal staff have in the giving of a guarantee of security by the Victorian State Government to the depositors in Farrow Group companies?

There was no input by myself or my personal staff to the Victorian Minister's statement of 13 February 1990. As I described earlier, at that time Victorian officials contacted the Reserve Bank about the status of lines of credit to the Pyramid Building Society by major trading banks. The Reserve Bank told the Victorian officials that-and I quote:

The Reserve Bank has a longstanding understanding with banks that they will consider sympathetically a request for finance received from building societies which are responsibly managed and have adequate asset backing.

These words were included in the statement of 13 February. This is a completely appropriate involvement for the Federal authorities. These contacts were at an official level and I first became aware of the terms of the statement when the statement was released to the media. I repeat: There was no involvement by myself or my office in the preparation of the statement or the decision to make that statement, nor was there any contact between my office and the Reserve Bank regarding the Reserve Bank's contribution to that statement.

What knowledge of the $300 million bail out of the State Bank of Victoria by the South Australia Labor Government (through the South Australian Financing Authority) in December 1989, did Mr Keating have?

I had no knowledge of any advance made by the South Australian Financing Authority to the State Bank of Victoria. Therefore, obviously enough, I had no input in negotiating that agreement. The fifth question stated:
What input did the Treasurer have in negotiating that deal in view of the fact that the Reserve Bank was fully aware and had given their approval for it to proceed?

In regard to the role of the Reserve Bank, the bank had informed me in recent days that it had approved the terms of the capital issue by the State Bank of Victoria in December 1989. It did not approve, nor was it aware of, the source of any subscriptions to that issue. The Reserve Bank would not normally seek that sort of detailed information. As I have stated, this information was provided to me by the Reserve Bank in recent days. It was under no obligation to inform me at the time, nor did it do so.

That answers the questions which have been put to me by the Opposition, including the one just asked about Pyramid. These are put on the basis that somehow everyone has done something wrong here-the Commonwealth Government, the State Government-but the Opposition never mentions the Farrow Group. It was the Farrow Group, which was close to the Liberal Party of Victoria, that was running a property company masquerading as a building society on which, we understand, huge fees were taken by the Farrow Group directors for modest services provided to the building society. It was then taking deposits off the market and people were lending to it at rates of interest which they believed reflected the safety of the institution.

If Opposition members want to attack anybody they should attack the Farrow Group of companies, which has been associated with and close to the Liberal Party, for misleading the public of Victoria, and Geelong in particular. It sought to have people believe that they were investing in a body which lent its funds on to housing where it had mortgaged backed security in the housing market with decent and sensible prudential ratios for the loans. In fact, they were lending to a highly geared property company from which the directors were taking fees.
Why do honourable members opposite not get up, if they want to bash their gums, and have a go at the Farrow Group instead of attacking the central bank?

TALK.START.PARA: —I look forward to a response from the Minister for Small Business and Customs to this, his maiden question. Is the Minister aware of the serious effects on the small, but internationally recognised, Australian manufacturers of high quality outdoor apparel caused by the escalating duty rate on the fabric known as Goretex? Why is the duty on Goretex fabric increasing when assistance to the textiles, clothing and footwear industries is being reduced by the TCF plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out that during the parliamentary inquiry into small business, two companies in the honourable member's electorate, Mont Equipment Pty Ltd and J. &H. Agencies Pty Ltd, did raise this matter with the parliamentary committee. I am also aware that the increasing duty on Goretex fabrics is placing additional pressure on a small but growing local industry that uses Goretex in the manufacture of high quality outdoor apparel. The increasing duty rate arises from the Government's decision on the assistance for textiles, clothing and footwear industries that arose from the Industries Assistance Commission inquiry in 1986. In 1986 there were over 5,000 possible tariff classifications, 50 policy by-laws, bounty schedules and tariff quotas. It was decided by the government of the day to rationalise these barrier arrangements. In this context the number of by-laws were rationalised with the intention of phasing them out by gradually increasing the duty rate to the level accorded other fabrics.

ANSWER.PARA: Overall these decisions by the Government substantially reduce the level of assistance available to the TCF industries and provide the framework for the establishment of a more externally oriented and competitive industry. In the case of Goretex, there were always tariffs on Goretex fabrics. However, these have been removed in the past by a policy by-law as part of the Government's TCF industries assistance plan. Goretex was picked up in this rationalisation and the policy by-law now has phasing rates which increase to the full duty rate of 40 per cent in 1993. The Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority is currently looking to establish a means by which links between the conflicting requests of the outdoor apparel manufacturers and the local fabric suppliers can be reconciled and will shortly report to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to statements made yesterday by the Minister for Community Services and Health calling for the Government to `substantially increase capital expenditure' financed by asset sales. In light of the Treasurer's recent comments about how he has presided over Australia's becoming a poor country, I ask the Treasurer whether he agrees with the Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the honourable member had got the quote right, he would know that I said that Australia is savings poor and it is savings poor because we have been relying on overseas savings for most of the 1980s. We have been relying on overseas savings from 1981, substantially, because of the structural weakness of the economy induced by the Liberal Party when in office. We could not produce enough goods and services, so we had to rely on someone else's goods and services, then pay for them by relying upon their savings. So that is the position with our savings.

ANSWER.PARA: It is this Government which has augmented national savings by reducing the call by the public sector on Australian savings to the tune of seven per cent of gross domestic product or, this year, about $30 billion. We can just imagine what kinds of interest rates would attend a bond selling program which this year added $30 billion of demands to financial markets; the effect would, of course, be quite profound.

What my colleague is saying is that there may be, in certain parts of the Australian infrastructure, places where there is need of more public support. That may well be correct, but it will be attended to with the kind of priority setting which this Government has become synonymous with. We have put in place a set of spending priorities which have been essentially paid for by taking away the spending priorities of former governments, or even our own former priorities. That is how we have attended to this issue.

Assets sales can produce a substantial structural improvement to a Budget because of the long term savings which come from public debt interest. But unlike, say, the Thatcher Government of Britain, we have not changed the Budget balance from a deficit to a surplus by relying on asset sales. We have done it by changes to recurrent government spending. But the structural benefit available to any Budget is from the long term benefit, which is in reduced public debt interest. That can assist in the development of other ongoing expenditure programs. To that extent the Government has used asset sales as a longer term relieving measure to the public debt interest side of the Budget. So there is no particular conflict in policy there, real or imagined.

The House should just bear in mind that the essential problem is that the country cannot produce enough goods and services and the reason for that is that we stopped investing in ourselves from the late 1960s until the middle 1980s. Basically, the main reason for that was indifferent fiscal policy, a hopeless wages policy, and a smashed profit share, all of which produced a great hole in our investment-and the honourable member's Party was responsible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the implications of the signing of the Treaty on the Unification of Germany by the foreign Ministers of the two plus four powers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I am sure the Opposition will join me when I say that the Government and I welcome the historic treaty, which settles the remaining aspects of German reunification, settled yesterday and signed yesterday by the foreign Ministers of both Germanies and the four wartime allies.

ANSWER.PARA: The treaty ends the four occupying countries' special powers over Germany, including the withdrawal of Soviet troops from East Germany by 1994. Importantly, it ensures that existing external borders will be maintained. It is indeed truly the final settlement to World War II. I believe that congratulations are due to the governments and the leaders of both Germanies and to the four wartime allies who, in fact, in seven months achieved what previously could not be done in 45 years.

For generations Europe has been locked behind barricades and it has been oppressed by the threat of hostilities. I believe that it has taken enormous vision, application and dedication by Chancellor Kohl, Prime Minister De Maiziere, Presidents Bush and Gorbachev, President Mitterrand, and Prime Minister Thatcher to bring about a dignified end to the cold war.

The signing of this Treaty removes the last obstacles to unification and allows a united sovereign Germany to take its place among the community of nations by 3 October. I and the other members of the Government welcome unequivocally German unification and it is our wish to see a unified Germany fully and harmoniously integrated with the rest of Europe. We welcome the agreement for a united Germany to be a full member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation in the context of the new relationships that exist between NATO and the former Warsaw Pact partners.

During the last year we have seen the fall of the Berlin Wall and the dismantling of Checkpoint Charlie and we see an unprecedented momentum towards the development of a new Europe. That is important not only for the countries and the people of Europe but also for the world. It is essential that these opportunities now be pursued with energy and vision, and I can assure the House that Australia will continue, as it has already been doing, to play an active role in the international community to support an open and free Europe.

TALK.START.PARA: —What advice did the Treasurer seek or was he given by the Reserve Bank of Australia in late 1988 when he approved the sale of the Australian Bank Ltd to the State Bank of Victoria's Tricontinental Corporation Ltd, a transaction which effectively gave Tricontinental access to a trading bank licence? What further information did he seek or was he given when that transaction was ultimately blocked, apparently by the Reserve Bank, in May 1989?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a curious line of questioning from the Leader of the Opposition. He has asked about three or four questions this week; he is almost the invisible man in the Parliament, but curious press statements come from his office and claims and charges come from the Leader of the Opposition himself. In one press release he mentioned `theatrically contrived crises'. He went on:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . each of which has had to be dealt with by Paul John Keating pulling on his yellow raincoat and zooming in to the rescue in his Betsy. . .Boy! What a script. Dick Tracy could not ask for more.
In my office we call this the Dick Tracy press release.

There are more. They go on and on. Some mention the State Bank. I remind people that in talking about Tricontinental, the Leader of the Opposition said that it was clear that this was a Victorian problem which should have a Victorian solution. That is, he said that an insolvent institution with about $25 billion worth of assets, with about 30 per cent of the deposit base in Victoria, should have a Victorian solution to its problems. He did not think that the Federal Government or the central bank should be involved in seeking to avert an enormous and major financial crisis in the State of Victoria affecting most of its citizens. For shabby political purposes, he alleges that it is a Victorian problem; therefore,the public of Victoria should wear the possible collapse of its largest financial institution and somehow the Commonwealth should stand back. I hope that Victorians understand what the Leader of the Opposition thinks about their welfare.

This line of questioning goes to the matter of Tricontinental and the Aust- ralian Bank Ltd licence. I would have been consulted about that; I remember the issue coming past me. I also remember the fact that I communicated with, I think, the State Bank of Victoria about it. But it chose not to use the Australian Bank licence in the end because Tricontinental could not meet the prudential standards required by the Reserve Bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —This was May 1989?

—I cannot remember what date it was; I can find out. But so what? We said, `You can use the Australian Bank Ltd if you want to turn Tricontinental into a bank, something which has the title of bank, which is a title conferred by the Reserve Bank of Australia'. It then apparently found that it could not use Tricontinental, that it would not meet the asset ratios required of a bank and it decided not to use it. That was its business; it had nothing to do with us. What the jokers opposite think they can read of that, God alone knows.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. As last Saturday was International Literacy Day, can the Minister indicate any undertakings which the Government has made to ensure that the commitment to the goals of International Literacy Year will continue beyond the end of this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I hope he will appreciate the brief answer with which I will provide him. Indeed, this has been International Literacy Year and Australia has been making a very significant contribution to the international year, not only here in Australia but also within our region. The national consultative committee that we established decided that there would be four major areas of its work, adult literacy being one, child and community literacy being another, overseas literacy another and public awareness another.

ANSWER.PARA: During the course of this year the national consultative committee has been very successful in bringing Australia's attention to the perhaps disguised problem of functional illiteracy amongst a relatively large number of Australian people and particularly drawing attention to the consequences of that in the work force and the economy generally.

During the remaining months of the committee's work it will be finalising its recommendations to us about what specific action should be taken by the Government to address some of these important issues. I want to say particularly that because we realise that the committee has done a good job and needs to continue its work, this Budget decided to extend its activities during the first half of next year and provided it with three quarters of a million dollars with which to continue its work.

In the context of this Budget we provided an additional $4.5m for each of the next three years to increase the programs available through technical and further education colleges and community organisations to address the problem of adult literacy. We have also provided $7m for assessment and provision of literacy services under the early intervention component of the active employment strategy as well as $3.3m to deal with literacy issues in skill share programs.

We recognise that this is a problem confronting Australians of all ages. It is something which needs to be dealt with not only within the education system as we are doing but also amongst the adult population and through the work force. In relation to that we have sought and achieved the support and cooperation of the trade union movement and employers. I think that those in the work force who recognise that they do have difficulties as far as their English literacy skills are concerned can look forward to a greater number of services and a greater diversity of services to assist them to overcome these serious problems.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the House take note of the paper.
