DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a received a letter from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The growing need for a wage fixing system based on true enterprise bargaining.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition brings this matter of public importance to the Parliament today appropriately enough because the Australian Industrial Relations Commission reconvened in Melbourne this morning on the application of the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Australian Chamber of Manufactures to hear the current national wage case. It gives to the Opposition and the Parliament an opportunity to say something about the relevance of the current wage fixing mechanism to Australia's economic problems. It also provides the Opposition with the chance of dealing once again with the big lie of the Australian Labor Party and the trade union movement about the history of wage fixation in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: One of these days a political commentator in Australia will write a series of articles under the general title of `The Myths of Paul Keating'. We got one of those myths today in Question Time, and I take the opportunity at the commencement of this speech to deal with it. That myth is that the current account deficit, which is the biggest single economic problem besetting Australia at the present time, is a product of economic mistakes in the 1970s. I say in reply to that, as I will say with equal relevance in reply to the big lies about wages policy, that it is a very instructive claim by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I have in my possession a document called The Australian Macro Economy in the 1980s. It is the transcript of the proceedings of a conference of Australia's best economists convened every few years by the Reserve Bank of Australia, an institution that we were told in Question Time was a great and decent financial institution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Above criticism.

—Above criticism, looking after the interests of the Australian people. There is a very interesting footnote in the introduction. The introduction says how during the 1980s the current account deficit became the great preoccupation of government and of policy makers in Australia. The footnote says that by contrast the current account was not included in the top 10 facts from the summary of the 1979 conference. In other words, the conference held 10 years earlier deemed the current account deficit as an economic problem not to be worthy of listing in the top 10 facts that were relevant to the Australian economy.

SPEECH.PARA: That particular myth of the Treasurer, of course, pales into insignificance compared with the great myth in relation to wages policy in this country. That, of course, brings us to present day circumstances. At the moment the course of action being pursued by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), ironically enough, bears many of the hallmarks of the union campaign in 1981 that ultimately led to the wages break-out of 1981 and 1982.

TALK.START.PARA: —Supported by the ACTU.

—That campaign was supported by the ACTU. It was supported by the then President of the ACTU, Cliff Dolan, and by the then Opposition spokesman on industrial relations, the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

SPEECH.PARA: What is happening at the moment is very simple. The ACTU has temporarily put the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to one side. Martin Ferguson has said the Commission is irrelevant for the time being. In other words, its relevance will return in the future. The ACTU is going into the field and attempting to get from employer groups wage settlements on an industry by industry basis-and that point is very important.

The ACTU will then go back to the Commission and say, `We have got this wage settlement in the field. Will you please put a rubber stamp on it'. As a result, under the principle of comparative wage justice, which is at the heart of the centralised wage fixing system, those agreements will flow through the entire economy. They will be imposed upon every employer in the country, whether the employer can afford it or not, and the ACTU will have the result that it wants.

The interesting thing about that process is that it bears great similarity to what happened in 1981. In 1981 the metal unions went to the Metal Trades Industry Association and extracted an agreement which was rubber stamped by the then Conciliation and Arbitration Commission as being in the public interest, and it then flowed through the whole system.

Of course, the economic conditions now are different from what they were in 1981. In 1981 the economy was not in as deep a recession as it is now. In fact, in 1981 the level of economic activity was still very buoyant, although by 1982 and 1983 that situation had changed. I readily acknowledge that.

It is important, as we examine what is happening with wage fixation in Australia, that we understand the great similarities, both structural and procedural, that exist between what the ACTU is now doing and what it did in 1981. At the moment the ACTU is trying to peddle the line-and Bill Kelty is the worst culprit-that in some way what the ACTU is now doing is an exercise in enterprise bargaining. It is not an exercise in enterprise bargaining. I am sorry to say that this misunderstanding is widely repeated by most industrial relations writers around Australia, who seem to accept as holy writ the definition of industrial terms put forward by the ACTU and by the other members of the industrial relations club.

An enterprise bargain is not a bargain struck collectively across an industry; it is a bargain struck between the owners of an individual enterprise and that enterprises's employees-either collectively or individually or by the appointed agent or representative of those employees. That kind of bargain is a world away from what happened in 1981, and it is a world away from what the ACTU is now proposing. I say here that I pay tribute to the resolution that has been displayed by the Metal Trades Industry Association on this occasion, although I acknowledge that the MTIA is no fan of my industrial relations policy and probably never will be. At least it is being consistent on this occasion. It rejected accord mark 6 at the beginning of the year and it has gone on rejecting it.

The major employer groups should now be going to the ACTU and saying, `Well, if you really want enterprise bargaining, why don't we try to reach some agreements under section 115 of the Industrial Relations Act?' That provides for certified agreements, which is as far as they can go under the present Government's policy to have an enterprise bargain. I will wager now that if the employer groups did that the ACTU would run a mile. It would say, `No, we're not interested in that'. The ACTU is not interested in enterprise bargaining of a true nature because once we have enterprise bargaining of a true nature the role of the ACTU and of the organised union movement is significantly reduced. That, of course, is what this campaign by the ACTU is all about. It is all about the role of the ACTU in the industrial landscape in Australia in 1990 and for the rest of the decade.

Right at the moment, I believe that the potential to achieve major change in Australia's industrial relations system is greater than we have had at any time since the end of World War II. Anybody who examines it ought to be very careful about making comparisons between now and the early 1980s or the mid-1970s because the world has changed completely. To start with, there has been a change in the legal balance between employers and employees because of the effect of cases such as Dollar Sweets and Mudginberri; the operation of section 45d; the fact that less than a year ago a former President of the ACTU, the present Prime Minister of Australia, exhorted the airlines of this nation to sue a trade union. He exhorted them, he told them, he begged them. He said, `Go ahead and sue it'. That would have been unheard of and unthought of five years ago when Hancock reported and said it was impossible to make ordinary unions accountable to the ordinary courts, that we could not really expect a union to take any notice of a decision of an ordinary court. Yet five years later President Hawke himself said, `Go out and issue writs against the union'. That shows the extent to which industrial relations in Australia has changed over the last 10 years.

Even more importantly than that, what has really changed is that the organised trade union movement, as with other organisations, including organised political parties, has a lesser grip on the hearts and minds of individual Australians than it used to have. The biggest problem that Bill Kelty and Martin Ferguson will have in the 1990s is holding on to their members. The ACTU in the 1990s will face a continuing crisis of legitimacy. It now represents only 32 per cent of the private sector work force in Australia, and increasingly it is having difficulty controlling some of the more intelligent unions as well as some of the more militant.
This morning I read in the Australian newspaper a comment I shall quote because it is very relevant to what I am talking about-the declining legitimacy of the ACTU:

What we promise is increased efficiency and that our people will work smarter. In response we need a commitment that a reasonable amount of money made in profits will be invested back into the company or industry to ensure good working conditions and up-graded technology, so as to ensure longevity of the business.
We also demand job security, that jobs won't be thrown away for any but the strictest economic reasons. And we are prepared to negotiate wages.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—That was a statement by Steve Harrison, the National Secretary of the Federated Ironworkers Association. Whilst I would not agree with everything in it, it is a mile away from the ramblings of Martin Ferguson. It is a mile away from the ramblings of some union leaders, who are so out of touch with reality that they do not understand that the ordinary workers of this country resent the fact that their real wages have declined by 15 per cent over the last six years and that this campaign of the ACTU owes a great deal to the fact that the ordinary rank and file of the trade union movement are very unhappy with what has happened to their real remuneration over the last six years.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason wages have declined-and I acknowledge that the decline in real wages has made a contribution to employment growth; I know that there is a link between the two-is that we have had an appalling productivity performance over the years of the accord, and what the Government effectively has done with its economic management is to substitute a wages blow-out with a foreign debt blow-out. In fact, if the Government had followed a different economic policy, it would not now be faced with the enormous foreign debt crisis which is the ongoing preoccupation of all of us.

What this country needs now more than ever before is a change in its industrial relations culture to a new culture that does not exclude trade unions, that does not go back to the days of `them and us', but is dedicated to one overriding principle. That principle is that the most important thing in the industrial world of the 1990s is not the success of the trade union movement, the industrial relations establishment or the employer organisations but the success and profitability of each and every individual enterprise around Australia.

The only way we will ever build national productivity in a way that will enable us to overcome our enormous debt problem is to build the aggregate productivity of every individual enterprise in this country. That will come only through an industrial relations system which puts the enterprise first, and there is only one side of politics in Australia that has the commitment to that, has the political freedom to achieve it and has the dedication to do it when elected to government-and that is the Liberal and National parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I address the attempts of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) to rewrite history, both in respect of the current account and wages. When the honourable member for Bennelong was the Treasurer he maintained that there was no current account problem. If he looks back at the economic records of this country, he will find that in 1981-82 the current account deficit was 6 per cent of gross domestic product. The current account and balance of payments problem did not begin with this Government. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said many times in this place, it was something which we inherited from the previous Government, for the reason that he has given-that is, the mismanagement of the previous Government, which for decades did not build competitive industries to compete with imports and win export markets.

SPEECH.PARA: When we came to office that current account deficit had been reduced somewhat from the previous year, but that was because we were in the worst recession for 50 years. Structurally, we had this enormously damaging factor in the Australian economy of the current account deficit, which was there as a result of the policies pursued for decades previously, including the years when the honourable member for Bennelong was the Treasurer of this country. That was the first attempt of the honourable member for Bennelong to rewrite history.

His second attempt to rewrite history related more directly to the topic of this matter of public importance, which is wages. The honourable member for Bennelong says that in 1981 similar things happened to what he sees happening now-that is, attempts by the union movement to go out and get employers to agree to give a certain level of wage increase, take that agreement to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and then have it flow through the Commission. I do not deny that that was largely what happened. However, there is an enormous dissimilarity between that and what is happening now. The enormous dissimilarity is that we are now operating on the basis of an accord, to which the trade union movement is still absolutely committed-and the Australian Council of Trade Unions has certainly not in any way suggested that it is walking away from that accord-which says that for this financial year there will be a wages outcome of 7 per cent. The wages outcome at its peak in 1981-82 was 17 per cent-an enormous wages blow-out which effectively blew the Fraser Government out of office.

Because there was no accord, because there was no understanding between government and unions about wages policy and because it was left to the market to sort out, that is what happened. The great difference that has occurred in this Government's period in office has been that, from the very first day, a wages policy has been in place that has ensured we have rational wages outcomes, outcomes which until recent times have produced the fastest rates of growth of any country in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), and certainly have produced a much faster rate of growth in employment than in any other country. Real unit wage costs have fallen by about 10 per cent in our period in office. That is an enormous turnaround compared with what happened during the term of the coalition Government, when real unit wage costs increased by several per cent.

We are looking at a totally different set of circumstances in regard to wages. Whatever one makes of what is happening at the present time, no one can claim credibly that it is a similar situation to 1981. The honourable member for Bennelong claimed that that was the situation, but he can in no way do so credibly. We are now taking a further step along the path of a relaxation of what has been largely a centralised wage fixing system-highly centralised in the first years of this Government's period in office and becoming a little less centralised as we have gone along, especially taking that step towards some greater decentralisation with the award restructuring approach, which essentially has put a lot of activity back into the enterprise, and I stress that. As part of the accord mark 6 a further step is being taken along that path, putting more of the emphasis back at the enterprise level.

Before I come to speak about what is happening now, I shall remind the House in further detail of what has happened in terms of developing wages policy at the enterprise level. In the wages policy before the current one, that is, the one relating to the first and second tiers, there was a clear attempt with the second tier to try to get a lot of activity at the enterprise level, to achieve the wages outcome. That resulted in a lot of enterprise level activity to cover the wage costs, to get Commission endorsement, and resulted in the establishment in many cases of consultative committees at the enterprise level. That indeed was a welcome development and certainly a substantial step towards having more activity at the enterprise level rather than the central level, but at the same time within an overall framework established by the Commission, flowing from the accord and with principles established and set out in detail by the Commission.

With the award restructuring we moved to a system where there is much greater flexibility available at the workplace, where through award restructuring there is multiskilling of the work force and wide classifications, instead of the very narrow type of classifications, so that management can use its work force much more flexibly. That was a development that was greatly welcomed and was a great challenge to management to use that tool of increased flexibility at the enterprise level, which it had not had before, certainly not this century. In addition to that development of a more flexible use of the work force in that broad sense, in many awards there have been changes made both to those awards and at the enterprise level that have enabled the introduction of greater flexibility.

I shall not take up too much time of the House to go into detail. Let me say simply that in regard to award level variations there has been an expansion of the span of ordinary hours, a common variation in a number of industries, inclusion of a provision for 12-hour shifts; several awards have been varied to allow for time off in lieu of overtime; there have been changes introduced to allow overtime to be used more flexibly; penalty rates have been changed to become less restrictive. In addition, there has been the introduction of part time work and the removal of restrictions on the use of casual employees. All of those have been changes at the award level. There have been also enterprise flexibility variations of different kinds.

The metal industry award-the largest award of all and therefore, I guess, the most important-has been varied significantly to provide more scope for key working arrangements such as 12-hour shifts, meal rest periods, timing of annual leave and scheduling of close-downs to be determined at the workplace level. When it is agreed to at the workplace level, this then overrides the provision of the award. This is enterprise level flexibility of a very substantial kind-and that is in the largest award of all. But it is in many other awards as well as part of the award restructuring process. So in the last few years there has been-and I think it has been totally unrecognised, certainly in public statements by the relevant Opposition spokesman or anybody else that I have noticed-a very substantial increase in the degree of flexibility at the work place level brought about by the wages policy that has been developed over recent years.

I think that that is welcomed by all. We certainly want to see a more flexible system and we want to see an enterprise being able to develop the use of its work force in a way which suits both the employees and management in the particular circumstances that they face. Those changes have not been greatly related to the actual level of wage increases at this stage, but in accord mark 6 we are now moving to a stage where the actual level of wage increase can be determined at the enterprise level to some degree.

Accord mark 6 has these features. It involves two general increases, the first of which flowed on to the consumer price index increase for the September quarter this year and the second of which, another $12 increase, will occur six months later. In addition to that, 3 per cent additional superannuation will be flowed-in over a two-year period beginning not before May next year. Furthermore, increases will be able to be achieved at the enterprise level and there will be a relaxation of what has been the central feature so far-the no extra claims principle-so that there can be enterprise level wage increases based on achieved productivity or profitability. That is the key element of change in accord mark 6. It is a very significant change and one which the Government supports within the context of a responsible wages outcome. As I said, this year that figure has been set at 7 per cent.

In the submission that the Commonwealth is making at the preliminary hearing of the national wage case-which hearing begins today, as the honourable member for Bennelong mentioned-we will be making it clear that we support accord mark 6 and we support enterprise negotiations for wage increases. Of course, as part of accord mark 6 it was also acknowledged that there would need to be framework negotiations with employer organisations and unions at the outset. We have had that and that has been happening in recent times. Negotiations have taken place between unions and employer organisations, as was agreed would happen in the context of accord mark 6, to try to get some greater agreement about the principles which will apply to wage fixation at the enterprise level.

Accord mark 6 also states that those principles will be eventually established by the Commission, rather than by agreement of the parties. We want to get agreement initially by the parties-that is not unusual; negotiation by the parties prior to a national wage case hearing has occurred several times since we have been in office as well as in previous times-and these negotiations are designed to get some greater agreement on the principles before the case starts.

Once the case begins and the Commission comes out with its principles, everybody will be able to proceed on the basis of enterprise negotiations on clear principles established by the Commission. That is, indeed, a very rational and sensible way to go. If I may make a prediction for the future, I expect that we will see more and more of the wages outcome determined in that way and less and less of it determined by across the board general increases such as the two that I have mentioned as being in accord mark 6.

We are in an evolving situation, and we are evolving in a very responsible way towards a much more flexible system, with much more of the wages outcome being determined at the enterprise level. Compare that with the Opposition which, as in most cases, has an extremist view-a view which totally sidelines it from the realistic debate. In relation to general economic, telecommunications and wages policies, the Opposition is right out there in the right wing field-so far out that it is just totally irrelevant to the debate.

The employer organisations do not want to have anything to do with the Opposition and neither does the union movement. Most of the commentators think the Opposition is way out there in cloud-cuckoo-land. Obviously the Opposition has no concept of what is needed to control wages. The Opposition's period in government proved that. The man who is laughing and giggling away at the table-the honourable member for Bennelong, the Treasurer of this country under a previous government; the man who presided over a 17 per cent wage increase in 1981-82-now sits back thinking he has all the answers. His attitude is, `Just let it all happen out there again, just like it did before. Let them all have enterprise level agreements. It will all be terrific and we know we will get a responsible outcome from that'. How does the Opposition know? The Opposition has no idea of what the outcome would be-absolutely no idea.

The only way that the Opposition would control that outcome would be to keep the economy chloroformed to a degree which would mean that there would never be any growth in this country. There would never be the kind of growth that we have seen in this country in the past seven years. The Opposition would have nothing like that. The only way that the Opposition knows how to control wages-as it showed when it was last in government-is to chloroform the economy periodically; then take it off; then let it all blow out again; finish up with double digit inflation and double digit unemployment. That was the Opposition's record, its terribly sorry record-the record with which the Opposition is permanently doomed and which means that the people of Australia will think very hard and long before they ever allow the Opposition back on the government benches.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House has just heard a `steady as she sinks, more of the same' speech from the Government. But I do not think anything could more epitomise what is wrong with industrial relations and wage fixing in this country today than what is happening in this very Parliament-the centre of democracy. It is not possible even get a business paper printed. We cannot even get the Daily Hansard printed. It is happening all around the Government and it cannot see it even yet. The Government is still trotting out the same message.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to honourable members opposite that the Government's success in the years it has been in office is very limited indeed, if not non-existent. The only thing the Government has had success at is at the ballot box because up until this stage it has been able to con people with promises of lower interest rates; promises of lower inflation; promises that no child will live in poverty by 1990. I wonder what the date is? Government members might have a look at the calendar and what is going on out there in the street. For instance, we had promises about no capital gains tax. While the rest of the world is passing the Government by, it is continuing with the same.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had more ballot boxes then.

—Yes. Interest rates have gone down in other countries. Inflation in other countries has dropped to half of what it is in Australia. Wage fixing methods have been tidied up and fixed up in other countries such as Germany, the United States of America and Japan, whereas Australia is continuing to labour under its antiquated system. The good years of commodity prices and buoyant world trade have been wasted. Instead, Australia has been drifting in a sea of indecision so that today we have arrived at a situation where Australia is virtually paralysed simply because every time the Government makes a decision, it virtually guarantees 60 per cent or more of the delegates who decide these things have to be trade unionists. This is what Australia is labouring under.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has centralisation of power and privilege in Canberra and with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), when the rest of the world, including Eastern Europe, is washing socialism, thankfully, out of the system. Australia today is an anachronism. Admittedly the Government has had some public relations success-our football loving Treasurer (Mr Keating) is still terrorising Caucus and the press, telling them that he is having great success, when he is getting failure after failure after failure.

We have the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) dropping so rapidly in the opinion polls and getting so desperate that he is now claiming as his friend-who would it be?-Margaret Thatcher. Twice in recent weeks, the Prime Minister has claimed, `Margaret Thatcher is my good friend'. If the Prime Minister would only look over his shoulder, he would see that all the backbenchers have their arms around Fidel Castro and Joseph Stalin. That is how bad things are.

Australia has had seven and a half years of this Government and what has it delivered? It has delivered lower living standards to the tune of $50 or $60 a week and unemployment. One of the Government's supposed successes is now skyrocketing. Since Christmas an extra 90,000 people have joined the dole queue. Earlier today during Question Time, the Treasurer blamed everybody-I thought he was even going to name Brutus the Dinosaur-for the failed policies of the Government. The Government has inflation stuck between 7 and 8 per cent; interest rates still up at 15 to 20 per cent or more; and even wage fixing-the jewel in the crown-is turning out not to be a sparkling diamond but cheap glass indeed.

Australia has a band-aid Government. No decision this Government takes is taken for the right reason. Look at uranium: what would the Prime Minister's favourite word be? Would it be `hypocrisy'? The uranium policy is only in place to pacify the Left, or what is left of it. The Treasurer has just put in place a fuel freeze. Why was that put there? It was put there so that the consumer price index figures could be put in place for the next wage fixing round.

Now we have the wage fixing policy. It has nothing whatsoever to do with the best interests of Australia; nothing whatsoever to do with the best interests of the workers; and certainly nothing whatsoever to do with the best interests for the employers who pay the bills. However, it is all to do with the best interests of this Government and ACTU power.

Each wage decision that has been brought down in this country under this Government has been a centralised wage decision where the employers have not been consulted. There has been no regard whatsoever towards that magic word `productivity'. Now that the system is starting to crack and break up, the Government is bereft of ideas. So what can the Government do? It cannot have another summit; it has had so many summits, it is getting embarrassing. The Government cannot have an inquiry-the Premier of Queensland has a monopoly on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —They might have another election.

—Yes. They might have another election. That would be a revelation indeed. When one turns on the radio in the morning and listens to the dulcet tones of the present leader of the ACTU coming over the airwaves, it is like a step into the past. The most alarming aspect of it, I am told, is that he actually believes what he says. The chamber is now half full on the Government's side with ex-ACTU presidents. I hope we do not have another one.

SPEECH.PARA: Look at the record of the Prime Minister in business. He ran Bourke's store and we know what happened to it-it went broke. He took on ACTU Travel and it went broke.

TALK.START.PARA: —ACTU Solo.

—Solo petrol is in trouble and now he is running Australia. I wonder what is happening to it. If we go out and talk to the people in the street and they will tell us. We have an ex-ACTU president here. They had to shaft the poor old member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) aside to give that ex-ACTU president a guernsey.

SPEECH.PARA: The two words that are lacking in the Government's wage fixing policy are `logic' and `freedom'. Those are the words missing from the Government's vocabulary. The Government is not doing things because they are right for Australia. Look at the wage fixing rigidity Australia has today at the very time the country is crying out for flexibility and decentralisation of agreements at the enterprise level.

I put it to the Government that it should recognise that the workers of this country are human beings; they are individuals; they have their own rights and they have different priorities. Instead of wanting to round them all up into a herd, like they used to do in Russia until recently-they still do to some extent-and if anyone stepped out of line, `bang, that is it; you do not get a job; you are persecuted' why can we not have a bit of freedom in this country today? This is what we want in the world. When the Opposition gets into power, one of the first things we are going to do is abolish compulsory trade unionism. That will go.

For some reason, the Australian Labor Party (ALP) is frightened of freedom. It does not matter that opinion polls say that 87 per cent do not want compulsory unionism, including an overwhelming majority of trade unionists themselves. They still want to force people into their mould. It might suit the ALP. It might suit the ACTU, but I tell the House this: it does not suit Australia.

Why do the ALP and the ACTU not do something for Australia's benefit for a change? Let us consider strikes. We are going to bring in secret ballots, but they will not have a bar of it. What do secret ballots do? They just find out what the workers genuinely want themselves. Is that such a dreadful thing? We are going to decentralise the decision-making processes with wages and grievances. We are going to abolish the days of closed shops and preferences to union members. Instead of rule by terror, we are going to give the workers what they want, in other words.

Civil courts will come more into play. Common law will be used for damages claims. We are going to encourage profit sharing and share ownership so that the workers themselves can have a slice of the action instead of what we have had in the past-the worker versus the boss mentality-which has been encouraged and rammed down our throats night after night on our television screens.

Individual agreements will be allowed to come into place. The employer will be allowed-surprise, surprise-to negotiate with the employee if he so wishes. What is so wrong with that? We will encourage these people to be paid on an hourly basis and that will put back into the system a bit of incentive for productivity. If people want to work a 30-hour week, so be it. They will get 30 times the hourly wage. If they want to work a 40-hour week, they will get 40 times the hourly wage. If they want to work a 50-hour week, they will get 50 times the hourly wage. They can work at night, during the day, on weekends, or whenever they want. It puts a bit of freedom back into the system.

Another thing we will do is eliminate secondary boycotts and get rid of the intimidation and thuggery that we see too much of in this country today. The Government has failed totally in the wage fixing area. It is tired, too outdated, and oppressively dominated by trade unions. It is time to free up the system and recognise for the first time in this country the rights of workers. It is time to give enterprise bargaining in Australia its rightful place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) noted that it was timely that we were speaking because of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission national wage case hearing today. It is timely in so far as the hearing itself represents a total repudiation by the Confederation of Australian Industry and other employers of what he is saying. While he is howling in the wind about section 115 of the Industrial Relations Act and saying that employers should utilise it for enterprise agreements, they have just told him, quite frankly, to get lost. They have indicated that all of this extremist, non-mainstream thought of industrial relations is not for them. They have to deal with these people in the long term. They cannot just come here, dish up a few slogans and walk away from them. They will actually have to operate in the industrial relations sphere. That is the first thing we have to realise when we talk about how timely this debate is, because it represents a total repudiation of what the honourable member for Bennelong said.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member put the historical context of two of his statements in a better light. When he made some kind of way-out analogy between 1981 and 1982 he very well knew that the aggregate total of 7 per cent for this period is a totally different picture from what occurred in 1981-82 when the system, it could be said, did not show enough flexibility. Those things were out of control and the Government had no input into where the wage pattern was going. As the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) indicated, that certainly was a very big contribution to the downfall of the Fraser Government.

The other very selective reference made by the honourable member for Bennelong was to a comment by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) with respect to a report put out by a meeting of economists convened by the Reserve Bank of Australia. He did not say that the current account deficit was not a problem. He did not actually go to the figures and establish that it was not a problem. He said that when they were looking at the economy, at that time it did not feature as one of the top 10 issues. That does not mean that they were wrong. That does not mean that things have not changed, that analogies 10 years later might say that something happened incorrectly at another time. That quote has nothing to do with whether the current account deficit was a problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't quite follow that. Have another go.

—I think the honourable member can understand it. As I say, it was a very selective quote. In recent times he has shed a lot of crocodile tears for the poor workers out there and what they are suffering. On 12 September he said that he understood the unhappiness of ordinary employees with the current wages outlook. On 3 September he said that ordinary wage and salary earners in Australia were realising that they had been taken to the cleaners by the accord. All these crocodile tears, all these concerns, about what has happened to wage earners! Of course, supposedly it will be solved by a very small minority of them struggling and actually accomplishing some kind of wage increase based on productivity in a small minority of enterprises. That is the reality.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst there has obviously been a reduction in wages share, as opposed to profits, in this country, whilst, as the honourable member says, workers have suffered, whilst the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) has been prepared to take a responsible attitude over the last few years in regard to our trade problems, people are suffering. That is the major point, but his resolution of this is to introduce a series of voluntary agreements.

In New South Wales we saw a legislative pattern of the kinds of things intended. The real scheme behind this supposed new freedom, this new right to do this and that, is to reduce the adult minimum wage to $294.10 and to eliminate the automatic right to arbitration. The policy is to ensure that fairly under-staffed, under-resourced groups of workers without information negotiate on a supposedly equal footing with their employer. What a lot of twaddle!

The actual reality of all this talk about freedom and how people are going to gain so much through productivity, et cetera is, as the honourable member says in a recent press release, a situation that reflects the reality of industrial relations at the moment, the fact that the unions are on the back foot. That is the reality of trying to introduce these kinds of measures to smash the union movement, to smash workers' rights.

It would seem from what the honourable member has been saying that the Government has sat on its hands for the last few years, that nothing has happened in regard to voluntary agreements, that the Government wants to tie totally the centralised wage fixing system with no variations. He knows very well that is not factually correct. He knows that in actual fact there is a transitional period at the moment in regard to industrial relations in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —The transient period, is it?

—That is correct-a transient period of industrial relations. We have seen the efforts by the Government in workplace reform programs, the actual assistance for research and pilot programs, employment of advisers, et cetera in respect of the work change assistance scheme, the workplace resources scheme, work change training schemes-actual initiatives by the Government about what is going to happen at the enterprise level, what is going to occur.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member well knows, despite the fact that he did not mention it, there has been a particular loosening up of a number of agreements, a number of awards, in areas such as overtime, penalty rates and weekend rates. It is occurring. What he is saying, in contrast, is that there cannot be a structured, negotiated process between employers. He wants to come in smack down the middle and destroy the whole system in one go because of some ideological predilection. He well knows that in mark 6 of the accord there is a place for productivity bargaining as long as it keeps within the 7 per cent total package. As I said earlier, that is a totally different situation from what happened in 1981-82.

As the honourable member deplores the poor lot of the workers, it is probably worth getting back to what has actually occurred during this period. Unemployment has been massively reduced. It is all right for him to come down with the latest month's statistics. They look pretty good compared to their performance in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't even mention them.
—It was mentioned in the honourable member's press release. It seems that he does not write them.
—I didn't mention them today.

—I am referring to press releases of recent days in which the honourable member for Bennelong made some reference to what happened in the June quarter. As I indicated, the actual deterioration of the employment pattern in this country is still massively better liked than the performance of the honourable member. More than 1 1/2 million jobs have been created, yet the honourable member talks as though the whole country were collapsing. That is the reality of the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The very great downturn in industrial disputes over the period of the Hawke Government does not count for anything either, apparently. We have recent statistics for those disputes. The figure for working days lost in the month of May is the highest monthly figure since July 1989, admittedly, but the average number of working days lost per month has fallen by 54 per cent-a fairly significant reduction since the Fraser Government period.

We are all bemoaning how serious the situation is, yet the trend in this country is for a 10.5 per cent decrease in labour unit costs. The trade union movement has worked with the Government, recognised the problems and is moving in stages toward a greater decentralisation of the wage structure and in the way decisions are made. The trade union movement has cooperated in regard to restructuring and has shown increased flexibility on a variety of fronts relating to industrial conditions.

The union movement is facing difficulties because of the loss of membership and other pressures on it. This situation represents a very good opportunity to ensure that wage conditions are reduced even further and this is the reality behind all the concerns, these throwaway lines, about the fact that the workers are discontented and that people can half understand their worries. This matter of public importance ignores the reality that much is happening in the union movement. It ignores the accord that is leading toward decentralised procedures for wages, and that is the reason why it should be rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The discussion is concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the following finance minutes on reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts: Department of Finance Minute on Report 302, `Engagement of External Consultants by Commonwealth Departments'; Finance Minute on Report 303, `Review of Auditor-General's Efficiency Audits-Department of Defence: Safety Principles for Explosives and RAAF Explosives Ordinance'; and Finance Minute on Report 305, Review of the Finance Minute on Report 270-`Implementation of the Offsets Program'. I seek leave to make a brief statement in connection with the minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tabling of these finance minutes today reflects the ongoing concern of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts about the accountability of the Executive to the Parliament. Arrangements to ensure that appropriate action is taken in response to comments contained in the Committee's reports have been in operation since 1952. The arrangements have been that after a report by the Committee is tabled in the House of Representatives and the Senate the Chairman of the Committee forwards a copy of the report to the responsible Minister. A copy is also forwarded to the Minister for Finance, together with a request that the report be considered and the Chairman subsequently be informed of actions to address the Committee's recommendations. The reply, in the form of a Department of Finance minute, is then examined by the Committee and submitted, with comment if necessary, as a report to the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: In its report 291, `Revised Procedures for Reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts', which was tabled in this place in June 1988, the Committee advised that it would consolidate the tabling of all finance minutes into one annual report, the only exceptions being finance minutes that were urgent or lengthy or which for some other reason required immediate reporting to the Parliament. The Committee tabled a consolidated volume of finance minutes for the first time in November last year under the chairmanship of the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), now Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

This consolidated volume of finance minutes was the Committee's 301st report and, not surprisingly, was entitled `Finance Minutes'. In this report the Committee noted that it intended to continue the practice of tabling all finance minutes received in a particular year within one annual volume but that it also intended to make each finance minute available to Parliament as soon as practicable after it is received by the Committee.

Importantly, the reason for this action is to facilitate the process of accountability. This action involves a slight revision of the procedures for handling finance minutes outlined in report 291, which referred to only an annual tabling of finance minutes. The Committee believes that the overall process of accountability is aided by the prompt tabling of the finance minutes. This gives parliamentarians and the public an opportunity to comment on the adequacy or otherwise of the responses of departments to particular concerns and recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee. In turn, the Committee can only benefit from taking account of such comment when it considers the finance minute in detail at a later stage. The tabling of these minutes should not be taken to mean that the Committee is satisfied with the contents of them, as the Committee reserves the prerogative of conducting a detailed analysis of particular finance minutes at a later time.

As the House would be aware, there have been instances in the past when such analysis has led the Committee to a further formal inquiry. I stress the fact that, while detailed analysis of a particular finance minute may follow rather than proceed its tabling, this does not indicate that the Committee has reduced in any way its oversight of the responses to the report or indicate any reduction in the importance with which the Committee views the actual finance minute process.

The finance minutes I have tabled today deal with recent reports of the Public Accounts Committee, as I have outlined. I would like to take the opportunity very briefly to thank the members of the Committee. It is a very hardworking committee and has a very strong feeling of bipartisanship and duty to work on behalf of the taxpayers of this country. I would also like to take the opportunity of thanking the very hardworking and dedicated staff of the Public Accounts Committee for their many long hours of detailed thought and analysis in conjunction with the members of the Committee. I commend these three finance minutes to all members of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works I present the fifty-third general report of the Committee and the sixth report of the Committee for 1990 relating to the dedicated computer centre for the Australian Taxation Office, Bruce, Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Committee's fifty-third general report covers the activities of the Committee during 1989. It was, as always, a very busy year for the Committee. Twenty-six reports were tabled. This is the highest number of reports that the Committee has presented on domestic projects. The estimated cost of the proposals reported on by the Committee in 1989 was $1.1 billion. Sixty-eight meetings were held to conduct public hearings, carry out inspections, consider reports and other matters.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of matters of concern to the Committee were raised in the report. First, there is the question of consultations between the departments or authorities and organisations or individuals who may be affected by proposed work. Far too often the consultative process is perceived as tokenism. The Committee believes meaningful consultation within realistic timeframes is essential during the development of any project.

Secondly, there is the question of the provision of child-care facilities in Commonwealth office buildings. The situation now is that departments are able to provide child-care centres for employees subject to cost-neutral and accountability guidelines. This, the Committee believes, is a step in the right direction.

Thirdly, there is the question of environmental reviews. The Committee would like to reiterate what has been a longstanding practice. Any assessment of the environmental impact of a proposal should be completed before a proposal is referred to the Committee.

I would like to pay tribute to all members of the previous Committee who worked very hard throughout 1989. Senator Glen Sheil and Mr John Mountford have left the Parliament and I am grateful for their support during their service on the Committee. The honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) and the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) were also members of the Committee and are now Whips of their respective parties.

Special mention should be made of the former member for Wide Bay, Mr Clarrie Millar, who, as Vice-Chairman of the Committee, was an example to us all for his dedication to the work of the Committee. I should also to thank the hard-working secretariat, especially the Committee's Secretary, Mr Peter Roberts.

The Committee has concluded that there is a need for the provision of a new computer centre for the Australian Taxation Office at Bruce, Australian Capital Territory. The proposed new centre will have an area of 6,300 square metres encompassing two levels. The mainframe computer will be on the upper level, while a number of support activities will be on the lower level.

The Committee found that the need for a dedicated facility stems from a number of factors including a need for the Taxation Office to operate computer systems at two sites, the nature of existing facilities, especially at the Parkes site, and the modernisation program now under way within the Taxation Office and the non-availability of alternative accommodation.

In recommending that the work proceed, the Committee believes that the Taxation Office and Australian Construction Services should review the requirement for dual independent power supplies to the building in view of the provision of substantial backup facilities.

The Committee also focused attention on the question of the energy efficiency of the building. It was claimed that energy efficiency and management would be a prime consideration. The report notes that whilst measures will be included to produce an energy efficient building, there was no evidence of the magnitude of cost savings which these measures could produce. The Committee therefore gives notice that the inclusion of design and engineering principles designed to improve the energy efficiency in new buildings will be kept under careful scrutiny. I commend the reports to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Brisbane Air Traffic Services Centre.

My colleague the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) has endorsed a proposal by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) to establish an air traffic service centre in Brisbane. The advent of satellite communication technology has provided the Civil Aviation Authority with the ability to centralise and rationalise airspace management over Australian and surrounding oceans to a number of strategically located centres.

The new centre is a vital component in the CAA airways productivity investment program as it will enable upgraded radar data to be displayed at new radar display consoles. It will also provide the necessary accommodation to permit consolidation and rationalisation of remote air services units into Brisbane.

The proposal being referred to the Committee will provide the necessary floor space to accommodate replacement radar displays as well as the functions currently provided by the existing Brisbane flight service centre and the flight service units at Charleville, Mount Isa, Weipa, Cairns, Townsville, Rockhampton, Dubbo and Coffs Harbour.

The proposal is to rehabilitate the former Australian Airlines domestic terminal building located at the old Brisbane airport. The CAA has purchased 14 hectares of the airport, including the former Australian Airlines building, to enable it to ultimately consolidate and collocate all its off-airport activities at the one location. This proposal will be the first facility for this new CAA site. All future development will be independent of this proposal and subject to separate approvals.

The current proposal will provide a main building and adjoining annexes with a total floor area of approximately 6,000 square metres comprising 2,000 square metres of an air traffic services operational and support area. The central and largest single element will be the operational centre itself. All other areas will support this element. The operational training facility will be incorporated within this area. It will also comprise a 2,300 square metre technical services and support area. The equipment and maintenance areas are the important central elements of the technical services support facilities. They will include the required service-loading bay access and air handling areas.

The 1,100 square metres of services area will contain the electrical and mechanical equipment, including standby generating sets and air conditioning plant. There will also be a 600 square metre administrative support and social facility. This zone will contain amenities, as well as the focal point for public access to the centre. The administrative office will be immediately adjacent to the entry reception area.

The CAA's estimate for the proposals, including allowances for contingencies and fees is $9.7m at June 1990 prices. The proposal is being referred to the Committee at the schematic design stage as part of the CAA's fast-track implementation strategy which seeks to maximise economic benefits while honouring an undertaking given to the industry and industrial organisations. I table the drawings of the proposal and commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Mr Speaker, this Bill is the Government's next major piece of anti-avoidance legislation. It contains provisions to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to give effect to the proposal, as announced in the economic statement of April 1989 and subsequent press statements. It will introduce an accruals system of taxing foreign source income that has been derived in low-tax countries by Australian controlled entities and has been accumulated offshore, avoiding Australian tax. Exemption proposals in the Bill will also simplify the existing foreign tax credit system (FTCS). The Bill will generally have effect from the 1990-91 income year.

An exposure draft of this Bill was released in June of this year following release of an initial draft in December last year. This Bill before the House is essentially the same as the June draft Bill. Many taxpayers and tax advisers who have an interest in the proposed legislation have provided constructive comment in response to the various policy documents and drafts of the legislation released over the last two years.

As a consequence of this consultative process, quite a number of significant changes were made between 1988 and 1990 to accommodate legitimate major concerns. For example, the control rule and active income exemption provided in the Bill were not policy features of the consultative document released in May 1988.

These and other policy changes have added considerably to the length and complexity of the Bill, but in general they have been made to take account of the genuine concerns expressed by those Australians to whom the legislation will apply.

There were some proposed changes that the Government could not accept because they would have left untouched tax avoidance opportunities the Government is seeking to close, or were inconsistent with the policy underlying the existing foreign tax credit system. The Government is firmly committed to these measures which will help significantly in the fight against tax avoidance.

For the great majority of Australians, those who do not have investments in offshore trusts and controlled foreign companies, this legislation will have no direct impact. There will be some beneficial effects for business in the exemptions and simplification of the FTCS. Development of a comprehensive system for taxing foreign income has been under way for some time. Under the law as it existed before this Government introduced the FTCS, Australian residents were exempt from tax in Australia on their foreign source income provided that income was taxed overseas, even if the income was subject only to a nominal rate of tax.

As a first step towards removing the bias that had encouraged Australians to invest in offshore tax havens rather than in their own country, this Government introduced the foreign tax credit system commencing from the 1987-88 income year. The system enables foreign income to be subject to Australian tax when it is remitted to Australia, with a credit being allowed for any foreign tax paid. It was acknowledged in the 1985 tax reform papers that the tax leakage through the use of tax havens would be closed off only if the FTCS was supported by a regime for taxing foreign source income derived in low-tax countries and being diverted and accumulated offshore in foreign companies and trusts. A number of other countries, including the United Kingdom, the United States, Canada and New Zealand have already introduced similar measures to tax foreign source income on an accruals basis.
I will now turn to the more detailed aspects of the Bill.
Controlled Foreign Companies

The main feature of this Bill is the controlled foreign company measures. Their aim is to attribute to Australian residents, with some exceptions, certain income derived by a non-resident company that is controlled by Australian residents, unless the company is subject to a tax system comparable to Australia's or is predominantly engaged in active business.

A foreign company will be a controlled foreign company, or a CFC, where five or fewer Australian residents own, or are entitled to acquire, 50 per cent or more of the interests in the company. The interest of a resident for this purpose will include both the direct and indirect interests of the resident and those of the resident's associates. Alternatively, a non-resident company will be a CFC if five or fewer residents have actual control of the company regardless of their shareholdings.

There is a difference between the treatment accorded to non-resident companies in listed, that is, comparable-taxing, countries and unlisted countries. Even where a non-resident company in an unlisted country is controlled by a small number of Australian residents, its income or gains will not be attributed if the CFC's `tainted' income is less than 5 per cent of its total income. In other words, the measures will not apply if the CFC is predominantly engaged in active business.

However, if it fails the test, the tainted income of the CFC will be attributed to the relevant Australian residents. The other income is not attributed and will be subject to Australian tax under the FTCS generally on remittance to Australia. With CFCs resident in listed countries, low-taxed income may be attributed to certain of the CFC's Australian shareholders where it is tainted income that benefits from a tax concession of a kind that is to be prescribed by the income tax regulations and fails the active income test; in other cases the income is from sources outside the country of residence that is not taxed by any comparable tax country; or the company derives certain categories of trust income.

The countries that are to be treated as comparable tax countries, and the concessions that are to be treated as designated tax concessions, will be listed in the income tax regulations. Tainted income includes the types of income that are readily able to be shifted to a foreign tax jurisdiction. These consist of passive income-such as dividends, interest, royalties and most kinds of gains on the disposal of assets-and business income from transactions with Australian residents and related parties.

The assessable income of a shareholder who is an attributable taxpayer will include the taxpayer's share of the attributable income of the CFC for an accounting year of the CFC that commenced on or after 1 July 1990 and ended during the taxpayer's year of income. In most cases the residents who will be taxed are those who, alone or with associates, directly or indirectly hold an interest of 10 per cent or more in the CFC as at the end of the CFC's accounting year.
Foreign Tax Credit System

The introduction of the accruals tax measures provides an opportunity to simplify certain aspects of the existing FTCS. Accordingly, with effect from the commencement of the 1990-91 income year, an exemption is to be provided for non-portfolio dividends received by Australian companies from companies resident in comparable tax countries. A dividend will be a non-portfolio dividend where the Australian company that received the dividend has a voting interest of at least 10 per cent in the foreign company. It will not be necessary that the foreign company be a CFC.

Further, the Bill provides that a dividend received by an Australian company from a company resident in an unlisted non-comparable-tax country will be exempt where the dividend is paid out of income that has been comparably taxed in a listed country or income that has already been included in assessable income in Australia. Generally, other dividends are to continue to be assessable and subject to relief measures along the lines of the existing FTCS.

The FTCS will also be modified to exempt from income tax, with effect from the commencement of the 1990-91 income year, the income or profits of a resident company derived in carrying on a business at or through a permanent establishment located in a listed country, except to the extent that the income or profits was not taxed (or is concessionally) taxed by any listed country.

Income of a resident company derived at or through a permanent establishment that is not located in a listed country is to continue to be subject to income tax, as is any branch income derived by a non-corporate taxpayer. Where foreign tax has been paid on branch income which is still assessable, a credit will continue to be allowed under the FTCS.

A number of technical amendments to the FTCS will also be made generally to accommodate the interaction of the accruals tax and the existing FTCS. These relate mainly to the definition of the classes of income, exemption of dividends paid out of attributed income, carry-forward of excess credits, and quarantining of losses and credits.
Non-Resident Trusts

Another significant feature of this Bill is the transferor tax measures. These attribute income of non-resident trusts in low-tax countries to Australian residents who have, either directly or indirectly, transferred property or services to the trusts.

In the case of a discretionary trust that was in existence on 12 April 1989, an exemption from these measures will be available to a transferor if neither the transferor nor an associate of the transferor was able to control the trust on or after 12 April 1989. In this context, the term `control' is given a wide meaning.

The attributable income of a non-resident trust estate that is not a resident of a listed country is to be the whole of the net income of the trust. In the case of a trust that is a resident of a listed country the attributable income will be limited to that part of the net income of the trust that benefits from a designated tax concession. In both cases a deduction will be given for certain amounts that have been, or will be, subject to full taxation in Australia or in a listed country.

A deemed rate of return based generally on the value of property or services transferred to an offshore trust will be included in the assessable income of the transferor where the Commissioner is satisfied that the transferor is unable to obtain the information necessary to compute a trust's income according to Australian tax law.

Attributable income of a trust estate that has been included in the assessable income of a transferor will be exempt from tax in the hands of a beneficiary to whom that income is subsequently distributed.
Additional Tax on Certain Trust Distributions

To the extent that a resident beneficiary's assessable income for the 1990-91 or subsequent income year includes a distribution by a non-resident trust estate of income of previous years that has neither been attributed to a transferor nor taxed to the trustee or a beneficiary at tax rates comparable to Australia's, the beneficiary is to be liable, in certain circumstances, to pay an additional tax in the nature of an interest charge in respect of that amount. This measure will achieve a parity with resident trust estates, the net income of which is liable to tax either in the hands of the trustee or the beneficiaries in the income year it is derived. The charge is to be formally imposed by the Taxation (Interest on Non-resident Trust Distributions) Bill.
Additional tax in respect of income that accumulated in a non-resident trust prior to the beginning of the 1990-91 income year of the trust will accrue only from 1 July 1990.
Certain Family Arrangements

The transferor tax measures will not apply in relation to an offshore trust that is solely for the benefit of family members in necessitous circumstances or is a family arrangement established under a court order following a divorce or separation. The beneficiaries of these trusts should all be non-residents.
Winding up of Existing Trusts

As an incentive to wind up non-resident discretionary trusts that were in existence on 12 April 1989 and to which a resident had transferred property or services prior to that date, a rebate of tax will be available so that the rate of Australian tax on distributions of income made after 12 April 1989 and before 30 June 1991 does not exceed 10 per cent. The rebate will apply only if all of the trust's accumulated income and corpus are distributed, and the trust is wound up before 30 June 1991.
Keeping of Records

An attributable taxpayer in relation to a controlled foreign company or a non-resident trust will be required to keep records that show how the CFC or transferor tax measures apply to the taxpayer. Generally, the records must be maintained for five years.
Information held Offshore

The Bill will authorise the Commissioner of Taxation to issue an offshore information notice in respect of information or documents held offshore. The proposed measures give 90 days to comply and the Commissioner can extend this time limit in special circumstances. Where the information or documents are not supplied there is no provision for a penalty or prosecution. Rather, the information or documents may not be used by the taxpayer as evidence to dispute an assessment. The approach adopted in this provision is similar to that taken in United States and Canadian tax laws and is aimed at ensuring the timely provision of all the information and documents needed by the Commissioner to get the full and correct picture of the transactions being examined.

In view of the significance of such a provision, the operation of proposed section 264a will be kept under review to ensure that its objectives are met and that the rights of affected taxpayers are adequately protected.
Changes from Draft Bill

I should mention that the Bill varies in some respects from the draft that was released in June 1990. The broad thrust of these changes is to remove tax avoidance opportunities and provide relief in certain circumstances where double taxation could have occurred due to the application of the proposed measures. Some of the amendments relate to cases where double taxation could have arisen on a change of residence of a CFC or in relation to transfers of profits between companies. The amendments reflect the willingness of this Government to address genuine taxpayer concerns on an ongoing basis.

However, the Government is committed to the measures contained in this Bill as they will ensure a more equitable tax system. The Government is also committed to ensuring that these measures operate as intended.
Not all of the announced changes have been included in the Bill. The Government intends addressing the most urgent of these in an amending Bill to be introduced late in the Budget sittings.

Some of the amendments are the result of the close monitoring of avoidance techniques that are being developed to frustrate the intent of the proposed measures. An example of this type of amendment is the redefinition of a non-resident family trust that is to be exempt from the accruals tax measures. Similarly, the exception from the deemed dividend provisions provided earlier for the investment by a CFC in the share capital of a wholly owned subsidiary is to be withdrawn if that subsidiary is being used to provide designated benefits to its associates.
Mr Speaker, implementation of these measures will require consequential amendments to two other Acts.
Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953
The Bill will amend the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953 as a consequence of the changes to the classes of income that are to apply for the purposes of the foreign tax credit system.
Taxation Administration Act 1953

The Bill will also amend the Taxation Administration Act 1953 to ensure that a person cannot be prosecuted in respect of a statement made in a document produced to the Commissioner in response to an offshore information notice or under the active income test substantiation provisions.
Financial Impact

The likely direct revenue gain resulting from the introduction of the accruals system of taxing foreign source income is difficult to determine. This is particularly so in the initial years because of the variation in CFCs' accounting periods and taxpayers' years of income; the branch exemptions; and the tax exemption for non-portfolio dividends received by resident companies from a company that is a resident of a country with a tax system comparable to Australia's.

Estimating is made more difficult because it is not known to what extent non-resident discretionary trusts will be subject to the transferor tax measures or to what extent resident controllers will take advantage of the 10 per cent final tax liability by winding up before 1 July 1991.

While the revenue gains in 1990-91 are not expected to be significant, it is anticipated that the direct revenue gain will increase to within the range of $60m to $70m in 1993-94 after the full impact of these measures takes effect. In addition, the domestic tax base is expected to increase but the revenue impact cannot be quantified at this stage.
I present the consolidated explanatory memorandum for this Bill and the Taxation (Interest on Non-Resident Trust Distributions) Bill 1990.
I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Peacock) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION (INTEREST ON NON-RESIDENT TRUST DISTRIBUTIONS) BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Crean, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will impose an interest charge on non-resident trust distributions that are included in the assessable income of a resident beneficiary where the trust income has neither been subject to tax on a current basis nor on an attribution basis under the transferor tax measures of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income) Bill 1990. The interest is to be calculated by reference to the provisions of this Bill. Accordingly, I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Peacock) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 September, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I was interrupted yesterday by the lunch adjournment, I posed the question: what has been the Government's response to the inquiry into small business, the so-called Beddall report? I was particularly interested to find out what the Government's response was in that area of government regulation that most concerns small business, that is, its taxation recommendations. When the Beddall report came out the Government claimed that it was committed to the enacting of those recommendations. The Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall), as I understand it, placed his ministerial career on the line if those recommendations were not to be implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: With this Budget we saw only three of a total of 66 recommendations acted upon, and I would like to refer briefly to those. Recommendation 28, which asks that the Australian Taxation Office reduce the remittance frequency of sales tax for qualifying small business from monthly to quarterly, formed the cornerstone of this Government's entire small business Budget strategy. As I said yesterday: big deal. This token gesture was limited to small businesses with sales tax bills of less than $50,000.

The second recommendation which the Budget picks up was even less significant, with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) generously raising the threshold of small businesses annual rather than monthly remittances of fringe benefits tax from $1,000 to $3,000. This was another token gesture. Finally, we have the exemption from sales tax of computers used in manufacturing. This is extracted from recommendation 31 in the Beddall report, which recommends that the system of exemption from wholesale sales tax be reviewed and simplified. What has the Government done with this recommendation? It has thrown a review of the entire system into the too hard basket and offered a small panacea, another token response.

What about the report's call for a public and comprehensive review of the wholesale sales tax system? Or the recommendation which suggests that capital gains tax be deferred on the capital gain realised on the sale of a trading business which is rolled over into another? Or the recommendation which calls on the Government to undertake a fundamental review of the provisional and company tax system as it applies to small business? What of these recommendations and the others not directly related to taxation matters that provide the guidelines which will allow small business to flourish?

A recent survey by Arthur Andersen and Co. conducted among 2,500 small businesses found that there is a confidence crisis in the small business sector, with all companies surveyed finding it almost impossible to maintain sales revenue and profit levels. Most companies surveyed have recorded a drop in profit averaging 10 per cent over the last 12 months, and most small businesses expect that the domestic economy will contract over the next 12 months.

The Treasurer seems to have an uncanny ability to overlook the issues that really matter, the ones that could make the difference. Another glaring example of this is the lack of recognition given to tourism in this year's Budget. If the Government's token gesture for small business was a slight to the vital contribution it makes to the economy, then the treatment of tourism was insulting and showed incredible lack of forethought. Tourism is Australia's largest and most rapidly growing industry, earning $6.5 billion in foreign exchange last year. Unless Australia allows for expanded overseas promotion, we will be losing an opportunity to increase those export dollars and take a bigger share of the international tourism market than the very small share we now have.

Tourism is also our largest and most labour intensive employer. This should have special significance with unemployment rates increasing last month for the sixth month in a row and now reaching an annual average figure of 7.3 per cent. The potential of the tourist industry is staggering and largely untapped. Yet despite this and despite the former tourism Minister, the Hon. John Brown, calling for a Budget allocation of $100m for the Australian Tourism Commission, what do we get in the 1990-91 Budget? An allocation of a mere $40m, which was relatively the same amount that had been allocated for the previous two years. This is lagging terribly by world standards. Even the Government of Greece spent $150m last year on tourist promotion. Spain spent $105m and Tunisia spent $47m. So Australia is lagging behind even those countries.

What amazes me is that, despite the prominent role that the tourism industry plays in this economy, it receives no protection, no subsidies and relatively little direct assistance. In fact, of the amount the Government outlays in direct industry assistance, tourism receives only 2 per cent while manufacturing gets 18.7 per cent and agriculture gets 61.5 per cent.
