While the tourism industry neither seeks nor needs protection or government handouts, it makes sense for the Government to view its Budget allocation to the Australian Tourist Commission as an investment. While it keeps getting a continued return, it must reinvest to secure even greater returns for the future.

My electorate of McPherson encompasses Australia's tourist capital, the Gold Coast. There are many small businesses there and in other tourists destinations around our country which rely on business generated by visiting tourists. The Government's policies, its failures in economic management, its disastrous performance over the last seven years, have exacerbated the problems that most small business in tourism areas have encountered since last year's airline dispute.

In the time I have remaining, I would like to make a short comment about another deficiency in the 1990-91 Budget in the context of the comments of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in recent times about Australia being a clever country. In the light of the fact that even today the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean) was attempting to justify during Question Time the Government's performance in respect of his area of responsibility, I find it interesting that once again the Government has treated shamefully the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). We find the Minister paying lip service only to the important role that CSIRO plays in the Australian economy and the Government once again is draining its budget by stealth each successive year.

As we begin a new decade and look towards the future, people desperately want to know where Australia is heading. They desperately want leadership, but this Government's policies are devoid of any positive direction. They are ideologically outdated, and the Government's 1990 Budget is a sad reflection of this outdated ideology.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Before I call the honourable member for Page, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Mr H.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am Harry Woods and I am the new member for Page. As a businessman the north coast of New South Wales was good to me, and I am here because of that-to do my bit for the people of the north coast, particularly the people of Page, who had the confidence to elect me.

SPEECH.PARA: The electorate was named in the 1984 electoral redistribution after the founder of the Country Party and former Prime Minister, Sir Earle Page. For the past 28 years it was held by the National and Country parties. The only former Labor member was Frank McGuren in the early 1960s. He died earlier this year, and I pay tribute to the service he gave to the people of the electorate. I acknowledge the efforts of the President of the Senate, Kerry Sibraa, in keeping the Australian Labor Party a strong force on the north coast of New South Wales in recent years.

Page is in the north-eastern corner of New South Wales in an area generally known as the Northern Rivers. Its major towns are Grafton, Casino, Ballina and Maclean, and there are many smaller inland and coastal towns and villages. The industries are mainly rural, but the coastal towns are experiencing high growth figures through tourism and the settlement of retirees. Most people find the climate of the Northern Rivers to be ideal-neither too hot nor too cold, but sometimes a little wet. It really is a beautiful part of Australia, and it is a constant source of amazement to me that this city of Canberra was not sited there-maybe at Rappville, Whiporie, Copmanhurst or one of the many other beautiful parts of my electorate. I can assure honourable members that they would be a lot happier if Canberra had been sited up my way; I certainly would be.

Everything would seem to be rosy, but there are problems and challenges in the Northern Rivers which are probably representative of many other rural areas of Australia. There are problems of very high unemployment and very low average incomes. These problems are accentuated in the Aboriginal community, and efforts need to be made for the advancement of Aborigines in my electorate. Discrimination does still exist and every effort should be made to change people's attitudes towards Aborigines, especially in regard to their employment. At Baryulgil, Aborigines live and play amongst the tailings of the town's former asbestos mine. It covers the streets and is in the school and pre-school playgrounds. It is in the air they breathe and the water they drink. It really is wrong, and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner), during a recent visit, agreed that all levels of government should be doing everything in their power to make improvements. Thankfully the Federal Government has started to do so.

The coastal towns of Ballina, Evans Head, Iluka, Woolgoolga and Yamba are popular tourist spots and have become increasingly popular retirement towns. With their rapidly expanding population of aged people, it is essential that their future needs be catered for. The inland towns of Grafton, Casino, Dorrigo and Kyogle suffer from negative or low population growth. Many of the problems they face can be traced to recent State Government cutbacks to services. One of the greatest hardships of these towns is that many people have to leave their families to find work or further their education. Country people have always faced hardships, and readily do so. But, as a Government striving to create a nation of equality, we should be making efforts to better their lot.

There are some disadvantages that country people should not have to face. In some of the major towns of my electorate the medical practitioners have joined forces and conspired not to bulk bill patients. They would not get away with it in a metropolitan area, where bulk billing is a success and on the increase. What many of the doctors are doing is lining their own pockets at the expense of pensioners and others who can least afford it.

There are two reasons for that: one is political motivation and the other is greed. They expound other motives, but they are just trying to create a smokescreen. People on low incomes in these areas really need protection from this type of exploitation. Really, if we look at it properly, it is in this nation's interests to improve the lot of country people. The hard part, of course, is to identify services which will provide ongoing benefits for these areas without costing an inordinate amount.

In my electorate we have primary and secondary industries which are efficient and innovative-for example, the sugar industry. In the mid-1970s CSR Ltd dumped growers because it thought it was making insufficient profit. With the help of the former member for Clarence, Don Day, and the State Labor Government at the time, the growers bought the mills, introduced efficiencies and operated a profitable cooperative. When this Government rightly signalled the end of trade protection for sugar producers, the growers of northern New South Wales broke their traditional ties with the Queensland Sugar Board and decided to refine and market their own product. A refinery was constructed at Harwood in record time, and the growers are now reaping the results.

We also have the biggest permanent fishing fleet in Australia. It is worth about $20m annually to the economy of the Northern Rivers. But there are problems. The present marketing system where prices are controlled by only a few people has resulted in fishermen getting lower returns than they should. Fishermen have little say over the environment that provides their income and holds their future prospects, namely, the rivers and the ocean. Many have large investments in boats and equipment and years of work in the industry but now find it difficult to make a living. The siltation of the rivers because of clearing upstream and particularly steep areas is of great concern to the industry. Fishermen are unable to get the taxation benefits available to other primary producers, and even within the industry there are anomalies, such as the ability to get a rebate on diesel fuel used for fishing but not on petrol used for the same purpose. The fishing industry, which has supported the Northern Rivers and other country areas of New South Wales so well over such a long period, really needs the support of this Government with policies to ensure its viability into the future.

Many of our primary and secondary industries, though efficient, are not working to their capacity. Much of the problem is getting the goods, many of them for export, to markets. The problem is recognised by this Government. It is recognised by the recommendations of the national freight initiative and by the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) through his interest in improving road links to major markets in the area. It is also recognised by the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall), who visited the area recently and agreed with me that there was a need to reclassify the port of Clarence as a port of first entry.

It is only by facing up to the challenges with positive policies that the problems of these country towns can be overcome. Lasting improvements do not come by one-off incentives by local councils for cheap land and the like; they come by improving access-that is, the roads, rail and ports-to those inland and coastal towns. These are the sorts of improvements needed in Page and in many other country areas.

Of course, the question comes easily: Why are these things not better now on the north coast of New South Wales? Why are the roads not better? Why have the ordinary people I represent not had these improvements before? During my election campaign I asked those questions of the people of Grafton, Casino, Yamba and other areas in my electorate. They told me that it was not something that had happened in the past five or 10 years but over 20, 30 or 40 years.

Crook government services and infrastructure developed over many years. It is right that roads are built to last more than five years and ports are long term projects, as are railroads. The crook treatment we got was because of the style of representation we had received over a long period. The gripe of north coast people was the same as those involved in the Boston Tea Party, where the chant was, `No taxation without representation'. They were paying their taxes at the same rate and under the same conditions as everyone else, but they were being short-changed on the representation side. That was true of State and Federal representation for the area and was plain for all to see. It was true on the north coast of New South Wales and is still true in some other areas of country Australia.

Even my most vocal political opponents agree with me that an unhealthy and undesirable political atmosphere had developed on the north coast because one political party had exerted complete political dominance in the region for a very long time. This unhealthy atmosphere was demonstrated in the recent Independent Commission Against Corruption inquiry which heard evidence of political bribery on the north coast of New South Wales. In Queensland, where the National Party dominated the scene for decades, evidence of political bribery was heard in the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct. This was the result of complete political dominance, of no political balance.

Many of my mates at home are members of the National Party. They are good people and completely honest, but they are disappointed. They are disappointed because the leaders and their representatives in the National Party have let them down. I am here as proof of that-and so is the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Newell).

The National Party was found wanting in its policy of promoting a huge pulp mill on the north coast on behalf of a foreign company in direct defiance of the known wishes of the people of that area. But its absolute stupidity knows no bounds. The National Party has recently resurrected an old goer to satisfy its bankrollers west of the range. Once again, it wants the northern rivers to be diverted to the west. This is despite negative reports in the past and the obvious opposition of north coast people and the cost to industries such as fishing and tourism. Let me tell honourable members now on behalf of the people I represent that I am totally opposed to the Clarence and Richmond rivers flowing west instead of east.

The National Party record on the environment is atrocious. The people know it, the Liberal Party knows it and we know it. The Labor Government has the runs on the board in regard to the environment; but we must not simply be happy with that. We have an ever-increasing ability to examine scientifically the results of actions we take, and we must use that ability to make informed decisions. With careful analysis we can make knowledgeable decisions and come up with proposals that will have a minimal effect on the environment but great benefits for the population. We must not lose sight of the need to leave this country fit for supporting further generations of Australians. Thorough examination of proposals, of costs and benefits where substantial damage is likely, is absolutely necessary. It is essential for the future of the timber industry on the north coast that the areas to be logged are defined and that logging is sustainable. In other words, we need to know the size of the resource and the rate at which we can harvest it.

I have grave doubts that the timber industry in New South Wales operates on a sustained yield basis. If we are to look forward to a long term, vibrant timber industry, harvesting must be done on a sustainable yield basis. In the past there has been overcutting, and it is debatable whether that is not still happening. It is in the interests of the timber industry and the workers in it that we are absolutely sure timber will be there to cut in the future. My doubts about this are well founded. The head of the Forestry Commission of New South Wales, Dr Drielsma, on 3 August admitted that the Forestry Commission is technically not working on a sustainable yield basis. He said that the forests of New South Wales were drastically overcut during the postwar decades. His Assistant Commissioner, Mr Fisher, said that sweetheart deals between politicians and timber millers had led to areas being cut that should have been left.

If we are to protect the long term prospects of timber workers, timber harvesting must be sustainable. It does not matter how big or small the resource is; if it is not being cut on a sustainable basis, it is not a long term proposition. This must be done in a way that takes into account the overall requirements of the environment. By doing this openly we can resolve conflicts in the timber industry. Most people do not realise that we have on the north coast of New South Wales a substantial woodchip export industry; but it is operating without any environmental assessment. I assure the House that the majority of north coast people are rightly concerned about the effects of woodchipping operations on the north coast. Environmental impact statements need to be done in this industry. That will be in the long term interests of the industry and the jobs that it provides.

The people of the north coast of New South Wales do not want a five-star concrete strip created on their coastline. The Nationals created that type of development in Queensland, and it is now largely owned by overseas interests. We want development that allows our rivers and beaches to retain their natural beauty. In the long run that will be a far greater attraction for tourists than high-rise apartments and glitzy casinos. Above all, our Government's development policy should reflect the needs and wants of the people it will affect.

The largest private employer in my electorate is the Northern Cooperative Meat Company Ltd in Casino. It is operated by beef producers of the district, who are concerned about developments in the industry, particularly vertical integration by foreign firms, which buy into every level of the industry-from farm to abattoir, to packer and exporter. Those firms are able to export much of their profits, to the detriment of Australia, and to compete unfairly with Australian meatworks. The management of this cooperative is also gravely concerned about excessive overseas ownership of meatworks in Australia.

While talking about foreign ownership of Australia, I should say that there is a growing concern among ordinary country people about foreign ownership of real estate. Many of them believe that our children will pay the price. Many foreign investors are interested only in speculative capital gains. That is not to the nation's good, as often it locks up finances that could be used for real purposes. Surely foreign ownership could be on a leasehold basis, which would encourage real investment. That could be done without compromising Australia's standing as a world trader.

Earlier I spoke of the need to improve the infrastructure, particularly roads, rail and ports in country areas. These things are essential if we are to make lasting improvements for country people. The handicap experienced by country areas relates to lack of easy access to markets for their products. If those barriers can be broken down, country Australia will thrive and Australia will thrive. Of course, the necessary ingredient in new or improved roads, rail or ports is capital, and large amounts of it. That raises the question: where does the money come from? We have to consider the best way to use the capital assets of our nation. Should the capital of public assets be tied up in facilities that can be operated just as well by private enterprise or is it better to invest that capital in facilities in which private enterprise cannot or will not invest?

By nature many assets of this country are the domain of government. They will not be renewed or improved by the private sector. Prime examples of these are roads, rail and ports. The benefit to our exports from providing those facilities are just as tangible as investment in such things as airlines, though not as easily quantifiable. It is on that basis that this Government should consider transferring its investment from those things the private sector can operate to those which only the Government can. We can use the finances saved in this way to rebuild the infrastructure of this country, which has been allowed to slip over the past 30 or 40 years. The choices we make must be made on the basis of financial benefit to Australia. Country areas will be among the main beneficiaries if decisions are made properly.

I bring to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on a bipartisan basis the support of the vast majority of the people of Page for his and this Government's stand on the crisis in Iraq. History warns of the price of inaction, and to allow Saddam Hussein to control a large slice of the world's oil reserves would be tantamount to selling our children into slavery. Saddam Hussein must be stopped.

I am proud to be here as a member of the Australian Labor Party. I am proud of the achievements of the Hawke Labor Government. I am proud of Medicare, Skillshare and of programs for the disadvantaged and the elderly, and the wages accord. I am proud that Kakadu has been saved, that Bass Strait is not polluted and that the Barrier Reef is safe. I am proud of the 1.6 million jobs created under the Hawke Government. I am proud that it was this Government that had the guts to bring in the hard decisions that have taken this country from one with a policy of unworkable protectionism to one striving to be competitive as a world trader. It is now widely accepted that those years of protectionism are the major cause of today's economic woes, and it is seen that Labor is the only party with the guts and the people to bring the nation through this testing time.

Finally, I thank the people of Page who put me here. I will never give them the opportunity to criticise me for lack of effort. I thank the branch members of the Australian Labor Party in my electorate. Without their untiring support I would not be here today. I thank them also for their attendance today. The ordinary country people of the Northern Rivers of New South Wales have given the Labor Party the chance to show them that it is able to represent them well in Federal Parliament. We on this side of the House have an ability to show the average country people of Australia the benefits of strong Labor representation and that it is in the interests of the rural folk to be represented by Labor. The Nationals have demonstrated that they are unable and unwilling to do the job. They are unwilling because they represent vested interests and not the ordinary people. They are unable and powerless because they are nothing more than a lap-dog on the knees of their Liberal masters.

Country people know that they can expect nothing from the Liberal Party, controlled as it is by the big business interests of this nation. Country people know that the Labor Party is their best chance of a fair go. Let us show them that their faith in us is well founded. If we do that, we will set an example for all country areas and reap the benefits at the next Federal election. The Labor Party is the natural political party of rural Australia, and it will be rural Australia that puts Labor into a fifth consecutive term of government.
Honourable members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Dunkley, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ford Mr F.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my privilege to represent the electorate of Dunkley. I thank all of those whose support was so great-my wife and family, our friends, my electorate chairman, Mrs Flo Parnaby, and the team who worked tirelessly to bring our campaign to a successful conclusion. Of course, I thank also the voters of the electorate. The State Secretariat of the Liberal Party needs special mention for its support. As the gateway to the Mornington Peninsula on the east coast of Port Phillip Bay, Dunkley is an area of many facets. From Mount Eliza in the south to Chelsea in the north, stretching approximately four kilometres inland, the area provides a perfect setting for water sports, while the historic features, art galleries and varied sporting facilities create enjoyment for residents and visitors alike.

SPEECH.PARA: Although mainly small to medium in size, business ventures of many varieties have developed over the years. The electorate is a great mirror of our society as a whole, though the emerging picture can be described only as bleak. There are many newspaper reports of increased serious crime. Housing figures show that new house approvals decreased from 747 in June 1989 to 456 a year later-a drop of just on 40 per cent. Around the central business district of Frankston one or two shops are empty in almost every block. Scores of empty offices and more than 100 industrial buildings stand empty, monuments to the days when success was commonplace and to be admired.

With my background in small business as a manufacturer and my involvement in small business employer organisations, particularly the Australian Small Business Association, it troubles me deeply that this once rich country is stagnating economically and is in a recession-even on the verge of a depression-with nearly 630,000 Australians listed as unemployed and small to medium sized businesses going bankrupt at an alarming rate. Many are old, established businesses, not newly created businesses that tend to fail even in good times. Our business base is being destroyed. We should give consideration to the introduction of a version of the United States chapter 11 mechanism which enables businesses to seek protection against bankruptcy proceedings and allows them the opportunity to trade out of their debts.

Business proprietors must realise that failure can occur at any time. If government or bureaucracy-that is, Big Brother-decides that a proprietor or his or her industry are irrelevant, both will be sacrificed without a second thought. My small engineering business was in such an industry. It was obliterated by the 1987 Budget without warning or consultation. Recovery is nearly impossible and takes years of sleepless nights, worry and family tension-a miserable existence one would not wish upon one's worst enemy.

Today there are thousands of people, not only in small business, caught in a trap by inconsistent policies and high interest rates, and their plight is ignored. I believe that the pain we are experiencing is unnecessary. We have been badly served by this Government, with its concentration on high interest rates as the only means of correcting the imbalance in our balance of trade. The tragedy is that the people who are hardest hit by high interest rates-that is, the pensioners, families, war veterans, the handicapped and people on fixed incomes-do not purchase or consume any imports. After outlaying most of their income on food and high housing rents, these people have little money left with which to purchase imports. There are many such people in the electorate of Dunkley who have been badly hurt by these high interest rate policies. They deserve, and will demand, better.

Nothing has been done to significantly free up the labour market or improve the efficiency on our waterfront. During May and June this year waterfront disputes, affecting 85 vessels, cost the nation an estimated $10m. Yet these very people will be rewarded with $100,000 each under the Government's proposed retirement arrangements. Is it any wonder that the average person in the community is disillusioned?

The Government and the unions have made a lot of noise about reforming the labour market, but until we get genuine voluntary agreements between employers and employees at the enterprise level we will continue along the same inefficient path that we have been following for decades. We must allow management and workers to instigate flexible work practices which lead to greater productivity and cost savings. This is in stark contrast to award restructuring which has, to date, been an excuse for wage rises.

We are now a part of a global economy and the cold facts are that we cannot compete because our costs are too high. In Australia, the best examples of greatly improved productivity concern companies and employees which have negotiated their own working conditions, such as Mudginberri, Robe River and, more recently, the Power Brewery in Queensland. The Power Brewery employees are receiving more money than people working at the competition brewery, yet they often earn it in just four days. The company is happy and so are the employees.

This arrangement now appears to be under threat from the Goss Government. At the instigation of the Federated Liquor and Allied Industry Employees Union, Mr Goss is prepared to force the management of Power Brewery to forgo a massive productivity increase of-I stress this figure-80 per cent more beer per person. If every business in this country could lift its productivity by even a quarter of this amount we would reverse our balance of payments overnight. This voluntary enterprise agreement is one of 60 that were ratified under the former National Party Government which Mr Goss has ordered to cease as at 30 December this year. Does the Treasurer (Mr Keating) agree with Mr Goss? Is this what the Treasurer means when he urges us all to increase productivity?

One of the most glossed-over problems facing this country is, I believe, our high inflation rate. It takes a heavy toll on business, discourages average Australians from saving and erodes the purchasing power of low income citizens- particularly families and those on fixed incomes, such as pensioners and war veterans. Our inflation rate is currently about 8 per cent, which is twice that of our trading partners. The major cause of inflation in Australia is this Government's now discredited prices and incomes accord. This unholy alliance between government and union leaders has had the effect of granting wage rises not related to productivity. This, in turn, has caused prices to rise and has also led to a lowering of quality, particularly in our manufacturing sector, as companies attempt to cut costs. This has not helped our efforts as an exporting nation; nor has it helped import replacement.

With indexed wage rises and indexed government charges and duties, we are guaranteed high, virtually indexed, inflation. Until we can bring our inflation down to the same level as our major trading partners we will continue our slide towards a banana republic. There is an old Latin proverb that says `time discovers truth', and the longer Australia's economic woes continue, the sooner we will hear the faint but final gasps of the Prime Minister's accord.

It would appear that one of the Government's most enthusiastic fellow travellers among the employer groups has forsaken it. It was reported in the Melbourne Age newspaper on Thursday, 16 August that the Metal Trades Industry Association (MTIA) appeared to be having second thoughts about the latest accord mark 6. The article stated:
The Victorian director of the M.T.I.A., Mr Bob Herbert, said the manufacturing industry had to be put in a ``separate basket''.
The article stated that Mr Herbert had said that the MTIA saw `considerable shortcomings' with accord mark 6. It continued:
``Our approach is that it provides too much of a stop-start approach to wage fixation'', he said.

I well remember back in the early 1980s when I was a member of that organisation, attending meetings at which members were asked to ratify the MTIA agreement with the unions for a 38-hour week and two huge wage rises. I disagreed with the MTIA for caving in under pressure and forecast that it would decimate the manufacturing industry. I regret to say that I was right. Close to 200,000 jobs have been lost, mainly in large engineering companies which have now ceased operations. This has made it almost impossible for many large engineering projects to be carried out in Australia.

Obviously Mr Herbert, when speaking of the manufacturing industry on 16 August in terms of putting it in a separate basket, omitted the final word, which is `case'. Manufacturing is a basket case, due in no small measure to the original agreement struck between the MTIA and the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union which was ratified by the then Arbitration Commission. Clearly, the accord must go, although whenever someone mentions freeing up the labour market there is an excited little chorus from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his colleagues about returning to the laws of the jungle. We should not return to the laws of the jungle or tribunals; we must return to real law with real evidence before real judges if, indeed, the law is required.

Instead of allowing for a more natural flow of supply and demand in the market place, Labor's interventionist activities are destroying the lives of many people who voted for it. As research by the Institute of Public Affairs reveals, since 1982, allowing for inflation, the average after tax earnings of Australians have actually decreased by almost $2,000. For some, the current year will be disastrous. The Budget last month promised a 9.2 per cent increase in pay as you earn collections, so the immediate future looks grim for employment prospects.

It has been stated that there is no perfect system. Yet the system of free enterprise is a granting of opportunity for personal liberty and independence to be passed on to future generations. It is both the cause and effect of individual freedom. The debt-ridden results of recent years will take at least a generation to rectify. Australia has an enormous overseas debt and huge unfunded liabilities in government superannuation schemes, both State and Federal. Each year that goes by the debt increases. By the end of the financial year just completed, it was worse than the last, which in turn was worse than the previous year and so on.

The lucky country is no longer. Instead, we have been told by the Prime Minister that we must become the clever country. One would hope, after the past seven years, that we will also emerge the wise country. Policies that are compatible with a healthy future will encourage excellence, initiative and competition at all levels. The Treasurer has persisted in high interest rates because he either could not or would not accept the alternatives of reforming taxation, reforming the labour market and cutting spending. All those countries producing goods at a lower price than Australia must be pleased with his efforts.

I am reminded of that quotation by Austin O'Malley, who said, `Some men are like a clock on a roof-they are useful only to their neighbours'. Apart from being known around the world as the land of the long weekend, it would appear that in the eyes of Asian investors we have been dragged into disrepute. According to former Builders Labourers Federation Secretary Mr Joe Owens, Asian investors do not agree with the way Australian construction unions conduct themselves. I wonder why?

In the early 1970s, I was privileged to be part of a team establishing a large aluminium fabricating facility in Indonesia. Not only did we give the international competitors a six-month start, but we were also first into production and produced better quality products. It is not possible to compare Australian management with management in overseas countries, except when working in the same environment.

The business environment in Australia is one of the most hostile and most regulated anywhere in the world. Generally, we have an excellent work force. Although I have heard a lot of rubbish spoken on the subject of so-called inefficient business, we do compare favourably with businesses around South East Asia, given our restrictive business environment. On the management side, with a few exceptions Australia is more than a match for many overseas countries. Had we the freedom and the conditions to operate sensibly, Australia could and would regain its position in the world.

Unfortunately, there have been some businessmen-only a few, the so-called high-flying entrepreneurs who have since crashed to earth-who have brought Australian business into disrepute. I regard the 1980s as the decade of greed, when entrepreneurs borrowed huge sums of money both within Australia and overseas and then proceeded with paper shuffling and dubious takeovers to be held up by the media and others as successful role models. We have all seen the end result of their behaviour and the effect it has had on Australia's international credibility.

Far worse, I believe, is the example such behaviour has been for our young people. These entrepreneurs who produced nothing were feted as successful while the struggling small business men or women who were actually trying to manufacture goods or services, research and develop products and employ fellow Australians, were regarded as fools and failures for toiling for long hours for very small returns.

Is it any wonder that the ordinary man and woman in the street feel disinclined to start at the bottom and work their way up? It has looked all too easy to get rich quick. We have to get back to basics and encourage people, especially the young, to realise one cannot get something for nothing. Success comes only from hard work and personal sacrifice.

I believe the 1990s must be a period of reconstruction, of examining our values and finding a way forward into a future which will benefit our children and our grandchildren. Excellence, competition, profit and individual responsibility must cease to be dirty words. Effort must be rewarded.

Our school system must suit the times. Of real concern is the experiment in social engineering called the Victorian Certificate of Education which is being foisted on our secondary school students in Victora. This is the brainchild of the Victorian Premier, Mrs Kirner, and aims for equality of outcomes. This, I fear, means a lowering of standards, and already some tertiary institutions are expressing disquiet.

I agree with the Prime Minister that Australia must become a clever country, but we will not do it by spending huge sums on a multifunction polis (MFP) when our existing research organisations are starved for funds. Several weeks ago, I spent two hours at the proposed site of the multifunction polis situated 25 kilometres out of Adelaide. If we are to have an MFP, what a place-a reclaimed mosquito-ridden swamp, a toxic waste dump and adjacent to the submarine construction area, the Osborne power station and a huge chemical complex. Personally, it is not an area in which I would choose to live.

Mr Deputy Speaker, we must encourage our young people, especially our young men, to become qualified in the fields of engineering and science. We must create a friendly atmosphere for business, universities, colleges and research establishments so that they have the money and the confidence to research new ideas. Australian scientists are among the best in the world. We do not need to import vast numbers from overseas. We just need to give our own people more encouragement so they will not leave this country for more attractive careers overseas.

The 1990s will be a decade of great challenge, especially in view of the exciting changes which are taking place in eastern Europe. This will mean a lot more global competition and we must be ready to accept the challenge. We must develop our natural resources, bearing in mind at all times our concern for the environment. We can have sensible policies for sustainable development, for without them our standard of living will slip further and further behind as we reach the stage when we can no longer maintain our pleasant lifestyle on the savings of foreigners.

Several months ago, I visited Kakadu, where I spent two days at Coronation Hill and the surrounding area, staying overnight at the El Sharana mining camp. If ever a project has received shabby, unfair treatment and bad publicity, it is Coronation Hill. The partners in this venture had fulfilled all the environmental impact requirements and had reasonably assumed that the project could go ahead. Now for reasons of purely politically expediency, I believe, the whole project is to be subjected to yet more investigation by the Resource Assessment Commission.

I was staggered at the number of mainly Federal Government bureaucracies which are involved in the evaluation process. To my mind, all this bureaucratic interference is contributing to many mining companies being involved in projects offshore. While I was there I spoke to a representative from the local Jawoyn people, a caring and thoughtful man who was particularly worried about the future of the local children. He fully understood the importance of the project going ahead and the benefits which were likely to accrue to his people. There is very little industry in this part of northern Australia and jobs are very difficult to find. We must nurture our most precious resource of all, our young people, and see that they have every opportunity to take up the great challenges facing this country in this last decade of the twentieth century and on into the twenty-first century.

I should like to see future generations have the same opportunities that were available to me. This was one of the motivating factors in my decision to enter politics. Leaving a huge overseas debt and similar unfunded liabilities is of great concern. As a nation we must not be reluctant to deal with values. If we are to develop in our children affection and a patriotism for Australia, we must first develop a philosophy that does not contradict the outcome we desire.

We members of this chamber must hold to the principles of democracy. We must not be found wanting in discharging our duty to see that the nation is well administered. We must address our fundamental problems: industrial relations, inflation, interest rates, taxation, education and the environment.

In conclusion, I look forward to being part of a coalition led by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), which will set about rebuilding the confidence of our people and making our great country, Australia, a happier and more prosperous place. I believe I am currently the only member whose namesake was a former Prime Minister, Mr Frank Forde. There are two not so insignificant differences: firstly, the spelling of our names and, secondly, our political philosophies. He may not have agreed with everything I have said here today.
Honourable members-Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I extend my congratulations to the two previous speakers, the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) and the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Ford). The Hawke Federal Labor Government has a very good record of change and policy implementation in many areas in its eight Budgets. Like many governments it has also made a number of errors which, of course, deserve to be rectified. There are many pluses. For example, by 1989-90 the 1983-84 Budget deficit of 4.1 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) had been turned around to a 2.6 per cent surplus.

SPEECH.PARA: Employment growth has averaged 3.5 per cent per year compared with an average of 1.7 per cent in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries over the past seven years. Primarily, this has been due to wage restraint by wage and salary earners and the trade unions. For example, in 1989-90, wage growth was 6.5 per cent against an 8 per cent consumer price index (CPI) increase. On average, in 1989 the four OECD European majors experienced a 6 per cent wage increase as against a 3.6 per cent increase in inflation; that is, real wages in those OECD countries increased much faster than in Australia.

One can also be proud of the tax reform program of the Hawke Labor Government. The introduction of the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax in 1985 and the income tax restructuring in 1985, 1989 and 1990 are most commendable. For example, the latest instalment of tax cuts delivers an extra $2.5 billion to wage and salary earners over a full year and still maintains an estimated $8.1 billion surplus in 1990-91.

In child-care this Budget delivers $87m towards the promised program of establishing 80,000 new places by 1995. Of course, the improvements to social welfare are well documented. The tightly targeted family allowance and family allowance supplement programs are welcomed, as are the changes which coordinated the tax payment threshold with the pension income-test-free area.

Higher education is a policy plus, as exemplified by the increasing number of university places which are available in Australia. For example, the University of Wollongong, a major regional university, has increased its student numbers from 3,500 to nearly 9,000 during the Hawke Labor years.

I turn now to some problem areas in the Budget for the Government and the nation. Firstly, I refer to the continued current account deficit and the associated problem of repayment of principal and interest on foreign debt. These repayments have been the main debilitating influence on the current account. It is increasingly a private sector issue. Over the years since deregulation of the financial system, the public sector borrowing requirement has been, of course, cut to zero. In the last financial year alone, $6 billion of domestic debt and $2.5 billion of overseas debt have been repaid as a result of Budget surpluses. Over four years Federal debt is down from 26.5 per cent of gross domestic product to 13 per cent of GDP. So Commonwealth-held debt is reducing. The majority of the record $127 billion net foreign debt is now held by the Australian private sector.

It is not so much trade deficits, but net income deficits, including foreign debt repayments, which are the main factor in the high current account deficits. As the Budget Papers show, trade deficits have declined in real terms from $3.5 billion in 1985-86 to $3.8 billion in 1989-90, whilst net income deficits have increased from $8 billion to almost $16 billion over the past four years. Honourable members can trace these figures in more detail in Budget Paper No. 1, section two, page 25. They will see, for example, that in the first half of the financial year 1989-90, the trade account was $3.4 billion in deficit and in the second part of the year only $0.4 billion in deficit. In the net income balance area the net deficit was $7.4 billion in the first half of the year, rising to $8.3 billion in the second half of the year. This means that imports, as a result of high interest rates depressing the economy, have decreased, but the current account deficit is still a very severe problem, mainly because of the fact that net income imbalances are still very much in deficit. They are blowing out as a result of the repayment of principal and interest on foreign debt, not as a result of a surge in imports.

The misconception of late that import costs are paramount in the current account deficit has led to an over-reliance on tight monetary policy leading to high real interest rates and an extravagantly overvalued Australian dollar. In effect, we are seeing the first deliberate policy-induced recession since the 1961 credit squeeze. Furthermore, this position will be exacerbated by external conditions, in part resulting from the crisis in the Persian Gulf.

So one comes to the weakest points, in my view, of the 1990-91 Budget. I refer to the basic and key Budget forecasts. Of course, these were: total demand rated to be zero; exports to increase by 7.5 per cent; imports down by 3 per cent; gross domestic product plus 2 per cent-seeing that zero growth is predicted in demand this means that that 2 per cent has to come from exports alone; I will return to that in a moment-unemployment predicted to rise to 7.25 per cent; and consumer price index increases to even out at 6 per cent some time towards the end of the financial year.

Let us have a look at these figures. Given that total domestic demand for 1990-91 is forecast to be zero, I think it is extremely unlikely that gross domestic product will amount to a total of 2 per cent derived from export growth alone in 1990-91. High real interest rates, favourable terms of trade and now capital inflow as a result of the Persian Gulf situation has produced an Australian dollar which is far too high to allow the 7.5 per cent increase in export revenue predicted in the Budget.

I just digress slightly from that theme to point out that Ronald Reagan's early eighties policies of big tax cuts and high interest rates and an overvalued US dollar have been identified by economists in the US Treasury-this was to me personally about five weeks ago-as having led to the huge US budgetary and trade deficits that we see today. In Australia, despite the tax cuts, as I have said, very tight fiscal policies have led to Budget surpluses, unlike the early Reagan years, but tight monetary policies, high interest rates and an overvalued dollar are contributing to our trade deficits. Our trade deficits are then hugely compounded by repayment of interest and principal on private sector public debt. As I have pointed out, public sector foreign debt is decreasing as a percentage of total foreign debt.

There are signals, other than the effect of an overvalued Australian dollar and exports, that growth will be less than 2 per cent. The Budget forecasts are based on oil priced at $23 per barrel. Already it is $27 per barrel and it could rise higher, depending on the situation in the Persian Gulf. Further, OECD forecasts in June, before the Gulf crisis, predicted 3.8 per cent average growth and 4.3 per cent inflation for the four OECD European majors.

The OECD report also predicted US growth of 2.3 per cent and inflation of 4.5 per cent in the United States. Since the Gulf crisis, the growth figures have been revised downwards, on average, by 1.3 per cent and inflation forecasts increased by 1.5 per cent. All the information is in the OECD's latest report which, I point out, was brought out a few days before the Gulf crisis; nevertheless, as I have just said, the figures have been revised downwards. Given all that, the OECD is now looking, on average, at 3 per cent gross domestic product growth or less; in the US, one per cent or less.

I think it is very unlikely that Australia will reach 2 per cent growth in GDP, given the low level of domestic demand predicted in the Budget and the bearish outlook for most exports. I include in the description `bearish' manufacturing industry exports and agricultural products but, of course, exclude energy related products such as liquefied natural gas and steaming coal.

If the GDP forecasts fall to something between zero and one per cent in Australia for 1990-91 other basic forecasts will also change. The surplus could be less than predicted and unemployment could be a good deal higher. The rise in unemployment is most worrying to me and should be of great concern to the trade unions in the current wages environment. It would be unfair if wage and salary earners in the smaller and weaker unions missed out on the 1990-91 accord mark 6 as a result of higher unemployment bearing down hard on the labour market, and the ACTU should note the deteriorating position in finalising accord mark 6.

The number of recipients of unemployment benefits has increased by 90,000 since last November. Unemployment is now over 620,000, a jobless rate of 7.3 per cent. That already equals the Budget average forecast for the whole year. If unemployment were to blow out to, say, 8.5 per cent we are looking at another 100,000 unemployed on top of the 70,000 inferred in the Budget figures. The Confederation of Australian Industry is pessimistic about Australian manufacturing in its latest joint report with Westpac Banking Corporation, and the Metal Trades Industry Association says that 30,000 jobs have been lost in the metal industry in the last three months.

I hope the scenario that I have painted turns out to be incorrect, but unfortunately I think it is a probable outcome unless official rates and bank prime and housing rates are eased significantly in the near future. Of course, that is what needs to be done. I accept that this will be no easy task, given that the international economic trends are probably running in the opposite direction. In the United States, Federal savings and loan bail-out problems will cost taxpayers $200 billion plus over the next several years. There are international costs associated with the Persian Gulf military expeditions and higher oil prices resulting from the Gulf crisis following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Further, there is the impost on international capital markets, particularly in Europe and Japan, which arise from the recapitalisation of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.

I predict that United States deficits will remain stubbornly high and West German and Japanese surpluses will surely gradually run down. All this leads to higher world interest rate regimes. I say this despite the over-optimistic commercial view from the commercial bank joyboys that I have read in the last few days that US and world rates are due to fall. They may fall slightly in the short term, but there is no possibility that we are looking at an international regime of lower interest rates in the intermediate and long term, given the combination of factors I have just spelled out. Nevertheless it remains imperative that Australian real interest rates and the Australian dollar be reduced to a more realistic level, otherwise we face a rapidly sinking economy in Australia.

Given the need to reduce interest rates, it is difficult to see privatisation making a significant contribution to micro-economic reform. Privatisation of major government business enterprises places heavy demands on domestic savings and means a certain increase to our already overloaded foreign debt. It is certain to put upward pressure on domestic interest rates-just the opposite of what is required. The real economic issues facing us are the need for lower interest rates and a lower Australian dollar, how to increase domestic savings, how to encourage exports and how to restrain foreign debt. They are the real issues, not privatisation.

I believe micro-economic reform, particularly in transport and communications, is essential, but improved industry efficiency and competitiveness is not necessarily derived from privatisation. That privatisation can be a cop-out rather than true micro-economic reform is unarguable. It can impose heavy strains on capital markets. For example, the Opposition's plans to totally privatise Telecom Australia, OTC Ltd, Aussat Pty Ltd, Australian Airlines Ltd and Qantas Airways Ltd would make a $20 billion call on domestic and overseas capital markets.

On the other hand, current Government privatisation and communication reform plans affecting OTC, the airlines and the Commonwealth Bank would impose a significant amount also in capital markets-say, approximately $5 billion plus. I think all this would push up interest rates and increase foreign debt. At the very least privatisation merely transfers private sector savings to the public sector. It transfers the task of raising funds, for example, for new equipment and technology to the private sector; it does not in itself make an industry more efficient.

In other words, privatisation is a Clayton's micro-reform. It is the sort of micro-reform you have when you are not having real micro-economic reform. There is no reason why the airlines equipment and equity requirements cannot be met from their own cash flows, borrowings from the Loan Council and moderate injections of government equity. As economists have pointed out, if the revenue return to government from such investments exceeds the cost of interest payments on borrowings, the investment is commercially sound. Indeed, that is how the private sector operates-or how it ought to operate even if it does not.

In the current propositions affecting communications, the Commonwealth Bank and the airlines, only the plans to improve efficiency and competitiveness in communications can be designated as true micro-economic reform. I favour the merging of Telecom and OTC. Aussat can provide the basis for a second competitive carrier. Competition could be allowed on overseas communications and in the value added areas such as mobile phones and business communications but not against the public switch telephone network.

I know this is a controversial issue, but I cannot for the life of me see how a second carrier connection with the existing public switch telephone network automatically gives increased competition and lower tariffs. If it does, the capacity must already exist for Telecom to reduce charges. In that case, why should an overseas corporation freeload on investment by Australian taxpayers? If it is intended to create a second separate network over a long period of time I cannot see why such wasteful duplication of investment is necessary, given the heavy demands on our savings that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, always refers to.

Overseas ownership should not exceed approximately 30 per cent after a reasonable period. I think an outcome such as I have described in communications creates a fully publicly owned Australian megacom in competition with a second carrier in all areas except the public switch telephone network.

Unlike communications reform, the acquisition of the State Bank of Victoria by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, financed by a 30 per cent sale of new equity to the private sector, is not micro-reform in my view but sheer expediency. The acquisition of the State Bank of Victoria can be funded easily by means other than partial privatisation such as drawing upon excess Commonwealth Bank contributions to the Commonwealth Bank Employees Superannuation Fund. In no way, in my view, can the Commonwealth Bank deal be presented as making the bank more efficient or creating more competition in the banking industry.

In addition to the State Bank of Victoria, it has been the private sector financial institutions, including the major private banks, who have lent recklessly, in the process amassing huge portfolios of bad debt. In comparison, the publicly owned Commonwealth Bank has been a model of financial rectitude.

I had intended to say more about the airlines but I will not have time. Suffice it to say that the best thing we could do in micro-reform in the airlines industry is to merge Australian Airlines and Qantas. That is the real way to introduce competition in the domestic aviation commuter industry. There is no doubt about that. The privatisation of Australian Airlines in itself-either 100 per cent or 49 per cent-will not produce true competition in the domestic aviation industry.

I conclude on this note: there are many initiatives and programs in this Budget of which we can be truly proud. But I do think that the Budget's key forecasts are questionable and our key economic priorities ought to be to get interest rates down and to get the Australian dollar down. Then we can take the true place that we deserve in our region and the world with regard to trade and foreign policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not the first time that I have followed the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) in a debate. In fact, there was a time in our respective careers when I responded quite regularly to what he had to say. As I listened to him talk about the Budget today I wondered for a time whether we had some form of conversion on our hands. We know that the honourable member for Cunningham has long held the view that Budget deficits were a highly desirable way in which to conduct our economic affairs, but today I heard him say that he was delighted to see a Budget surplus.

SPEECH.PARA: I also wondered whether we had a conversion when the honourable member started to criticise this Budget that I will be talking about in a minute. I am afraid that I was misguided because the honourable member for Cunningham did not waste too much time before he got back to the things that he really does like to talk about-belting the private sector, belting deregulation of the financial market and, last of all, having a go at privatisation. I say to the honourable member for Cunningham that privatisation is not the only thing that needs to be done to restore Australia's economic position, but it is one of the things that needs to be done. It joins a list of about 15 or 20 things that need to be done.

I say to the honourable member that he will have his chance in this chamber to decide whether he wants to live up to what he has said today. He will have a chance to vote against legislation that will be required to give effect to his Government's decisions on privatisation. He will have a chance to vote against a 30 per cent private shareholding in the Commonwealth Bank. It will be interesting to see, when he has that chance, whether he takes it. I say to the honourable member for Cunningham that, if he does vote against that legislation and joins some of his other colleagues who have his disposition, although his career in the Labor Party will be short, at least he will be highly regarded for having the courage of his convictions.

I wish to say one other thing in relation to what the honourable member for Cunningham had to say about the public sector borrowing requirement. He said that the public sector borrowing requirement would be at zero. He then went on to identify a whole series of weak links in this year's Budget. He will know that yesterday, in response to a dorothy dix question, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) said that he was lifting the ceiling on borrowings that would be allowed for the Australian Wool Corporation. If current trends continue, the Australian Wool Corporation will have to borrow an extra $2 billion in order to fund the wool stockpile. That will right there and then blow out the public sector borrowing requirement by about one half of a percentage point of gross domestic product.
I thank the honourable member for Cunningham for his contribution to the Budget debate. It was a little all over the place, but I guess I have come to expect that from the honourable member.

By now we know that every time the Treasurer (Mr Keating) gets into trouble he blames someone else. He has been true to form with this 1990-91 Budget. There is clearly something seriously wrong with the Budget because in the few weeks since it was brought down-it has been widely described as an anticlimax-the Treasurer has lashed out wildly. To start with he blamed the media, which is extraordinary, given the way that he has manipulated and tried to manipulate the media over the years. Not content with blaming the media generally, he turned his attention to the Melbourne Age newspaper and gave it and several of its commentators a sound lashing.

The Treasurer then blamed the banks for the excesses of the recent boom that he, the Treasurer, helped to fuel with his loose monetary policy. Then it was the turn of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the Opposition generally. In the last few days it has been the turn of his own colleagues. At a recent meeting to discuss telecommunications competition and airline funding matters, both of which we were led to believe some months ago would be included in the Budget but neither of which were, he described his colleagues as hopeless and stormed out of the meeting to talk to the Australian Council of Trade Unions and presumably give it a blast.

Criticism of the Budget brought forth the Treasurer's reaction, but it is now clear that those criticisms are well-founded. The Budget is a flawed and most peculiar document. Huge amounts of it seem to have been left out, almost as if the Treasury computer lost some of the pages or chapters in the print-out. There is, for example, hardly a word about our exchange rate. I thought it was quite interesting today that the honourable member for Cunningham spent several minutes talking about the exchange rate, but there is hardly anything about the exchange rate in the Budget. The Treasurer may not know it, but this problem of a wildly fluctuating currency is absolutely critical to our farmers, our miners, our manufacturing exporters, our import competing industries and, as a result, to our economic stability.

Where in the Budget document does the Treasurer have anything to say about exchange rate movements? There is nothing in the index. There is virtually nothing in the Treasurer's long speech. However, in Statement 2, `The Budget and the Economy', in the section entitled `Structural changes, economic policy and economic performance' on page 2.53 there is, buried away, a footnote, number 16, in the section headed `Current Account'. The wording in the footnote suggests that the Treasurer wanted the information contained in it to be incapable of interpretation. Here for the record is what footnote 16 says:

For example, in an investment upsurge (such as that experienced in recent years), demand for savings pushes up real interest rates (assuming an unchanged monetary policy stance) and increased aggregate spending puts pressure on domestic prices. The Australian dollar tends to rise as foreign savings flow to Australia. The widening of the gap between domestic investment and saving increases the capital account surplus with the current account deficit also widening (as the decline in competitiveness shifts production away from net exports) to match the increased capital inflow. As noted, fluctuations in the terms of trade, foreign demand or relative costs (for example, via a wages break-out) can directly influence the size of the current account deficit; however, any such effects will only be sustained in so far as they alter domestic saving and investment behaviour.

There it all is. It is hard to interpret, but this is what it means: current government policies will result in a reduced capital inflow. It means that a lower exchange rate will result from that reduced capital inflow. A lower exchange rate will improve our international competitiveness. A lower exchange rate will move resources out of imports and into exports and a lower exchange rate, according to footnote 16, is therefore crucial in the medium term to bring our overseas debt under control.

That is what the Treasurer is saying to us. He may have put it all in code but nonetheless that is the message that the Budget footnote has given us. Since these magic words were written the exchange rate has not gone down. The exchange rate has gone up as it has been doing for some months. The market reality is that the Government's deliberate high interest rate policy and the perception that there will be a reasonably strong demand for our commodities in the near to medium term have pushed up the value of the Australian dollar.

Despite the Treasurer's policy settings which were established in the Budget and designed to bring the dollar down, it has risen. What an extraordinary dilemma the Treasurer now finds himself in. If he causes monetary policy to be eased significantly-and remember he has told us that he tells the Reserve Bank of Australia what to do-and interest rates come down, then the Australian dollar might well fall somewhat, but that would only rekindle domestic demand and imports would start to rise again. So the Treasurer will be right back where he was over a year ago. His sole reliance on monetary policy has left him in a situation where the dollar is likely to stay firm. He knows that a rise of one cent in the value of the Australian dollar means about $150m for our farming sector, more for the mining industries, and that export manufacturers will decide to stop producing here and become importers instead.

The Treasurer has consistently maintained that his deliberate high interest rate policy is designed to cut back our imports. Perhaps the Minister at the table, the Minister for Local Government (Ms Fatin), would like to tell the House whether anybody in the Labor Party has ever had the cheek to raise with the Treasurer the possible effects that his high interest rate policy might have on the value of the currency. Does the Minister at the table know that $40 billion can be traded every day? Do the Minister and the Treasurer know that our Reserve Bank is not big enough to get into that game when the stakes are so high? It would appear that the Treasurer does not really understand how his policies affect the value of our dollar in a floating exchange rate environment. Perhaps we can ask Senator Walsh to tell him.

So the Treasurer's policies are resulting in a higher exchange rate, lost markets, cheaper imports, and a worsening current account deficit-unless we do what the Treasurer has been trying to do, and that is to drive the Australian economy into a one-way tunnel of doom.

The Treasurer is still going through a learning curve that is decimating the Australian economy. In his early days he tried Keynesian demand stimulation and that did not work. Then he tried to increase taxes and balance the Budget and that did not work. Then he tried to loosen monetary policy and stimulate growth with the savings of foreigners and that did not work. Now he is trying to use high interest rates to dampen demand, but that is driving the country into a recession. No doubt he will now try to learn about the exchange rate effects in a commodities trading society, but if history is any guide he will mess that up too.

In last year's Budget there were only one and a half pages on the exchange rate in a document of some hundreds of pages. This year there are just a few lines and a footnote written in language that is barely comprehensible. The clear fact is that the Government's current economic policy can achieve its limited objective only if it crushes the very life out of the country and if it crushes demand for everything, including household necessities, basic services and productive investment.
To underscore this even further, the failure of the Treasurer's policies were identified in the Melbourne Herald last Monday, 10 September. This is what the newspaper said:
A strong Australian dollar, supported by its perception as an energy currency, has become independent of the need for high interest rates to attract capital for the first time in years.

In its report last week Syntec Economic Services said,``Oil prices do not have to leap for the Australian dollar to be ensconced now as a kind of Middle East substitute currency. But in the process, it may leave import-replacement manufacturing without viability''.
The stronger dollar will permit interest rates to fall further than the slowing economy would justify by itself.
But it also seems the dollar will not revisit the mid-US 70c level again.

So it is clear that the Treasurer and the Government have their priorities wrong and must clearly think again about what their new priorities should be. Ironically enough, in a fashion that appears inconsistent with the rest of the document, the conclusion on page 2.55 of Budget Paper No. 1 gives some clues to those new priorities. Three quotations from that conclusion on page 2.55 might be relevant. They are, first:

...it is now more widely recognised that maintenance of real wage restraint and a healthy rate of return on capital are vital to both employment and investment prospects, and hence to output growth and living standards.
Furthermore, it goes on:

As a consequence, much more of any growth in living standards in the 1990s will, as in earlier decades, need to come from improved productivity feeding in part into higher wages and in part into lower prices and thus lower inflation. Lifting the pace and broadening the focus of micro-economic reform will be crucial in this respect, as will a well-managed transition towards more flexible labour market arrangements, including enterprise bargaining.
Finally:
One of the main challenges of the 1990s will be to reduce our inflation rate and inflationary expectations significantly.

The Government is quite incapable of delivering policies that will achieve the objectives set out in its own conclusion. How can the average Australian be comfortable with wage restraints with the current high level of interest rates?

TALK.START.PARA: —They will never get it right.

—As my friend and colleague remarks, the Government will never get it right. He is quite right because it has not got it right for the last seven and a half years and it would be quite unreasonable to expect that it would get it right now.
—Like you did not get it right in the previous 20 years.

—The honourable member for Throsby will be able to have his say. I will ask him what he is going to say about unemployment and inflation and what he is going to do when the Bill comes to this Parliament on the part private financing of the Commonwealth Bank. With a restive work force and declining investment, where is the evidence to suggest that productivity can be improved when it has been unchanged for the last seven years? Why does the Government now think it can lower inflation when it has been locked in at 7 per cent for some years, a level twice as great on average as that of our major trading competitors? Where is the evidence of major changes in micro-economic reform when progress has been at a snail's pace at best? Finally, where is the evidence of a transition toward the coalition's policies of a more flexible labour market arrangement, including enterprise bargaining? The evidence is not there and unless the Government changes its priorities, the Budget will fail and the economy will sink further into the mire.

SPEECH.PARA: The priorities should be those that have been clearly enunciated by the coalition in its policies: firstly, quickly reducing inflation to the level of our major trading competitors, a point made most forcibly and effectively by my friend and colleague the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Ford) in his excellent maiden speech made in this chamber just half an hour or so ago; and secondly, cutting government expenditures. The Government has to cut further on government expenditures. Just prior to the last election the coalition in its Economic Action Plan detailed $3 billion worth of cuts in government expenditure. It is there to be cut if the Government will only grasp the nettle and have the courage and the political will to make the cuts, but it will not do that. It has not done it and it will not do it. It has not got the courage to do it.

The third priority is privatisation. This means the transfer of assets from the public sector to the enterprises' employees, and investors in the private sector. It does not mean this half-hearted business about 30 per cent financing. The fourth priority is contracting out; the fifth, taxing spending instead of taxing investment and savings; the sixth, ending by legislation present labour market monopolies and restrictive practices; and, finally, removing barriers to the growth of export industries. Only these priorities can allow Australia's economic difficulties to be resolved and only these priorities will restore Australia's place as one of the pre-eminent nations in our region of the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak in this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1). I would like to congratulate those new members to this place on their maiden speeches. I thought that the maiden speeches of honourable members on both sides of the House in this Thirty-sixth Parliament were particularly impressive. One need not always necessarily agree with everything that is said.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, I suppose that one could call this section of the debate the Illawarra section. The previous Government speaker was my friend and colleague, the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West). The Government speaker scheduled to speak after me is the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin). It is most unfortunate that the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Beale) is leaving the chamber. I was about to say it is always a great pleasure to follow the comments of the honourable member for Bruce.

I listened to what the honourable member said. Honourable members opposite rail at the Government and tell it what it should be doing. They never say, though, what they did during the 30 years they occupied the treasury bench. Of course, they got it right all the time. They always had it right. Their policies placed this country in a wonderful economic situation!

The honourable member for Bruce is a very nice chap. I remember when he was on the Opposition front bench. I frequently spoke after him in this place. A favourite target of his was the waterside workers, especially at Port Kembla. In fact, a couple of articles were published in the Australian describing what he would do to clean up the waterfront. On many, many occasions I have said to the honourable member for Bruce, `Come with me to Port Kembla. The next time a ship is held up in Port Kembla, you come there with me. We will talk to them and you can put your ideas to the workers at Port Kembla'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he go?

—No. He found it much more comfortable to stay in this place and criticise the workers of Port Kembla than to come to the waterfront at Port Kembla and face the workers there and deliver his criticism. Today he tells us that we all have to be hairy chested and go out there and cut and slash. He repeated the Opposition nonsense about privatisation-`Let's go in there and privatise the lot'. The honourable member said that there were more opportunities to cut if only the Government had the courage to cut.

SPEECH.PARA: Again in this chamber I offer an invitation, or a challenge, to the honourable member for Bruce. When the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) calls the next election, whenever that may be, I invite the honourable member to come with me to Port Kembla, to Wollongong, to Dapto, to Shellharbour and tell the people there, the pensioners, the workers, the teachers in the schools where the Opposition would make cuts, what it would do. Let us not have all this nonsense.

There is the challenge. I challenge the honourable member for Bruce to come to my electorate. I will be there. He could come with me. I will not be aggressive. I will set up a couple of public meetings and he can tell the workers that I represent about the policies of the Opposition, what funds the Opposition would cut. If the honourable member comes with me to speak to the pensioners of Dapto, 200, 300 or 400 people will be there. He could tell the pensioners about Opposition policies, the areas in which funds would be cut.

I issue that invitation here. I do not know when the next election will be. The honourable member need not bother to wait for the next election. He is always welcome there, but particularly in the run-up to an election. He can tell the people in my electorate how members of the Opposition are hairy chested and how the Government is composed of wimps. He can tell the pensioners and all these other people about the economic policies of the Opposition.
I will leave that point. There is much in the Budget that I was very pleased with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I go now?
—Yes. You may leave now. We will see you in Port Kembla.

SPEECH.PARA: There is much in the Budget that I am very pleased to be associated with. The Budget, as I suppose is natural, covered a wide range of topics. Many of the previous speakers from this side of the House were complimentary. On the other side, I felt that some of the comments were unnecessarily carping.

I was interested to hear some of the comments in this debate. Honourable members usually select an area in which they have some particular expertise or some topic that they are interested in. I fall into that category myself. One of the areas that I am particularly interested in is adult literacy. I propose to devote part of my speech to International Literacy Year (ILY).

As honourable members would be aware, the United Nations has declared 1990 to be International Literacy Year. The Hawke Labor Government has established a national consultative council to guide Australia's involvement in the year, and I have the honour to be a member of the council. I was particularly pleased during Question Time today to hear the comments of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) to the effect that additional funds had been made available to the council to enable it to continue into the early part of next year to finish some of the work that has already been started.

The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation has assumed the role of lead organisation in the preparation leading up to International Literacy Year. The general conference of UNESCO passed the following resolution:
