International Literacy Year will not consist of a set of isolated activities but will rather be a means serving essentially to stimulate greater public and government awareness and consciousness in furtherance of the objective of eradicating illiteracy by the year 2000-in the knowledge that literacy training is not simply teaching people to read and write, but teaching them to understand so that they can live their life to the full.

It is no small challenge to eradicate illiteracy by the year 2000. International Literacy Year is not only for one year. People say that international years come and go. They come, they flower briefly, and then disappear. In this case, however, UNESCO has called for a plan of action to achieve literacy for all by the year 2000. It is certainly true that to achieve literacy for all in Australia will take longer than this year.

There are many misconceptions about the term `literacy'. Literacy is not a clearly definable position or a negative accomplishment. It is a set of skills people have to varying degrees and the fact that they lack what society perceives as an acceptable level of literacy has nothing to do with their intelligence. People who cannot read or write are not dumb, but their greatest fear is that other people will label them as such when they discover that they cannot read or write. Consequently, they often build their lives around a disguise.

At the commencement of this international year many people in the community thought that when we talked about illiteracy in the community we were talking about children or people who came from a non-Australian or non-European background. There are many people who were born in Australia, who grew up in Australia and who went to school in Australia who, for one reason or another, are illiterate.

There are many reasons why adults cannot read or write well enough in English. Many of them have grown up in poverty. Some of them were ill during those important formative years. Some had sight or hearing problems. They may have lived in an isolated area, left school early, or come from a family where English was not spoken very much at home. What has emerged this year is that many people have lost this skill. They may not have had it to a great degree. They had this skill at school, but because they have not used it, and for other reasons, they have lost it after they have left school. No matter how good the excuse, that perceived stigma is the biggest hurdle a person faces when coming forward for help.

In some parts of the world literacy simply means being able to sign one's name. Expectations vary in accordance with cultural demands on society. Before I came to this place I worked in the area of adult education. I was aware of the literacy problem in the community. It often seemed to me that where the problem came to the fore in the people I was dealing with is when their children would come home and ask their parents to help them with their homework. The parents could not do that and it was becoming an embarrassment to them. Often, after many, many attempts, they would pluck up the courage to come to the organisation that I worked with to see whether we could help them. They were embarrassed when their children asked for help with their homework and they had to admit to their children that they could neither read nor write.

UNESCO estimates that there are one billion adults worldwide who lack literacy skills, with 600 million of these living in our own Asia-Pacific region. Indeed, Australia's near neighbour, Papua New Guinea, has an illiteracy rate which exceeds 50 per cent. The giant Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee of this Parliament at the moment is looking at relationships between Australia and Papua New Guinea. I hope the Committee will look at that problem too. I do not think we should go in there with a big brother attitude and try to put an Australian solution onto the illiteracy problem in Papua New Guinea. We must listen to what the people there say and work with them to help them overcome the problem.

Right now more than one million adults in Australia lack some sort of literacy skills considered adequate for our society. It is always difficult when we are talking about illiteracy. Does it mean that a person cannot read or write? The organisation has come up with the term `functional illiteracy'. This means people cannot read a simple sentence in English, cannot decipher telephone dialling instructions, cannot read classified newspaper advertisements or fill out simple application forms.

The goal of Australia during International Literacy Year is to achieve active literacy in the community. For an advanced technological society such as Australia, active literacy is defined as the sort of literacy which allows people to use the language to enhance their capacity to think, create and question. In this way they can participate more effectively in society. As politicians, we should also be aware that it is very necessary for people to be literate. We have compulsory voting in Australia, and I think it is very important for the political process that people be literate.

The social cost of low literacy skills is inestimable and will grow as society's increasing sophistication puts unprecedented demands on the general population. With computers taking over so much of our lives today, I used to be fond of saying that in a few years time those who were computer illiterate-which I think I am-will be as disadvantaged in society as those people in society today who are functionally illiterate. It is encouraging that children are introduced to computers in primary school because they are increasingly so much a part of our lives.

It has been estimated that a lack of English language skills could be costing Australia something like $3.2 billion a year in the additional communication time needed in the workplace. But that figure could be much higher if it took into account the increased cost of industrial safety, poor product quality, low job mobility and flexibility, high staff turnover and limited quality of life. It is interesting to note that the House of Representatives Committee on Employment, Education and Training has set up a subcommittee to look at literacy in the workplace. Already that subcommittee has received much valuable information and insight on the needs of the work force through submissions from people in the work force and by going around and looking at some of the problems that exist in the workplace.

We really must have a literate workplace if we are to have a literate population. Everyone is bandying words around about the clever society and things like that. Basically, if we are going to be a clever society we really must have a literate work force. The United Nations sees International Literacy Year as a way to stimulate a greater public and government awareness of its objective of eradicating illiteracy by the year 2,000. Remember, that is less than 10 years off and there is a lot to be done, but already much has been done.

An important part of Australia's agenda for International Literacy Year has been to make adult literacy classes freely available in a variety of settings to those who need them. That may be in people's homes, both in the suburbs and in the country, in the workplace and in educational institutions. The ILY program in Australia already has two themes: the pursuit of lifelong literacy learning and the notion that literacy development is a whole community responsibility. In terms of lifelong literacy, the existence of literacy programs for both children and adults reinforces the development of both groups. Conversely, neglect of adult literacy needs contributes to generational cycles of literacy difficulties.

Meeting the literacy demands of a contemporary society and economy will produce real benefits for the nation. The converse of that is that the costs of inadequate literacy are enormous. International Literacy Day was marked last Saturday by an announcement by the Federal Government of a $40m package of initiatives in extra literacy support. Literacy involves the integration of listening, speaking, reading, writing and critical thinking. It incorporates numeracy. It includes the cultural knowledge which enables a speaker, writer or reader to recognise and use language appropriate to different social situations. For an advanced technological society such as Australia our goal must be an active literacy which allows people to use the language to enhance our capacity to think, create and question, which helps them to become more aware of the world and empowers them to participate more effectively in society.

Finally, I would like to congratulate and thank all those who are making special efforts to work for literacy development in Australia. The literacy task force of the Illawarra and South East Regional Council of Adult Education, headed by Fran Sanders, is conducting adult literacy programs throughout the Illawarra and south coast region of New South Wales. As the honourable member for Macarthur said, within that region there are 10 volunteer groups, each with 10 volunteers working in the community helping to meet the needs of people who are experiencing literacy problems.

In my own electorate of Throsby, Margaret McAllister, the literacy officer at the Shellharbour College of Technical and Further Education, produces an excellent newsletter-a copy of which I will send to the honourable member for Macarthur, if he has not already received it-which is proving to be a valuable resource for those 100 volunteers. In the Shoalhaven region, Ms Terry Eddy is planning an innovative workplace literacy program with Shoalhaven City Council. Mention here must also be made of Anne Krone, coordinator of the Illawarra and South East Regional Council of Adult Education, who has come to Eden-Monaro and has made a valuable contribution to literacy development in her region.

With the contributions of people such as Anne Krone, Terry Eddy, Fran Sanders and Margaret McAllister, the clever country will become a highly literate country, one in which we will all be articulate readers and writers and, above all, be critically intelligent users of language. For it is through language that we shape our experience, form our values, structure our community and give expression to our hopes and aspirations in a democratic society. After all, to be deprived of literacy is to be denied access to many of our fundamental human rights.

In conclusion, there is one aspect of this debate that concerns me. I keep hearing words such as `the clever country' and how we are going to become more articulate. This comment is not original; I gleaned it last week from my friend and colleague the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) when he was addressing a literacy meeting in Melbourne. The point he was making, which I think is worth sharing, is that when we talk about the lucky country and becoming the clever country and things like that, it is assumed that it was by some accident that we became the lucky country. We became the lucky country only because there were already a lot of skills in Australia. Certainly we have mineral resources and so on, but it took an amount of skill to extract those resources.

The honourable member for Lalor was saying at this conference that we should be very careful about talking as though it were some freakish accident that we happen to be the lucky country. The lucky country involves a lot of skills. But we will not become the clever country unless we are the literate country. With the work we are doing and the great support the Government has given to the International Year of Literacy, we will most certainly become an increasingly literate society.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget introduced a couple of weeks ago has been described as a Budget with lots of pain and little gain. That is a pretty true description. We still have the highest taxing Government that this country has ever known. Even though the Budget provides for a surplus of $8 billion, which is highly commendable of course, I think it should be pointed out that $6 billion of that surplus is coming directly out of the taxpayers' pockets because the total tax revenue in this Budget has been increased by $6 billion. So it is straight out of the taxpayers' pockets and purses-an increase in taxation of 6.4 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, of course, there are the cutbacks to the States and to local government. Local government will suffer a cutback of $25m in real terms for each of the next two years, and we are looking at a Budget which provides, plans and is designed for an additional 60,000 of our fellow Australians to be unemployed by the end of this financial year. But I will return to that question of unemployment.

Under this Budget, family allowances are going to be assets tested from next January and 98,000 Australian families will lose the family allowance; Austudy will be tightened; and, once again, pensioners have been thoroughly confused. Every time the Treasurer (Mr Keating) brings down a Budget he changes the rules and confuses them. I happen to believe very strongly that elderly Australians have the right to relax in their later years and not be subjected to confusion, worry and stress. It seems to me that every time the Treasurer provides us with a Budget, he provides extra stress for elderly Australians.

Inflation is stuck again at between 7 per cent and 8 per cent at the present time. The Treasurer forecasts that inflation in 1991 will be 6.5 per cent. With respect, I suggest he will be wrong again. He has been wrong every other time he has delivered a Budget since the Budget of 1983. The rate of inflation that we are suffering, compared with some of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries, quite frankly is just a joke. The latest 1990 figures are Australia, 7.7 per cent; Austria, 3 per cent; Belgium, 3.1 per cent; Denmark, 2.4 per cent; West Germany, 2.3 per cent; Japan, 2.5 per cent; and the Netherlands, 2.2 per cent. Yet this is the world's greatest Treasurer with a Budget which is on track. I think most Australians now have become so cynical that every time the Treasurer tells us that his economic plans are working and are on track they have got to the point of having not a laugh behind their hands but a quiet little cry.

It was only on the Friday after the Budget that the Treasurer had a sudden rush of honesty to the head. In the election in March he told us that everything was right and on track. On the Tuesday night of the Budget he said again that everything was fine and hunky dory. But on the following Friday he said-with an uncharacteristic frankness and forthrightness-that Australia was indeed back on the Argentinean road.

One group in our society who must realise and know this, because they are suffering so much, are the farmers of this country. It has been said, and I will say it again and again, that the Australian farming community is the most efficient in the world. All I can say is: God help it if it were not, because the Australian primary producers, suffering under high interest rates and inflation and being devastated by economic conditions, would be in even greater trouble than they are now. This year there is a 48 per cent decrease in the terms of trade for our farmers. On top of that, in this Budget farmers will have to pay 100 per cent of all export inspection, domestic meat inspection and quarantine fees. At the present time they are paying only 60 per cent. With commodity prices down, there will be a further fall in net farm income.

Another feature of the Budget concerning our primary producers is that the actual amount contributed by the Government to agricultural, forestry and fishing industries is continuing to fall. In 1989-90 the Government contributed $445.4m. The budgeted figure for this financial year is $423.3m-down $20m-odd-and the projected figures for the next three years are $356.8m, $349m and $308.9m. The expenditure on our important agricultural, forestry and fishing industries is going down and down. While the Government will spend only $423.3m this year, the rural community will pay $1,369.9m in levies and charges. One cannot talk to me about subsidies for Australian primary producers; they are paying far more than they get.

The Government talks about increases in agricultural expenditure, but most of this $429.7m is the extra money collected from the increase from 8 per cent to 18 per cent in the tax paid by woolgrowers and another $21m in increased levies from the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. This treatment of Australian farmers is just not good enough.

In passing, I take this opportunity-because what is happening in the Persian Gulf is very important-to support the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Government and all of us in this Parliament who are determined that the iniquities of Saddam Hussein shall not be condoned and shall be stopped. When our ships were sent off it was announced that our sailors and other military personnel would get special pay. I have been handed a letter-I hasten to say not from somebody in my electorate, because I would hate the sailor to be harassed in any way-written by one of our sailors to his father. I quote:

Did you hear that we were to get $30 a day and $45 a day in the Gulf area and our pay was to be tax free. It has been 3 weeks since they made that promise and wouldn't you know it, that's as far as they have gone, the pay people keep asking Canberra and all they get is we will get back to you. The boys are getting a little cheesed at that, a lot of money-we could be earning interest on it.

If that is the case, if there has been some delay because of a failure in the bureaucracy, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister should take immediate steps to make sure that that situation is remedied. Those Australian men serving in those ships need and deserve the total support of every Australian, and this Parliament in particular. The question is: When will they know? I hope they will know very soon indeed.

It will come as no surprise to members of this Parliament that, in speaking to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1990-91, I would like to say a word or two about roads. Even though there has been some increase in the allocation for roads in this Budget, in the seven years since the Hawke Government came into office there has been a decrease of 27 per cent in real terms in the money provided for roads in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—I agree that it is indeed a shame, because the roads of Australia are the transport infrastructure. Unless adequate funding is provided, the condition of roads will go backwards at a great rate. Members of the National Party of Australia all know of bitumen roads that local government organisations are having to plough up, because they do not have sufficient funding to continue the maintenance. I know the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) has occasionally taunted me and said, `You want all this money for the Pacific Highway, but you want to cut expenditure too. You can't have your cake and eat it as well'. I suggest one can, because the cake for roads is growing bigger all the time. The amount being collected in fuel levies is increasing. Even from the dreadful situation in the Gulf the windfall in fuel levies will be $100m or more. That should go immediately into a road funding program.

SPEECH.PARA: I must be fair to the Minister for Land Transport and say that I welcome the fact that in the next three years an additional $300m will be spent on the Pacific Highway to take it along the way towards becoming a four-lane dual carriageway divided highway. That must occur. That is not open to debate any more. It was some six years ago when I started campaigning for a new Pacific Highway. When I started, some people said, `Garry Nehl, you are a bit of a nut; that is pie in the sky and you will never get it'. I am not told that any more. Everyone in Australia agrees that the Pacific Highway must have special national priority.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you have worked hard at it!

—Indeed I have, and I thank the shadow Minister for his comment. I welcome the additional funding, but should point out that of that $300m over the next three years, $130m will come from the Federal Government and $170m from the State Government of New South Wales. I take this opportunity to praise Nick Greiner, Wal Murray, the Minister for Roads, Mr Bruce Baird, and their team, for their recognition of the priorities for the Pacific Highway. It will and must be a four-lane dual carriageway divided highway.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the Minister for Land Transport for finally accepting my invitation of a couple of years standing to come up and drive the length of the Pacific Highway from Hexham to the Queensland border. I see that my friend and colleague the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) is present in the chamber. Recently he drove a few hundred kilometres of the highway. I say to the Minister that this issue will not go away until there is a new Pacific Highway. I am going to stick to the Minister like a flea on a dog until we get it.

The Pacific Highway is the major highway in Australia and carries the heaviest volume of traffic. It is significant to all Australians. I would not have the hide to stand here and say that we should spend $1 billion, $2 billion or whatever it takes to upgrade that highway just for my constituents or for the people of the north coast. The issue is much broader than that. The Pacific Highway serves the whole of Australia.

I should briefly mention the fact that the aerodrome local ownership plan (ALOP) is being phased out. It is unfortunate that no consultation occurred with local government owners of local aerodromes before that decision was made. As an example, in my electorate the Kempsey Council this year has a subsidy of $27,000 under ALOP, but it still expects a loss of $25,000 and is looking to a loss of $41,000 in 1991. When the subsidy of $27,000 goes, that will be added to that loss. It is difficult to understand how the small airports will continue to be viable once the Government withdraws from that funding. I wonder how many other communities are in the same boat. Also, the `location specific charger' will be introduced. That is another piece of jargon for landing fees that will be phased in over the next 12 months for aerodromes still under ALOP. Of course, there has been no consultation, and I am most concerned for the future of those aerodromes.

On the broader scene, I make the strongest possible protest about the $200 landing and departure fees at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport in peak times. Those fees are designed to discourage smaller aircraft from landing and will have a disastrous impact on country airlines and commuter airlines. Country people will be vastly disadvantaged by that proposal. Country air services will decline.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ambulance services, too.

—Ambulance services will be affected. More people will be compelled to travel by road, at a greater risk and cost to the nation. It is unfair that the same fee should apply whatever the size of the aircraft. For a nine-seater the fee will be $22 a head. If the aircraft has only five passengers-and that often happens-the fee will be $40 a head. These fees will put the smaller airlines out of business. Compare those fees with that which will apply to a 767 aircraft with 207 passengers, where the fee will be only $1 a head. Even if the aircraft were only half full, which is a rarity, the fee will be only $2 a head. The reason for the introduction of that charge is that there is no third runway at Mascot, and that is because this Government has been unable to grasp the nettle and do what had to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: I should speak also about the Commonwealth Bank and the fact that it will bail out the State Bank of Victoria by privatising 30 per cent of the Commonwealth Bank's capital base. The Treasurer has said that the 30 per cent will be funded by superannuation funds. On an Australian Broadcasting Corporation television program on the night of 28 August the Treasurer agreed that the dividend paid to the Government out of annual profits from the Commonwealth Bank was 22 per cent. The superannuation funds are controlled largely by insurance companies and the trade unions. This 30 per cent privatisation will be highly selective so that big business and the trade unions will be the ones to benefit from it. But what about the battler, what about the ordinary Australian, what about the Commonwealth Bank customers? Why can they not get a piece of the action and buy shares to participate in this 22 per cent profit?

It has been suggested already to the Treasurer by one of my constituents that the 30 per cent interest should be put on offer to every individual, every citizen, every corporation, every superannuation fund and any other legal entity in Australia. Why not have a scheme for all Australians? On the 7.30 Report tonight I heard the Prime Minister telling Paul Lyneham that the Government will privatise up to 49 per cent of Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines Ltd. How about a piece of that cake too for ordinary Australians? Or will that all go to the trade unions and the major companies as well?

During the week when the Budget was brought down I spoke in the grievance debate about the proposed closure of the Medicare agency at Macksville in the Nambucca Valley. As I said then, it is strange that the Medicare office will close when the Commonwealth Employment Service is expanding, and Social Security already has plans to put an office in there. I have had tremendous support from organisations and citizens throughout the Nambucca Valley in making representations to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe). I spoke to him on the day that I contributed to the grievance debate. He has been very sympathetic and I am pleased to say that shortly prior to coming into the chamber tonight I received a letter from the Minister. In part he said:
The Commission has a responsibility to maintain a balance between the provision of Medicare offices throughout Australia and the containment of costs.
I agree with that. He said also in the letter:
In the current economic climate the Commission, in common with all Government departments and agencies, is required to examine its operations against the available funds.

Again, that is fine. What has to be pointed out is that the State Manager of the Health Insurance Commission told me in no uncertain words that the people of the Nambucca Valley could rely on the usual prompt mail service and, as well, that they had to close that agency to find work for the workers in Sydney. I am not prepared at any time to accept blindly and quietly that people in my electorate should be sacked to keep people in jobs in Sydney. This fight will not go away. The Minister concluded his letter by writing:
However, I have asked the Commission to report to me on the circumstances surrounding the decision to close the Macksville agency. I expect a final decision towards the end of October.

I hope that the final decision will be a sane and sensible one. I conclude by making one point, and that is to convey to the Government through the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean), who is at the table, the appreciation and thanks of the Surf Lifesaving Association for the continued financial support, in particular from the Macksville-Scotts Head Surf Life Saving Club, for the rubber duckie which was handed over at the presentation dinner last Saturday night. I say to all members of this Parliament that we must have samaritan conditions for surf lifesaving clubs. We are getting to the point where individual surf lifesavers and clubs are being sued, litigation will boom and the people doing this work on a voluntary basis have to be protected by samaritan indemnity. I appeal to the Government to give this matter strong consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before making some comments from this side of the House on our perspective on the Budget, I would like to endorse the last comments made by the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl). He touches upon a very real problem concerning community service providers. This is indeed a problem in the surf lifesaving movement right around Australia which perhaps needs to be looked at, if not by this Government, then by State governments, to see whether there is a legal base for securing indemnity for people against some of the claims that might be made against them.

SPEECH.PARA: In my contribution tonight I want to touch on one or two issues that were raised by the Budget that has been brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I must take issue with those speakers from the other side of the House who have variously described this as being a dreadful Budget. Some have said that it has been too harsh; others have described it as not being tough enough-which, of course, is the position of the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), and others. The Budget clearly has a strategy which is designed to ensure that the present economic difficulties facing Australia are met head on. It is designed with a clear set of objectives in mind and it is designed to ride through what commentators are at present describing, quite rightly, as a particularly rough period for Australia.

One of the issues which some people seem to be glossing over very readily is the question of unemployment. We hear those honourable members on the other side bleating quite loudly and quite often, suggesting that the Budget estimates which say that unemployment is going to rise are understating the problem and that this is-shock, horror-terrible news. It is convenient that these people forget that in 1983 the unemployment rate in this country was in the double digit figure range-10.3 per cent-that it had been brought about by a `fight inflation first' strategy adopted by the former economic advisers and the former economic Ministers of the Fraser Government and that in the last 12 months of that Government we saw more than 500,000 fellow Australians thrown onto the unemployment scrap heap-as the Treasurer rightly reminds honourable members in this place on different occasions.

It is very easy and very cynical to say that the same sorts of circumstances and the policies being pursued by this Government will lead us to that same conclusion. I think not, simply because the Government has a clear strategy in place which, because of our burgeoning overseas debt problem which has been essentially created by the private sector-and I think even those honourable members on the other side would agree that that is the case-is, in fact, being tackled properly by this Government. One only has to look at the direction in which the Government is proposing to move with regard to the way in which the surplus in prospect is to be utilised to see just how effective our strategy is in that regard.

If one goes to the Budget Papers one can see that Commonwealth debt is, in fact, going down on a yearly basis because the Government chooses to pay it off. In this present debate about asset sales and what should be done with some companies which, at the present time, are under the control of this Government, we have heard suggestions that some of that money should be directed at paying off our overseas debt from the Commonwealth's perspective. That is a view to which I subscribe. This Government's debt has continued to decline progressively over the last few years. It may well suit those on the other side of this place to take a look at some of those figures before they start mouthing some of the platitudes, as they have previously, as to how this Government has caused that overseas debt problem.

The other issue associated with unemployment was clearly explained in an article by Ross Gittins which appeared this week in the Sydney Morning Herald. In that article he said that probably one of the major achievements of the Treasurer was the real growth in jobs in Australia during the past seven years and the real decrease in the unemployment rate. It is, I suppose, strange times indeed when people on both sides of this place, economic commentators and those in the world of business look to unemployment statistics to give them some sort of guidance as to whether the level of domestic demand is being slowed. It really is a strange set of circumstances when people say, `Isn't it good, the unemployment rate has gone up? That must mean that the Government's policies are working' and we translate that to mean that interest rates will start to come down and the economy will stabilise. I believe that the Government, clearly, must keep a weather eye out for those unemployment trends.

In the area that I represent people suffered drastically as a result of the inactivity of the policymakers opposite in their last period of government and the economic recession that befell this country in the early 1980s almost devastated the Illawarra region. I think that I am the third speaker in succession from the Illawarra region to talk from this side of the House on the Budget measures. I know I speak on behalf of the others when I say that we will be working assiduously to ensure that the same sorts of problems that we faced in the early 1980s do not reappear. I feel confident enough to be able to say that that is indeed the case.

It was my real pleasure to be able to attend a breakfast in Wollongong a week after the Budget was delivered which was arranged by the Wollongong business community and to speak on behalf of the Government on what the Budget 1990-91 would mean for the Illawarra region. I was a member of a panel of people who represented Government and Opposition interests, the business community and other levels of government, and it was quite interesting to hear people from the chambers of commerce say that whilst the Budget did not contain measures specifically geared towards the Illawarra region, as had occurred in the past through such measures as the steel regions assistance program and so on, nevertheless it was generally felt that the area had steeled itself-for want of a better pun-to withstand any further attacks, in an economic sense, on our region.

It is quite interesting to see that, in the case of 1980, 1981, 1982, 1983 and 1984, when the recession hit the steel industry for a number of reasons that have been well documented, the massive lay-offs that followed will not be repeated now. It does not necessarily matter if interest rates are at the level at which they are now in an endeavour to slow down domestic demand; the real effect in a region such as the Illawarra will not have anywhere near the disastrous consequences that it had in the past, simply because the work force in major industries in the region cannot be cut further economically.

I also indicate that in our area there has been considerable work at diversifying our economic base. The tourism industry is alive and well and the university is prospering and developing some outstanding programs in association with local industry. I am pleased to see the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean), who is at the table tonight, nod his head when I talk about that because he knows full well that the university and industry, working in partnership, have put forward a number of proposals under the cooperative research projects grants scheme that he administers. He also knows, from his visit to my electorate and to the university, how important those particular projects will be.

As part of the revitalisation that is taking place in the Illawarra it is in telecommunications that we see one of the great advantages that can result. Telecom Australia has moved to the University of Wollongong and is carrying out extensive research work, particularly in the area of fibre optics. It is our view that, through a cooperative research centre project, that level of industrial development and new technology can make Wollongong and the Illawarra the centre for telecommunications throughout the whole of Australia. We believe that there is a real chance for us to advance in that area. We need funding to develop at campus east, which is an adjunct of the University of Wollongong, in order to house the new technology that wants to come to the Illawarra region.

We have been successful in attracting Nortel from northern Canada and, as I have said, we have also been successful in attracting Telecom from within Australia. There are many high-tech companies that would like to come to our region and, in the long term, help create further jobs and opportunities. Because of those activities and because of the work of my colleagues and myself in bringing to the attention of Ministers of this Government the specific needs of our region, we believe that by working in harmony at government level with the business community and with the ordinary working person within the Illawarra region, we have really developed an economy which is a lot stronger and able to withstand some of the other domestic problems confronting other parts of Australia.

I should now take the opportunity to refute a couple of the furphies raised by the Opposition on some of the measures contained in the Budget. The honourable member for Cowper described the Budget as being terribly tough. The honourable member claimed that every time the Treasurer brings down a Budget it affects the aged in Australia and that the pensioners get hit. Let me remind the honourable member that the only thing the Government has done to the aged in the community-until the Budget imposed a $2.50 charge for prescriptions-is ask them to delay receipt of indexed pensions for six weeks on two occasions. That was subsequently also withdrawn.

Yes, the Government has been dreadful to those pensioners by increasing their pension level to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. The Government fully indexed those pensions in line with the consumer price index, and the Government does that automatically three times a year. The Government is also doing dreadful things such as taking aged pensioners out of the tax net so that by 1995 no pensioner in receipt of a social security benefit will pay tax. These are the sorts of dreadful things that this Government is doing to Australian pensioners.

Yes, the Government has done further terrible things by giving an 8.4 per cent real increase to pensioners in the seven years the Labor Party has been in government. Compare that to a miserable decrease of 2.8 per cent in the seven years under the former Liberal-National Party Government in this country. The Government has also done some terrible things as far as the provision of aged care services are concerned. The Government has done terrible things by providing approximately $337.8m for aged persons homes, $27.3m for hostels for the aged and $195.5m for the home and community care program. Those are all the terrible things the Government has done in looking after the aged and the infirm in the community. This is what the dreadful Labor Government has done: it really has no compassion and does not care for the poor battlers in the community, whom we have done nothing for. What absolute rubbish! The quicker those sorts of furphies that are raised by honourable members opposite are shot down, the better it will be.

The Budget also makes one or two very important commitments as far as the Australian Customs Service is concerned. I should like to touch quickly upon a couple of those commitments. As honourable members would be aware, at present the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration is inquiring into the Australian Customs Service. I am a member of that Committee and it should be noted that as the Committee has travelled around Australia and spoken to members of the Customs Service, it has observed a great need for the continued work of that Service.

I am pleased to note in the chamber two honourable members opposite who are on that Committee. The Committee has noted the different needs of the Service that have arisen in different parts of Australia to effectively allow it to undertake the work it does on its own behalf and on behalf of a variety of agencies such as the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and so on.

It is pleasing to note that provision has been made in the Budget for an upgrade on much needed computer equipment to enable the Australian Customs Service at airports and other locations to put in place its pass and tracking systems to keep tabs on people entering and leaving Australia so that people who are on wanted lists or those persons who are trafficking in narcotics, and undesirables of course, are clearly identified. Approximately $18.3m has been made available for that service. Approximately $3m has also been made available for a barrier enforcement strategy, which is clearly needed. I commend the Customs Service for its initiative in installing this type of equipment, especially the latest equipment which was installed at the recently opened international terminal at the Cairns Airport.

There are a number of other areas in which the Budget provides increased funding. Again, this refutes the argument that the Government lacks compassion and, as a Labor Government, does not fairly represent those people whom it is supposed to represent. Let me cite the allocation to the disabled. Something of the order of $3.4 billion is being provided by the Government for disability services. That is a sizeable allocation. However, honourable members who spoke earlier claimed that the increased funding for disabled persons, pensioners and others on social security benefits was too much. Those honourable members also claimed the Government has been too generous.

Yet the honourable member for Cowper bleated that the Government had done terrible things such as tightening up on the family allowance, Austudy and unemployment benefits. Honourable members opposite cannot have it both ways: either they want to see some real cuts made and moneys directed to those who are most in need-that is, cut out the middle class welfare-or they do not. They should make up their minds when they start getting involved in looking at the Budget Papers in a little more detail.

Finally, I turn to the Budget Papers to deal with an area that is near and dear to my heart, and that is sport. I and the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), and other honourable members, were responsible in no small measure for ensuring that the Government commitment to funding for sport in Australia increased massively as a result of an inquiry that we undertook during the life of the last Parliament. It is pleasing to say that there is an allocation in the Budget of approximately $75m for sport.

That allocation covers programs in which every day people will have the opportunity to participate in health and fitness programs. The philosophy behind it is that if people are encouraged by either role models or by other activities to undertake a more healthy lifestyle, at the end of the day whichever government is in power, it will cut the social cost of having to provide medication, hospital care, health benefits and so on.

The Government has adopted an approach that earlier governments should have adopted, and that is one of prevention. For example, $3m has been committed to the international swimming championships to be held in Perth next year. The improvements to the facilities for those championships will be most welcome. Generally the outlay for all sports programs has been increased, in real terms, by 28 per cent.

Some of the other programs which the increase in sport touches upon are things like elite athlete assistance, sports science, sports medicine, applied sports research and community programs. Of course, there is an allocation of $6m to pick up some of the community sport and recreation programs which were announced last year and which have to be covered in this Budget. Funding has also been increased for the Australian Sports Drug Agency. I am sure all honourable members would certainly applaud what has been done to weed out those people in sport who would bring it into disrepute by using performance-enhancing drugs. In that respect, we all pay a great deal of tribute to the former Senator John Black for the work he did with the Senate inquiry in that area. National sporting organisations and community sports groups are also receiving funding.

This is an appropriate way for the Government to develop across-the-board support for sport. However, if I do have a criticism of the Budget allocation for sport it is not that it is not enough but that there is no national facility sports program in place. While people would recognise that the spending of $190m on the Olympic Games bid is appropriate, naturally, the people in the capital city of Melbourne will be the ones to benefit. That is great but in regional centres such as Wollongong, Geelong or regional centres like the Hunter--

TALK.START.PARA: —Hobart.

—or regional centres out of Hobart in Tasmania, people do not get the benefit, even though there are programs in place which we in the local community are supporting. For example, in the Illawarra district for approximately two years there has been a proposal for an indoor sports entertainment centre. The construction of that centre hinges upon getting Federal and State funding. The problem is that there is no funding available, as there was some years ago, to support the construction of that centre.

SPEECH.PARA: People's views on this matter should expand beyond the capital cities. Everything should not be thrown at Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane, Adelaide, Perth and so on. The regional centres should not be forgotten because they are the ones that require support as well. The Budget goes a great deal towards supporting the objectives of the Government, and I commend it to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Moore, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I stand here as the new member for Moore I find it difficult to convey the feelings of honour and intense pride this moment has aroused in me. I am, I believe, the first former police officer to be elected as a coalition member to the Parliament. I follow in the footsteps of two earlier policemen who have made their mark in this chamber, Dr Jim Cairns and His Excellency the Governor-General, the Hon. Bill Hayden.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently I had the opportunity to meet His Excellency and inform him personally of this fact. He remarked to me that on his appointment to the office of Governor-General, the Queensland Police Union wrote to him and said, `Well done, Bill. As a former Queensland police officer, you've gone the furthest yet.' Presumably members of the Queensland Police Union have some loftier position in mind for their former colleagues.

I would not be standing here addressing this House were it not for the efforts of those who worked tirelessly on my behalf in my campaign in March and who continue to assist me. I therefore take this opportunity in this, the greatest of Australian public forums, to thank them all once again.

I would also like to make special mention of the great assistance provided to me by my State Liberal parliamentary colleague, the Hon. Reg Davies, MLC, whose advice, encouragement and organisational feats formed the essential components of the campaign's success. Reg has always been a great friend and supporter. He has stood by me through good times and bad. Never during those tumultuous years has his support or his friendship wavered.

Sometimes one takes the most ardent supporters for granted, all too often unthinkingly relying on their continuous backing as a matter of course. To my wife Geraldine and sons James and Phillip, who are back in Perth and who have long put up with the tension, absences and financial constraints that go hand in hand with modern political campaigns, I thank you dearly.

Of course, that campaign would not have been the success that it was had it not been for the faith the people of Moore placed in me. Ultimately it is to them that I owe the greatest thanks for allowing me to stand here as their representative and address this chamber. I intend to repay the compliments they have shown in me by working hard on their behalf and by providing a strong voice for them in this Parliament.

I would like to speak a little about the man after whom my electorate is named, George Fletcher Moore. I find in his character the quality of unselfish devotion to public duty, a quality that I intend to emulate as the representative of the electorate that bears his name.

Moore arrived in Fremantle in 1830 after a gruelling voyage from Ireland. Initially he sought an official legal position within the fledgling colony but, having been unsuccessful in obtaining such a position through the Colonial Office in London, he decided to sponsor his own journey to Western Australia. While farming eventually displaced his legal interests, Moore was a man of boundless energy who always took a keen interest in the colony's progress. He found an outlet for this energy in exploration and it was due to his efforts that desperately needed grazing land in the York and Northam districts was opened up to land hungry colonists.

He also utilised his legal skills in the service of the colony of Western Australia as the first Commissioner of the Civil Court, as Chairman of Quarter Sessions, and ultimately as Advocate-General. By virtue of his office, he became an early member of the Legislative and Executive Councils and did very useful work as a parliamentary draftsman. Although he also had the right to engage in private practice and reap the attendant financial rewards, there is no record of his having done so. Such was the spirit of the man whose name is carried by my electorate, such was the spirit of the man whose example I hope to emulate as the new member for Moore.

I am, however, no stranger to such concepts of public duty. At an early age my father, Terry Filing, a group captain in the Royal Australian Air Force, instilled in me the importance of placing duty before one's personal well-being. In fact, my most cherished memory is of me as a child accompanying my parents and brother to Buckingham Palace in 1965. There Her Majesty the Queen invested my father with the Air Force Cross for his exceptional leadership, airmanship and courage exhibited during an incident in which he safely landed the Handley Page Victor he was flying after losing three of the four engines. He is present this evening, along with my mother, who has demonstrated her own quiet courage and determination during a 10-year struggle with serious illness.

The notions of public service impressed on me by my father were further enhanced during my years with the Western Australian Police Force. From my days of walking the beat as a young constable to my time in the company fraud squad, my work made me acutely aware of my duty to society and of the need to make it a better and safer place in which to live. At the WA police academy there is a notice to which the attention of all new recruits is drawn. It simply says, `Cultivate a thick hide; you'll need it.'

May I take this opportunity to acknowledge the tremendous efforts of my former colleagues in the Western Australian Police Force. I am proud to serve alongside men and women who selflessly assist the community with little thanks or recognition and with pay and conditions that do not reflect the sacrifices they are required to make daily in the pursuit of this duty.

Indeed, we, the elected representatives of the people, must devote ourselves to similar concepts of public duty, for it is this duty that forms the very bedrock upon which our Westminster system of government is built. I believe it was Edmund Burke who provided the most comprehensive definition of the Westminster model of parliamentary representation in his address to the electors of Bristol. He said:

Certainly, gentleman, it ought to be the happiness and glory of a representative to live in the strictest union, the closest correspondence, and the most unreserved communication with his constituents . . . But his unbiased opinion, his mature judgment, his enlightened conscience, he ought not to sacrifice to you, to any man, or to any set of men living . . . Parliament is not a congress of ambassadors from different and hostile interests, which interests each must maintain, as an agent and advocate, against other agents and advocates; but Parliament is a deliberative assembly of one nation, with one interest, that of the whole . . . You choose a member indeed; but when you have chosen him, he is not the member of Bristol, but a member of Parliament.

We therefore have a duty to the people of our electorates, a duty to support and protect their rights and interests, a duty to legislate wisely on their behalf, a duty to ensure that the Executive does not abuse its power or exercise it arbitrarily, to protect our system of democracy. Should we forget that duty we shall forfeit our right to be here. The will of the people of our electorates will have it so.

Yet, as the findings published in the recently released McCusker report demonstrate, despite that report's extraordinarily narrow terms of reference, the Labor Government of Western Australia abandoned this duty to pursue short term financial gain, losing in the process hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money.

The Government of Western Australia was elected by the people of that State to administer them with honesty and integrity. The people of Western Australia paid their taxes in the belief that these funds would be wisely spent and the benefits of that expenditure would accrue to them in the form of a stable administration and better services.

Just how were these taxes spent? The McCusker report illustrates a government bedazzled by its high-flying entrepreneur mates, seducing them with tacky and shoddy get-rich-quick schemes. In the Rothwells fiasco alone, the Government lost something in the order of $300m of public moneys through repeated rescue attempts of a company that was apparently being bled dry by its chief executive. The Rothwells collapse represents a mere episode in the long and sordid saga that is WA Inc.. In all, the Western Australian Government squandered something in the order of $700m of taxpayers' money in worthless big business dealings.

I appreciate that for some in this chamber the affairs of Western Australia may appear to be of limited relevance. I would, however, stress the contrary. In his Budget Speech the Treasurer (Mr Keating) referred to the standard of behaviour of some individuals in Australia's corporate sector having fallen short of what should be expected by the general community. The honourable gentleman talked of his Government's ensuring the regulation of corporate activity in the interests of ordinary shareholders and investors, and yet the business dealings of his Labor counterparts in the Western Australian Government, roundly condemned as irresponsible and often camouflaged to the shareholders-that is, the people-behind the excuse of commercial confidentiality, has escaped his criticism.

The decisions that shaped WA Inc. not only bore the hallmarks of administrative ineptitude and financial incompetence but also represented a rancorous betrayal by members of the Government of the people of Western Australia, who had entrusted to them the right to govern, and a betrayal of our system of democracy under which they were bound by duty to provide fair and honest government.

The deception and corruption that the entrepreneurs' money cultivated in the Government of Western Australia is of particular interest to me for I too was a victim. Before the Federal election of 1987 I was required to resign from the Western Australian Police Force to contest the seat of Cowan. Shortly before this my colleagues in the company fraud squad arrested and charged the then Chairman of the State Superannuation Board, Mr Len Brush, on charges of public corruption and forgery. Mr Brush, who held several key government posts and whose wife was the Premier's personal assistant, was alleged to have accepted a $150,000 loan from Perth businessman Robert Martin on condition that he would use his influence on the State Superannuation Board in Martin's favour.

Whilst Mr Brush was ultimately acquitted of all charges, the affair was not forgotten. Having been unsuccessful in winning the seat of Cowan, I contacted the Commissioner of Police seeking reappointment to my old position. I was informed that I would be required to go through the standard selection procedures, that there would be a one-year waiting list and that I would be required to resume at the rank of the most junior member of the force. Hence I lost my rank, my long service leave entitlements and my superannuation simply because I dared to participate in the democratic process. For whatever reasons the powers that be in Western Australia decided to punish me for seeking office, it represented an insidious and unforgivable attack on our system of parliamentary democracy.

Democracy by its very nature is dependent upon the participation of the people. It may be cliched; however, nothing defines that concept of democracy better than the axiom: `Government of the people, for the people, and by the people'. As our system of democracy is all about the people, I would like to take this opportunity to describe the electorate and the people I represent in this House, for they are foremost in my mind as I stand here as their representative addressing this chamber for the first time on their behalf.

The division of Moore lies framed by the Liberal-held seats of O'Connor in the north and Pearce to the east in the northern suburbs of metropolitan Perth. To the south it borders upon the Labor-held seats of Cowan and Stirling, which were until the last election considered safe for that Party. To the west the Indian Ocean washes up on to sun-bleached beaches which have largely survived unblighted the refuse of urban expansion.

Encapsulated within Moore is the modern Australian predicament. The electorate is mostly situated in one of the fastest growing municipalities in Australia, the city of Wanneroo, with a population of 150,000. The city of Wanneroo forms a major growth area within the State, its suburbs forever reaching further north as new parcels of land are opened up for development to cater for those who seek to realise the greatest of Australian dreams, the establishment of a home of their own. From the crisp white sands that line the Indian Ocean in the west, a sea of tiled roofs and bricks punctuated by television aerials and power lines extend inland to the Darling Ranges. Grey tongues of bitumen probe vast sand-blown blocks of land that stand empty, expectantly awaiting new arrivals. Within months hopeful young families will begin cementing their dreams upon this land in bricks and mortar.

The people who have imprinted their hopes and aspirations upon these raw tracks of sandy ground come from all sections of society. They are market gardeners, cray fishermen, public servants and small businessmen; they are white collar workers and blue collar workers. Indeed, I too am one of these people. This is suburbia. This is the distinctive Australian landscape so aptly defined by that great Western Australian, Sir Walter Murdoch, when he wrote:

Your suburban villa, and even your Shakespeare Society, are just as much parts of the real Australia as Chamber's Pillar; more's the pity, perhaps, but the fact is so. The cities we have built may be plagiarisms but they are as real as the vast sunburnt land on whose outer edge we have chosen to build them.

If we look into the minds of those who live in the electorate of Moore we may gain a lucid and accurate insight into the mind of middle Australia at present. In the last election the sitting member for Moore, Mr Allen Blanchard, experienced a swing against him of 18 per cent in the primary count. This was not because Allen Blanchard was a bad member; indeed, in the adjoining seats of Stirling and Cowan there were swings against Labor of 11 and 14 per cent respectively. I believe that we may quite safely draw the conclusion from the response of the people of Moore at the last election that they were sending a short and sharp message to the Government.

From the Australian heartland an anguished cry arose and permeated the national tally room: `Enough is enough'. The people of Moore said that they resented having to bear the brunt of the Government's economic incompetence, which relies so heavily on high domestic interest rates to reduce consumer demand. The first-time home buyers of Moore were saying that they did not want to be financially beholden to the banks for the rest of their working lives simply because they could not keep up with the extortionate monthly repayments. The small business people of Moore were saying that they did not want to see businesses that they had devoted their whole lives to building up, injecting every ounce of available capital into them in an effort to make them secure, fall into the hands of liquidators as a direct result of a government sponsored recession.

These are the concerns and fears of the voters of Moore. These are the harsh realities that daily descend upon the lives of average families throughout Australia. These are the truths of our so-called economic recovery, where families are forced to have two breadwinners to ensure that the weekly bills are met, where young Australians are delaying or even putting off having children because of the constraints of seven years of Labor financial mismanagement.

The people of Moore have demanded change. That is why I stand here as their new conservative member of parliament. Many of the honourable members who sit opposite me in this chamber may find the terms `change' and `conservative' incongruous. However, the realities of modern Australian politics have rendered them synonymous. Indeed, in the past, in the minds of some commentators on the Australian political system, the Labor Party has assumed the mantle of the party of initiative while the conservative parties are dismissed as merely the parties of resistance. That strikes me as being laughingly obsolete as I stand here in this, the Thirty-sixth Australian Parliament.

Nothing demonstrates the converse better than the recent Budget. Undoubtedly it will go down in history as the great cop-out Budget. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) seems either to have lost his nerve or to have sacrificed economic sanity on the altar of personal ambition. What has happened to the wide ranging micro-economic reform promised by the Government during this session of Parliament? I feel a remarkable sense of deja vu as I see the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Deputy, like their predecessors Arthur Calwell and Gough Whitlam, awaiting the decision of the 36 faceless men before daring to implement Government policy.

So this is the Party of initiative. I see before me a government that has been in power for too long, a government that is bereft of ideas and direction. That is a government that the people of my electorate demonstrated in the last election had betrayed them. That is the sort of government Australia cannot afford in the current economic crisis.

I feel immensely privileged to have entered this Parliament as part of the most talented political team Australia has seen. These faces that occupy the benches around me are the future of this country. We all share an old philosophy that now stands triumphant above the citadels of collectivist thought. We are the exponents of the philosophy that represents the future. We believe that freedom, both economic and political, is indivisible, that the economy ought to be left to regulate itself through the invisible hand of market forces with governments making and enforcing the rules of fair play. The States should not be a fairy godmother magically appearing at the maternity hospital, then, arm in arm, travelling alongside us on life's journey, whispering soothingly into our ears before finally standing as a silent mourner at the graveside.

Yet over the last century government has extended its tentacles into most facets of everyday life, conforming to a Fabian timetable of state ownership. We as conservatives stand committed to rolling back the intolerable precedent of government interference that has permeated every aspect of day to day life. Yet despite the most overwhelming rejection of collectivism by its former victims in eastern Europe, here in Australia we have a government that still quibbles over an increasingly irrelevant and outmoded party platform.

It is now only too clear that the reforms necessary to extricate our country from this economic malaise will only come following the election of the coalition in 1993 or earlier. I am therefore proud to call myself a Liberal in times like these, I am proud to be able to expound the philosophy of the future, and I am proud to be a member of the team that almost certainly shall form the next government of Australia.
Honourable members-Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) on his maiden speech. If he earns the respect from both sides of the House that his predecessor enjoyed he will be doing very well.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise a few items relating to the Budget. In particular, I was impressed by some of the remarks of the honourable member for Moore in relation to the reaction of his constituents. It is ironic that the honourable member for Moore can make a maiden speech deploring the impact of this Government's action when in response to the Budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) got up and said, `You really haven't done the hard work. We really need to cut $3,000m more out of Federal Government expenditure'.

What that means for the electorate of Chifley is prospective cuts for my six pensioner clubs, affecting the senior citizens that go along to them. Perhaps we would not be getting the child-care centres that I am so proud of and will speak on later. Perhaps people would not be enjoying Austudy and have that encouragement. At least $1 billion of savings can be made there if, as the Opposition believes, Government expenditure needs to be cut by $3,000m.

In addition, the Opposition not only believes that we ought to be cutting back Federal expenditure by 3,000m, bearing in mind that it is the smallest it has been for some time expressed as a percentage of gross domestic product, but it also now believes that we ought to introduce a consumption tax. When my electors go to the supermarkets and fork out their money-to be frank, they often complain about the increasing prices they face at supermarkets-they will get a once-off hit of 15 per cent on every item that they purchase. This will follow through to every aspect of their lives, and this will be particularly noticeable for those who currently do not enjoy any government assistance. For example, when they go to have a haircut they will find that haircuts are 15 per cent more. Petrol is already heavily taxed. We hear Opposition speakers time after time complaining about the amount of excise on petrol tax, but under them petrol will cost 15 per cent more.

We on the Government side very much reject the notion of imposing a consumption tax. The thing that fascinates me most is that the Opposition is going to do away with industry policy. There will be no tariffs and no measures of assistance to industry. There will be no government intervention in an attempt to get strategic industries going. But this should come as no surprise to manufacturers and it should come as no surprise to small business because the Opposition is always changing its industry policy. Every time it has a change of shadow Minister it trundles out a new industry policy. At least up front, nice and early, it is mentioning that it will not have an industry policy.

I have a particular vested interest in raising child-care at this time. I am very proud of the Government's record in child-care. Since 1983 the Hawke Government has increased the number of child-care places from 46,000 to 114,000. Expenditure on the children's services program has increased from $62m in 1982-83 to an estimated $232m this year. In the 1988-89 Budget the Treasurer announced a new national child-care strategy to provide a further 30,000 places over four years. The national strategy includes 20,000 outside school hours places, 4,000 centre based places, 4,000 family day care places and 2,000 occasional care places. Up to 1,000 of the 4,000 centre based places will be available for the industry program under which costs will be shared between employers and the Commonwealth employees using the centres. An estimated 8,240 of the new places under the national strategy will be available by the end of this financial year.

Already in the electorate of Chifley, I am very proud to tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, we have 813 long day care places, 88 occasional care places, 350 family day care places and 1,548 outside school hours places, making a total of 2,799 places. I am sure you will not be surprised to hear, Mr Deputy Speaker, that Chifley is targeted as an area of high need. Whilst this Government may share a vision for wanting to provide the men and women, the families of Australia, with more child-care places, I am sad to report that that vision is certainly not shared by Blacktown City Council.

Let me explain that. In 1987 at Bowman Hall, the main hall owned by Blacktown Council, the Blacktown Migrant Resource Centre held a seminar entitled `Where to in the 1990s?'. Over 500 people attended that seminar, and I was one of them. Blacktown City Council, being the host council, was invited to send its representatives but not one turned up. But more importantly, arising out of that seminar, arising out of having 500 people together trying to look at what was needed in the 1990s, a number of clear things came out. There was one very identifiable need-the need for a child-care centre that specifically catered for the needs of those migrants for whom English is a second language.

In Blacktown we have a very large migrant population. The largest group would be the Maltese. We have lots of Yugoslavs, Germans and Poles. There are lots of Filipinos. There is a very good mixture. We have Afghans and people from Mauritius. People from all over the world come to Blacktown. I have said many a time that I am very pleased to receive them. Arising out of this seminar was this proposal for a child-care centre. It would be not just to service Blacktown; it would be a focus for migrant people not only in Blacktown but regionally as well.

On 20 April 1990, after having discussed the matter with the town clerk, I sent him a letter saying that I strongly supported this proposal. I pointed out the advantages of this proposal to the council and the people of Blacktown. I asked him, since I was fairly confident that we would get Federal Government funding because the relevant department was represented on the committee, as was the relevant State department, whether the council could provide a block of land so that we could construct this child-care centre. Last Wednesday night at council the report went to open council. Surprise, surprise, in that Liberal controlled, so-called independent council what was the result? They said no to this child-care centre. But they said no because they believed that it would lead to segregation.

I can tell honourable members of the complete hypocrisy of the Liberal alderman, Alan Green. He and I were together on Saturday. I spoke first at Carnivale, where I said how strongly I supported this Government's multicultural policies and multicultural approach; that I was not threatened by the differences of different people coming to settle in Blacktown and I recognised that they contributed a unique quality to Blacktown that enriched us. I was not threatened, and I said that it was a challenge to make sure that no-one else was threatened.

Alderman Alan Green followed and said, `I endorse all of the remarks of Mr Price and on behalf of council I open Carnivale'. His saying that he supports multiculturalism is a lie and a damned lie. Following that, on the Wednesday night he said, `We can't have this child-care centre because it would lead to segregation'.

What is happening here is that we have a racist council. When overseas dignitaries like the Prime Minister of Malta visit the council area, council members get up and say, `We value the contribution of the Maltese community, we support a multicultural society'. They are hypocrites and racist because every time they have to put their hands in their pockets, admittedly only to provide the land, they want to reject the idea. It is unnecessary and it leads to segregation. It is just poppycock.

Of course there is an advantage in having a child-care centre where the children are from families who have English as a second language. I am never afraid of multiculturalism or of different groups saying that they want to preserve their cultures. Frankly, Mr Deputy Speaker, in your electorate as in mine, over time people become very much Australian. They very much mix into society, and they bring with them some values that we often pick up and incorporate into our broader society. But they are not a threat to us. In terms of settling down into a city area, these ethnic groups need assistance. They have special needs. Report after report demonstrates that. That is not good enough for Blacktown Council. It says, `No, we don't want it. We believe in multiculturalism but we want the freedom to practise a racist policy whenever we like'.

I do not know whether Alderman Alan Green speaks with authority as an acolyte of his local State member. I do not know whether the State member shares that view; I hope not. Certainly she has never given me any indication that that would be the case.

What is the situation? Where does that leave us? For my part I am always happy to see facilities being provided for the City of Blacktown, but I know that the Labor council in Penrith will be absolutely delighted to pick up this project. I have spoken to the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott), who loves getting new facilities for his electorate, and he is as keen as mustard to pick it up. So another facility that could have been a very good focus for our migrant community in Blacktown will go to another area.

I also want to raise the broader issue of the way in which council runs its child-care centres. We have quite a number of council run child-care centres. There is not one parent body at any of those centres. The parents cannot claim ownership, they cannot have an input into the way in which the centres are run and they are not even allowed to undertake voluntary fund raising. In fact, it is very much an autocratic operation, made more autocratic by this independent, so-called Liberal-controlled Council. It has made it a lot worse.

That is not all. The centres have enormous trouble holding staff because of the inadequate support given by Blacktown City Council, and the dictatorial way in which they are run by the Council's Campbell Street head office. The Council pays, in comparison with Penrith and surrounding councils, very poor wages. So we have this constant staff turnover. I speak up on the main issue: the citizens of Blacktown, in federally funded council child-care centres, ought to be able to have a say. There ought to be a local management committee at every centre.

I will be raising with the Minister at the earliest opportunity this issue of Blacktown City Council rejecting this application which is supported by the Federal and State departments. I will be raising with the Minister that federally funded child-care centres in the City of Blacktown do not accord with good management principles, and are not allowing the citizens and parents of Blacktown to exercise their rights. I regret to say that inevitably I will be forced to approach the Penrith Council or Parramatta Council to ensure that this facility, a concept born out of a seminar in Blacktown that the Council refused to hold, is not lost to the western suburbs.

I also say that it is rather tragic that the Blacktown Council rejected an offer by the Federal Government to build a child-care centre and instead chose to use section 94 contributions to build a child-care centre in Minchinbury. It did not consult with the Federal Government, and we have a real funding problem there. I was working, I thought with reasonable success, through the Minister's office and the Department to get funding for that. No doubt the outrageous activities that occurred at the council meeting last night, bringing disrepute not only to the Council but tragically to the people of Blacktown, have undermined any prospect for success that I might have had.

There were some other matters that I wanted to raise. I am pleased to report to the House that we had a very successful visit by the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown). You may recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, from our policy speech that Federal money was being provided for outer metropolitan urban centres to improve public infrastructure. I was able to inspect, with the cooperation of my good friends and colleagues the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free) and the honourable member for Greenway (Mr Gorman), the bus terminal at St Mary's, the one at Mount Druitt and also the one at Blacktown. Whilst it is the State Government that sets the priority for new bus terminals, I certainly hope that they will rate highly on the list presented by the State Government. It is certainly true to say that, if the State Minister is not aware of the circumstances of these depots, certainly the Federal Minister is.

I also wanted to raise very quickly a couple of other issues, but I will not have time to do so. In particular, the honourable member for Moore in his maiden speech worried about whether the Government was going to deliver micro-economic reform. The thing that really amuses us on this side of the House is that the Opposition, in its 30 years in government, had every opportunity to introduce all the things that it believed in. Today we were reminded yet again by the Treasurer in relation to the two-airline policy that the Opposition, when faced with the opportunity to remove that and institute micro-economic reform, of course fumbled the ball. Not only did it extend it, but it entrenched it and required at least 12 months notice of the abolition of the agreement. Indeed, this Government wanted to move earlier but was not able to.
