In looking at any of the other major issues, such as the upgrading of our railways and reform of the waterfront, one sees that it is this Government that has taken the initiative and is getting stuck into the hard issues. Notwithstanding the rhetoric that comes from the other side of the House, it is this Government that is leading the way, in cooperation with the employers and the trade unions, to provide real micro-economic reform on the waterfront.

Lastly, I place on record that prior to the last election I was very much in favour of an inquiry into the banks. I opposed the appointment of an independent banking ombudsman and believed there should be a public banking ombudsman. It is a fact that that inquiry did not go ahead. But given some of the disclosures since the last election, particularly the lending policies of the banks and the way in which the banks are now starting to foreclose on small business, if ever there were a time for a full public inquiry by an ad hoc standing committee of this Parliament into the banks, I believe now is the time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, before I speak specifically to Appropriation Bill (No. 1), I want to pay tribute to the fine maiden speech made by my colleague from Western Australia, the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing). At the same time, I would like to pay tribute to each of those honourable members who, since this Parliament commenced, have made maiden speeches. Each has made a particular contribution. Without exception, the speeches have shown various degrees of merit, which shows promise for the contribution those honourable members will be able to make in the years ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: I would enjoin those honourable members on the other side of the House who have made their maiden speeches to remember that executive government will ride over them unless they exercise their rights. I ask those honourable members to try to develop a respect for the parliamentary process, which is in danger of being lost as a result of the trend towards executive imperialism which is evident in this Parliament. That will be a matter for them to decide in the fullness of time. I do not want to preach to them and I am sure they will not let me do so very often.

There have been few episodes more despicable in the recent history of Australian politics-and I use the word `despicable' advisedly, knowing that it is one that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) likes to use; he has that in common with Sylvester the cat, but Sylvester delivers it with more conviction and class than the Prime Minister-than the Government's bout of post-election honesty about the state of the economy. In the weeks following the campaign, senior Labor Ministers and former members of the Government let slip that they had deliberately engineered a recession as the cornerstone of economic policy. The first indicators of that recession were in evidence during the election campaign, but it was only after the election that the true extent of the current economic downturn was admitted by some Ministers and a former senior Minister.

It was without the benefit of this information that the electorate narrowly returned the Government. How much different the decision of the people of Australia could have been had they known of the economic hardship that was about to be thrust upon them by a government devoid of policy solutions for this country's economic problems. Faced with record current account deficits and a mounting foreign debt, the Government resorted to the only strategy it is capable of-a deepening recession in the private sector.

Recession is the best, the absolute best, solution this Government can find to restore external and internal balance to the economy. The Government seeks to choke off demand for imports by flattening the economy and succeeds instead in throttling all demand. It goes without saying that this is no solution to our current account and external debt problems. Nor is it a substitute for improved productivity and export performance. Positive, outward looking solutions are beyond the capacity of this Government.

In the meantime, there is considerable evidence that the Government's high interest rate and recessionary strategies have been counterproductive. In recent months, we have witnessed recessed private demand, a declining profit share, a deterioration in the labour market, increased bankruptcies, and falling output and investment across significant areas of the economy. Yet despite all the policy-induced hardship, the current account has continually failed to show any significant improvement.

The current account deficit for 1989-90 was higher than that for 1988-89, increasing from 5.3 per cent to 5.6 per cent of the gross domestic product (GDP). Net foreign debt has mounted to $124 billion. At the end of March this year, foreign debt stood at 34.3 per cent of GDP, up from 32.6 per cent at the end of June 1989. The annual debt servicing ratio has increased considerably from 17.2 per cent at the end of June last year to 19.8 per cent at the end of June this year. It is widely thought that foreign debt will not stabilise until the current account deficit is reduced to about 2.5 per cent of GDP.

This result is hardly surprising. The Government's high interest rates have produced an artificially high Australian dollar. The dollar has defied recent attempts by the Reserve Bank of Australia to keep it down. This, in turn, has reduced the price of our imports and raised the price of our exports-the exact opposite of the result that should have been sought and achieved. High interest rates have also attracted greater foreign capital inflow, adding to the current account deficit.
These are factors which the Reserve Bank itself has noted. In its annual report and financial statements of 30 June 1989, the Reserve Bank noted:
In the short run, there may be perverse effects on the balance of payments if higher interest rates produce an exchange rate appreciation.

That is exactly what we witness today. As well, the findings of two senior private sector economists were outlined in an article in the Australian Financial Review of 8 May this year in which they concluded:
It is probable that Australia is experiencing a policy-induced recession to solve a current account and foreign debt problem which was, in large part, the result of the policy stance itself.

Their conclusions are based, in part, on Reserve Bank research, the very body responsible for administering the Government's restrictive monetary policy. Indeed, in June this year, the Reserve Bank Deputy Governor, Mr John Phillips, in a speech to the Committee for Economic Development of Australia, said:

Monetary policy is not primarily about resolving Australia's balance of payments problem . . . It is blindingly obvious that while tighter monetary policy reduces spending and therefore imports, which is good for the current account, higher interest rates do tend to hold up the exchange rate. That is good for inflation, but not what exporters or those competing with imports would like.

No-one is advocating undisciplined monetary policy. What is being pointed out is the complete bankruptcy of the Government's crude efforts at demand management as a means of addressing the current account deficit. Killing off growth in the economy is not a solution to the imbalance in savings and investment in Australia. It does nothing to address the structural problems which are the cause of this imbalance. In the absence of other policy measures, high interest rates have been and are simply a recipe for recession. Mr Phillips also noted that the Government faces a real risk that its tight monetary policy will flatten out the `real side of the economy without stabilising the price side'.

The Government's appalling performance on inflation throughout its term in office bears out this conclusion. Inflation under this Government has been far in excess of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average and is currently running at about 8 per cent. The calls by the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Mr Fraser, for urgent government action in the area of micro-economic reform must be seen in this light. It seems that everyone but the Government is aware of the desperate need for structural reform to complement monetary policy.
In its most recent annual report the Reserve Bank notes:

Lower inflation will assist in improving Australia's savings and competitiveness but different policies must always attack these other structural problems if sustained and excessive reliance on interest rates (with all that that implies for business investment and competitiveness, especially in the traded-goods sector) is to be avoided.

No-one seriously thinks of high interest rates as a substitute for structural adjustment, but that is the policy on which this Government has relied and, by the indicators in this Budget, on which it will continue to rely. In his Budget Speech, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) informs us that fiscal policy will now be `the Government's principal weapon in the fight against the current account deficit and our overseas debt'. But the outlays and revenue measures foreshadowed in this Budget suggest that the Treasurer is simply graduating from being a failed monetarist to a born-again big spender.

Nobody is fooled by this Government's Budget surpluses. We all know where the money comes from. In previous years the surplus has been largely tax driven. This year it consists of a fiddling of debt between the Commonwealth and the States, asset sales, returns from government business enterprises, and a massive $370m windfall in provisional tax payments. The other area of saving is in Commonwealth payments to the States, which have been cut by $482m. If only the Government would apply the same degree of spending restraint to itself as it imposes upon the States. If it had, as Dr David Clark has pointed out, the surplus for 1989-90 would have been a massive $20 billion or more.

No such restraint on the part of the Commonwealth is evident in this Budget. The Commonwealth's own purpose payments will increase by 2.4 per cent in real terms in 1990-91. The real savings announced in the Budget-that is, the cuts in Commonwealth Government spending programs-are pathetic. They scrape the bottom of Labor's empty policy barrel. In contrast, the coalition's Economic Action Plan identified $2.7 billion in possible spending cuts, coupled with tax relief for Australian families. But this Government's expenditure review process could come up with only a miserable $534m in cuts from Commonwealth programs.

The coalition sought a mandate for real fiscal restraint, not simply to play with the figures in the manner of the Treasurer. It is not surprising then to find that there is no substantial tax relief for Australians in this Budget. The Treasurer boasts that Australia is the third lowest taxing country in the OECD. Does he really expect us to congratulate him for keeping taxes below the levels experienced in such fiefdoms of democratic socialism as Sweden, Denmark and the Netherlands? What about the United States? What about the dynamic economies of Asia, such as Hong Kong, that are not members of the OECD? Surely it is their tax performance that we should be emulating if we are serious about competing in the world economy.

The few tax concessions in this Budget are uninspiring, to say the least. They tinker at the edges of complex and burdensome tax laws which are the bane of this country's economic performance. The Government's tax law continues to be totally insensitive towards the needs of business. For example, the Treasurer will continue to require companies to decide upon and partly settle their tax obligations within 28 days of the end of the financial year, with only minor concessions. This measure, with its devastating impact on company cash flows, has acted as an effective increase in the tax burden on companies since its introduction, and all for the sake of last year's fraudulent surplus.

In failing to offer significant tax relief to small business-in particular, greater rollover relief under the capital gains tax-the Government has ignored the recommendations of its own Beddall report on small business. In other words, this Budget fails even the test set by members of the Treasurer's own Government, his own Party. Rather than getting on with the job of reforming and simplifying the tax law, the Treasurer sees the Budget as an excuse to take up cudgels against the coalition's consumption tax-the goods and services tax (GST) initiative. But all the while his renewed efforts to patch up the wholesale tax system announced in this Budget will give the lie to his post-1985 repudiation of a broad-based consumption tax.

The Treasurer's criticisms of a broad based consumption tax involve a rewriting of his own consumption tax proposal in the 1985 draft White Paper-and he knows it. The Treasurer now grossly underestimates the revenue that will be collected by a GST. Similarly, he has artificially increased the amount needed to compensate individuals for the effects of such a tax. Only by distorting all the relevant assumptions-some of them his-can the Treasurer misrepresent the efficacy of a consumption tax.

It goes without saying: this Budget is a total abrogation of responsibility. It is a total abrogation of responsible government. All the significant reform measures that this country needs have been put off until some indefinite time in the future-many probably forever. The absence of any substantial measures of structural reform, whether in the form of true privatisation, wage and productivity measures or tax reform, confirms what we already know about this Government: it is paralysed by indecision. It is unable to free itself from the intellectual backwardness of its own Party and backbench. The vital decisions required of the Government are caught up in the internal processes of the Labor Party.

The first Budget of the fourth term of this Government was where reform should have begun, and begun in earnest. Instead, we are witnessing a rerun of the Government's failed third term and the beginnings of its own demise. There is a black cloud, a pall, over the private sector economy, and the only argument about that is how we spell `pall'. The fact is that the coalition continues to set the agenda for constructive political and economic debate in this country. We are streets ahead of the Government in every major area of policy. This Budget will see us maintain that position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1990-91 Budget reaffirms the Labor Government's commitment to social justice through the implementation of important programs in a variety of portfolios. This Budget continues the work of the last seven years in fulfilling the objectives of real social justice for all Australians. I wish to concentrate my address this evening on the Hawke Government's social justice strategy-its achievements and its future initiatives. It is when one closely examines the achievements in this field over the past seven years that we are clearly able to identify that this Government has been a government of real and positive reform to enhance the lives and living standards of the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: What is meant by the term `social justice'? Is it just a catchy name for welfare? What does it mean for ordinary Australians? Social justice is about creating a fairer Australia for all Australians. It is about ensuring that all of the Government's programs are directed at expanding choices and opportunities for people, so that they are able to participate fully as citizens in economic, social and political life and are better able to determine the direction of their own lives.

The concept of social justice has four principal elements: equity, equality, access and participation. Equity means fairness in the distribution of economic resources. Equality means equal, effective and comprehensive civil, legal and industrial rights for all. Access means fair and equitable access to services. Participation means the opportunity to participate fully in personal development, community life and decision making. The capacity to make choices is constrained for many people because of factors such as inadequate income, gender, race, location or disability. The social justice strategy addresses the disadvantages that often result from these factors and seeks to reduce the incidence, severity and duration of disadvantage so that all in society can enjoy a decent standard of living and expanded choices.

Implementation of the social justice strategy has required an integrated approach to the key elements of economic and social policy so that they are directed at the underlying objective of social justice. The key mechanisms utilised over the past seven years have been employment growth, wages policy and major reforms of the taxation, social security, education and training and community services systems.

It is the record of these achievements which underlines the fundamental differences in philosophy between Labor and our conservative opponents. Those opposite operate on the basis that the individual is all important and that the community good is secondary. The policies espoused by our opponents suggest that all things are possible in a totally free market situation where, if an individual has enough money, he or she can purchase from private enterprise any service required. To a Liberal, it is the responsibility of each person to make his own way. If people are poor, disabled or disadvantaged, that is their problem.

In stark contrast to this sink or swim philosophy, the Labor Government stands for the provision of high quality services to all in the community based on capacity to pay and equality of access. It is clear that governments have the most cost effective and efficient means of providing social infrastructure on an equal basis. To attempt to provide the broad range of social services on the open market would be much more expensive and would exclude the poor from any access to such services. The conservative forces continue to pursue the mythology that people can always purchase services they require in an open market situation. Such philosophical dogma ignores the reality of poverty, unemployment and disability.

The universal health care system, Medicare, introduced in 1984 emphasises this stark difference in approach. Under the previous conservative administration, over two million Australians were denied access to health insurance and, therefore, to decent medical attention because of this free market philosophy. Access to affordable and high quality health services and participation in decisions relating to their health are basic rights of all Australians, and it is an important element of social justice.

Medicare provides automatic entitlement under a single public health insurance fund to medical and optometrical benefits for all. Medicare provides a universal and equitable system of health care for all Australians, financed on the basis of a progressive levy through the taxation system. It is a major contribution to the Government's social justice strategy. Medicare has been supplemented by programs such as the national women's health strategy and Aboriginal health initiatives to meet the special health needs of these groups.

The key priority of the Government has been, and still is, sustainable generation of employment. Employment offers opportunities and choices for people to have a decent standard of living. It is employment that offers the most effective solution to overcoming poverty. The Hawke Labor Government has been responsible for the creation of 1.7 million new jobs in its seven years in office. It has led the world in its job creation strategies and achievements.

This compares starkly with the record of the previous Liberal-National Party Government, which drove 600,000 families into severe poverty through unemployment because of its economic mismanagement. The social justice strategy involves a much more complex approach to employment than just job creation. It goes to the question of tackling the reasons for unemployment and the structural problems faced by certain groups seeking to enter the work force. Those four key words-equity, equality, access and participation-are all in the forefront of the Government's approach to employment.

Special programs to assist people who face particular disadvantages in the labour market-such as age, language difficulties, disabilities, responsibility for the care of children-and require additional assistance to help them join the labour force have all been important priorities. Through a more active approach, which is being considerably enhanced in this Budget through the active employment strategy, disadvantaged people are being provided with opportunities to escape the circumstances which cause difficulties in entering employment.

A number of specific programs have been set in place. The jobs, education and training (JET) program provides individual assistance such as counselling, training and educational opportunities, child-care and job placement for sole parent pensioners to help them achieve financial independence. From July 1991 unemployment benefit will be replaced with a new income support structure comprising a short term job search allowance available for those unemployed up to 12 months and a Newstart allowance for those unemployed for more than 12 months. These new structures will be accompanied by support from programs which will assist long term unemployed people back into jobs by tackling the work force barriers they face.

The youth social justice strategy addresses the special needs of disadvantaged young people, particularly the homeless, through an integrated set of measures to provide accommodation and special education, training and health programs. The Aboriginal employment development policy is directed at providing sustainable job opportunities for Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. This is complemented by the Aboriginal education policy, which seeks to ensure equity of educational opportunities and improved outcomes for Aboriginal people.

Each of these programs uses a coordinated approach to address special needs, recognising that a range of measures in the income support, education and training and other systems is required to assist disadvantaged people back into the work force. The programs are complemented by the high priority given to improving access to child-care facilities for the increasing number of women in the work force. Since 1983 an additional 60,000 child-care places have been created. This Budget continues the massive expansion of child-care places with the funding of an additional 50,000 places in non-profit services by 1995-96 and changes the income tested relief arrangements to make child-care more affordable for low and middle income families, including the extension of eligibility for fee relief to users of commercial and employer provided child-care centres. Our commitment to child-care is a fundamental element of the Government's strategy of expanding choices and opportunities for women, along with legislative changes such as the introduction of the Sex Discrimination Act and the Affirmative Action Act, as part of the national agenda for women.

Of major importance to social justice and the improvement of equity is the structure of the tax system. The Government has reformed the tax system over its period in office with further reductions in tax contained in this year's Budget. The tax system is now both fairer and more conducive to enhancing overall productivity and efficiency. This has been effected through closing tax avoidance and evasion shelters, taxation of capital gains and fringe benefits as well as changed arrangements for occupational superannuation. These have been accompanied by reduced tax for low and middle income families in return for the wage restraint necessary to ensure sustainable employment growth.

There are also many other significant areas of achievement in social security, retirement incomes, education and training, and care for the aged, but time does not permit a detailed explanation of all of these issues. Let me just say that all of these measures have achieved considerable improvement in income distribution, equality of treatment and greatly improved participation in community life. All of these things have been achieved under a Labor Government. None would even have been considered by our conservative opponents.

The Government's approach to implementing its social justice strategy has been to ensure that its objectives are contained in all programs and services delivered by the Government. The most appropriate way of ensuring that it is integrated into the mainstream of government administration is ensuring that within each department's program management and budgeting system, social justice objectives and implications have to be clearly identified and assessed.

One of the key aims of program management and budgeting is to improve the effective management of programs. From a social justice perspective this means that program managers should consciously identify the social justice impacts of their programs and work to improve them by actively looking at ways of making them more equitable and accessible. To help ensure that social justice elements of programs are being focused on by all managers, the Government has determined that social justice aspects of program objectives should be clearly identified and that a discussion of each one's achievements in social justice terms should be incorporated in the general performance information in the portfolio explanatory notes. Departments also are required to report in their annual reports on how they perform against social justice criteria.

It is important to understand that the Government's social justice strategy is not confined to what some may call the welfare portfolios of social security, community services and health, and Aboriginal affairs. This approach encompasses all portfolios and all departments. The four key elements-equity, equality, access and participation-are relevant in all of the Government's policies and programs, whether in defence, primary industries and energy, transport and communications, or community services and health.

As the chairperson of the Caucus social justice committee it is my responsibility to assist in the monitoring of the implementation of our social justice objectives across the portfolios. Within that role I have the opportunity to assess the Government's legislative program on the social justice strategy. As part of the process of alerting the wider Australian community to the Government's achievements and commitments to social justice, I believe it is appropriate to request all Ministers to include an assessment of social justice implications of their proposed legislation in their speeches introducing leg- islation to the House or Senate. I know that my colleague the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) will do that. Such action would certainly highlight for all members and senators that social justice is integral to the Government's whole approach.

The Government now wishes to take the social justice strategy to a new and vitally important area. We wish to address in an integrated manner issues related to locational disadvantage. Such disadvantage arises where people live in areas where there are deficiencies in physical and social infrastructure and inadequate access to jobs, training and educational opportunities and recreational facilities, thereby reducing the standard of living of those affected, and exacerbating other disadvantages they may face. An essential first step is to work with the States and local government to analyse in depth the causes and effects of locational disadvantage and to develop a more integrated information base for the development of appropriate policy initiatives.

The Government therefore has provided funds in the 1990-91 Budget to undertake pilot projects on locational disadvantage in a number of local areas and research programs on wider issues impacting on locational disadvantage. Both of those initiatives will be undertaken in close cooperation with State and local governments. Over the course of 1990-91 pilot projects will be undertaken in 10 separate geographical areas. The objective of the pilot projects is to provide information and suggest approaches to better integration of the planning, provision and delivery of social facilities, housing and employment and training opportunities, and transport links between them that are currently undertaken by the three levels of government. They will provide lessons for application in other geographical areas.

Responsibility for many of the issues relevant to addressing locational disadvantage is shared by Commonwealth, State and local governments. As noted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his speech on 19 July on Commonwealth-State relations, this Government is seeking to cooperate fully with other levels of government to ensure that initiatives to address these issues are conducted in a cost efficient and effective manner to ensure successful implementation of this social justice objective. The Government has put in place the essential building blocks for further fundamental reform over the next few years. The national housing and health strategies and the research and pilot projects on locational disadvantage will provide the necessary analysis and research required to continue the Government's record of putting in place fundamental and durable reforms that progress its objective of achieving a fairer Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only redeeming feature of the Federal Budget is finally the acknowledgment by political commentators, by business analysts and, significantly, by the very heart of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) itself, that this Government and its Treasurer (Mr Keating) have failed their charter. There was no attempt this time to manage the public relations euphoria of past Keating Budgets. The confidence and the arrogance could not replace the stark recognition that the Australian so bluntly printed in Tuesday's paper, that we are now on the crumbling road to rack and ruin. Tragically, despite this public acknowledgment of failure, the real problems in our economy have not been addressed. Record interest rates, high inflation and an overvalued dollar have together produced a self-destructing financial mess that is consuming all that has been strong and enduring in our economic and social life.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia today is without doubt facing its most serious economic crisis since the 1930s. Not since then has our foreign debt been such a high percentage of our gross domestic product; nor has the interest burden ratio, which is now up to 24.2 per cent, been so great. Unlike those early crisis periods when our debt situation generally was due to a major international collapse, this time the problems have been created by government. Sadly this has occurred in a period of unprecedented growth in world trade and general economic activity, which commenced right at the beginning of the Hawke Government's election in March of 1983. Clearly Government economic mismanagement is to blame, and clearly Australia no longer is in a position to be able to absorb any major external shocks. The huge productivity increases in our primary industries, both mining and agriculture, socioeconomic stability, and the decentralisation of small business and industry have been undone in a few years.

We in rural Australia-and I do not ignore the difficulties of the cities-are on the brink of losing control of our own destiny. For decades farms have increased in size, the commercial sectors of small towns have declined, and regional cities have expanded, mainly due to mechanisation, better transport systems, better roads and increased options for those modes of transport. As a recent paper prepared by the Economic Planning Advisory Council clearly indicates, the explosion of transport systems, communications infrastructure and technology has given Australians greater mobility. No longer are people and the services provided confined to geographical boundaries or to one jurisdiction of government. The world has changed also. We may not now like the internationalisation of Australia, but this is our nation in the 1990s.

While these issues need to be addressed, they are not the major cause for the present concern, the lack of confidence, the frustration and the uncertainty. These factors alone do not explain the appalling state of small businesses, the massive decline in employment opportunities, the sharp downturn in farm incomes and the unprecedented failure of financial institutions. The latest statistics are clearly worrying. We have a stagnant economy with negative growth in the last quarter and growth for the year just gone was only in the public sector. Private sector demand is down by nearly 2 per cent. We have seen business investment fall by a massive 16.6 per cent through 1989-90 and our debt situation has continued to escalate, with the current account deficit over $20 billion in 1989-90 for the first time ever.

Australia's gross debt burden has more than quadrupled under Labor, rising from $36 billion in March 1983 to a massive $157 billion in March this year. This figure is now running at unsustainable levels. Business Council of Australia papers prepared for the debt summit in March indicated that we would have to shift nearly 4 per cent of economic activity in net exports for the next five years merely to stabilise this debt. The papers point out that, even then, debt would continue to grow in absolute terms right up to the turn of the century.

We can well see the enormity of this task and it can be judged from the fact that we have not had anything like this percentage shift in net exports in any five-year period since 1945. In fact, we have not had any shift to that degree in any single year. During the seven years of the Hawke Government, consumer prices in Australia have climbed at an annual average rate of 7.6 per cent, while the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) average is just 4.1 per cent. Our core rate of inflation is the highest in the OECD and inflation in Australia has only once been below 5 per cent in the past 20 years.

The Government's Budget does not address the causes of these problems; nor, sadly, does it offer any hope for their resolution. What is more worrying is that the burden of this serious economic climate is being borne totally by the private sector. On the Government's own forecast, in 1990-91 the public sector will be growing at a rate of 2.75 per cent while the private sector will not grow at all. Business investment is forecast to decline again by 7.25 per cent on top of the huge fall last year.

Everyone knows that the Government's excessive overreliance on monetary policy is causing, and will continue to cause, the domestic economic climate to deteriorate, particularly through continued high interest rates, which have been counterproductive as far as the balance of payments is concerned. It has kept the exchange rate for the dollar well above its long term competitive level, thereby encouraging imports and discouraging exports-exactly the opposite to what Australia needs. This excessive dependence on monetary policy has been forced on the Government by its failure to take any action in the fiscal area and on other micro reform fronts. This is having disastrous effects on Australian business, particularly small business, and on families and those attempting to purchase family homes.

There has been a massive 26 per cent rise in the level of bankruptcies in the year to June and this figure alone bears testimony to the Government's failure. The Australian Labor Party has been forced to corrupt its own party platform in the areas of communication and transport and, through mismanagement, it has created an irony that could well work to Australia's advantage if efficiencies are ultimately achieved. However, the fact that nothing is being done to help the expanding debt and to encourage savings places extreme limits on any spending that micro-economic reform will demand. Every member of this House knows, if he or she is prepared to analyse this Budget honestly, that these two requirements are not achievable. They require either cuts in public sector spending or major taxation rises.

The big ticket items of social security and health have not been touched in this Budget; and health, with the monster of Medicare raging out of control on both the demand and the supply side, threatens ultimately to consume the system and further impede other areas of social progress and reform. Of course, the Treasurer has managed, quite cleverly, to expand Federal Government outlays, but to transfer the huge burden of service delivery and debt to State and local government. These two areas of government have little capacity to deliver, and there is no doubt that at that level we shall see major retractions of essential services. Again, it is the ultimate irony that the Labor Party has, through mismanagement, subverted its long term platform of wealth redistribution. Its platform is now one of debt redistribution.

I would like to make some comment on the recently announced changes to Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines Ltd and Telecom Australia. These changes have, unfortunately, been made for entirely the wrong reasons and the compromises that have been necessary in order to satisfy the factional differences within the Labor Party will not produce the benefits of competition or privatisation for the Australian public. The only reason that the ALP was forced to go through the trauma of the past weeks was its inability to fund the public sector with the capital requirements that these national authorities demanded. Only time will tell if the Telecom-OTC proposal will get the all-clear from the ALP conference. Only time will tell if this massive conglomerate gives Australia the capacity to meet the challenges and the dynamism of the new technology and communications revolution that could offer so much for Australia's future. It is therefore tragic that such an important decision is not being made with Australia's best interests in mind, but simply as a means of overcoming the paralysis in a government torn to pieces by factions and outdated ideology and awaiting the call from its masters outside this House.

What is clearly obvious is the fact that the Hawke-Keating Government is now totally out of touch with the worsening economic and social conditions outside Canberra, the nature and depth of the recession in small business and the growing impact of falling commodity prices on the mining and primary industry sector. The very socio-economic fabric of our rural towns and cities has never before been under such threat. Decades of economic and social progress, established by community and voluntary effort in cooperation with government, languishes under high interest rates, excessive red tape and regulation, and uncompetitive transport costs. Of course, we can now add to that list. I refer particularly to my State of Victoria and the collapse of, and loss of confidence by many people in, our building societies and property trusts. Few businesses and families have been left untouched by these collapses, either directly or indirectly, as their savings or investments have been lost or frozen, the building industry grinds to a halt and many businesses find that they are unable to pay many of their employees.

The Treasurer's policies have not worked but we see no changes, and added to the total economic vandalism and incompetence that I mentioned in my own State of Victoria we must now have deep concerns about the future. This Budget provided an opportunity to give a boost to our productivity and improve our export performance. It appears that that opportunity has again been lost.

The Mallee electorate that I represent depends very much on the productivity of rural production and exports. The industries that service them, the extension services of government departments, the small factories and the engineering works would not exist without the agricultural sector. It is in this regard that I am most disappointed about the outcome of this Budget because I believe we could have expected at least some understanding from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). But we see major cost increases placed upon the rural sector at a time when it is simply unable to cope with an increased burden.

Last year the Federal Government and the primary industry portfolio contributed $445.5m to the agricultural and fishing industries. This year there has been a decrease to $423.3m and over the next three years we will see this figure drop to some $308.9m. That is an indictment of any commitment by this Government to the most important sector in the Australian economy. At the same time, while the Government contribution falls, the rural community is paying some $1,369.9m in levies and charges. Of this, $429.7m is from the recent increase in taxes paid by woolgrowers from an increase in levy from 8 per cent to 18 per cent and from the $21m increase in levies to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation.

This big leap in export costs and charges on export inspection, domestic meat inspection and quarantine charges will go forward as from 1 January next. Overnight, charges will go from a 60 per cent cost recovery to a 100 per cent cost recovery. This comes at a critical time for many export industries, especially the farmers facing a 48 per cent decrease in net farm production this year.

I have not always agreed with-in fact I have actively opposed on a number of occasions-many of the changes the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has made under his portfolio in recent years, particularly those to the Australian Wheat Board. At this time of low commodity prices, we have lost that important price buffer on the domestic market provided by earlier wheat legislation.

Today, the Australian wool industry is confronted with an appalling situation. I acknowledge the renewed commitment in recent days by the Government to our greatest industry but the uncertainty and speculation due to the nature and the process of earlier action has been highly damaging, both domestically and internationally.

Despite the fact that statements made by the Minister over the past few months indicated that he appeared to understand the need for conservation policies to be in balance with development policies, one must now question this commitment when seeing that some $5.2m of the primary industry budget has been used to help lock up native forests and World Heritage payments allocated under the forestry development program.

TALK.START.PARA: —A misnomer.

—It is a misnomer, and even the Minister himself today has become a captive too. He is being held hostage by the dark green movement. As an indication of this, I refer to a speech the Minister made recently to the Australian Capital Territory Fabian Society on sustainable development, where he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The single most important immigration initiative which the Commonwealth Government could ever have made would have been to have lined the Chaffey brothers up against the wall. This is simply because the second round effects of measures inspired by the Chaffey brothers-closer settlement, a transplanted rural peasantry, a huge investment in public water infrastructure and the exuberant exploitation of fragile, skeletal soils-have been debilitating in social, in fiscal and in environmental terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —A gratuitous insult.

—These off-the-cuff gratuitous insults from the Minister are no substitute for fundamental policy objectives and priorities aimed at correcting errors of the past and to ensure stability and productivity for the future. The Minister's comments-made no doubt to impress the isolated Fabians of Canberra-are substantially untrue. The planning by the Chaffeys of the Sunraysia irrigation area and the urban infrastructure were far ahead of their time.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply ask honourable members to personally inspect and compare the Sunraysia area in my electorate with the unplanned, inadequate infrastructures and chaos of many of our major cities. While some argument can be developed on the suitability of many soils presently under irrigation throughout Australia, the structure of the deep, sandy loams of the Mildura area are a stark exception.

I conclude my comments on the Budget by dealing with an area of change which has received little national media attention but which will be devastating in its effect. I was interested to hear the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) speak so highly of the Hawke Government's social justice program. The honourable member mentioned four principles: equity, equality, access and participation. In one area the Hawke Government has failed on all counts, and I refer particularly to the discriminatory asset test on family allowances, family allowance supplement and Austudy eligibility.

These new asset test levels will create huge problems in the equitable provision of Government services. No doubt this change satisfies the philosophical bent of the Australian Labor Party, as the truth is that these changes mean that no farmers and few small business people will qualify. Farmers and business people will lose the benefit if they have $300,000 in assets and no allowance will be made for additional children.

I ask the House to compare this to a wage earner who can earn up to $57,620 and still qualify for family allowance and have this amount increased for each child. Farms of this value have no capacity to generate income at this level. The drop in maximum allowable assets from $322,750 to $200,000 for the family supplement will end this benefit for farmers and owner-operated country town business people.

Austudy has also been attacked and, with the 50 per cent farm-business discount, claims will be allowed up to $400,000, but even this will rule out most farming families. Worse still, students are being advised to manipulate the system-to cheat-in order to afford a tertiary education. Some students have realised that through arranged marriages and immediate separation they can be better placed to be assessed for assets as individuals. What a shameful state this nation has been driven to.

At the same time country students who must live away from home for senior secondary and tertiary education have had their return trip entitlement reduced from three to two per year. I call upon the Government to review and to amend this appalling decision. It shows a total lack of social equity and will ensure that the erosion of people from rural Australia will escalate to the disadvantage of those students and families directly affected and to the future maintenance of the social and economic fabric of our nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —At 7.30 on the night of 23 August I turned up in the chamber to hear the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) deliver his speech in reply to the Budget. My presence here was partly accidental. There was a malfunction in the paging system within the Parliament that night. For some reason my pocket pager was receiving a message coming from the office of the Opposition Whip. The message said, `Come into the chamber immediately'. So I did. However, having arrived here, I settled back to listen to the speech and I tried to assume the role of a dispassionate observer-one looking at both sides of the question in an attempt to form an objective judgment about the Leader of the Opposition and his reply on the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: From that standpoint, I found the reply on the Budget by the Leader of the Opposition very disappointing-in fact the weakest that I have listened to in the 10 years I have been a member of Parliament. It was a speech that was both feeble and unconvincing by any analysis. The Leader of the Opposition commenced his speech with the claim that the Budget must be redone and it must be redone with a package of essential measures which he intended to outline on the evening of 23 August. How did the Leader of the Opposition go about establishing the proposition that the Budget needed to be redone? Did he succeed in presenting Parliament with a package of what he called essential measures?

The Leader of the Opposition began his speech with what was essentially a series of hollow appeals-a series of appeals to groups that are in fact faring far better under Labor in current times than they every would under a coalition government. The appeals were hollow because people can remember what life was like under the coalition and they can recognise a bottle of snake oil when they see it. Four groups attracted the attention of the Leader of the Opposition: home owners, industry and business, the needy, and the young.

The Leader of the Opposition said that members of the Government should get out and talk to those people struggling to buy a home on mortgage interest rates of 16 per cent and those who are forced to sell their home in a falling market. The Leader of the Opposition said that Government members should get out and talk to those families in which both parents have been forced to go to work just to pay the mortgage and the supermarket bills. He said they should walk up and down any street in any city, suburb or town and count the empty shops and the `for sale' signs.

I have certainly done those things; Government members do. It is our job to get out and talk to people in our electorates, particularly home owners and buyers. This is what they tell us. They tell us that life is certainly not a bowl of cherries at the moment, but at the same time they know that they would never have had the opportunity to buy a home under a coalition government. They recognise that many of them simply would not have had jobs had the coalition continued in government in 1983. They know that second income to which the Leader of the Opposition refers would never be coming in without job growth and without the expansion of children's services that has been provided under Labor. Oh, yes, we certainly get out and talk to them; more than that, we listen, so home buyers are represented in the communities in which we live and work.

Last year under the gaze of television cameras from a current affairs program I talked to a group of home buyers in my electorate, a group from Kingsley Close, Kingswood. I must say that these home purchasers demonstrated a degree of understanding for which the Leader of the Opposition simply fails to give them credit. These people knew of the impact of the balance of payments on the economy. They knew-and they told me-of the impact that proposed Liberal Party cuts on government services would have on their standard of living. They knew of the effect of wages deregulation and open slather in the labour market would have on the living standards of their families.

We talked. While they certainly were not happy people, neither were they voting for the coalition. They certainly did not in the last election. In my electorate it was the worst result for the Liberal Party in very many years. The reason for that was that those people knew that there was no quick fix for interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —They had a good member.

—The Minister is too kind. They may have had some confidence in me, but they also certainly had confidence in the policy of the Government which has been delivering for them since the election and will continue to deliver for them in the form of lower interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition also directed an appeal to business and to industry. He talked of industry complaints, black bans, go-slows, stop-works and labour market deals. We on this side of the House certainly talk to industry as well. This is what industry tells us. It tells us that it is pleased with our record. It tells us that it is pleased with the dramatic fall in industrial disputation under Labor. It is pleased with the success of the accord. Industry and business certainly know and value a government which believes in cooperation rather than confrontation in solving difficulties and disputes.

The Leader of the Opposition appealed to the needy-that is a group that the Opposition can certainly identify with. This is what the Leader of the Opposition said. He appealed to the Government to get out and talk to:

. . . the genuinely needy in Australia, the sick, the aged, the genuinely unemployable, who have to get by on less because others who could otherwise pull their weight in our society have been allowed to rip off the welfare system-a system which makes it easier to put out your hand than to help yourself or lift your game.

We certainly talk with the needy. I know that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples), talks with people in his electorate and members on this side do. This is what they tell us. They know that pensions and benefits have risen in real terms under this Government after a period in which they fell in real terms under the coalition. They know and are pleased that indexation of pensions and benefits has been brought forward under this Government. They appreciate the major reforms that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) when Minister for Social Security brought in in family assistance, and the wonderful success of the family allowance supplement program after the failed program of the Liberals.

They know that all of this has been made possible only by careful targeting of benefits, by assets testing and by the introduction of schemes such as the child support system. The Leader of the Opposition referred to rip-offs, but the facts are that there has been in the social security system increasing vigilance. We have instituted better systems for the delivery of pensions and benefits, particularly through the bank credit system of pensions and benefits. A range of other measures have also been introduced to prevent abuse of the system. But how high can the Leader of the Opposition's criticism be when we remember that it was his Party that worked to destroy the Australia Card proposal and I am sure would, if it possibly could, destroy the effectiveness of the tax file number system which will be so effective in reducing rip-offs.

But while talking of pensioners and the Budget, I want to refer to two matters of concern that have arisen following the Budget. They concern changes to pharmacy benefits for pensioners and the introduction of the deeming system. I must say that I recognise that any change that involves this group causes some confusion and concern. Most of that concern is unnecessary, but the changes that have been introduced are certainly absolutely necessary.

Let me turn to the new pharmacy measures. The introduction of a charge against the backdrop of a scheme in which costs have been blowing out at an increasing rate is absolutely necessary. When one considers that the cost to the taxpayer of a single prescription item would, I suppose, be around $50 if one assumes an average cost of a drug of around $25, a dispensing fee of $4.85, and cost of a doctor's visit of $20, obviously careful controls have to be introduced.

One should also consider the waste that results from drugs being prescribed but not used. They are frequently held in large quantities by pensioners and become outdated, in which case an associated danger also needs to be taken into account. Drugs that are out of date and easily confused lead to some thousands of pensioners, I understand, being hospitalised each year because they have been taken incorrectly.

The introduction of the charge of $2.50 will make doctors more careful in prescribing drugs. At the same time the pension will be increased by $2.50 a week for single pensioners and after 52 prescriptions, subsequent prescriptions will be provided free. As the average pensioner receives only 27 scripts a year, the average pensioner is clearly $62.50 a year better off under this scheme.

Some problems have arisen. I understand now that all State housing departments are cooperating and not treating that increase as part of the income for rental purposes. That is one possible difficulty which I believe has been overcome. The other difficulty which was resolved by the Government in recent days concerns those pensioners in receipt of large numbers of prescriptions that are absolutely necessary for them-in other words, the chronically ill. I certainly welcome the Government's decision to provide a $50 advance to assist those people.

At the same time I point out that pensioners receiving large numbers of scripts in fact represent very good business to pharmacists. I would have thought it would be in pharmacists' interests anyway to operate a credit system. The record for prescriptions so far goes to a lady in Brisbane who claims to require 27 prescription items a week. If we take that case and assume that they are all absolutely necessary, we see that that lady would be worth to her pharmacist $4.85 times 27 a week in prescription fees. That is worth $133.45 a week in business to him. I would have thought she represented a very good business to him and would be a real incentive for that pharmacist to operate a credit scheme. However, the $50 advance will solve her problem in any case.

I point out that that reform will certainly benefit the average pensioner. It will take care, with its adjustment, of the chronically ill pensioner and it will take care of abuses because under the current scheme the real beneficiaries have not been the pensioners at all. They have been doctors, pharmacists and drug companies. In particular, I was concerned to read in the Herald of complaints about chemists in Grafton and Brisbane who, two days after the Budget, were telling pensioners that the new scheme had been introduced and was effective immediately and were charging pensioners. So I think parts of those professions really need to look at their ethical standards. I am sure that standards throughout those professions by and large are very good and I expect that there will be positive efforts to make sure that this new scheme works well and is introduced smoothly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to direct some remarks to an aspect of the Gulf crisis that has so far not received much public comment-that is, Australia's relations with the Palestine Liberation Organisation, the PLO. All Australians would no doubt be pleased to see a solution to the so-called Palestinian problem determined by negotiations between the parties concerned in a way that brought ongoing secure borders, peace and stability to all countries in that troubled part of our world. Accordingly, the renunciation of terrorism by the PLO some 18 months ago came as a welcome step toward the reconciliation process. Unfortunately, however, recent developments give real cause for concern and serious reservations must now be expressed on whether the PLO has changed its objectives and its methods of achieving them.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this year some Israeli tourists were attacked in Egypt by PLO activists. Then several months later an Iraqi-sponsored PLO associate attempted to make a terrorist assault on some of Israel's crowded summertime beaches. These breaches of PLO undertakings should have resulted in, at the very least, some form of denunciation by the Hawke Government, but they did not. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), previously quite sympathetic to Israel's interests, has by his stance and his silence placed Australia in a position where we might be seen to be condoning those PLO activities.

The moderate Arab states have now started to distance themselves from the PLO. This process has been sharply accelerated as a result of the new association between the PLO and Iraq. The world stands appalled by the actions of the dictator of Iraq. In addition to the eight-year war he initiated with Iran, he has bombed and gassed his own people, attempted to blackmail the Gulf states to raise arbitrarily the price of crude oil, which would have been a serious threat to Australia's economic interests, then invaded and annexed the sovereign state of Kuwait and now holds citizens of other countries as hostages. He has been unanimously condemned for his latest acts of aggression by everyone except the PLO.

Not only that; the PLO has been vocal in its support of Iraq. Recent statements by the PLO and its associates include: `We declare our support for Iraq', made at the May Baghdad Arab summit; `Strike at the interests of the treacherous agents in the Arab nations'; `Open fire on the American enemy everywhere. Quake the earth under the feet of the invaders and collaborators'. Further, how anyone could be associated with the Iraqi dictator's declaration that `his chemical missiles would incinerate Israel with fire' is quite beyond me.

As reported in the Australian newspaper in the last few weeks, not only has the PLO said that the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait is another step toward liberation of Palestine but also that much of the logistical planning for the invasion was derived from intelligence supplied by PLO workers and officials based in Kuwait. It seems beyond question that the Iraqi annexation of Kuwait took place with the active support and blessing of the PLO.

Australia's Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has said in the last few days that the Government will not change its current relationship with the PLO. That is not good enough. It is clearly time for Australia to rethink its relations with the Palestine Liberation Organisation, and the Government has an obligation to do so as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not need to remind those honourable members present of the importance to all Australians of the Federal Government's Greening Australia program. To this end I am very proud of what has been done in my electorate. In a joint project in February of this year between Greening Australia, Redbank Plains High School, Taubmans Paints and the Moreton Shire Council, Mrs Hazel Hawke, the wife of our Prime Minister and the patron of Greening Australia, officially opened the newly named Greening Australia Park, a park that adjoins the Redbank Plains High School in my electorate. This event also saw the planting of over 1,000 trees, which I understand was the beginning of Greening Australia's program to plant over one billion trees. The cost of these trees was sponsored by Taubmans Paints.

SPEECH.PARA: The aim of this project is to conserve native vegetation on the site and to establish three local plant communities, these being rainforest and a closed canopy forest including paperbarks, ti-trees and gums in this woodland. The students of Redbank Plains High School have taken on the caring of these trees as a special project under the guidance of their school principal, Mr Rod Simson. I was particularly pleased to be associated with this and also with the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), the Minister then responsible for that area, and also the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) from the Federal electorate of Rankin.

The trees are all growing pretty well. Some people who were there that day must have had green fingers because some 86 per cent of the trees are still growing particularly well. The students, the school and Mr Simson are to be commended for the way they have actively participated in the Greening Australia program. As their Federal representative, I have been pleased to assist with this project.

Telecom Australia, which is the topic of the moment, of course, does many good things in our community. It had a facility in the corner of the park. The management committee of the new park suggested to me that the perimeter fence needed tidying up and that it would be good if we could have some trees planted around it. I took this matter up with Telecom on behalf of the management committee. Telecom also has a line depot on this site. Whilst these facilities are necessary, I certainly shared the views of the committee that the greening of the fenceline would lend itself more to the picturesque surroundings of the park.

I was pleased to take this up and I have recently been advised by Telecom that it would be pleased to participate in the greening of its perimeter fence. For this I put on record my deep appreciation for Telecom's participation in this way. However, Telecom will be selling part of this land within the next six months and it has indicated to me that it will be offering the land to the Moreton Shire Council, the local authority. I am very pleased about that too and I hope that the Moreton Shire Council will take up that option and will convert it into parkland.

I was pleased with the response from Greening Australia and pleased to have participated in this item of national significance. As I said earlier, I understand it was one of the first works commenced as part of the Greening Australia program. The program is part of the national goal of Greening Australia, which will see one billion trees planted by the year 2000. This program fits well into the mix of measures the Government has put together to combat the problems of soil erosion, land degradation and salinity. In my view, this demonstrates the Government's recognition that more is required than merely planting trees.

The national soil conservation program, Landcare Australia Limited and Greening Australia are working cohesively to address Australia's pressing environmental problems. Through the participation in Greening Australia Park the people of the Oxley electorate are playing a very vital part. I would like to put on record my appreciation to all those associated with this program and to thank particularly the local school, Redbank Plains High School, for its participation. The project was really the school's idea. I particularly thank the school principal, Mr Simson.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cheryl Kernot, the Australian Democrats' spokesman for transport, in a letter to the Gold Coast Bulletin on 8 September states that she remains unconvinced that deregulation of the airlines will lead to the economic benefits which Mr Dick Smith, Chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority, outlined in a speech to the National Press Club recently. Senator Kernot says further in her letter:

SPEECH.PARA: My major concern with the deregulation of the airlines however, is the potential effect on passenger safety.

Senator Kernot is doing little more than scaremongering. The competition that will arise in what is currently a very small market will ensure that safety standards are maintained and improved. One mistake or accident by a single airline could cost it its entire business in such a highly competitive field.

In the United States flying has proved to be safer since deregulation. In the nine years leading up to deregulation there was an average of 33 fatal and non-fatal accidents a year. In the first nine years following, that number was reduced to 20 a year. Considering the enormous increase in flights and passenger numbers since deregulation in the United States the improvements are even more pronounced. Fatal accidents in the United States per million miles travelled declined by a staggering 57 per cent. Also in America the number of Americans using aircraft has doubled since deregulation there, resulting in an average of 1,700 fewer road fatalities and 66,000 fewer injuries due to road accidents each year. This has special significance in Australia where most of the highways between our capital cities are precarious at best. Senator Kernot also appears to have doubts about the cost benefits of deregulation for all air travellers. Air fares in the United States declined by 21 per cent between 1978 and 1988, saving the American travelling public about $100 billion.

Despite all of this Senator Kernot's attitude does not surprise me. The Democrats tend to be way out of step when it comes to economic rationalisation. Australia is just about to break free of the shackles of the two-airline policy and there is a real sense of anticipation that the move will be the salvation of the domestic tourist industry.

Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines have served us well for many years but we now have a more mature market and competition that other carriers will provide will see a major revitalisation of domestic aviation and cheaper air fares for all Australians. Senator Kernot can be concerned if she wants but I assure her and the Australian Democrats that her fears and their fears are completely without foundation. The 84 per cent of Australians who currently do not fly regularly, largely due to the cost, are looking forward to cheaper air fares and higher safety standards that will result from deregulation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan Mr I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to raise a matter of international interest. I welcome the opportunity given me by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) to clarify my position on the development of industry in Australia. Yesterday the Minister claimed that I had said that we should `do the development first and then solve the problems'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister was referring to a speech I made to the Murray Valley League in Murray Bridge on 31 August when I was explaining that we should make a decision to approve the development of the Australian Newsprint Mills expansion program by some $600m first and set the rules so that the corporation can then work out how to do it in a way which does not damage the environment and may even enhance it.

I gave that conference an example of a French company that I visited in 1975 and which was coerced by the French Government to move into a remote rural area by a soft loan. The one condition was that there should be absolutely no pollution at the end of every day or week from that factory. That was at the time held to be impossible. However, as the coercion, if you like, of the soft loans encouraged the factory, technology solved the problem and at the end of every day a few jars of ash were put on the rose garden. That factory is flourishing to this day.

My point, which was distorted or perhaps misunderstood by the Minister, was that if one makes a decision, sets the rules and sticks to them, one is much more likely to enable corporate Australia to solve the problems that confront it. If one keeps changing the rules, Australian corporations, given the choice-and many of them now are-may finally make the decision to go overseas.

Tragically, four of Australia's major corporations-CSR, Boral, Adsteam and Amcor and others perhaps that we do not know about-have made that decision in the last 12 months. Indeed, Amcor has spent about $450m overseas in the past 18 months buying packaging companies in North America and France and building fibrebox plants in Britain and California. This company has found it easier to build plants in other places than to build them in Australia and is looking to direct capital expenditure overseas after having invested $2 billion in Australia in new plants and acquisitions in the last five years.
The Minister went on to say that I had said that conservation had been in the hands of very powerful urban conservation commandos who used scare tactics to coerce support.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you said that, you were right.

—Not withstanding that that compendium of grabs which she used were put together in another speech which I made in Sydney in February before the election, and not on 31 August, what I actually said in that speech was that conservation to me was a way of life-and these are the words-`a way of managing the area for which I am responsible so that it is left in the best condition for the next person. It is for people and by people, and a vital part of this plan is an informed and ecologically responsible public'.

SPEECH.PARA: I said that unfortunately, in recent times, `the views of some of the zealous urban conservation commandos have been a powerful instrument shaping the policies and practices of governments desperate for votes'. The Australian Government, with one notable exception-the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), I said-`has sadly embraced the politics of cant and catastrophe peddled by the dark greens in a belated attempt to coerce voters'. I warned them then that they may succeed if responsible Australians do not stand up.

I thank the Minister for giving me the opportunity by her misunderstanding simply to say that she vastly understated my views on these matters, which have been correctly put in recent times by Robert Haupt of the Melbourne Age, to the effect that this Government has given the radical greens the right of veto over every important development in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to address the chamber this evening to congratulate the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) and the Government on introducing the new superannuation scheme applicable to Defence Force personnel. I have the pleasure of representing, amongst others, the service men and women attached to the Enoggera army barracks in Brisbane. They are indeed a fine group of people. They have up until recently been contributing to a superannuation scheme, the old defence force retirement and death benefits (DFRDB) scheme, which was in many respects well and truly out of date in its provisions. Put in a nutshell, those contributing to that scheme were required to remain in the system for 20 years in order to get any benefits back other than their own contributions. That may well have been a yardstick common throughout the superannuation industry in years gone by, but it is clear that in the last decade that system has changed dramatically in the community and that vesting rights which are normally available to others in the community had been denied those in the defence forces.

It is very pleasing to see that following a review and an examination of the DFRDB, the Minister and this Government have made some very substantial and important changes to that superannuation scheme which provide real and tangible benefits to Australia's service men and women.

Whereas other schemes have introduced vesting rights that enable contributors to receive either part or full employer contributions after a reasonable period of time-for example, 10, 15 or 20 years-the Defence Force scheme lagged behind. The new scheme, I am happy to say, provides for service personnel to receive interest on the contributions that are made and for them to receive increasing entitlements of employer benefit according to their years of service. Beyond that there is a full payment at 15 years of service which ensures that service personnel are no longer required to remain within the armed forces for the 20 years. Clearly this has some implications for the retention rate difficulties that the defence forces have faced in recent years. The Government has taken steps not only to remedy the superannuation entitlements that they have, but also to ensure that the defence forces do not lose experienced officers and staff as a result of these changes.

Accordingly, the Government, as part of this package, has introduced a selective retention benefits scheme which provides selected defence personnel with an additional payment of one year's salary after 15 years of service. That is a very substantial incentive for those long serving defence personnel to enlist for a further five years, providing a substantial payment to them whilst at the same time giving them a realistic opportunity to leave the defence forces short of the 20 years and take with them at that time a substantial amount of superannuation-importantly, an amount of superannuation which will include a contribution from the employer and the interest thereon. Of course this is all over and above the 3 per cent productivity benefits which apply in the defence forces.

It is worth noting that that 3 per cent productivity superannuation which applies throughout industry is for many the only source of superannuation benefit they receive-a great initiative of the trade union movement and the Government through the accord and providing many Australians with some form of long term security which they would otherwise not have.

Finally, I would like to commend the Minister and the Government for the way in which they have set about explaining these important changes to the defence personnel. The material which has been produced and distributed by way of the various service newspapers and specifically designed brochures and booklets has provided the necessary background for service personnel to make their decisions as to which scheme they wish to belong to.
