SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to draw the attention of the House to a particularly objectionable aspect of our current Industrial Relations Act-more specifically, section 299 of that Act. Members of the public and no doubt members of the House are aware of the recent use of this section-or its equivalent under the old Conciliation and Arbitration Act-against the former Secretary of the Victorian Builders Labourers Federation (BLF), Norm Gallagher. Whilst one could never condone the actions of the former BLF Secretary nor the means by which he operated there are nevertheless a number of very disturbing features about the ambit and operation of section 299.

SPEECH.PARA: A case presently before the courts-an action by the Director of Public Prosecutions against Nationwide News-serves as a poignant example. Section 299 states that a person shall not, amongst other things:
. . . by writing or speech use words calculated . . . to bring a member of the Commission or the Commission into disrepute.

The penalty is a fine of up to $1,000 or six months imprisonment for a person, or $1,000 for a body corporate. The case itself concerns a prosecution instigated by Justice Maddern and the Industrial Relations Commission (IRC) against the publishers of the Australian newspaper for an article published on 14 November 1989 in which Max Newton, journalist now deceased, made some rather hostile comments about the Commission.

Needless to say, the Commission was not enamoured with what Mr Newton had to say and demanded that an action be launched in accordance with section 299 of the Industrial Relations Act. The first thing which has to be said is that the section itself represents an extraordinary immunity against criticism for what is in effect a statutory body.

Of all the institutions worthy of debate, analysis and objective assessment there would be no better candidate than the IRC at such a crucial time in Australia's history. I do not want to speculate on the details of the case because, as I have said, it is currently before the courts. I do, however, wish to make quite plain the undesirability of section 299 and the severe restrictions it places on one of our most fundamental democratic rights-the freedom of speech.

We are all well aware that Australia is facing stagnation and a decline because of our outdated, inflexible and highly intransigent industrial relations framework. Why then should the main arbitrator of the system not be deserving of at least an analysis if not an objective critique for its role in our current economic crisis?

The ambit of section 299 is that virtually anything said or written about the Commission or its members, unless fawning in its flattery, as Paddy McGuinness of the Australian has remarked, may be interpreted as bringing him, it or her into disrepute. In other words, anything which may be interpreted as critical of the Commission faces a good chance of prosecution.

By virtue of its very existence as a statutory body, its performance should be continually scrutinised and debated, if only as a means to ensuring its continued relevance in our industrial framework. The fact is that section 299 sets up a barrier to effective and quite possibly useful analysis of its role as an arbitrator in our industrial relations system. It provides a protective screen behind which the Commission is able to do virtually anything it desires, including the perpetuation of its own entrenched position in our present industrial framework. So much for the principles of freedom of speech-the very lifeblood of democracy and community well-being.

Perhaps more disturbing is the implied threat it poses to all other newspapers and publishers and television and radio broadcasters who, by virtue of their own independence of mind, find both the Commission and its decisions somewhat iniquitous. In effect, the threat is an implied direction that a commentator must look not only to the normal laws of defamation and contempt but also to censorship of any comment at all capable of being construed as critical of the Commission or face the penalty. Worse still, no-one is beyond the reach of section 299, except seemingly a politician speaking within the bounds of parliamentary privilege. Hence my comments tonight.

It may be that Newton's comments were not particularly respectful of the Commission or of those sitting on its benches, but the article does not impute improper motives or slander any particular individual. Perhaps it does offer for public interest the other side of the coin-the side of which the public is rarely made aware. The present action against Nationwide publishers merely serves to stifle legitimate public debate on the role and behaviour of the Commission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 10 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to the answers to questions Nos. 2076 (Hansard, 22 December 1989, page 3635) and 2077 (Hansard, 28 November 1989, page 3100), has Australia deposited the instruments of accession to (a) the Unesco 1961``Rome'' Convention for the Protection of Performers, Producers of Phonograms and Broadcasting Organizations and (b) the Unesco 1974``Brussels'' Convention relating to the Distribution of Program-carrying Signals Transmitted by Satellite.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Australia has not deposited the instrument of accession to the``Rome'' Convention;
(b) Australia deposited the instrument of accession to the ``Brussels'' Convention on 26 July 1990 and the Convention will enter into force for Australia on 26 October 1990.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Melham Mr D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 17 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: What resources of his Department are made available specifically for Aboriginal prisoners and ex-prisoners in New South Wales during (a) their incarceration, (b) their post-custodial probation period and (c) if they are subject to fixed terms of imprisonment, the twelve months following their release from custody to assist in their post-custodial management or rehabilitation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —the answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) No actual resources of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) are made available specifically for Aboriginal prisoners during their incarceration. In 1989/90 ATSIC provided $1.3 million to NSW Police Services for upgrading of police cells in towns with a high proportion of Aboriginals detained in police cells.

ATSIC also funded an Aboriginal organisation to visit gaols in NSW to talk about drug and alcohol problems and to put on concerts. These talks and concerts were for all prisoners who wanted to attend, and not just Aboriginal prisoners. In 1989/90 this cost $4,500.

(b) ATSIC is funding the NSW Department of Corrective Services to undertake a 3 year pilot program of providing post-release education and vocational training for Aboriginal ex-prisoners. The cost over 3 years is $864,000. At this stage three Aboriginal organisations are being funded and a fourth is planned for the new financial year. The project commenced in September 1989.
(c) No differentiation is made between prisoners serving minimum sentences and those serving fixed terms of imprisonment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 17 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a proposal by the World Health Organisation (WHO) in its global nutrient goals that sugar consumption should be restricted worldwide to 10 per cent of total caloric intake.
(2) Does the WHO proposal run counter to current scientific opinion which has established that sugar should not be distinguished from other carbohydrates.

(3) Would the WHO proposal, were it accepted, lead to (a) a worldwide reduction in sugar production of 19 million tonnes, (b) hardship and hunger in developing countries and (c) the loss to Australia of many thousands of jobs and key export markets, including the USSR, China and the US.
(4) Will the Australian Government take action against the WHO proposal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A study on Diet, Nutrition and the Prevention of Chronic Diseases, conducted on behalf of the World Health Organisation (WHO), has been brought to my attention.

I am advised however, that the report on the study has yet to be released or endorsed by the WHO. I understand that the report is likely to be presented to the Executive Board of the WHO in January 1991 for its consideration, and that Australia will be represented at that meeting.

(2) The Minister for Community Services and Health has advised that the WHO proposal does not run counter to current scientific opinion. It is the general scientific view that simple refined sugars should be distinguished from other simple and complex carbohydrates because unrefined simple carbohydrates and complex carbohydrates are associated with other essential nutrients and fibre in food. This is the basis for present Australian nutritional labelling legislation.

(3) The impact of any WHO proposal will depend on the extent to which member countries can and actively seek to implement recommended courses of action. Given the considerable uncertainty surrounding this issue, any estimate of the effects of such a proposal must be dubious at best.

On the issue of increased hunger in developing countries, the Minister for Community Services and Health has advised that the diets of low income populations are frequently deficient in nutrients and while the consumption of simple refined sugars increases the intake of energy it does not overcome this deficiency. Indeed, excess consumption of sugar could reduce the overall nutritional quality of national diets.

(4) Australia's position in respect of the final WHO report, will reflect the goals and targets contained in the Health for All Australia Report which is the basis for the National Better Health Program. This program is Australia's response to the WHO objective, Health for All by the Year 2000, and it includes nutrition as a priority area. In respect of sugar, the Australian goal has been defined as `to reduce the contribution of refined sugars to dietary energy from 14% (1983-84) to 12 per cent or less by the year 2000'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce upon notice, on 1 June 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What sum was allocated for the Science Public Awareness Section established in the Minister's Department in August 1989.

(2) For each project funded under the section's allocation, (a) what sum has been allocated, (b) how have the funds been spent to date and (c) will the sum allocated to that project be expended by the end of 1989-90.
(3) How many staff in (a) total and (b) each level or classification are employed in the section.
(4) How many staff have worked (a) full-time and (b) part-time on the administration of the Australia Prize.
(5) What is the estimated total cost of the Australia Prize.
(6) Were funds drawn from other projects, or from elsewhere, in the allocation to the section to cover the costs of administration of the Australia Prize.

(7) Was an advertising company contracted to promote the Australia Prize to the Australian and international media; if so, (a) what company and (b) was the contract reached by open tender; if not, why not.
(8) Were staff from the Minister's Department involved in the public promotion of the Australia Prize; if so, to what extent.
(9) What sum was spent on (a) promoting the Australia Prize and (b) conducting the Australia Prize presentation evening.
(10) What was the extent of the media coverage in (a) Australia and (b) overseas of (i) the announcement of the Australia Prize and (ii) the Australia Prize presentation evening.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Science and Technology Awareness Section administers the $800,000 annual funding for the Science and Technology Awareness Program announced in the May 1989 policy statement. The Program aims to raise public awareness of the central role of science and technology in national life, and consists of 4 major inter-related elements agreed by Ministers: Australia Prize, Journalists Awards, Science Information Projects and Industry-Science Forum. Staff cover of $70,000 was also provided for in the Budget allocation of the Program.

(2) Australia Prize: (a) $410,000; (b) Prize money of $250,000; initial start-up costs: including market research, design consultancy, corporate and publicity materials, medals and presentation packaging; and on-going administrative costs: including Committee travel and accommodation, printing and postage, public relations consultancy, winners' travel and accommodation; (c) No. Total expenditure for this element amounted to $390,000.
Michael Daley Awards for Science and Technology Journalism: (a) $20,000; (b) Prize money, fares, publicity, judging costs; (c) No. Total expenditure amounted to $19,000.

Science information projects: (a) $270,000; (b) Education resource materials, speakers, conferences, targeted media program productions including co-productions with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, projects with science centres including a feasibility study for an Australian science, technology and innovation interactive exhibition and prototyping of a travelling interactive maths exhibition; (c) Yes. The balance of the Program funds, $313,000, was committed to Science Information projects.

Support was also provided to the Australian Academy of Science for the Australian Science and Technology Information Service proposal: (a) $20,000; (b) Support for feasibility study; (c) Yes. $20,000.

Industry-Science Forum: (a) $10,000; (b) Not applicable; (c) No. Planning for the implementation of this element of the Program was interrupted by the announcement of the election. A new format is being developed for 1990-91.
Departmental staff cover: (a) $70,000; (b) Salary and administration; (c) No. $55,000. It has been possible to undertake the administration of the Program more efficiently than had been anticipated.
(3) (a) Currently four; (b) AS08, AS07, ASO5, AS04 at 1 June 1990.

(4) (a) At no time has anybody in the Section worked full-time on the Australia Prize element of the Program; (b) At no time has there been more than four persons in the Section involved part-time to any extent with the administration of the Australia Prize element of the Program.

(5) The Australia Prize comprises $250,000 prize money and an inscribed medal. The administrative costs of this element of the Program are estimated as $75,000 start up costs, and $65,000 administrative costs which are expected to be on-going.
(6) No. The actual costs of administration of the Australia Prize element have been less than anticipated.

(7) (a) Leo Schofield and Associates were the successful tenderers for the public relations consultancy for the Australia Prize element of the Science and Technology Awareness Program. In responding to the consultancy brief, Leo Schofield and Associates carried out more duties than simply advertising the Australia Prize to the Australian and international media.

(b) The consultancy was let in response to quotation by tender, which is normal practice for projects involving creative work and materials. Four quotations were sought and three were received. The Department was advised and assisted in this process by the Office of Government and Advertising. As is usual practice, this consultancy was approved within the public relations outline for the Science and Technology Awareness Program by the Ministerial Committee on Government Information and Advertising.
(8) Staff from the Department briefed and liaised with Leo Schofield and Associates regularly as part of the management of the consultancy, as well as providing advice as appropriate.

(9) (a) A consultancy contract for $19,500 was let to Leo Schofield and Associates to provide a diverse and wide range of public relations activities including: preparation of media briefs and releases, media liaison, advice and assistance in organising the winners' programs and events associated with the awarding of the Prize, facilitating the engagement of key personnel for specific activities, and other public relations activities to promote the Australia Prize as an element of the Science and Technology Awareness Program. (b) Costs of the Australia Prize presentation evening were borne by the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet. That Department has advised that the cost of conducting the evening was $31628.

(10) The publicity strategy for the Australia Prize included a public lecture by the winners, research seminars in Canberra, Adelaide and Sydney, meetings with senior research managers and young scientists, the Presentation Dinner hosted by the Prime Minister to which some 400 government, industry, youth and science community representatives were invited and use of the occasion in a video to encourage young scientists. It is not practical to separate the coverage associated with the announcement from that associated with the presentation. (a) The announcement of the winners of the inaugural Australia Prize received good coverage in the Australian media. For example, the announcement of the winners of the Australia Prize was the lead article on ABC TV's Quantum program for the 1990 series, on the evening of the announcement. The announcement was also carried by at least 27 print media outlets, covering newspapers and specialist magazines, and by radio and TV evening news bulletins. Additionally, interviews with the Australian winner were carried by 6 commercial and 3 ABC National radio stations. The only negative publicity about the Australia Prize was a number of articles by commentator Dr Peter Pockley. (b) International coverage was not fully monitored. Some examples of coverage are: 65 articles in German print media, three in international magazines, and an interview broadcast by BBC radio.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 21 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What sum was paid for a site for Commonwealth offices located on the corner of St Andrews Avenue and Lyttleton Terrace, Bendigo.
(2) How was the price determined for the purchase of the site.
(3) What construction is proposed for the Commonwealth offices, including provision of office space, allocation for departments and parking.
(4) When will tenders be called for the construction of the Commonwealth offices at Bendigo.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The agreed purchase price is $1.8m and settlement is expected to take place in September 1990.
(2) Through negotiation on the basis of valuation advice supplied by the Australian Valuation Office.
(3) Planning is proceeding on the basis of a 4900 square metre office building to collocate departments presently accommodated in leased premises in Bendigo.
(4) The government has not at this stage approved the construction.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 22 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the face value of share certificates in the Farrow Corporation building societies recognised for the purposes of the means test; if so, how long will this continue?

(2) Has his attention been drawn to the fact that (a) the shares are no longer considered to have any actual value and there is an expectation that there will not be any residual amount paid to share certificate holders when the affairs of the societies are wound up and (b) the value of the shares may have been up to 75 per cent below face value for up to four months before the appointment of the administrator.
(3) Will he examine whether the full face value of this class of shares should have been maintained for assets test purposes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The market value, not the face value, of shares is used when valuing shares under the assets test. This is usually the buy back price.
(b) While the Farrow Corporation may not have had assets which backed the shares to their full value, I am advised that shares were being traded at full price, right up until trading ceased.

(3) This matter has been examined by my Department and, currently, all Farrow Corporation non-withdrawable shares are assessed as having no value under the Assets Test. The date of effect of this change is 28 June 1990, being the first pay date following announcement by the administrator for the Farrow Corporation that shareholders would be unlikely to receive any return on their investment.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Victorian Building Societies: Pensions and Benefits

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 22 August:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the announcement by the Victorian Government that no interest will be paid for 1989-1990 to investors in the Pyramid, Geelong and Country Wide building societies.
(2) Are persons who have had income from these societies included for means test purposes entitled to have pensions and benefits reviewed because no interest will be paid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) All interest payments on Farrow Corporation building society investments have now been disregarded under the income test. My Department, through its automatic data processing facilities, reassessed all identifiable pensioners with investments in these societies with effect from 28 June 1990, being the first pay date following the announcement by the administrator for the Farrow Corporation that no interest would be paid to depositors. My press statement of 12 July 1990 advised any veteran or war widow with enquiries concerning their deposits with the Farrow Corporation to contact the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 22 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Which of the states represented in the International Conference on Indo-Chinese Refugees, held at Geneva from 13 to 14 June 1989, have not yet become parties to the (a) 1951 Convention relating to the Status of Refugees, (b) 1954 Convention relating to the Status of Stateless Persons, (c) 1961 Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness and (d) 1967 Protocol relating to the Status of Refugees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Participating states represented at the I.C.I.R. who have not yet become parties to the 1951 Convention relating to the Status of Refugees.
Observing states represented at the I.C.I.R. who have not yet become parties to the 1951 Convention relating to the Status of Refugees.
(b) Participating states represented at the I.C.I.R. who have not yet become parties to the 1954 Convention relating to the Status of Stateless Persons.
Observing states represented at the I.C.I.R. who have not yet become parties to the 1954 Convention relating to the Status of Stateless Persons.
(c) Participating states represented at the I.C.I.R. who have not yet become parties to the 1961 Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness.
Observing states represented at the I.C.I.R. who have not yet become parties to the 1961 Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness.
(d) Participating states represented at the I.C.I.R. who have not yet become parties to the 1967 Protocol relating to the Status of Refugees.
Observing states represented at the I.C.I.R. who have not yet become parties to the 1967 Protocol relating to the Status of Refugees.
